WASHINGTON--If the promises that have been spread thickly on the record are kept, the nation's military preparedness costs may be reduced by as much as $1,500,000,000 in the fiscal year 1951 from the record peacetime high this year of $15,000,000,000.

LONDON, Jan. 2--Serious doubts about a supposed new United States policy toward China, and fears of disagreement between the United States and Britain, were voiced today by responsible British newspapers.

For the first time since the end of the war, the scrap trade in 1949 was looking for business and urging greater utilization of iron and steel scrap in steel and foundry operations to preserve other raw materials.

TOKYO, Jan. 2--American private business appears to have been virtually frozen out of Japan's import trade. For the first quarter of 1950 the United States will be permitted to supply only carbon materials for fertilizers; gilsonite, a kind of asphalt; pearl essence, used in making artifical pearls and small quantities of miscellaneous goods for industry.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 2 (AP) --The Finnish Foreign Ministry declared tonight this country has "a serious intention to do everything" to fulfill its obligations under the peace treaty with Russia.

The increase of pension plans adopted in 1949, which has created new concepts in relations between employers and employes, may bring not only a further expansion this year but a more realistic approach to the subject.
BOSTON--New Englanders are facing 1950 with considerably more optimism than was the case twelve months ago, when the effects of a "rolling recession" were beginning to be felt.
WASHINGTON--Government experts foresee a rise in public works construction for the third straight year. All types are expected to show an increase.

In a move to ease the housing shortage for middle-income groups, the Democratic party will sponsor a four-point housing program at the session of the Legislature that will open tomorrow, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, state chairman, announced yesterday.
During the first eleven months of last year sales of United States savings bonds were smaller than during the comparable period in 1948, but redemptions of all issues also were less.

SAN FRANCISCO--West Coast shipping men are looking hopefully at 1950, with their eyes on China, Japan, the Philippines and the East Indies, but without making predictions of a definite increase in foreign trade.
DALLAS, Tex.--Southwest Texas had a good year in 1949, economically speaking. It was moderately less prosperous than in 1948, but still a good year.
Miss Anne Wilbur has been appointed manager of the children's underwear and hosiery department of Macy's, New York.

The leading Chambers of Commerce of foreign countries and official trade commissioners here are expanding efforts to increase imports into the United States to meet their dollar needs. Such imports last year fell below expectations, but these groups vote confidence on the 1950 outlook.
JAKARTA (Batavia), Indonesia, Jan. 2 (UP)--President Sukarno of Indohesia predicted today that New Guinea would be incorporated into independent Indonesia "before the last sunset falls this year."

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 2--Mayor John V. Kenny and his fellow-commissioners put on the traditional New Year's reception today. The affair outstripped any that preceded it at City Hall in the thirtytwo years of the Hague regime.

Though a lower rate of taxation might create the incentive to stimulate business and individuals so that the Government actually would receive more tax dollars, it is unlikely that such a program will be enacted in 1950, according to Henry H. Heimann, executive...
The nation's great concern in recent years over the future adequacy of iron ore supplies was ended in 1949, according to top steel authorities.
Soundly conceived assistance to Indonesia was urged over the week-end by the National Foreign Trade Council, Inc.
A long term trend toward larger uses of heavy equipment in all kinds of buildings has appeared,...
ROME, Jan. 2--L'Osservatore Romano accused the Italian Communist party today of carrying out a subtle and devious campaign to sabotage the Holy Year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--Daniel F. Cleary, chairman of the War Claims Commission, announced today that former American prisoners of war and civilian internees of World War II could file claims for compensation beginning tomorrow.
For upward of five years many intensive and systematic studies have been made of post-war Federal tax plans by various civic and industrial organizations.

An intimate revue, entitled "Tickets, Please!", co-starring the comedy team of Grace and Paul Hartman, was announced yesterday for production by Arthur Klein, who plans to place it in rehearsal late this month. The entertainment will be tested in New Haven and Boston, and should ar rive in New York in the spring.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 2--Secretary General Trygve Lie suggested today that the United Nations begin examining the possibilities of international control of biological and chemical weapons of mass destruction.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP)--The Senate Democratic Policy Committee recommended today that Congress go slow in acting on proposals to cut excise taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--Not since the foreign policy viewpoint which was expressed by such respected leaders of "America First" as Gen. Robert E. Wood came into conflict with President Roosevelt's revealed interventionist policy in Europe (1939-1941) has so sharp and widespread a division of...

The appointments with which Mayor O'Dwyer filled out his administration for the second term are, for the most part, good. We believe he starts with a stronger team, and certainly far more experienced, than in January, 1946. To the important post of Health Commissioner Dr. John F. Mahoney brings long and successful experience in public health administration.

VIENNA, Jan. 2--Whether the Hungarian Government will sentence and imprison Robert A. Vogeler and, if so, what the United States will do about it has become the liveliest subject of speculation in diplomatic circles in this part of the world.

The Astor Estate interests, identified with hotel properties on Manhattan island since 1848, will add another large one to their holdings with the construction of a fifteen-story and penthouse luxury hotel-service apartment building on the blockfront covering the west side of Madison Avenue between Sixty-first and Sixty-second Streets. It will have its main entrance at 680 Madison Avenue.
Rossiter Howard, retired music and art educator, died Sunday night of a heart attack after a long illness in his home at 28-21 210th Place, Bayside, Queens. He was 71 years of age.
Earnings of the nation's industrial corporations in 1950 again will slide, lacking the superior strength of the mighty steel and automotive industries.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 2--Giving an account of his stewardship to a hushed, respectful Knesset (Parliament) today, Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett, who recently returned from Lake Success, blamed a "front resting on two main formations--the Roman Catholic and Soviet blocs" for his failure to defeat the United Nations plan for internationalization of Jerusalem.
Alfred A. Cook, for many years counsel for THE NEW YORK TIMES, died early yesterday morning in his residence at 630 Park Avenue after an illness of several months. He was 76 years old.

This year, for the first time since the war, American hotels will offer accommodations to travelers equal to and surpassing those found in 1941, according to Charles A. Horrworth, executive vice president of the American Hotel Association.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP)--A gay throng of 15,644 saw George Crump, a son of Blue Swords, drive to an exciting victory in the New Year Purse, feature of the morning card that ushered in the 1950 campaign at Tropical Park today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2--The home furnishings industry is looking to the building boom which took shape in the last half of 1949 and veterans' insurance refund checks to bolster sales during the first six months of the new year, Lawrence H. Whiting, American Furniture Mart president, said today.

Despite smaller profits last year, corporations distributed a larger share of their earnings in cash dividends than in 1948, estimates indicate. But while a greater proportion of income was so disbursed, the percentage gain in divident payments over 1948 was expected to be less than half the 14 per cent increase scored in 1948 over 1947. And the ratio of dividends to earnings will remain well below pre-war levels, it is believed.

LOS ANGELES--General business activity in the south Pacific Coast area in 1949 was slightly under the record year of 1948, but the situation was regarded locally as satisfactory and the outlook for 1950 considered good.

WASHINGTON--It is the consensus among Washington financial observers that 1950 will include in its repertory of events some important changes in the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

The situation in Turkey is "immensely sound," George Wadsworth, United States Ambassador to Turkey, declared when he arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, last night from London. He was among forty-six passengers on a Pan American World Airways Stratocruiser that landed at 8:35 P.M.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP)--Santa Clara's fighting Broncs overcame a seven-point half-time deficit to upset the University of Kentucky Wildcats, 21 to 13, in the sixteenth annual Orange Bowl classic today before 64,816 thrilled spectators-- largest crowd ever to attend a sports event in Florida.

Coach Frank McGuire's unbeaten St. John's University basketball team places its winning streak of twelve straight on the line tonight when it squares off against an old foe, City College, in the feature of the collegiate double-header at Madison Square Garden.

As 1950 begins, banking and the money market, as at the start of last year, face the future with considerable uncertainty over the prospects of further readjustment or greater inflation. Although 1949 saw a "break" in the established policy of monetary authorities with regard to interest rates, pending further developments, the current program continues to be one of "neutrality."

LONDON, Jan. 2--A fear of becoming "paper happy" was given seriously here today as one reason why the British Government's semi-independent Colonial Development Corporation had turned down the offer of a $5,000,000 loan from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development after months of negotiations.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 2-- Mayor Luke A. Mercandante, who led his Democratic, ticket to victory last November, today administered the oath of office to members of the City Council in a ceremony at City Hall.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP)-- Taking a long lead which he never relinquished, Moonrush sped home a two-length winner in the eleventh running of the $50,000 added Santa Catalina Handicap before 41,000 chilled holiday turf fans at Santa Anita today.
STROBL, Austria, Jan. 2 (UP)-- Emil Jannings, thick-set German who was a leading movie actor for many years, died tonight in his home at Lake Wolfgang at the age of 63.
The primary concern of the Treasury in formulating its monetary and debt-management policies is to promote sound economic conditions in the country.
The effects of Marshall Plan aid to Europe during 1949 were mirrored in the slowing of the inflow of gold to the United States.

The international market in foreign-owned blocked internal securities of Great Britain, the Netherlands and Belgium is continuing here at prices generally reflecting substantial discounts from the free home-market prices for corresponding securities in London, Amsterdam and Brussels.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 2 (UP)--The Euthanasia Society of America, Inc., disclosed tonight that it would seek the nation's first "mercy-death" law in New Hampshire as a result of the murder case against Dr. Hermann N. Sander, accused of killing an incurable cancer patient.

The death of Alfred A. Cook leaves us with a very special sense of loss. For more than a half century he was counsel for this newspaper--from its purchase by Adolph S. Ochs in 1896 until his retirement from active practice two years ago.

ALBANY, Jan. 2--Creation of a state civil defense agency with power to prepare now for meeting possible atomic bomb or bacterial warfare attacks on the United States will be recom mended by Governor Dewey in his annual message on Wednesday.
The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York called yesterday upon Congress "to alter its organization and procedures in order more effectively to exercise its financial responsibilities."

In a new move obviously designed to tighten its grip on Finland, the Soviet Government has charged in a formal note that the Finnish Government is violating the peace treaty and the Soviet-Finnish "friendship" pact by hiding 300 "war criminals" under false names and documents instead of turning them over to Russia. The Soviet press has been sniping at Finland for many months, accusing it of "rightist"...
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 2--The Communist daily, the Hora, whose fate has been delicately in the balance for more than a year, was finally closed down today.

WASHINGTON--Point Four of President Truman's inaugural address still is virtually nothing but an idea almost one year after he declared that the United States "must embark on a bold new program" to aid the underdeveloped areas of the world.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska--Four years after the close of the war, military construction was still the biggest business in Alaska in 1949. It will continue to occupy first place in 1950.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey Goodrich Parker of Washington and Beechwood, Aldie, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cecilia Sherman, to Philip Laussat Geyelin of Washington and Devon, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. Emile Cantille Geyelin of Tregarick, Devon. The wedding will take place in the spring.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 2--A blueprint for the Mississippi Valley for 1950 will be charted by river men, industries, and soil-conservation leaders when the Mississippi Valley Association meets for its thirty-first annual convention here Feb. 6 and 7.

The year-end inventory of the Department of Welfare showed that fewer than 15,000 of New York's two million children were cared for outside their own homes, according to figures made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON--With roughly two-thirds of United States exports to Western Europe currently financed by the Marshall Plan, the concern originally felt over its impact on the domestic economy now has shifted to apprehension over the adjustments indicated by its gradual curtailment and end in 1952.

As industry awaits President Truman's remarks on excise taxes, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company presents in the third quarterly issue of the Bell System Magazine, released today, a statement showing the effect of such wartime Federal taxes on the subscriber's bill.
A gain of a mere 70,000,000 gallons--barely a drop in the bottom of Father Knickerbocker's teacup --was the increase reported yesterday in the city's dangerously low supply of water in storage.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2--Business men from every continent are requesting applications to participate in the first United States international trade fair, to be held here next Aug. 7-19.

Despite unfavorable weather conditions in the older part of the belt, where the yield was poor, the domestic cotton-growing industry last year produced the sixth largest crop in history. Placed at 16,034,000 bales by the Department of Agriculture, it was the largest yield since 1937, when 18,252,000 bales were ginned.
ST. LOUIS--Industrial activity in this area moved along on an even keel in 1949, better than the national average, but with some "adjustments" from the 1948 record levels.
CHICAGO--The year 1949 in the Central West set a mark slightly below that of 1948 in most fields of economic activity, but 1948 was a record year in many respects.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (U.P.)-- Two Federal agencies reported today that profits of manufacturers in the third quarter of last year were 15 per cent greater than in the second quarter, despite a relatively small increase in sales volume.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP)--Bob Ward, 180-pound guard, held together a great defensive line that paced Maryland to a 20--7 victory over Missouri in the Gator Bowl today.
PHILADELPHIA--As 1950 begins, a large part of this area's highly diversified industry was running in high gear and was confident of continuing at that pace for at least six months.
HONG KONG, Jan. 2 (UP)--The freighter Brooklyn Heights of the Isbrandtsen Line arrived today to load cargo for a scheduled run through the Chinese Nationalist blockade of Shanghai.
Gas transmission pipelines went far to explain the 7.3 per cent rise in total revenues of the gas industry last year to an unprecedented $1,694,331,000. Receipts in 1948 amounted to $1,579,603,000.
As the year begins, enough favorable influences are in sight to keep retail sales during 1950 even with or slightly ahead of good performances in 1949.

Following peak production last year which is expected to show more than 1,000,000 housing units added to the nation's supply by the time the complete statistics are compiled, the building industry is anticipating only a slight decline during 1950 from this high level of operations.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 2-- Nichols School, which captured the honors in the event last year, and Northwood School of Lake Placid gained final berths as the opening session in the second annual twoday Lawrenceville School invitation hockey tournament was completed. The finalists were the survivors of a starting field of eight of the top prep schools in the East.

SARASOTA, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP)-- Robert Edward Ringling, chairman of the board of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, died of a stroke tonight at the age of 52. He had been in poor health for several months and last summer had been near death in a Chicago hospital.

PITTSBURGH--Pittsburgh district business recovered from the heavy slump caused by the dual strikes in the two major industries --steel and coal--with a rush that bears out predictions of continued good business through at least most of 1950.
The use of United States-made synthetic rubber, proportionately to natural rubber, was higher in 1949 than it was in 1948, according to a year-end statement of the Rubber Manufacturers Association.
For the first time since the war no clouds are seen in business skies for at least the early months of a new year. Forecasts of clear weather are so unanimous that skeptical eyebrows are raised.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 2 --It was announced tonight that the Yugoslav Communist party had ordered the complete reorganization of the educational system to rid Yugoslavia of Soviet "counter-revolutionary" and "dogmatic" ideas of socialism as well as of the bourgeois ideology of the capitalist West.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--A ninepoint program for the advancement of stated goals in the childwelfare field was announced today by the American Parents Committee. The committee added that the proposals were designed especially for the attention and action of Congress.
As the new year opens, the foreign trade stage is being set for the greatest drive to increase imports that this country has ever experienced.

For a month the children of the Hoffman School, in the Riverdale Section of the city, have been busy making little things to sell at the school bazaar to raise money for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Yesterday they sent their collection of $135 to help other less fortunate children.

Lyell Barbour, pianist, who gave several recitals here in the Twenties and then settled in California, returned last night to give his first New York recital in almost eleven years. He played at Town Hall and his program was confined to Beethoven, Schumann, Chopin and Debussy.

Large refunding operations by public utility corporations and increases in retirements of industrial and railroad issues lifted the total of bonds called before maturity for payment in 1949 to $450,761,000, compared with $417,510,000 in 1948 and $1,844,505,000 in 1947.

LONDON, Jan. 2--The turnover on the stock markets here today was at a minimum in almost all sections, with price movements of no real significance. Most of the activity was in foreign bonds, some of which advanced.

The steel industry's record $2,000,000,000 post-war expansion and improvement program was nearing completion as 1949 drew to a close, but several companies have already started additional construction programs to take care of long-term steel needs of a growing nation.

The Bayside National Bank, New York City, reported as of Dec. 31, 1949, total deposits of $16,818,934 and total assets of $18,418,163, compared, respectively, with $13,001,310 and $14,226,241 on Dec. 31, 1948.

Developments of 1949 indicated that a drop in business spending will constitute the thing most to be feared this year as the basic cause of business softening, according to The National City Bank's Monthly Letter, published today. When business spending is slow, consumer income suffers, the bank points out, adding that an economy in which expenditures on producers' plant and equipment are sluggish is a "stagnant econonmy."

The tendency of investment funds is to provide goods and services wherever the need is greatest, Louis W. Dawson, executive vice president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, said yesterday in a year-end statement.
The year 1950 may well be the first billion-pound year for margarine, according to Paul T. Truitt, president of the National Association of Margarine Manufacturers.

John F. Ward, president of the National Institute of Governmental Purchasing, Inc., and Deputy Commissioner of Purchases for the city of Chicago, Ill., said that market research indicated that "the general commodity market for 1950 will show a decline" on most product groupings.

STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 24 --Shipping circles here believe that Strasbourg's great Rhine port, ranking fourth among the ports of France, will not come fully into its own until free competition wins out against the barriers of planned economy.

IF there is a slight slump in basketball attendance this season it certainly won't be apparent tonight, when the dribble addicts storm Madison Square Garden in a hysterical horde for the twenty-ninth game of the City College-St. John's series, a sure-fire thriller. It carries even greater appeal this time because these ancient rivals rank with the best in the country and this may be the most important fray of the entire campaign.

Last year was a poor one for the fur industry, but the trade looks forward to substantial improvement in 1950, especially if the 20 per cent Federal excise tax is removed. Mink was the outstanding fur of the year, reflecting lower...

HONG KONG, Jan. 2--The controversial international angles in the disposition of two Nationalist Chinese airlines here became further involved today with the announcement that an American company headed by Maj. Gen. ...

Increased recognition of packaging as a vital factor in integrated sales planning ranks as one of 1949's most important merchandising developments, according to a survey of top authorities in the $8,000,000,000 packaging industry.

After a rather disappointing year from an earnings standpoint, the railroad industry is looking forward to improved results in 1950. With the virtual completion of their post-war improvement and modernization program, they also are expected to handle the traffic offered them with the greatest efficiency in their history.

A further shrinkage in American exports to Russia appears to be inevitable in 1950. Those who believe that 1949 shipments touched rock bottom at barely $8,000,000, may find that exports will go even lower this year, according to those in touch with Soviet trade.

The women's outer apparel trades came through a difficult transition in 1949. Manufacturers of coats, suits and dresses suffered a considerable loss in volume as a result of cautious buying by retailers. Manufacturers of such items as blouses, skirts and separates, however, did a record business.

DALLAS, Jan. 2 (AP)--Rice ground power beat the North Carolina eleven, 27--13, in the Cotton Bowl today as the Tar Heels arrived too late with an offense that was sweeping the Texans out of the park at the finish.
WASHINGTON--From a midyear slump that caused a minor scare, employment rebounded toward the end of the year to an encouraging level.

Final figures for 1949 are expected to show relatively small declines for consumption and production in the paper field, exclusive of newsprint, according to a report by Dr. Louis T. Stevenson, economist of the American Paper and Pulp Association.

WASHINGTON--The Federal Government is facing a growing fiscal dilemma, with the national debt again mounting after some reduction in 1947 and 1948 and expenditures outstripping receipts by huge amounts.

Retail prices of food will decline and the number of sales will increase in supermarkets throughout the country this year, according to Claude W. Edwards, president of the Super Market Institute, a trade organization whose members do a business of about $2,500,000,000 a year.

The primary objective of the New York Stock Exchange last year was to expand its public relations activities in its campaign to acquaint the potential investor with its facilities as a free trading market.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2--The packing industry expects 1950 to set a new meat production record for peacetime that will exceed even some of the huge wartime totals.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 2 (UP)-- Booth Tarkington's evaluation of some of the world's literary figures was revealed today in three unpublished letters unearthed in a forgotten strong box at the Indianapolis Public Library.
A two-story taxpayer is planned on the parcel at 1289 Madison Avenue, which has been purchased by the Hansair Realty Corporation from the East River Savings Bank.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--Former President Herbert Hoover and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio called on the United States today to protect Formosa, present haven of the Chinese Nationalist Government, by naval force if necessary.
DETROIT--The automobile industry, with a $4-a-ton price increase imposed upon it for steel, goes into the new year wondering whether it will have to raise its own prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--On the eve of the second session of the Eighty-first Congress, which convenes at noon tomorrow, all indications pointed to a resumption of the legislative tug-of-war centering on President Truman's Fair Deal program, with both sides seeking records on which to go before the voters in November.

EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 2 (AP)-- Texas Western today became the first Border Conference team to turn back an Eastern eleven in the Sun Bowl. The proponents of straight football used power and the breaks to defeat Georgetown University of Washington, D.C., 33--20.
As the first half of the Twentieth Century enters its final phase, it finds the national economy weathering post-war readjustments better than any prophet had reasoned.

TOKYO, Jan. 2--Japanese attendance at Shinto shrines has fallen off heavily this year for the first time since the surrender, at least during the opening days of the New Year's holiday season, it was revealed today.

SAN JUAN, P.R.--As a result of cooperative expenditure of $1,500,000 in promotional work last year, shipments of Puerto Rican rum to the United States more than doubled over the low level of 1947 and are expected to show a further sharp rise this year.
WASHINGTON--Labor-management relations in 1949 were sharply influenced by union maneuvers that substituted demands for pensions in place of wage increases.

The British New Year honors carry five more Laborites to the House of Lords and remind us once again that democracy is more than a leveling process. So far as Great Britain is concerned, this is a very old custom, and if any eyebrows are raised they will be in the ranks of the workers whose class has been receiving its due tribute in recent years.

GOLDENS BRIDGE, N.Y., Jan. 2--Although it has been alleged that there is little variety in hunting pheasants on a game preserve, this would seem to depend largely upon the point of view, the shooters involved and the dogs used.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 2-- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has completed the cast of "Father of the Bride" with the assignment of Don Taylor to play the bridegroom and the engagement of Billie Burke and Taylor Holmes to play his mother and father.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Jan. 2 --The "chiseler" on unemployment insurance benefits is not finding it profitable in Missouri, according to a statement issued here today by Charles A. Ricker, director of the Missouri Division of Employment Security.

An overabundance of goods carried over which forced prices to the lowest level since the war was balanced out by curtailed production in the textile industry last year. Continued consumer demand bolstered a sagging market at the wholesale level and beginning in...

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 2 --Dr. Irving Langmuir, 1932 Nobel Prize winner in chemistry and one of the world's most noted industrial scientists, retired today as the General Electric Company's research director and took occasion in one of his rare interviews to sum up modern trends, which he does not find impressive.
Nutrition comes into the kitchen, but must stay out of the dining room.
WASHINGTON--In the months before that astonishing Presidential election a year ago, the Truman Administration was assailed on many sides for its relentless program of anti-trust prosecutions.
Two developments during 1949 have long-range significance for the wool industry, according to a statement by Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

Violent deaths in the nation neared the 400 mark for the threeday New Year holiday as the period drew to a close last night. Meanwhile the rush of travel winding up the Christmas-New Year season taxed transportation facilities.

PARIS, Jan. 2--Abandonment of negotiations between the International Bank and the British Colonial Development Corporation for a $5,000,000 loan caused observers in this Marshall Plan capital to ask today what would become of President Truman's Point Four program if such loans fell through.

One of the results of our "wait-andsee" policy in regard to East Asia has been the total loss of the initiative on our part. Whatever we do now has to be provoked instead of inspired. Any decision now will probably have the great handicap of bad timing.

A persistent trend toward higher prices and lower yields again is dominating the market for basic investments as the new year gets under way. The strong prices are reminiscent of the spring of 1946, when a ten-year rise in the bond market reached its crest.

The marriage of Miss. Joan Nugent Straub, daughter of Mrs. Robert A. Straub of Forest Hills, Queens, to Claude J. Hislaire, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rene Hislaire, also of Forest Hills, formerly of Brussels, Belgium, took place yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, Forest Hills.

CAIRO, Jan. 2 (UP)--Egypt's voters will go to the polls tomorrow in the first election in twentyfive years in which all parties are participating, and with the Government maintaining that it has provided for the fairest balloting in the country's modern history.

The Salvation Army will start its seventieth anniversary appeal tomorrow, asking $1,292,000 in public contributions, it was announced yesterday by John G. Phillips, president of the International Business Machines Corporation and general chairman of the appeal.

The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange provided one of the most spectacular gyrations of any of the futures markets in the country last year. And predictions are that coffee prices will climb even higher in 1950.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--Statistics that may well be quoted in debates that will ensue when the question of continuing aid to foreign countries arises in the new session of Congress were released today by the Department of Commerce.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 2--Formation of a national laymen's organization to combat alleged Communist teaching by some Protestant clergymen came to light here Saturday when articles of incorporation for the American Council of Christian Laymen were filed with the Secretary of State's office.

Reflecting the cutbacks ordered by regulatory bodies in order to keep production in line with demand, production of crude petroleum in the United States last year fell sharply below the recordbreaking level of 1948.

Charles A. Collins has been elected vice president of James N. Wells' Sons, Inc. Associated with the real estate firm for the past five years, Mr. Collins formerly was with A.G. Walker Associates and the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan 2 --Prospects for a French-German rapprochement, which many Germans view as a cornerstone of a truly united Europe, are far dimmer west of the Rhine than many persons living east of that river believe.

A cruise-cargo service between Miami, Fla.; Kingston, Jamaica, and Cludad Trujillo, Dominican Republic, said to be the first such service, will be started on Jan. 21 by the Flota Mercante Dominicana (Dominican Merchant Fleet), it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP)-- Col. Philip Schwartz, Air Force ordnance expert, scoffed today at charges that the Air Force's strategic bombing plans make it an advocate of "mass murder of enemy civilians."
WASHINGTON--The story of the Administration's efforts to control inflation last year could be told in a nutshell, thus:

Beginning March 1, the British edition of the Reader's Digest will accept a limited amount of advertising, it was announced over the week-end by the Reader's Digest International Editions, Inc. The British edition has been published in England without advertising since December, 1938. Net paid guaranteed circulation for the first six months is 400,000.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2--An eleventh-hour field goal by Ohio State's doughty Buckeyes today broke a 14-14 deadlock with California's Golden Bears and gained for the Western Conference its fourth straight victory of the fiveyear Rose Bowl compact with the Pacific Coast Conference.

Designed to give the television viewer an imaginary night out on Saturday evening while he relaxes at home, the National Broadcasting Company's TV network will initiate a two-and-a-half hour package of varied programs on Feb. 4, beginning at 8 P.M.
Two major North Atlantic steamship lines released yesterday their annual reports of passenger traffic.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 (AP)-- Brilliant and bold Oklahoma shattered Louisiana State University in football's Sugar Bowl by 35--0 today for one of its easiest victories in a great string of twenty-one games without a loss.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP)-- The State Department tonight published a list of items which the authorities of the French zone of Morocco have declared can be imported into the zone without official allocation of exchange.

From the depths of a 13-point deficit at 7:55 in the second half, the Long Island University basketball team emerged with a 69-58 victory over Muhlenberg last night at Madison Square Garden. With a spine-tingling rally that sent the Blackbird stock soaring, Clair Bee's men turned apparent defeat into a glorious conquest of the energetic, resourceful Mules from Allentown, Pa.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 2 --The Tennessee Valley Authority's program to advance watershed protection through forest development in its seven-state area has been "highly successful," Willis M. Baker, TVA Director of Forestry Relations, reported last week.
The Department of Agriculture announces that because of the present surplus of eggs it will take steps to discourage the chickens of America from laying.

Several hundred young women, including debutantes from New York, Westchester, Tuxedo Park, New Jersey, Pittsburgh and Washington, attended the annual Debutantes New Year's Ball last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

GENEVA, Jan. 2--The United Nations Permanent Central Opium Board, in its annual report published today, censured the Government of Iran for failure to live up to its obligations under international conventions for the control of narcotics.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 2--It is generally accepted in political circles that Dr. Rajendra Prasad, president of the Indian Constituent Assembly, will be elected the first President of India by Parliament on Jan. 24, two days before India becomes a republic.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Jan. 2-- This city, which was without buses New Year's night, will be served by two rival bus companies tomorrow, but nobody around here knows when a snarled transportation franchise dispute will be resolved.

Reflecting the drop in inventory replacement and strikes in key industries, industrial production last year declined to an estimated average of 175 per cent of capacity from the peacetime record of 191.75 per cent in 1948.
"DELIGHT,"* by J.B. Priestley, is a random harvest of cheerful essays on all sorts of things that have helped give that professional grumbler and self-made curmudgeon the strength to go on.

Resources of savings and loan associations throughout the nation last year increased about $1,325,000,000, according to current estimates. When the final figures for 1949 are tabulated some time this spring, it is expected that total resources will reach nearly $15,000,000,000.

Individual mirrors are being used in more homes and in more rooms in the home today because they can perform decorative and architectural as well as utilitarian functions--often all simultaneously.

As in the case of most American businesses and industry, the nation's aluminum industry felt the impact of economic readjustment in the middle of 1949.
Despite a mild recession in midyear and a major strike in the fourth quarter, the year just ended was a good one for the domestic steel industry from the standpoints of production and profits.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 2--The deadlock in the wage dispute between major international airlines and ground-crew employes continued today, curtailing traffic in and out of Buenos Aires. The absence of Pan American and Panagra flights was most pronounced, since their schedule was daily while other lines have two or three planes weekly.

The copper industry is just this side of a tight supply situation. This means that requirements for the red metal in automobiles, refrigerators and innumerable electricity-consuming appliances will continue to be met if there is no drastic change either way in the economy.

With the aim of decentralizing the United Jewish Appeal campaign for 1950, Henry Morgenthau, general chairman, announced yesterday the formation of a national campaign cabinet of fourteen Jewish leaders.
Applications for apartments in a low-rent housing project in the Bronx will be distributed beginning today.
The travel and resort industry faces 1950 in a much more stable condition and in a happier frame of mind than that with which it greeted the year just ended.

DETROIT, Jan. 2 (AP)--The nation's automobile industry should make some more production records in the six months immediately ahead. That is the conviction of most car makers and industry observers as the car factories get started on their 1950 operations. There was no production today, but with the exception of KaiserFrazer all plants have scheduled assembly line operations for tomorrow.

EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 2--June graduates of the nation's colleges and universities are faced with a sharp decline in employment prospects with large corporations, Dr. Frank S. Endicott, director of Northwestern University's Bureau of Placement, has disclosed.

HONOLULU--The tourist business, which annually ranks fourth in Hawaii as an income-producer, suffered along with other businesses in the 1949 Hawaiian dock strike, but Hawaiian officials are looking for a travel influx in 1950.

Among the many year-end firm changes announced by brokerage and underwriting securities firms, is the admission of Dudley N. Schoales as a general partner in the investment banking house of Morgan Stanley Co. which he joined in 1946.

The financial and business review of this newspaper, which makes its annual appearance today, reflects a general and reasoned opinion that, for the immediate future at least, the prospect is for clear economic skies. In fact, the principal area of disagreement is not whether a continuation of a high level of economic activity may be expected-- on that point judgment is fairly unanimous--but whether we face the possibility of a resumption of inflation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--Two labor experts suggested today that the National Labor Relations Board was going too far in regulating the bargaining process. They are Archibald Cox, professor of law, and John T. Dunlop, associate professor of economics, both of Harvard University.

For the merchant marine industry the last year was a stabilizing and "shaking down" period. The tonnage of the fleet and the work force of officers and seamen manning it were reduced nearer to what may be the permanent postwar level.

Earnings of the St. Regis Paper Company will reflect the adverse effect of economic readjustments last year, according to Roy K. Ferguson, president and chairman. Indications are that net sales for 1949 were about 25 per cent below the 1948 volume of $162,673,925, he said.

Deposits in the nation's mutual savings banks approximate $19,300,000,000, representing 19,340,000 depositors, as 1950 begins. At present one in every three inhabitants of the area served by the savings banks holds an account and in New England and New York, where the banks are most numerous, the proportion is far greater.

A rising mortality rate in business, which reached its peak in the third quarter of 1949, was the cause for considerable concern among the nation's credit men. An improvement in business in the closing months of the year, however, has resulted in a leveling off of failures and forced liquidations.

BALTIMORE, Md.--Baltimore's position, with its wide diversification of its manufactories, further improved in 1949 with the establishment of forty-three new industries and the expansion of eightytwo existing plants in the first eleven months of the year.

To the surprise of public health experts, the birth rate here continued high last year although the number of marriages declined, the Department of Health announced yesterday. There were 157,194 births, a rate of 19.3 for each 1,000 of population in this city of 8,161,000 persons.

Many buyers are expected in the wholesale garment markets here within the next two weeks to complete spring purchases of women's and children's apparel, according to reports prepared especially for THE YORK NEW TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 2--Oscar Ewing, United States Federal Security Administrator, announced tonight he would recommend that the United States Commissioner of Education lend technical and advisory assistance to this country. Details will be worked out during the next few weeks in Washington, he said.

Over-all home furnishings dollar volume last year decreased approximately 10 per cent, compared with 1948, at both the wholesale and retail levels.

Nearly 100,000 new members came into the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York during 1949, it was reported yesterday by David M. Heyman, president of the plan. Preliminary figures compiled by the Grocery Manufacturers of America from a continuing study of sales and earnings of eightynine representative grocery manufacturers indicate that dollar sales during 1949 were about the same as in 1948.

Anne English Colcord, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Husted Colcord of New York, to Dr. James Beall Rodgers, son of Judge Decatur H. Rodgers of Martinsburg, W. Va., and the late Mrs. Annie Lancaster Rodgers. The Rev. Dr. Charles P. Deems performed the ceremony.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 3 (AP) --Vice Admiral Gerald F. Bogan, one of the Navy officers involved in the row over armed services unification, today applied for retirement rather than accept a lesser command. He is 55 years old. Usual retirement age in the Navy is 62.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP)-- The United States Atomi Energy Commission plans to spend $817,000,000 in the 1951 fiscal year to expand the output of atomic bombs and to develop "new and improved" weapons.
ROBINSON, Ill., Jan. 9--The Wabash River surged against weakening levees along the Illinois shore today, with water from small breaks, overflows and tributaries isolating several communities.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9--This city's five largest department stores--Wanamaker's, Gimbels, Snellenburg's, Lit's and Strawbridge Clothier--were fined $2,500 each today for conspiring to fix prices in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

The time in which foreign holders of German industrial Reichsmark securities may apply for certificates of negotiability for their holdings has been cut two months by a ruling by German authorities, it was learned here yesterday. The new terminal date is Jan. 31, instead of March 31.
The State of Maryland sold yesterday $9,740,000 of tax-exempt Bonds to finance school improvements at an interest cost of about 1.21 per cent. The bonds will be due Feb. 1, 1953 to 1965.

A proposal drawn up by a special committee of prominent playwrights that would seek to establish the theatere on a sounder economic basis will be submitted for consideration today to the council of the Dramatists' Guild.

ROME, Jan. 9--Five persons were killed and more than sixty injured in rioting in Modena today. It was the most serious clash between the police and workers that has occurred in Italy in eighteen months.

Fire swept through an apartment at 196 Elizabeth Street shortly after 4 P.M. yesterday, badly burning a father and his 2-year-old twin sons as he rescued them. His wife, their 7-year-old daughter, and a fireman received minor injuries.

The federal budget for 1950-51, sent to Congress yesterday by the President, adheres closely in its general outlines to the public's expectations. Receipts are estimated at $37,306,000,000 and expenditures at $42,439,000,000, leaving an indicated deficit of $5,133,000,000.

The American Association of Advertising Agencies will hold its fourth annual examination for advertising in twenty-two cities on Feb. 18 and 25, it was announced yesterday by John E. Wiley, chairman of the board of Fuller Smith Ross, Inc., who heads the examinations committee.

Mayor O'Dwyer appointed yesterday a four-man fact-finding board to study the demands of Board of Transportation employes for higher wages and improved working conditions and the effect increased labor costs would have on the city's fiscal position.

Reacting against Mayor O'Dwyer's proposal for state-controlled gambling, the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America reiterated yesterday its opposition to gambling in any form.

The Port of New York Authority asked the Maritime Commission yesterday to lease Governmentowned Piers 1, 2 and 3 in Hoboken to the Authority at $1 a year for fifty years.

ALBANY, Jan. 9--State Senator Seymour Halpern, Republican, of Queens, said tonight he would introduce a bill later this week to require compulsory semi-anual inspection of automobiles at stateowned and operated inspection stations.

The Standard Oil Company (Ohio), which during its first twelve years of its existence was the parent company of an organization that made Cleveland the oil metropolis of the world, celebrates its eightieth birthday today.

LONDON, Jan. 9--Although Britain is producing half again as much as in 1938 and selling more to North America, she is earning fewer dollars than prior to devaluation last Sept. 18, Sir. Florence Salb, a promising young Cleveland pianist, gave her first New York recital last night at Times Hall: Her program, which showed taste and intelligence, was restricted to Mozart, Schubert Beethoven and Chopin.

Mayor O'Dwyer was authorized by the Board of Estimate yesterday to appoint a committee to negotiate for the services of an organization qualified to conduct a survey of the city government in the interest of efficiency and economy. Any proposed contract would be submitted to the board for action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--Republicans and Democrats in the Senate, already hard at work for the 1950 Congressional elections, emerged from separate campaign meetings today with highly conflicting claims of approaching victory.

The city's Hospitals Department spent $1,785,000 for pharmaceuticals in 1949 for indigent patients in municipal wards and clinics, Louis Samuels, director of the agency's Division of Pharmacy, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--A Wisconsin-born woman lost her United States citizenship by signing a document before she married an Italian vice consul in this country, the Supreme Court held today in a 6-to-2 decision.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--President Truman submitted to Congress today a budget for the 1951 fiscal year calling for $42,439,000,000 in expenditures, $858,000,000 less than his revised estimate for the current fiscal year, but $5,133,000,000 more than expected receipts.
COLUMBUS, Ohio Jan. 9 (AP)-- Wes Fesler decided today to remain as Ohio State University's head football coach.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 9-- The Chamber of Deputies will open its long delayed debate tomorrow on the bill for a national referendum on the return of King Leopold to the Belgian throne. James H. Sheils, deputy commissioner of Investigation, was sworn in by Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday as executive assistant to Deputy Mayor William Reid. He succeeds G. Joseph Minetti, who last week was appointed a member of the Board of Transportation after holding the other post less than a week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--President Truman in his budget message today proposed to Congress an expenditure of $13,545,000,000, for national defense in the fiscal year 1951, starting July 1.
