Church groups continued yesterday to attack Mayor O'Dwyer's proposal for state legislation to legalize gambling on sporting events. The Protestant Council of the City of New York urged the Legislature to reject it, and two church meetings adopted resolutions opposing it.

Mayor O'Dwyer took steps yesterday to try to head off a threatened strike of 1,200 fuel oil and coal drivers, set for midnight tonight. The walkout would cut off virtually all coal deliveries to homes, hospitals, schools and industrial users and would tie up the bulk of the city's fuel oil.

Dr. Lawrence H. Chamberlain, 43 years old, Professor of Government at Columbia University, has been chosen dean of Columbia College, it was announced yesterday by the University trustees. He will assume the new post on July 1.

WASHINGTON Jan. 10 (UP)-- The Department of Justice said today it was just a "coincidence" that all United States district attorneys had been called to a conference here next month immediately prior to the Democrats' annual Jefferson-Jackson Day fundraising dinner.

FRANFORT, Germany, Jan. 10 --Pressure for a full and frank statement from Foreign Minister Robert Schuman of France's intentions toward the Saar is growing among German politicians in anticipation of the French statesman's visit to Bonn this week-end.

A day of hurried activity is in store for the crew, shoreside personnel and stevedores engaged in handling the arrival and sailing today of the Home Lines passenger vessel Atlantic, it was learned yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 10--Unexpectedly strong opposition to Federal scholarships for college students emerged today at the annual convention of the Association of American Colleges.
The stock market had difficulty Yesterday in getting its bearings.

As the city's Catskill and Croton reservoirs showed a reduced gain in water storage again yesterday, water officials asked the eighty up-state communities using city water to observe the same "water holiday" tomorrow that will be in effect here.

BUFFALO, Jan. 10--Seventeen hundred employes of the Bell Aircraft Corporation here, where an eighteen-week strike ended last October, received an hourly wage increase of 5 cents today from a State Board of Inquiry.

Thomas F. Murphy, Federal prosecutor in the Alger Hiss perjury case, spent most of the thirtyfirst trial day yesterday in an effort to nullify testimony that Whittaker Chambers, his key witness, was "a psychopathic personality."
RUSSELLVILLE, Ala., Jan. 10 (UP)--A doctor brought a baby boy into the world with a pocket-knife last night six minutes after its mother was shot fatally by accident.

In an investment deal on Washington Heights, the six-story apartment building with-self-service elevator at 875 West 181 Street, northeast corner of Riverside Drive, was sold yesterday by Margaret Hotel, Inc., Herbert S. Neubauer, president, to a syndicate through the Rowley Realty.

Coffee futures advanced in early dealings on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Trade hedge-lifting and demand from producer interests brought gains of 30 to 40 points, but prices turned easier as trade interests sold. Toward the close, prices dropped suddenly when long liquidation found demand filled.
ROME, Jan. 10 (AP)--Church of Christ evangelists have been given a three-month extension of their visas to remain in Italy, an Italian Interior Ministry spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The annual Collier trophy for the greatest achievement in aviation was presented by President Truman today to the Radio Technical Commission for Aeronautics for pioneering the development of an electronic air safety system. The system will cost more than $1,000,000,000 by the time it is fully in use in 1963.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 10 (AP)--Buffalo may be without a team in the new professional football set-up but its last head coach, Clem Crowe, and two assistants will be there with the Baltimore Colts.

Irving Horowitz, who returned yesterday on the Queen Mary with his 4-year-old son, Steven, after a six-month stay abroad, was greeted at the pier by detectives from the District Attorney's office in Brooklyn, a representative of the Internal Revenue Bureau and an irate wife.

While fully aware of the inconsistencies in the present situation and regretting the corruption of police officials that undoubtedly accompanies it, we do not favor new law to legalize certain betting that can only, in the long run, increase gambling by those who cannot afford it.

Ernest Poole, author and foreign correspondent, who wrote "His Family," which in 1918 won the first Pulitzer Prize ever awarded for a novel, died yesterday of pneumonia at his home, 139 East Sixtysixth Street. He would have been 70 years old on Jan. 23.

Eldridge Haynes; publisher of the magazine, Modern Industry, was elected to head the National Management Council at a meeting held before the annual dinner of the organization last night in the Statler Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 10--A United States welfare worker, who has spent the last two years helping to carry out the United Nations feeding program for 600,000 Greek youngsters, warned here today that the curtailment of relief would bring "terrible suffering" to the gild population in Greece.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 10--Jacob A. Malik, the Soviet representative, walked out of the United Nations Security Council this afternoon in protest against the Council's refusal to give immediate consider ation to a Soviet resolution calling for the exclusion of Dr. T.F. Tsiang, the representative of Nationalist China.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 10--Opposing New York City's plan to tap water from the Hudson River, Mayor Horace S. Graham of this community told the members of the New York State Water Power and Control Commission here today that such a project...

Fifteen thousand more miners joined yesterday in the series of "mystery" strikes that cast a pall of idleness over many areas of the country's soft-coal industry Monday. The new walkouts brought the number on strike to more than 60,000 and cut 400,000 tons of new production a day from the country's dwindling coal pile.
Two outfielders, one of proved ability, the other untried as a major leaguer, were signed by the Giants yesterday.
MADRID, Jan. 10--A vigorous attack on Hollywood "psychological" films and on North American methods of psychiatry has been launched by Spain's Royal National Academy of Medicine.
PARIS, Jan. 10--Premier Georges Bidault's compromise proposal for solving the cost-of-living-bonus dispute was coldly received by the Socialists today as Parliament reconvened for the 1950 session.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Seven foreign trade salients "requiring exploration," mapped here last week-end by the new fourteenmember Foreign Agricultural Policy Advisory Committee, were made public today by the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--President Truman is expected to recommend to Congress a program of aid to deserving college students calling for Federally financed scholarships ana Federally-guaranteed loans on the basis of need and ability.

Paul Hall has been re-elected to a third term as secretary-treasurer, of the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, AFL, it was announced yesterday by the union's tally committee, The SIU's annual elections ran from Nov. 1 to Dec. 31, 1949.

The economic integration now being urged on Marshall Plan countries raises the question whether trade between Western and Eastern Europe should be restored, Mrs. Vera Micheles Dean, research director of the Foreign Policy Association, said yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Statler Hotel.
The New York Telephone Company's earnings in New York City are high enough and rate increases are unnecessary, Francis I. Howley, Assistant Corporation Counsel, declared here yesterday,

David J. Coddaire, a member of the United States Maritime Commission, told the New York Foreign Freight Forwarders and Brokers Association last night at the Commodore Hotel that it would do well to set its house in order and cooperate with Federal controls and regulations.
A syndicate of investors yesterday purchased from David S. Meister the sixteen-story office and loft building on plot 94 by 78 feet at 404 Fourth Avenue, northwest corner of Twenty-eighth Street.

Helen Hayes, national women's activities chairman for the 1950 March of Dimes, yesterday called for volunteers "to reach every citizen that has a doorbell and a heart" in the two-week campaign opening Monday.

ROME, Jan. 10--Premier Alcide de Gasperi and his Cabinet will resign on Thursday evening or Friday morning. It is a foregone conclusion that the task of forming a new government will be re-entrusted to signor de Gasperi.

Robert Montgomery has been named an executive television producer by the National Broadcasting Company, and will narrate, direct and produce a new video dramatic series, which begins Monday, Jan. 30. The hours will be from 9:30 to 10:30 P.M. The program, sponsored by Lucky Strike cigarettes, will be presented on alternate Mondays.

Boat racing, with either power or sail, instead of just lazily cruising on summer vacations or yachting week-ends, held the interest yesterday of many of the thousands attending the National Motor Boat Show at Grand Central Palace.

A truckload of finished silk goods valued between $75,000 and $100,000 was stolen yesterday in Brooklyn by four armed men who kidnapped the driver and his helper and left them bound and gagged in an apartment house cellar.

Three veteran shipmasters of the United States Lines have retired, the company announced yesterday. All three had served through two wars and had commanded either freighters or passenger liners of the American merchant marine in recent decades.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Secretary of State Dean Acheson stood unbendingly today before his Republican critics in a long closed conference with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on the Administration's refusal to help Formosa militarily.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, asserted today that the tightened budget of $13,545,000,000 for the armed services that President Truman submitted to Congress yesterday offered the country "an adequacy of defense for any situation that may arise in the next two years."
BAYONNE, N.J., Jan. 10--The Navy has here a machine that, given the chance, would mix up a delicious five-gallon rum cocktail in three minutes. That, however, is not its appointed function.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 10 --Western Allied officials charged the Bonn Government today with procrastinating in attempts to solve the refugee problem. German officials were accused of hoping that the surplus population in...

Changes in proposed Japanese taxation affecting foreign investment and trade beyond those recommended by the Shoup Mission were urged yesterday by the Tax and Japan Committees of the National Foreign Trade Council at a press conference at its offices at 111 Broadway.
DETROIT, Jan. 10--A motor fuel engineer reported to the Society of Automotive Engineers today that a modern automobile had been driven 150 miles on one gallon of gasoline.
It's the things that are the same as they were fifty years ago rather than those that have changed that Victor Eckstein, president of Luchow's, likes to remember.
At last we know the date of one of the most interesting events of this fateful year, the day on which the British are to hold their general election.

BOSTON, Jan. 10--The Republican leadership of the Massachusetts House of Representatives charged today that a "Democratic plot" was responsible for the omission of a union label from the official stationery of the GOP letterheads.
The National Catholic Resettlemerit Council met here yesterday and urged the Senate to pass pending legislation to permit this country to admit more of Europe's displaced persons.

HONG KONG, Jan. 10--Prospective formal relations between Britain and Communist China were launched on a note of acrimony today by the Communist New China News Agency in a release that denounced the British for stating that recognition of the Peiping Government did not imply approval.
The composition of the fact-finding board appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer assures a sympathetic hearing of the complaints of transit workers on their pay and working conditions.
The club that has been toughest of all for the New York Rangers-- the Toronto Maple Leafs--visits Madison square Garden tonight for a National Hockey League battle with the Blue Shirts.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the Chinese generalissimo, left La Guardia Field, yesterday for San Francisco on the first leg of a flight to Formosa. She thanked those who had expressed "sympathy and love for my country."

ROME, Jan. 10--Private United States capital investments in Italy would be welcomed by the Italian Government, Foreign Minister Carlo Sforza, said today in a speech delivered to a group of industrialists.
ROME, Jan. 10--Strikes occurred all over Italy today in prote against the shooting clash between the police and demonstrators in Modena yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan.10--A fulldress House inquiry into the "true state of the national defense" was scheduled by the Armed Services Committee today as it unanimously dismissed, as unsupported by evidence, the accusations that led to last year's B-36 investigation.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 10--Three of Atlanta's four largest Clearing House Association banks, in annual stockholders' meetings, today reported substantial increases in earnings for 1949.

Good sales and slightly lower prices were predicted by retail stores during 1950 by leading business analysts yesterday at the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association's annual convention in the Statler Hotel.

LAST week when the new year was only four days old a novel was published which may well be the strangest and most original to appear in all 1950. It is "The Scapegoat," by Jocelyn Brooke, an English writer unknown in this country until now.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan, 10-- Gov. Chester Bowles today blamed Republican State Administrations over the last ten years for the State's high bonded debt.

ALBANY, Jan. 10--The Appellate Division, Third Department, refused today to allow an appeal on the constitutionality of the 1949 Feinberg Law barring subversive employes from public school employment to go directly to the Court of Appeals.

"The Corn Is Green; second in the series of a quartet of fortnightly revivals by New York City's Theatre Company, done under the watchful and artistic eye of Maurice Evans, will be trotted out this evening at the City Center. The curtain will rise at 8:15.

Jacob A. Malik, the Soviet representative, walked out of the United Nations Security Council yesterday when it refused to consider immediately his resolution to expel Dr. Tsiang, representative of Nationalist China.

Blood banks throughout the city are "dangerously" low on the rare O-Rh negative blood type, it became known yesterday as appeals were made for blood donations to save the lives of two small girls suffering from leukemia.

About 175 stockholders attending the half-hour annual meeting of the National City Bank of New York yesterday heard William Gage Brady Jr., chairman, sound a note of pessimism on the 1950 earnings outlook for this second largest bank in the nation.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 (AP)-- Little Ben Hogan almost hit the jackpot in his dramatic comeback to golf today but Sam Snead came through with a spectacular putt on the eighteenth green and tied for top honors in the $15,000 Los Angeles Open.

Battle lines were being formed quietly yesterday for the first show-down on the punitive strength of the new Sanity Code of the National Collegiate Athletic Association as delegates convened at the Hotel Commodore for the fortyfourth annual meeting.

A year-old brown and white pedigreed Yorkshire canary named Chickie escaped yesterday from its cage in a West Flatbush, Brooklyn, apartment and for five hours the police and neighborhood residents sought to capture the bird.
TOKYO, Jan. 10--Japan's Communists kicked out of the party today a prominent veteran member who supported the Communist Information Bureau attack against the Red leader Sanzo Nosaka.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP)--The Montreal Canadiena moved to within a point of the second-place New York Rangers in the National Hockey League's only game tonight as they routed the cellardwelling Chicago Black Hawks, 7-3, before a crowd of 12,151.
LONDON, Jan. 10--Victory in Britain's next general election, the date for which was set today, may hinge on a very narrow margin of votes.

CHICAGO, Jan 10--Purchasing by smaller and medium size stores on the second day of the home furnishings market continued heavy, with retailers placing more and more small volume orders. Store officials said it is now definite that buyers are here "to buy and not to look."

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 10--The British Foreign Ministers conference was highlighted today by differences of opinion regarding the Commonwealth's attitude toward Communist China whose government has been recognized by half the countries participating in these discussions.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10-- About 300 tanks, armored cars and half-tracks, described as Army surplus and destined for the Chinese Nationalist forces on the Island of Formosa, were being loaded today aboard the Mardin, a Turkish freighter.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 10--The Soviet Union's march out of the Security Council chamber today was planned carefully in advance, worked out in detail to the point where even Russian chauffeurs were alerted and waiting for the word.

ALBANY, Jan. 10--Mayor O'Dwyer's proposal to legalize gambling produced a mixed reaction from legislators today, ranging from enthusiastic support to uncompromising opposition. Its chances of receiving serious consideration appeared dim.
LONDON, Jan. 10--Britain's election was fixed todady for Feb. 23. On that day the people of this country will decide whether they want more or less socialism.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10--Six teen Philadelphia banks that held annual meetings today reported to stockholders that dividend requirements were amply covered. Several announced modest additions to surplus and undivided profit accounts.

WASHINGTON, ,Jan. 10 (AP)-- Near-record stocks of 2,401,279,000 bushels of corn--including much stored under Government pricesupport programs--remained on farms on Jan. 1, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10-- Federal Judge George B. Harris ended an almost incredibly violent session of the Harry Bridges perjury trial today by ordering the matter of falsified testimony of a government witness referred to the grand jury "for such action as may be taken in the premises."

In a week that has been devoted to pretty serious matters, such as the President's budget message and the China situation, one news story has nevertheless stood out like a sore thumb--or perhaps we should say like a yellow convertible.

Fifty detectives were searching the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn last night for clues to the slaying of a 74-year-old business man and his 80-year-old wife in their six-room apartment at 105 Quincy Street.
Allen County, Ind., announced yesterday that it will receive bids until Jan. 18 on $3,000,000 of coliseum bonds dated Feb. 1, 1950, and maturing from July 1, 1951 to 1970.

The Government began yesterday to present testimony that it said would prove it could have built up its spy case against Judith Coplon and Valentin A. Gubitchev even if it had not resorted to illegal wire-tapping.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan.10--Louis W. Wheelock, former Philadelphia newspaper editor and advertising executive, died today at his home in suburban Swarthmore at the age of 79.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10--Traders in grains generally placed a bullish construction on an estimate by the Department of Agriculture on stocks of leading grains on farms as of Jan. 1, regarding the disappearance during the last three months as comparatively heavy and somewhat above expectations.
MADRID, Jan. 10--A spamsn Cabinet meeting discussed last night "the trade negotiations with Argentina," it was officially acknowledged today, but all details were kept secret.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Radio transmission is crowding the air channels more and more as the weeks go by, the Federal Communications Commission announced in its annual report today.

JAKARTA (Batavia), Indonesia, Jan.10 (AP)--A former Dutch Army captain leading a private rebel army in western Java has threatened open warfare against the new United States of Indonesia, a Government spokesman said today.

State prison sentences of two to four years were imposed yester-- day in General Sessions on three so-called "principals" in the operation of a "rigged" interstate policy ring. In addition two defendants were fined $3,000 each and the third $1,000.

With inspiration leaping the gap from the Renaissance to surrealism, crisp and pretty simplicity was the pervading note last night in the over-all spring millinery picture for 1950 as observed in the semi-annual Millinery Stabilization Commission and Fashion Bureau showing at the Astor Hotel by custom designers, members of the Millinery Creators Guild and Thirty-ninth Street manufacturers.

Faster touring speeds and increased gasoline mileage from a higher gear ratio are offered in the 1950 British Austin line presented yesterday by Joseph Dudley, vice president of the Austin Motor Company, Ltd. The cars are on display in dealer showrooms here.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10--Homer J. Livingston, executive vice president of the First National Bank of Chicago today was chosen president of the institution. He succeeds Bentley G. McCloud, who retired at 65 years of age from the presidency but remains as a director and member of the executive committee.
The Mason-Neilan Regulator Company, manufacturer of industrial automatic control equipment, has leased space in the thirty-sixstory office building nearing completion at 100 Park Avenue.
HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 10 (AP)-- Three members of a family were killed today when an automobile and a tractor-trailer crashed on a slippery highway during a heavy rain.

Independent retailers can successfully combat chain store competition by making their stores important to the price conscious customer, according to Joseph W. Dye, president of Wolf Dessauer, department store, Fort Wayne, Ind.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 10--Senator Harry P. Cain, Republican, of Washington, today told Governor Dewey of New York that Congress would not extend the Federal rent controls for a year, as President Truman has recommended.
TRENTON, Jan. 10--A balanced state budget without new taxes became a prime objective today of Republican legislative leaders as the 1950 session of the New Jersey Legislature convened.

Jerome S. Eisemann has purchased the taxpayer with seven stores at 68 to 108 Covert Avenue in Stewart Manor, L.I., from Covert Properties, Inc. Sale was subject to a mortgage of $43,900 and at the closing a purchase-money mortgage of $17,000 was executed. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

Aeolian Hall, a thirteen-story and penthouse, store and office building at 27 and 29 West Fiftyseventh Street, near Fifth Avenue, which was purchased in 1948 by the New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese for the purpose of housing its Catholic Charities organization, yesterday was resold by the Archbishopric to L. Jerome Riker for investment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)-- The Maritime Commission insisted today that it has need for all the extra money listed for it in Presi-- dent Truman's budget for the new, fiscal year.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan, 10-- Bruce Addison Clarke, technical illustration editor for Bell Telephone Laboratories in New York, died unexpectedly at his home, 136 Ivy Lane, early today.

The large buyer influx into New York stems from the genuine need of retailers to replenish starved stocks and a resurgence of confidence in business prospects through the middle of the year, according to Henry Rosenfeld, dress manufacturer.

HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 10-- The Finnish political situation, made tense by the sudden strairing of relations with the Soviet Union, has been further complicated by the prospects of a government crisis.

Mayor O'Dwyer requested state and Federal welfare officials yesterday to join with corresponding city officials in a re-examination of the basis on which allowances to relief recipients here are computed.
ALBANY, Jar 10 (AP)--Two proposals for investigating boxing in New York State were introduced today in the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The question of the seniority rights of displaced newspaper mailing and delivery employes was put up to Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, today.
Sherman White and Eddie Gard spearheaded a second-half drive that carried Long Island University from behind to a sparkling 58-42 triumph over St. Louis last night at Madison Square Garden.

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company's business is growing and therefore its directors believe it would be unsound to increase the dividend at this time, N. Baxter Jackson, chairman, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday.

Officers and members of the council of the National Academy of Design have arranged a dinner for Jan. 17 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria to mark the one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the organization.

Representatives of business, professions and the arts in Greenwich Village joined yesterday at the first meeting of the newly forhed Chamber of Commerce in that locality in a program to improve the services of city departments in that area.
ALBANY, Jan. 10--Practices of the Port of New York Authority were denounced vigorously here today as New York City legislators moved for sweeping investigations into the powers of the bistate body.

The Board of Education will seek the largest budget in its history for the operation of the city's public schools next year. It announced yesterday that its tentative estimate for 1950-51 was $232,003,241 and that this included $13,000,000 for raising the salaries of teachers and supervisory personnel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Is Harry S. Truman the thirty-third President? This question was revived today by the new issue of the Congressional Directory.

Spokesmen for Queens business and civic groups clashed heatedly yesterday during a hearing before the Board of Transportation on a proposal to relieve congestion at the Flushing bus terminal by diverting more than 2,300 commuters to the near-by Willets Point Boulevard subway station of the IRT line.

In a purchase for investment, Max G. Tompkins, retired New York and California business man, has acquired the Briarview Manor Apartments at Shapham Place and Bosband Avenue in White Plains, N.Y. The seller was the Briarview Manor, Inc., of which Oscar Regan of New York is president. The Myron L. Blum Company was the broker. The purchase price was reported to have been more than S400,000.
A drive to raise $12,000,000 for a projected engineering research Center was officially started yesterday by Columbia University at a luncheon in the Men's Faculty Club, 400 West 117th Street.
The engagement has been made known here of Miss Helen Marie Hosp, adviser for women's education to Gen. Douglas MacArthur, to Dr. Herbert L. Seamans of New York.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 10 (AP)-- George (Good Kid) Susce, bullpen coach for eight years, lost his job with the Indians today because his son, a promising pitcher, spurned a Tribe offer and signed with a Red Sox farm club.

Plans are being completed for the twenty-sixth annual benefit of the Episcopal Actors Guild, which this year will be a preview performance of "The Cocktail Party," by T.S. Eliot, on the night of Jan. 20 in the Henry Miller Theatre.
After a brief ceremony in a little waiting room, Bellevue Hospital's big new clinic was declared officially open yesterday afternoon.

The city is ready to award to the J.K. Welding Company of 71 Paidge Avenue, Brooklyn, a contract for reconstructing the center spans, including roadways, of the Brooklyn Bridge, Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen announced yesterday. The company was the low bidder.

The St. John's University basketball team, which has a 13--1 record and is one of the leading quintets in the nation, smilingly absorbed a 38--26 beating at the De Gray Gymnasium in Brooklyn yesterday.

The management of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company would rather make liberal loans to its small depositors than participate in large low-interest-bearing erm loans, and it favors for investment the tax exempt bonds of the ...

LONDON, Jan. 10--The stock markets made a mixed showing here today while waiting for official announcement of the general election date. The turnover contracted further and much of the business done represented precautionary trimming of sales in advance of election.

TOKYO, Jan. 10--The Japanese now are being assured that their enlarged and modernized fishing fleet soon will be permitted access to fishing grounds in the South Pacific and in the Indian Ocean, possibly as far south as 5 degrees below the equator.

ALBANY, Jan. 10--Democratic legislative leaders charged the Republican state administration today with neglecting school construction, and invited Governor Dewey and the Republican leaders of the Senate and Assembly to join them in a tour "to see for themselves the crisis in education facing the state."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Orders went out from the Defense Department today dispatching two destroyers to give assistance to and help repair the United States freighter Flying Arrow, which was fired upon by gunboats of the Chinese Nationalist naval forces.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 10-- Eugene J. Gribbin, Superintendent of Schools here and a civic worker, died this afternoon in the North Country Community Hospital after a brief illness. He was 55 years old. His home was at 24 North Lane.
WASHINGTON Jan. 10--The Senate Banking and Currency Committee today recommended an early study to ascertain whether the anti-trust laws should be applied to labor unions.

For the final week of his engagement at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, Uday Shankar last night presented his Hindu dancers and musicians in a program consisting partly of new dances, partly of repetitions from the previous...

The report of Hiram WalkerGooderham Worts, Ltd., distillers, and its subsidiaries, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $8,625,821 for the three months ended on Nov. 30, last, after taxes and all charges.

The Grace National Bank last year earned $475,622, or $15.85 a share, but the bank directorate and major stockholders are not disposed to increase dividend payments until there is a relaxation of the present double tax on corporate income. Last year the dividend was $4 a share.

ALBANY, Jan, 10--Twelve bills sponsored by the State Banking Department, including measures that would permit payments to savings bank trustees for attending meetings and would broaden the mortgage opportunities of savings ...

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 10-- Muzahim Amin el-Pachachi, Minister of Foreign Affairs and Deputy Premier of Iraq, said today that the Iraqi Cabinet under Premier Ali Jawdat al-Ayubi sought the friendly cooperation of and the most cordial relations with the United States.
ANNAPOLIS, Wednesday, Jan. 11(AP)--The Naval Academy announced early today that Eddie Erdelatz would be its new head football coach.

It fell to the lot of that gifted pianist, Claudio Arrau, to introduce to his audience new music, not only by the late Eric Satie, but by one Robert Schumann, at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall.

Continuation of Marshall Plan aid to Europe is "absolutely necessary" for rehabilitation, and "too much of a cut in funds would result in disaster," Paul-Henri Spaak, former Prime Minister of Belgium, declared here yesterday.

A $2,000 anonymous contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was sent yesterday by "A Friend" who had previously donated a large sum. With the second gift a pre-Christmas promise to "send the rest later" was fulfilled, the donor said.

One hundred and fifty civic and industrial leaders attended the opening last night of the Legal Aid Society's campaign to raise $225,000. They met at the headquarters of the Junior League, 130 East Eightieth Street.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 10-- The Harvard Student Council early today refused to lift a ban on discrimination for "race, color or nationality" in all college organizations. This was accomplished by an 8-8 tie vote on a motion to rescind the ban, following a fourhour debate.

PARIS, Jan. 10--Communist organized demonstrations against war in Indo-China ended in a clash with the police in Marseille today. Ten policemen were injured, one of them seriously, while six of the demonstrators were arrested.

Most hunter's are inclined to weigh the desirability of a 300pound deer against the distance from camp, but there must have been plenty of heaving and hauling up in Maine this year, for more than fifty-five bucks scaling better than 300 pounds were killed during the season.
WILMINGTON, Del., Jan 10-- Shermer H. Stradley, who had served as Acting Mayor and President of the City Council, died this morning at his home at the age of 67.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Harry Van Arsdale Jr., business manager of New York Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL, went on trial today on four charges of violating union laws.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted today regulations requiring the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to file with the agency substantially the same information, documents and reports as would be required if the bank had securities registered under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

ALBANY, Jan. 10--Governor Dewey approved today stopgap legislation revalidating until May 1 the New York City rent and eviction control law that was voided by the Court of Appeals at the end of last month.

The management and board of directors of the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company of New York are "entirely alert" to the possibility of merging the bank with another institution under suitable conditions, Walter G. Kimball,...

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 (AP) --Navy Capt. John G. Crommelin. outspoken foe of armed services unification, extended his attack tonight to Gen. Dwight D. (Ike) Eisenhower. Without naming the general he told the Pacific Traffic Association of San Francisco:

The first Commonwealth conference to be held in Asia occurs as a new and incalculable power rises in China. The scene and timing of the meeting, not to speak of the profound changes it underlines in the Commonwealth itself, dramatize the revolution that has taken place in the Far East since the end of the war.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11--Retailers today began cautious ordering of less desirable new bedroom furniture items here at the annual winter furniture market in the Merchandise and American Furniture Marts. As the third day of the market drew to a close, manufacturer after manufacturer of bedroon and dining room furniture informed dealers seeking to place

A nation-wide ring dealing in stolen collectors stamps has been responsible for the theft of $700,000 in rare stamps in this city, it was reported yesterday with the arrest of two men on charges of criminally receiving stolen property.

A rally by the stock market yesterday afternoon drew prices away from indecision and, under the sponsorship of she steels, the list made a new high on the New York Stock Exchange. The rally in the late hours produced the heaviest trading in fourteen months and advanced the composite rate 0.46

The winter thus far has been singularly free of snow. This situation no doubt pleases all city administrations, which are inclined to be a bit prosaic about such matters. It also must seem the next best thing to a rate increase, certified by the ICC, to all of the local railroads.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 (AP)-- Rain washed out the Los Angeles Open golf play-off today, forcing postponement of the Sam SneadBen Hogan eighteen-hole match until next Wednesday. Similar weather caused a delay in the tournament Sunday.

HONG KONG, Jan. 10--Wealthy families and individuals in Shanghai are being put through the Communist financial wringer under the program of marketing the Peiping Government's new victory bonds just launched throughout Communist China.

If the commercial airlines had to provide for themselves the various facilities maintained by the military forces, but which are available to civil users, the cost might mean the difference between survival and liquidation, Earold C. Stuart, Assistant Secretary of the Air Force, declared here yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 11--Assurance that the almost 70,000 miners on strike in eight bituminous producing states will be back on the job next Monday--but on only a three-day week--was given tonight by district leaders of the United Mine Workers.
The Port of New York Authority promised yesterday to institute automobile commutation rates for its three Hudson River crossings on or before July 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--Rumblings of dissatisfaction at the way the Republican policy statement for the 1850 campaign is being put together became louder today as the nature of the House committee that will work on the job became known.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 11-Because of their financial plights, a growing number of colleges and universities are buying up businesses or entering into "dubious" partnerships with industrial companies, and thereby are abusing their tax-exempt status under the Federal income tax laws, leading educators asserted here today.
Emergency sandbag squads braced weakening dikes yesterday awaiting the surging crests of turbulent rivers in Indiana and Illinois, with more rain expected, The Associated Press reported.

A new steamship line that will operate out of Houston and other Gulf ports, offering competitive rates below those of existing steamship conference tariffs, was announced here yesterday by the principals in the new concern.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts sold yesterday five issues of tax-exempt bonds totaling $14,950,000 and maturing from Oct. 1, 1950 to Jan. 1, 1980, at an interest cost of 1.49769 per cent. The bonds were sold at sealed bidding to a banking syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust at a bid of 100.03 for 1 s.

Present international tensions make it necessary for the Atomic Energy Commission to devote a major part of its efforts to building atomic weapons rather than exploring the possibilities of peacetime utilization of atomic energy, Gordon E. Dean declared here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11--The possibility that farmer cooperatives may push legislation to keep the Federal Government out of the marketing of farm products loomed today at the annual meeting of the National Council of Farmer Cooperatives.

Banking is likely to find it difficult to maintain interest rates at current levels this year, especially in view of the Government's "cheap money" policy, Charles J. Stewart, new president of the New York Trust Company, declared yesterday.

Mrs. Alan T. Schumacher, chairman of the committee for the benefit bridge and canasta party for the Association for the Relief of Respectable, Aged and Indigent Females, will give a luncheon tomorrow in the Chanteclair Room of the Sherry-Netheriand for the vice chairmen of the committee,

Housewives in Queens were told in no uncertain terms yesterday that today is a "water holiday." Instead of water they had sound pouting at them from amplifiers mounted on a station wagon that toured through areas of the borough covered by the Sunnyside and Woodside Health Councils, urging the neiehbors not to waste water.

American Safety Razor Corporation will begin a strong bid for a major share of the camera market about mid-year, it was disclosed yesterday by Milton Dammann, board chairman, in a press interview during a sales meeting at the Belmont Plaza Hotel.

Wine will soon be packed and sold in three-ounce tumblers through package store, outlets, it was learned here yesterday. The winery that will package, their products in this manner is the Roma Wine Company of Fresno, Calif. The new package is expected to retail between 19 and 22 cents, to be determined by state taxes. Port, sherry, muscatel, burgundy, sautern and claret wil be offered.

WASHINGTON, San. 11--The possibility of re-establishing full diplomatic relations between the United States and Spain was raised today as officials indicated that a statement of American policy toward the Franco Government might soon be issued.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11--The grain markets closed strong today after an easy start on the Board of Trade, final sales being about the top with wheat showing gains of 3/8 to 1 3/8 cents, May leading. Corn was up 1/8 to 1 cents, oats were unchanged to cent up, rye rose 1 to 1 cents and soybeans were up 1 cents to 2 cents down,

Mayor O'Dwyer, to speed action on his proposal to legalize gambling, used a police airplane yesterday to send to the majority and minority leaders of the Republicancontrolled Legislature, copies of a letter supporting his suggestion.
MOSCOW, Jan. 11--The Soviet press today published regulations under which the new elections to the Supreme Soviet will be conducted March 12.
SALLIS, Miss., Jan.11(AP)--A prison trusty today helped capture the last two men of a white trio hunted as the drunken marauders who killed three Negro children.

Excessive alcoholic beverage taxes cause public resentment which compromises temperance and undermines respect for and obedience to law, it is emphasized in a resolution adopted yesterday by the New York State Liquor Authority urging Congress to consider public opinion in the revision of the tax structure.
The three public library systems serving New York asked salary increases for virtually all their 2,000 employes in hearings on 1950-51 city budget requests yesterday.

Two hundred and fifty state and city officials, including Governor Dewey, crowded a court room in the New York County Court House in Foley Square yesterday to attend a two-hour ceremony at the induction of Charles D. Breitel as a justice of the State Supreme Court.

New York's Knickerbockers gave it the stymie treatment at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. They did nothing to distinguish themselves in the early stages of their National Basketball Association game with the Washington Capitols, but they hustled up at the finish to take a 73-72 decision.
The Guaranty, Trust Company of New York is redeeming the outstanding 6 per cent first mortgage bonds dated Jan. 1, 1914, of the Hastings Square Hotel Company.

Two five-story apartment buildings with a total of fifty-one apartments and four stores on plot 100 by 100 feet at 1530-32 and 1534-36 Webster Avenue, south of Claremont Parkway, the Bronx, were sold by Sol Rebhun and Rubin Schenkman to Sol Bassik for investment. Allan S. Feldman Co.

The critical plight of the ship repair industry and its poor prospects in the immediately foreseeable future, were depicted by industry leaders yesterday morning at a meeting with the Maritime Commission and its staff in Washington.

Communism can become an active threat to our institutions if governmental fiscal policies create public distrust in the value of the dollar, James G. Blaine, president of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York, warned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--senator William Langer, Republican, of North Dakota, injected the three basic "civil rights" bills today into the Senate's efforts to repeal the excise tax on oleomargarine.

Fred Lazarus Jr. of Cincinnati and this city, since 1945 president of Federated Department Stores, Inc., received last night the seventh annual Tobe Award for Distinguished Contribution to Amercian Retailing, at a dinner in the St. Regis Hotel.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Thursday, Jan. 12--Chinese Communist regular army troops have landed on Hainan Island and have established a substantial beachhead on the southwest coast, Nationalist dispatches reported today.

The Egyptian elections are now over, having resulted in an overwhelming and decisive victory for the Wafd opposition. That the Wafd should have won an absolute majority of more than two to one over the other parties combined was wholly unexpected and is very significant.

The two-platoon system received the strong endorsement of the American Football Coaches Association yesterday with its adoption of a recommendation to the Football Rules Committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association that the substitution rule now in force be retained, with an added liberalizing provision.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 11 (AP)--Henry Levy, director of the American Joint Distribution Committee in Czechoslovakia, was ordered to leave the country today and to liquidate the Jewish relief agency by the end of the month.

The 13-year-old mystery of the whereabouts of the rarest European postage stamp, a Swedish 1855 error-variety considered worth more than $30,000, was solved yesterday with the announcement here that the owner is Rumania's former King Carol II, now living in exile at Estoril, a suburb of Lisbon, Portugal.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11-- Allusion to the long and bitter struggle over communism within the Congress of Industrial Organizations was made by the defense today at the perjury-conspiracy trial of Harry R. Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--Senator Pat McCarran of Nevada, long cool to liberalization of the Displaced Persona Act of 1948, declared today he could not say whether the Judiciary Committee, which he heads, would report any bill on the subject by Jan. 25, as directed by the full Senate.

The annual report of the Irving Trust Company, presented yesterday to stockholders at the annual meeting, disclosed that operating income, operating expenses and net operating earnings were the highest for the last ten years.

Thirty-odd years of expert millinery design shone through the Laddie Northridge spring collection yesterday at 1 West Fiftyseventh Street. Here was the workmanship, the mastery of color, the exquisite blendings and combniations for which this designer is so well known.

ALBANY, Jan. 11--If existing colleges at Binghamton and Plattsburg are preserved by making them parts of the State University system, the present needs of the state for four-year colleges will be met, the State University trustees decided yesterday.

A $200,000 stallion, the 7-yearold bay horse Nirgal, headed the shipment of thirteen thoroughbreds which arrived yesterday aboard the United States Lines' cargo vessel American Merchant. In charge of the shipment was Jack Hare, who has handled horses on more than 300 crossings of the Atlantic.
Dr. Carl Binger clung to his diagnosis of Whittaker Chambers as "a psychopathic personality" yesterday as his cross-examination that had begun last Friday ended at the Alger Hiss perjury trial.
The persistence of abnormally high unemployment at a time when the general economic situation is supposedly excellent is puzzling state labor officials.

PARIS, Jan. 11--After long considering how fast the economic integration of Europe could move, officials of the Economic Cooperation Administration have defined what they regard as a "manageable" minimum of action to be expetted in the immediate future and by the end of 1950.

Net earnings of the Public National Bank and Trust Company last year amounted to $2,507,427, compared with $2,576,793 in 1948, according to the annual report being distributed today to the bank's 4,959 stockholders.

A "quickie" strike of 150 restaurant and service employes halted the flow of food and liquor to guests at the Governor Clinton Hotel, Thirty-first Street and Seventh Avenue, for a half hour early yesterday evening.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 11(AP) --The University of Rochester reported today it had photographic plates showing "strong evidence" of a new atomic particle, the neutral meson.

Federal aid to the people of New York State during the fiscal year ended June 30 totaled $148,022,749, according to a preliminary report yesterday by Joseph B. O'Connor, regional director of the Federal Security Agency.

Resolutions urging the Senate to ratify the United Nations Genocide Treaty and adopt the Celler Displaced Persons Bill were unanimously adopted yesterday by 2,000 delegates at the thirtieth annual convention of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Systematic tapping of the telephones of United Nations delegates and employes was charged yesterday against the Federal Bureau of Investigation during a pretrial hearing on the Coplon-Gubitchev spy case.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--The proposed new $42,000,000,000 single appropriation bill, on which nine House subcommittees have begun work, has started two movements at Capitol key points, both aimed at preventing log-rolling and defeat of the economy objectives of the omnibus plan.

With four of her crew hospitalized, the Home liner Atlantic docked at Pier 56 North River at 11:30 A.M. yesterday after a crossing from Lisbon that was described by Capt. Nestor Martinoli, her master, as the stormiest he had experienced in twenty-five years. The ship was not damaged.
In its mid-winter furniture show, opening today, Gimbels proves there is well-styled, tasteful contemporary furniture for families with small pocketbooks and big ideas.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 11--The Rev. Dr. Walter Arthur Maier, noted radio preacher for the Lutheran Hour, died at the Lutheran Hospital here today at the age of 56, He was stricken with a coronary thrombosis on Dec. 29.

The Southern Pacific Company obtained financing yesterday for the acquisition of new equipment by selling at competitive bidding an issue of $13,530,000 of equipment trust certificates maturing from Jan. 1, 1951 to 1965, to Salomon Brothers Hutzler and associates at an interest cost of 2.1734 per cent.

Chased on the Belt Parkway, Brooklyn, by a dozen radio cars receiving directions over the police two-way radio system, three armed men fleeing in an automobile after a hold-up were captured early yesterday morning.

Dr. Takeo Iwahashi, blind author and social worker of Osaki, Japan, here on a visit to acquaint himself with American methods of education and employment for the blind, said yesterday that we were doing wonders with our blind.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Jan.11-- Nathan Pendleton, who started as a messenger of the Citizens National Bank and Trust Company of Oneonta, was named today president of the institution. He started with the bank in 1922.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--General increases in international telegraph rates will not be permitted at this time, the Federal Communications Commission announced today.

Katharine Cornell announced yesterday the she would conclude the Broadway run of her starring vehicle, "That Lady," at the Martin Beck Theatre after the evening performance of Jan. 28. Two days later she will open the attraction at the Harris Theatre in Chicago on the first lee of an extended tour.

LONDON, Jan. 11--News came from Funchal, Madeira, tonight that Winston Churchill, who is on a holiday there, was planning to return on the first good flying day to lead the Conservatives in their fight to oust the Laborites from power.

On the eve of the city's second "water holiday" in the drive to cut consumption, Mayor O'Dwyer appealed yesterday to the public for "whole-hearted cooperation" in keeping water use to a minimum today.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 11--A bill that would insure the bank account of an individual up to $10,000 and completely revise the law under which the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation operates was endorsed today by Maple T. Harl, chairman of the FDIC, and Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency.
Paul Alexander Christoffel Willem Brandenburg van den Gronden is a young man of the world who just likes to fly the Atlantic.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 11-- Princeton University's slow-starting basketball team tonight broke up a tight contest with Pennsylvania in the last eight minutes, upsetting the Quaker quintet, 72--53, for their second Eastern Intercollegiate League victory.

Bradley University, which has won twelve ball games and first two, will play in the feature of the basketball double-header akainst Manhattan at Madison Square Garden tonight. Duke University will oppose New York University in the first game, at 8 o'clock.

Cheese cake is such a favorite with New Yorkers, who feel for it the way the Chinese do for winter melon soup or the Armenians for baklava, that we may be forgiven perhaps for discussing it twice within a week.
Robert L. O'Brien has been appointed general sales manager of Bourjois, Inc., and Barbara Gould, Inc. He formerly was sales manager of the wholesale and chain divisions of Bourjois, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--The United States, although "ready and eager" for a peace discussion with the Soviet Union, reiterated today its opposition to a world peace based only on a bilateral settlement.
Recent developments on opposite sides of the globe, in France and in Formosa, gave strength yesterday to world sugar futures dealings on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he would leave the city at 2 P.M. today for a two weeks' rest at Key Largo, Fla.

GENEVA, Jan. 11--Senator Pat McCarran's criticism of the administration of the Displaced Persons Act and charges that subversive elements were being admitted to the United States as DP's were characterized as baseless and distorted today by a leading Catholic welfare official.

LONDON, Jan. 11--Wallis Roach's telephone started ringing this morning at 7:15. The date of Britain's next general election, Feb. 23, had been announced on the British Broadcasting Corporation's first news program at 7 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--Herman W. Steinkraus, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, proposed today the creation of a Hoover-type commission to study the over-all social security problem arising from labor's drive for employer-financed pensions.
In keeping With tradition, students of Riverdals Country School, in the upper Bronx, sent $500 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday as their annual offering.
The nation's production of raw steel in 1949 was the third largest in a year free of war or the influences of war, according to yesterday's report of the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The big wind that has been putting a tinge of green under the tan of the Miami and Key anglers apparently has not had too much force by the time it reached Palm Beach and Stuart, for some excellent sailfish catches have been reported from both fishing centers.

Another Williams, who may be the fourth member of that clan to become a famous big-time ball player, came into the major leagues yesterday when Dave Williams signed his 1950 contract with the New York Giants.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (UP)--The Stewart-Warner Corporation tonight discharged five employes who, it said, refused to sign noncommunist affidavits prepared by the company.
Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare Commissioner, refused again yesterday to see a delegation seeking to protest scheduled cuts in city relief allowances.
Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League officials yesterday voted to drop the "two-minute rule" and Ivy games after Saturday will be played under the same regulations for the entire forty minutes.

ALBANY, Jan. 11--Welles V. Moot, a Regent, told Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein today that every member of the Board of Regents, to his certain knowledge, favored the basic purposes of the Feinberg law.
BERLIN, Jan. 11--Joy was spread throughout Germany many months ago when the Western powers proclaimed that all German prisoners of war soon would be repatriated.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan.11 --At the request of John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, the State Department has allocated $1,000,000 and the Economic Cooperation Administration 50,000,000 Deutsche marks ($13,328,000) in counterpart funds for a special program aimed at developing a democratic spirit in Western Germany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--About $31,000,000,000, or approximately three-quarters of the proposed national budget for the 1851 fiscal year, is earmarked "to pay the cost of past wars" and to provide insurance, in the form of military forces, against the danger of wars to come.

IF T-formation quarterbacks ever formed a union, the first coach they would blackball for unfair labor practices would be Bud Wil kinson of Oklahoma, a personable, level-headed young man of 34, who has been named as the Coach of the Year. The estimable Frank Leahy once offered the opinion that T-formation quarterbacks could play their position in dinner jackets and never get them rumpled.
United States exports this year are likely to approximate $11,000,000,000, a decrease of about $1,000,000,000 from the 1949 total, according to the first forecast to be made in official quarters.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 11 (AP)-- Citation, a magic name in horse racing, hit the comeback trail today, scaring an easy victory in the mud and rain at Santa Anita park.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 11--A firmer Allied attitude toward Western Germany, symbolized by the French intention not to discuss a Saar plebiscite, was evident today as the Federal Parliament convened for its first sitting of the year.

The Glass Container Manufacturers Institute will spend $1,000, 000 during 1950 to promote the noreturn beer bottle, it was announced yesterday. Benjamin Wood, marketing director of the institute, said a "substantial part" of the budget will be spent on a concentrated advertising schedule.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 11--Amid a storm of protest, the Board of Aldermen passed tonight an ordinance, making year-round leashing of dogs mandatory within the limits of this city. The measure then went to Mayor William H. Hussey, who signed it, making it effective at once.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 11 (AP) --Eddie Erdelatz assumed his first football command today, taking over as skipper of Navy's buffeted crew.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--John L. Lewis called off another skirmish in his push-button strike warfare today.
A strike by 2,200 fuel oil and coal drivers set for last midnight was postponed a few hours before the deadline when union members voted to accept a temporary peace formula proposed by Mayor O'Dwyer.

The alertness required to cross a crowded Manhattan street would have dispelled Hamlet's melancholy moods and transformed him into a lively lad, a modern visitor from Denmark said yesterday in telling her impressions of traffic conditions here.

Maybe the rest of the National Hockey League is tough for the Toronto Maple Leafs, but it's certain that the New York Rangers aren't any bother to them. The Northern skaters streaked their way to a 2-to-1 triumph over the Blue Shirts at Madison Square Garden last night, while a crowd of 13,187 looked on.
More than 300 members and guests will assemble tonight in the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria for the twelfth annual dinner of the Boxing Writers' Association of New York.

Television has been enlisted by the police in the search for 12year-old Josephine Leech, missing from her Yonkers home since last Thursday night. The use of television in a missing persons case is unprecedented.

Columbia's Ivy League leaders encountered unexpected opposition from Fordham's scrappy young quintet last night. The Lions had to come from far behind to flag down the rampant Rams, 58--51, in an exciting contest witnessed by 2,500 spectators at the Maroon gymnasium. It was the fifth straight triumph for the Light Blue, which has an over-all record of ten victories and four defeats.

COPENHAGEN, Jan. 11--Mrs. Karin Michaelis, widely known Danish author, died today at her home in Copenhagen. She was 77 years old. Her novels, short stories and children's tales have been translated into many languages.

There were no experiments or problems at the concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night. Charles Munch, the ensemble's permanent conductor, directed a program of staples of the repertory that are unfailingly successful, and the guest artist was Yehudi Menuhin,
Joint action by five leading fur dealers to fight fraudulent bankruptcies in the fur industry was announced here yesterday.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 11-- Two new directors, Robert Winthrop Kean Jr., and Donald M. Liddell Jr., have been elected by the shareholders of the National State Bank here. All other directors have been renamed. Officers will be elected at the board's organization meeting next Monday.

ALBANY, Jan. 11--The powers of the State Industrial Commissioner over the employment of children on farms and in street trades would be greatly strengthened under the provisions of two Labor Department program bills introduced in the Legislature today by Assemblyman John F. Wadlin, Republican, of Ulster County.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 11--The American Farm Bureau Federation, which presented its views on agricultural issues to a large press conference here today, has two goals for 1950. One is to increase to 1,500,000 the 1,409,000 farm "families" who constitute its membership. The other is to make permanent legislative and political junk of the "Brannan Plan."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--The "trend toward the Welfare State" with its attendant high taxes makes it "impossible" for the American people to pay "an economic rent," Representative Ralph W. Gwinn, Republican, of New York, declared today.

URBANA, Ill., Jan. 11--Dr. Franklin William Scott, former head of the English department at the University of Illinois and retired editor-in-chief of D. C. Heath Co., textbook publishers, died here yesterday of a heart ailment. He was 72 years old.

Plans for a one-story taxpayer to be occupied by a food market were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by. Franklin E. Knobel of 52 Market Street from Minnie Tannenbaum. The buyer recently acquired 48 and 50 Market Street and now controls a plot 75 by 100 feet which he is clearing for the new building.

Describing the neglect that led to the starvation death of a 3-yearold child, Assistant District Attorney George P. Monaghan said yesterday at the Felony Court arraignment of the victim's parents that it "equalled any horror story that had arisen from the concentration camps of Germany."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--The plan for liquidation and dissolution of the United Light and Railways Company and the Continental Gas and Electric Corporation, both of Chicago, has been approved, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today. The plan was amended to meet recommendations of the SEC.

Axel Jonsson, president of the Swedish American Line, who had long been prominent in Swedish shipping affairs, died yesterday in Stockholm, according to word received here at the office of the line, 636 Fifth Avenue. He would have been 62 years old on May 16.

The seven-month advance by the stock market was halted yesterday by an avalanche of selling which produced the heaviest trading in fourteen months and tumbled prices from 1 to 5 points with a 2.41 points drop in the composite rate.

ALBANY, Jan. 13--The state's tax receipts for the 1949-50 fiscal year, which ends next March 31, again will set a record, it was indicated today by figures on revenues for the first nine months, released by the Department of Taxation and Finance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--The Administration's Senate leaders yielded today to angry Republicans and agreed to call the high military authorities for Republican questioning about the strategic aspects of the hands-off policy toward Formosa.

The Interstate Commerce Commission was urged by the Port of New York Authority at a hearing in Washington yesterday to encourage the restoration of coastwise shipping services by approving rates for citrus fruit of tie Refrigerated Steamship Lines, the bi-state agency announced here last night.

A five-man panel of the Joint Committee on the Economic Report, under the chairmanship of Senator Paul Douglas of Illinois, conducted an inquiry during the closing weeks of 1949 in the field of monetary, credit and fiscal policy. The group has just released its findings in a fifty-page report, and the result is a document which is as refreshing for its plain speaking as it is for its hard-headed common sense.

A treaty that will eliminate official red tape and accelerate international motor travel for twentyone nations is likely to be approved by the United States before the summer touring season begins, according to H.H. Kelly, chief of the State Department's inland transport policy staff.

Leading engineers in this district said yesterday that fabricated steel is being offered on comparable work at lower prices than were quoted last summer. In a typical job, now being erected by a large New York consulting engineering firm, price savings now, over costs last summer, amount to more than 10 per cent.
A strike by 2,200 drivers of oil and coal trucks still was threatened yesterday.
Impressive figures that cannot be laughed off about the growing popularity of the sport of recreational boating emanated yesterday from the National Motor Boat Show at Grand Central Palace.

George D. Widener, top man at the nation's No. 1 race track, Belmont Park, is the new top man of The Jockey Club. Announcement was made yesterday of his election as chairman of the parent body of the American turf following the resignation of William Woodward at Thursday's annual meeting of the organization.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 13--The Commonwealth Foreign Ministers endorsed today and will recommend to their home governments a plan offered by Percy C. Spender, Australian Minister for External Affairs, for a Commonwealth mutual aid program aimed especially at the development of the naturally rich producing areas of South and Southeast Asia.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 13 (AP)--Bantam Ben Hogan and his golfing comeback ran into a temporary road block today in the first round of the Bing Crosby $10,000 invitational tournament.

Though the deer hunting season in this state ended Dec. 1, tips on cooking venison are still apropos. This is because the meat is not ready for oven or spit until its been hung about thirty days. Keeping it in a cool, dry place for a month or so modifies the gamey flavor and develops tenderness.

Next Thursday was set as a third New York "water holiday" by water department officials yesterday after final meter readings showed that last Thursday the public had used 840,000,000 gallons, or 42,000,000 gallons more than on the first "dry day," Dec. 16.

A curious item of news originating in Washington yesterday was that the House Rules Committee had voted 9 to 2 to regain its old power of holding up legislation indefinitely. PARIS, Jan. 13--Gen. Charles Mast, former Resident General of Tunisia, asked the Minister of Defense today to be allowed to appear before an honor jury to reply to charges that had been kept under cover in French politics for several weeks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13--J. R. Robertson, first vice president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, and a co-defendant in the Harry Bridges perjury and conspiracy trial, was linked to Communist party activity today for the first time since the Government opened its case thirty-five court days ago.

Twenty-eight contributions totaling $369 were received yesterday for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, bringing the Fund's thirty-eighth annual appeal to $302,999,67.

HONG KONG, Jan. 13--The conviction is growing among military observers here that Communist mainland China may soon be forced to attempt action to end the steady attrition that is being caused by the Nationalist air and naval attacks on the coastal areas.

TRENTON, Jan. 13--Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons instituted an appeal today "in the public interest" from a seven-cent bus and trolley fare authorized for most transportation lines in New Jersey by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

FAIR LAWN, N.J., Jan. 13-- William A. Hegarty, the advisory master, must decide whether the three Kretzschmar children will have to return to their mother, Mrs. Edna Kretzschmar, in Hollywood, Fla., or be permitted to remain with their father, Fred Kretzschmar, of 9 Ryder Road, in the Radburn section of this borough.

Asking 589 additional employes to help handle a heavy backlog of complaints and violations, Bernard J. Gillroy, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, submitted yesterday a 1950-51 departmental finance budget that was $1,997,042 higher than the current one.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 13--Connecticut organized labor, in a demonstration of unprecedented unity, laid the groundwork here today for unified political action in next November's election.

An enterprising series of "Chamber Music of Our Time" was initiated in Times Hall cast night. Its policy of presenting the works of four representative composers regardles, of the issues of fame or first performances suggests the thought that our century has come of age, musically, and its music should be treated the same as any other.

ALBANY, Jan. 13--Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education, today told the State Controller's Committee that is studying the problem of constitutional tax and debt limits that the Board of Regents considers school construction the state's most critical problem.

A new war risk bonus and insurance agreement, which contains improvements over the terms of the Maritime War Emergency Board's rules, has been signed by the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., and the National Maritime Union, CIO, it became known yesterday.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 13--The Iraqi Government has started a campaign to mobilize or perhaps force capital existing in Iraq to be employed within Iraq for her development.

PARIS, Jan. 13--There is evidence that negotiations taking place in Moscow between the Soviet Union and the Chinese Communist Government delegation headed by Mao Tze-tung are immensely important, but have developed in a more complex fashion than had been foreseen originally by the Kremlin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today that a European currency union for clearing payments among Marshall Plan countries would be "set up and operating" within ninety days.
The British token import plan for goods from the United States will be continued on an unchanged basis for this year, it was made known here yesterday.
An unprecendented medical meeting was held last night in the auditorium of Lenox Hill Hospital.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 13--The United Nations sent a protest today to United Nations Galleries, Inc., at 24 West Fifty-sixth Street, requesting the Manhattan concern to stop using the name of the United Nations.

The mystery in the pre-trial Coplon-Gubitchev spy case hearings deepened yesterday as to what took place on the morning of last March 4 in Room 2220 of the Department of Justice Building in Washington.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP)--Stan Hack, former star Cub third baseman, today was handed a managerial berth just one notch below the major leagues after only two years of field boss experience. The Cubs named the 39-year-old Hack to pilot their Springfield (Mass.) club in the Triple A International League next season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--The Texmass Petroleum Company, Dallas, Tex., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $3,000,000 of 4 per cent senior cumulative-interest debentures, due Jan. 1, 1965, and $1,000,000 of 5 per cent junior income debentures, due Jan. 1, 1970.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13-- Van Heflin, who recently obtained a release from his Metro-GoldwynMayer contract, has been signed by Horizon Pictures, the Sam Spiegel-John Huston company, to play the leading role in "Cost of Living," which Horizon will produce...

COLUMBUS, Ga., Jan. 13--A freakish gust of wind buffeted to earth a glider full of paratroopers today as it swooped in for a landing at near-by Lawson Field, killing twelve of the seventeen men on board. The five survivors were injured seriously.
