GENEVA, Jan. 13--The Drafting Committee of the United Nations Trusteeship Council completed tonight its "first reading" of the statute under which Italy will govern her former colony of Somaliland under United Nations trusteeship.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Jan. 13-- Miss Betsy Reed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey W. Reed, has chosen the afternoon of Feb. 4 for her marriage to Richard M. Hollingshead 3d, son of Mrs. Elsa C. Hollingshead of Riverton, N.J., and Richard M. Hollingshead Jr. of Philadelphia.

The only book published today is "Albert Schweitzer: Life and Message," by Magnus Ratter, which the Beacon Press of Boston is selling for $2.75. It is a biography of the famous doctor, musician, theologian and scholar.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 13 --A group of German generals and staff officers has informed Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Federal Republic, that Western Germany's minimum requirements in the event of rearmament are one infantry division by June of this year and the addition of an armored corps by 1951, it was learned today from an unimpeachable source.

A somewhat nonplused contingent of adults tried to make free with paints and brushes yesterday for the first time in territory that up until now has been reserved exclusively for their 3 to 8-year-old children.

LONDON, Jan. 13--Continuous study for many month, both here and in the United States, has so far failed to produce any plan that would offer Britain permanent large-scale relief from the oppressive burden of her sterling debts to other countries, inquiries in London indicated today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 13--Champ Carry, president of Pullman, Inc., was elected a director of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company at the annual meeting of shareholders today.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 13--On the eve of his departure for the United States, Ambassador Jeronimo Remorino announced today that the National Economic Council had approved "almost without exception" the recommendations of the joint Argentine-United States trade commission.
The "for-allergy-sufferers-only" label has been removed from foam rubber pillows and mattresses and they are growing more popular among people who simply prize sleep.

LONDON, Jan. 11--Both major political parties will take special pains to woo the women of Britain in the coming election campaign in the belief that it may well be the housewives and mothers who will cast the deciding vote.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--The Senate Labor Committee agreed today to a public hearing on a Republican-sponsored resolution urging President Truman to act in the coal dispute, but reports from the Executive Branch, including a Cabinet meeting, indicated Presidential action was still quite remote. No date was set for the Senate hearing.

The Conolidated Edison Company ef New York, Inc., may acquire the Staten Island Edison Corporation. This was announced yesterday by a spokesman for the utility at a weekly luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts in Schwartz' Restaurant, 54 Broad Street.

Warner Bros. Pictures Inc., and United States operating subsidiaries had a net profit of $10,466,534 in hte fiscal year ended with last August, after taxes and all charges, the annual report of Harry M. Warner, president, disclosed yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 13--The Court of Appeals made it legally possible today for the Consolidated Edison Company of New York to ask the United States Supreme Court for a review of the state court decision upholding a temporary 10 per cent reduction in the company's electric service charges.
KATONAH, N.Y., Jan. 13--Mr. and Mrs. Donald Percy of Katonah and Manchester, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia, to Henry Belz 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Belz...

Taking four first places and scoring in every event, Cardinal Hayes easily captured its third straight Bronx indoor interscholasthe track and field title at the Third Engineers Group Armory last night. Sixteen schools and 450 anthletes participated in the championships.

FRESNO, Calif., Jan. 13--An intensive organizing campaign among agricultural workers, with 100,000 new members as the goal during 1950, was outlined today to the sixteenth annual convention of the National Farm Labor Union by Harry L. Mitchell, its president.

The right of the City Council to expel one of its members was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Thomas A. Aurelio, who dismissed the petition of Benjamin J. Davis Jr. to have vacated the board's decision of Nov. 28 which ousted him, and to obtain payment of his salary to the end of his elective term.

While top local athletes scramble for titles in the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior indoor track and field championships at the Third Engineers Group Armory, a notable collection of national headliners will assemble in Washington's resplendent National Guard Armory for the third annual Washington Evening Star games.

LITTLE FALLS, N.J., Jan. 13-- As a result of a newly devised "Shut-in Telephone Service," 8year-old Bobby Filippello will be able, beginning Monday, to "attend" classes at Public School 3 without leaving his home a quarter of a mile away.

A fog that harbor men described as "cottony" blanketed New York and offshore areas yesterday, handicapping port traffic, forcing diversion of inbound transatlantic planes to other cities, causing cancellations of domestic air arrivals and take-offs and hampering land traffic to a lesser extent.

WEST NYACK, N.Y., Jan. 13 --Residents of this village had a preview today of what is believed to be the largest scientific model of a housefly at the home oF Cris E. Olsen, 70-year-old retired modeler and sculptor for the invertebrate and marine departments of the American Museum of Natural History.

BERLIN, Jan. 13--Dissolution of Soviet zone concentration camps at Sachasenhausen and Buchenwald within the week is expected. An official announcement by Wilhelm Pieck, president of the German Democratic Republic, will be issued and details of the action given by next Friday, according to indications from Soviet quarters.
Seven of the new one-man exhibitions of painting and sculpture opening this week in metropolitan art galleries are markedly different, one from the other.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--The Senate agreed today on its first test vote Tuesday on the Administration bill to repeal excise taxes on oleomargarine. The vote will come on the "dairy" Senators' substitute amendment.

Myra Hess, the distinguished English pianist, joined her compatriots of the Griller String Quartet for an evening of enthusiastic and illuminating chamber music at Town Hall last night. The occasion was a birthday celebration--the twenty-first anniversary of the founding of the quartet.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (U.P.)-- The Federal Trade Commission today asked Congress for powers to break up corporations big enough to dominate an industry even though they are not monopolies.

WARSAW, Jan. 13--The Polish Government continued its campaign of reprisals against France today by arresting twelve more French nationals and ordering the French Institute to suspend completely its activities in Poland.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 13-- Six rinks reached the quarter-final round today in the three-day curling bonspiel for the Archibald Douglas medal on the indoor rink at the St. Andrews Golf Club. All but three of the nineteen entries had seen action by nightfall, when play was suspended until tomorrow morning. All the participants from nine United States clubs and two in Canada attended the annual dinner.

LONDON, Jan. 13--Dollar stocks fell several points on the Stock Exchange here today and the premium dropped from 14 to 13 percent following the slump in Wall Street. Added to pre-election slackness in business this accentuated general dullness.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 13 (U.P.)-- Reports spread through the eastern coal fields today that many groups of United Mine Workers would ignore John L. Lewis' "suggestion" that they return to work Monday.
LONDON, Jan. 13--The Conservative party took a stand today on the question of election expenses, the proper definition of which has beclouded the early stages of campaigning for the poll on Feb. 23.

MANILA, Jan. 13--The remarks by Secretary of State Dean Acheson yesterday about the Philippines' misuse of much of the $2,000,000,000 in United States aid funds causes angry Government reaction here today and opened up a sore subject.

The young pianist, Robert Cornman, made his second Carnegie Hall appearance last evening in a program that included the first performance of two little pieces by Stravinsky, as well as Bartok's "Suite for Piano," opus 14; Schumann's "Carneval" and smaller pieces by Scarlatti, Bach-Liszt, Purcell-Bartok and Ravel.

When the day rolls around that you raise more than twenty sailfish behind your baits you can take it for granted that the season is under way. Democratic leaders decided yesterday to press for a split session of the Legislature in the belief, that a change in the present procedure would result in a more ef. ficient manner of handling legislation.

CHATHAM, England., Jan. 13-- The British Navy said tonight sixty-five men perished in the sinking of the submarine Truculent. There were eighty men aboard the 1,090-ton submarine, a veteran of the Pacific war, when she was rammed at 7 o'clock last night by the 643-ton Swedish oil tanker Divina.

Miss Marlene Bauer, a poised 15year-old golf star who has been swinging a club since she was 3, has been chosen the woman athlete of the year for 1949--the youngest player ever to win that prized honor in the annual Associated Press polls.

The spectacular rise of Paddy Young to the front as a middleweight title threat was halted dramatically last night in Madison Square Garden under explosive circumstances as he sought his thirteenth straight victory and went down instead to a knockout defeat that almost caused a riot.

The United States Government, through the Postoffice Department, paid American and foreign steamship lines $22,500,261 in the fiscal year ended June 30, 1949, for the transportation of all classes of mail to foreign countries, it was announced yesterday by Greever.

AN illustrated talk on orchids will be given by Mrs. L. Sherman Adams at the January meeting of the Horticultural Society of New York to be held on Wednesday at 2:30 P.M. Also scheduled for that day is the annual presentation of trophies awarded for outstanding achievements in 1949.

Knowland, imperiled their party's campaign against the Administration's China record by the proposals they have made to keep Formosa out of the hands of the Communist Government at Peiping?

At the end of one of the most harmonious annual meetings of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association, the West Side Tennis Club went on record yesterday as having no objection to holding the 1950 national championships at the same early date as last summer.

Theoretically it was as wonderful an idea as that other noble experiment, the Prohibition Amendment. Yet it also was doomed from the start for the simple reason that it wouldn't work, human nature being as it is.

The local phase of a countrywide campaign to "put one million Protestant women on record for Christian unity" was started yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York Council of Church Women.

Marta Toren has been named by Universal-International to take over the leading feminine role in "Panther's Moon," previously announced for Nadia Gray. LONDON, Jan. 10--A suggestion that German ship-repairing concerns were deliberately quoting below cost to regain foreign business was made today by George S. Cromar, chairman of British Drydock Owners and Repairers Central Council.

A double-deck bus of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, coming off the Manhattan end of the Queensboro Bridge with a capacity load of eighty-five or ninety passengers, started a chain reaction of crashes yesterday morning that brought death to two persons and injuries to forty-seven.

Though shorn of the "white tie and tails" luxury-hotel atmosphere characteristic of life on large passenger liners, voyaging on tramp cargo ships is attracting increasing numbers of tourists to off-the-track pleasure spots where prices are lower and facilities less crowded.
The report of the Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries issued yesterday for the six months ended with last November, showed a net profit of $15,133,416 after taxes and all charges.
In years gone by, matters no doubt, have been more complicated, but local college basketball coaches can't remember when.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 16-- Two hundred thousand persons in the Bridgeport area were threatened tonight with a complete stoppage of gas facilities as a result, of a strike of 212 production workers at the Bridgeport Gas Light Company, which began last midnight.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 16 (AP)-- The Chinese Nationalists announced today that one of the heaviest air attacks of the Civil War had smashed many Communist vessels massed for invasions of Hainan and other Nationalist islands.

A 19.4 per cent increase in domestic passenger travel at La Guardia Airport, New York International Air port, Idlewild, Queens, and Newark Airport in 1949, as compared with 1948, was reported by the Port of New York Authority yesterday.

As the new cuts in food and clothing relief allowances went into effect yesterday in the city, the persons who felt them most were those with jobs receiving supplemental assistance, children in the upper age levels of five new categories, and persons on special diets.

Declaring that the public was not aware of the power behind the present prohibition movement, liquor men warned here yesterday that completely new tactics had been adopted by the drys in their fight to bring back prohibition.

ROME, Jan. 16--The "Capracotta Clipper," the snowplow that the people of Jersey City, N.J., sent as a gift to the people of Capracotta, high up in the mountains of the Abruzzi, was unloaded in Naples today from the American Export Line's Exiria. The ship arrived yesterday, but so late that unloading was postponed until today.
A call for a vital and dynamic Judaism to meet the challenge of a troubled world was made last night by Dr. Maurice N. Eisendrath, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 16 (AP) --Finnish voters held their first presidential election since 1937 today without knowing what their government will reply to Russia's demand for extradition of a long list of alleged Soviet war criminals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--President Truman was reported today to be "considerably disturbed" over the surprise move Friday by the House Rules Committee to recapture its long-held power to block legislation from floor consideration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, Majority Leader of the Senate, tonight pledged that he would bring the Fair Employment Practices Bill to the floor "within the next few weeks." He said, however, he could not predict its passage.

BOSTON, Jan. 16--Gen. George C. Marshall dedicated the nation's thirtieth Red Cross blood center today with the disclosure that the Boston unit would serve as a pilot plant for testing new methods of collecting, processing and storing blood.

The States Marine Corporation, operator and agent for dry cargo vessels in the African and Mediterranean trades, is considering the construction and operation of two large ore carriers to transport iron ore from Monrovia, Liberia, to the United States, it was learned here last night.
The stock market suffered a weak spell in the early trading yesterday but bidding for the aircrafts and later the railroads enabled prices to close irregularly higher.

CAIRO, Jan. 16 (U.P.)--Premier Mustapha el Nahas Pasha said today that his new Wafdist Government would build up the army, end martial law, industrialize the country and eliminate illiteracy by making primary and secondary schools free.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--By identical divisions of 4 to 3, the Supreme Court twice ruled today that the Federal Government could bar from the United States persons whom it believed might endanger the internal security of the country, The tribunal:

Over the last week-end the city shut off the water of two automobile "laundries" in Brooklyn after they resumed washing cars in defiance of the Water Department's edict, Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP)--A Government-industry communications conference agreed today that overseas press rates should not be tied to the commercial message rate structure. The meeting had heard objections that such a link might be used to censor the press.

Pleas for increased salaries for school employes, reducing the size of classes, improved school and community services and expanded state aid were voiced yesterday at a public hearing on the Board of Education's proposed budget for 1950-51. The board's tentative estimate provides for $232,003,241, including $13,000,000 for pay rises for teachers and supervisory personnel. It is the largest in the city's history.

The Welfare Department yesterday opened a new family shelter for women and children at 330 East Fifth Street. It has 307 beds for families who have lost their homes through evictions, fires or other disasters.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16--Grain markets developed a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade today, and it was not until the last few minutes of the session that there were other than feeble rallies.
LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 16--The Soviet Union walked out of three more United Nations organs today in protest against the continued membership of Nationalist China.
GENEVA, Jan. 16--Italy is getting plenty of advice on how to govern some 950,000 inhabitants of the part of Somaliland for which she is to be the United Nations trustee for ten years.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16--The National [Railway] Mediation Board started sessions in Chicago today in an attempt to settle a pay and rules dispute between the country's railroads and the Order of Railway Conductors and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.

Net income of the American Telephone Telegraph Company and subsidiaries--the Bell System --declined $4,931,886 to $230,696,265 in the twelve months ended Nov. 30, 1949. This was equal to $9.35 a share. Earnings in the preceding twelve months amounted to $235,628,151, or $10.21 a share.
Brooklyn College athletic officials are anxiously watching for the effect of the new entrance ruling for city colleges on the number of athletes who will come to the Flatbush campus.
Holy Cross has replaced St. John's of Brooklyn as the nation's No. 1 college basketball team in the third weekly Associated Press poll, released today.

Five youngsters who have recovered from infantile paralysis helped yesterday to open New York's annual March of Dimes drive. The campaign, conducted on behalf of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, is seeking $4,000,000 here as part of a $52,000,000 goal throughout the country.

PARIS, Jan. 16--Finland's amiable, homely, eighty-year-old President Juho K. Paasikivi has decided to stand for re-election only because he felt it was an urgent patriotic duty and because his doctors told him his astonishing physique could stand the strain.

An unexpectedly favorable development in both the volume and direction of Europe's foreign trade is revealed in a survey by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe. Europe has been able to reduce its trade deficit with the United States from $1,000,000,000 in the second quarter of last ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--A slash of $3,000,000,000 in President Truman's $42,439,000,000 budget was proposed today by Senator Walter F. George, Democrat, of Georgia, as the White House announced it expected to send Mr. Truman's special tax message to Congress late this week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The Government's leading aviation research agency declared today that the international race for air leadership probably included development by the U.S.S.R. of aircraft to carry atomic bombs.
Three men accused of using false shipping declarations in operating an export racket were found guilty last night by a jury in Federal court here.

Retailers seeking replenishment of stocks of curtains, drapery and linen are placing good size orders for February and March delivery, according to suppliers at two merchandise shows in the New Yorker ...

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 16-- The dispute between India and Pakistan over Kashmir is a definite hindrance to the plan adopted by the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers Conference for improving the living standards of South and Southeast Asia in order to stem communism, Ghulam Muhammed, Pakistan's Finance Minister and leader of his country's delegation to the conference, declared today.
PINEHURST, N.C., Jan. 16 (AP) --Here in this peaceful North Carolina sandhills golfing country a group of seventeen men today began a three-day study of national collegiate football rules.

Guy Lombardo, band leader and one of America's most spectacular speed boat pilots, tossed his hat into the 1950 regatta ring yesterday and declared he is rebuilding his mile-a-minute Tempo VI to recapture the Gold Cup which he won in 1946.

The Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, of which Fabien Sevitzky is conductor, gave a concert last night in Carnegie Hall, when Jacob Lateiner was soloist in the performance of Bela Bartok's Third Piano Concerto. Two compositions were given first New York performances: a "Dance Suite" from Hilding Rosenberg's "Orpheus in Town" and Hoagland Carmichael's' "Brown County Autumn."

In a rarely invoked step the Government seized yesterday the machine shop operated by Alfred T. Bunyard Jr. at 37-18 Twelfth Street, Long Island City, Queens, in a "last resort" to collect $7,000 Federal withholding and social security taxes.

THERE is an old legend that newspaper men talk about the books they are going to write but never write them. Although there is some truth to it, there are more exceptions than could be listed single spaced on one sheet of typewriter paper.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--President Truman asked some of the country's leading bankers tonight to use their financial power in support of this country's effort to insure world peace, prosperity and the welfare of all people.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Robert N. Denham, heading the independent office of general counsel, National Labor Relations Board, has decided to ask a Federal court to enjoin John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers.
Federal prosecutors trying Alger Hiss for perjury produced rebuttal testimony yesterday to show that the Hiss-owned Woodstock typewriter had not left his possession until March, 1938.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16--The trial of Preston Tucker and seven others charged with fraud and conspiracy moved abruptly and surprisingly toward an early close today when the defense rested its case without calling a single witness.
Importance of printing as a major New York industry and as a builder of national prosperity was emphasized dramatically yesterday with the opening of large-scale observance of Printing Week.

TRENTON, Jan. 16--O. John Rogge, New York lawyer and former Assistant United States Attorney General, sought in a Federal court proceeding today to reenter the so-called "Trenton Six" murder case along with two legal associates.

WASHINGTON, Jan.16--Much more than action by the House at this session on the fair employment practices bill is bound up in the conflict over the 9-to-2 proposal of the Rules Committee that this group resume its old role as legislative traffic controller. Some excellent judges of Congressional behavior believe the proposal will substantially assist efforts to head the Treasury toward solvency earlier than fiscal 1951.

TRENTON, Jan.16--Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll said today that his first executive appointment after his inauguration for a new term tomorrow would be the renaming of Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons of Red Bank.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP)--Fifteen sprinters were named today to run in the $7,500 Inaugural Handicap at Hialeah race course tomorrow and Calumet Farm's Bewitch was not among them.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 16--Yugoslav propaganda services today described Soviet delegate Jakob Malik's walkout from the United Nations Security Council as an act of hypocrisy, contrary to the interests of the new People's Republic of China, and dictated by. the Soviet Government's own narrow interests.
The Army dredge Essayons, largest of its type in the world, war formally commissioned yesterday at Pier 26, North River and Beach Street, where the vessel is temporarily berthed.

It is good to remind ourselves as often as possible that there are twenty nations to the south of the United States, all of them linked to each other and to us by many bonds. The peace and economic welfare of the world and the survival of Western democracy depend as surely on our relations with Latin America as they do with Europe or Asia. In such respects, this is "one world."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP)-- The Government today abolished a special wage rate for learners in the textile industry, boosted a similar rate in the hosiery industry and revised it for students in vocational training programs.
A strike of 2,200 oil and coal drivers was averted last night when members of Local 553, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, voted unanimously to accept a last-minute offer by employers.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 16-- Foreign Minister Ernest Bevin envisages a considerable role for the United States in aiding the development of non-Communist Asia as planned at the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers conference here last week, he indicated today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 16 --A group of eighteen former generals and staff officers of the Wehrmacht has been advising Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Western German Federal Republic, on rearmament questions, it was learned on unimpeachable authority today.
PARIS, Jan. 11--A short story of French fabric openings must confine itself to skipping from highlight to highlight among a wealth of exquisite summer materials.

LONDON, Jan. 16--Labor has taken the initiative in Britain's slow-starting election campaign. Tonight, in his constituency of Lewisham, Herbert Morrison, Government leader in the House of Commons, appealed for the votes of the middle classes. Mr. Morrison made it clear that the costs of the meeting he addressed would be charged to his election expenses.

The rapidly increasing importance of the study and practice of conservation of natural resources has now been recognized by Yale University with the establishment of a two-year graduate course in the subject.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--President Truman asked Congress today to continue for ten years, until 1960, the federal interest in the $700,000,000 synthetic rubber industry, including authority to prescribe minimum consumption standards pending early disposal of Government-owned plants to private owners.

Praise of the work being done by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York and of its plans for the future was voiced last night by Governor Dewey and Mayor O'Dwyer in radio addresses urging support of the federation's $50,500,000 maintenance and building fund campaign.

Franco's Spain has had misfortunes, some due to accidental causes, some owing to political and economic errors. Before the civil war Spain's wheat production was about 4,000,000 tons a year. In 1948 the total was about 2,500,000 tons.

GENEVA, Jan. 16--Pronounced and favorable changes in the direction and volume of Europe's foreign trade occurred during the third quarter of 1949, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP)--The feature of the nine-race getaway program at Tropical Park today was the $5,000 Tropical Handicap, a six-furlong whirl for 3-year-olds, and Attentive was the winner in a spectacular finish.

Consolidation of the local research and media departments in McCann-Erickson's Chicago office was announced yesterday by the agency. Homer Havermale, vice president, said the two departments had worked closely for many years and "each day brings additional evidence of the necessary ...

G.C. Schueler, former manager of H.J. Heinz Company's New York sales branch, has been named manager of the company's new chain store sales branch in New York, G.R. Sunden, former manager of the Manhattan branch, succeeds Mr. Schueler in the latter's former post.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Tighe E. Woods, Federal Housing Expediter, analyzing what has happened to rents in six large cities where controls were ended by local option, said today that significantly "the longer a city has been decontrolled, the more general the rent rise."
A "mutual agreement to disagree" has been reached by the sovereign states of New York and New Jersey in a little private war about licenses of junior automobile drivers.

Sixty years ago, come July, a maimed and gnarled Dutchman stood in the stubble of a foreign field and shot himself. With that bullet Vincent Van Gogh rejected for all time the world that had for so long rejected him. All of the man that was mortal died.

Formal effectuation of the merger of Blair Co., Inc., and E.H. Rollins , Sons, Inc., under the new name of Blair, Rollins Co., Inc., took place yesterday. Announcement also was made of the composition of the executive personnel.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 16--American industry's maintenance bill has been climbing so rapidly that it now almost doubles annual net profits for the years 1935 to 1940, inclusive, 1,300 of the nation's business leaders were told at the opening sessions of the four-day plant maintenance show today.

A visitor to the Parkchester sub-branch of the New York Public Library yesterday would have thought that it was annual read-a-book day in the Bronx housing project. More than 150 youngsters and their parents flocked into the two-room library at the afternoon peak, queueing up at the desks and taxing the services of the four-woman staff.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 16-- With a bewildering suddenness that caused defense attorneys to shout charges of "unfair" tactics, the Government today rested its case in the perjury-conspiracy trial of Harry Bridges, head of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 16-- A sweeping reorganization of the state government will be proposed within the next three weeks by a special five-member commission appointed last May by Gov. Chester Bowles, it was disclosed today.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 16-- In a setting of Easter lilies, snapdragon and greens, Miss Mary Lou Flicker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Flicker of near-by Fairfield, was married here at noon today to Rockwell J. Larrabee, son of Mrs. Guy P. Miller, also of Fairfield, and the late Rockwell J. Larrabee, in St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church.

Archbishop Michael of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America announced yesterday that he would visit President Truman Friday to appeal for the direct intercession of this country on behalf of thousands of Greek children abducted by Communist guerrilla fighters since 1946.
ALBANY, Jan. 16--The State Conference of Mayors today took the Legislature to task for mandating increased local expenditures without providing the revenues to meet them.

The technique of mixing furniture of different woods or sectional units or various periods for greater warmth and individuality is highlighted in a group of room settings opened yesterday at McCreery's.

A decade of prosperity for this country was forecast yesterday by Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation, at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He said that unwarranted fear might blight the continued high buying power of the American people in the next ten years.

It appears that Santa Claus, on his tour of Manhattan's West Side, failed to put in an appearance at the home of Seleno Nova, 53-yearold janitor for an apartment house at 223 West Twenty-first Street.

HONG KONG, Jan. 17--Nationalist planes bombed and strafed Canton in three attacks this afternoon, hitting shipping and wharves and causing damage in the residential district where Communist officials stay. The attacks in each ease were carried out by a group of three planes.

Lively bidding marked the return of lead futures to the trading pits of the Commodity Exchange yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 17--The Charysler Corporation offered, and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, spurned a $100-a-month pension plan today. The plan would be part of a five-year contract that could be opened annually only on the issue of wages.
American democracy is being threatened by a growing inadequacy of the country's public schools, Gen. Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, warned here last night.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 17--Hialeah Race Course drew a Chamber of Commence Day crowd of 19,685 and a million-dollar-plus betting handle for the first of its 1950 racing programs today. It also drew a 6-to-1 winner in the $9,620 Hialeah Inaugural Handicap.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 17-- Lucien Jouvaud, who was from 1909 to 1942 president of the French Benevolent Society, which conducts the French Hospital in New York, died today in a nursing home here after a brief illness. His age was 87. He lived at 50 West Seventy-second Street, New York.
A few months after Vladimir Kazakevich, White Russian emigre economist here, had been accused of being a Soviet agent, he returned to Russia and took up Soviet citizenship, it became known yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 17--The Ford Motor Company disclosed today that it would erect a production foundry and motor plant, with an ultimate payroll of 10,000 employes, on a 200-acre tract it had just acquired adjacent to the Cleveland City Airport.

A novel device expected to reduce considerably the prevalence of seasickness among ship's passengers has been placed on the United States market, it was announced yesterday by W.G. Schalscha, executive vice president of Lidgerwood Industries, Inc.

Several weeks ago Senator Johnson of Colorado told some thousands of hearers, during the course of a television appearance, that our physicists. were trying to make a superbomb which would be 1,000 times as powerful as the plutonium bomb.
HELSINKI, Finland, Wednesday, Jan. 18--Dr. Juho K. Paasikivi seems certain of remaining President of Finland when the new sixyear term begins March 1.

Local college quintets suffered through the saddest Madison Square Garden twin-bill of the season last night, as first L.I.U. bowed to North Carolina State, 55--52, and then St. John's fell before De Paul, 74--68, completing two major upsets.

In a bid for funds to capitalize expansion or establishment of industries that Great Britain considers essential, she has modified exchange regulations to guarantee repatriation of new investment funds at any time. Word of the changed regulations was circulated here this week by the British Information Service in Washington.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 17--The United Nations Security Council acted in the face of a Soviet boycott today to order a new study of French proposals for a world census of non-atomic weapons and armed forces.
LONDON, Jan. 17 (U.P.)--The Moscow radio said tonight that Soviet industrial production during 1949--fourth year of the current five-year plan--had been 3 per cent higher than in 1948.
PARIS Jan. 17--Maud et Nano give the sailor first place for spring 1950, but give it new life by making it square or pentagonal, or with brim scalloped like a four-leaf clover.

A property in the vicinity of Pennsylvania Station and opposite the General Postoffice passed to a new control yesterday when Maxwell L. Low, operator, took title to 314 to 338 West Thirty-first Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. It is 243 by 100 feet and consists of one-story buildings and parking lots.
A woman need not make a choice between being in "Who's Who in America" and having a husband and children, but the probabilities move in opposite directions.
MORGAN, Pa., Jan. 17--If there is a revolt against John L. Lewis going on in the mine fields, the men who are participating in it are the most respectful rebels the world has ever known.

For the second night in succession, the Brooklyn College basketball team downed the visiting University of Mexico at the victors' gymnasium, 84--62, last night. The triumph was the sixth in a row for the Kingsmen, and gave them a season's mark of fifteen victories against three losses.
Four more contract signers yesterday hopped aboard the Giant band wagon which aims to oil into Phoenix on March 1 with a squad of contented athletes.

ROME, Jan. 17--It was a day of rejoicing in Capracotta today when the "Capracotta Clipper" snowplow, donated by the people of Jersey City, N.J., came roaring into the village. Its 4,000 inhabitants almost to a man joined in happy "vivas" for America and for the donors.
The State Department of Social Welfare did not "order" the relief adjustments in food and clothing allowances in this city, State Welfare Commissioner Robert T. Lansdale declared yesterday.

Senator Brewster of Maine called on President Truman yesterday to ask him to intervene to end the "40 per cent" coal strike that is now in its seventh month.

Netley Offices, Inc., a concern renting office space with telephone, secretarial and stenographic services, has leased for ten years the major part of seven floors in 132 Nassau Street, it was reported yesterday.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 17-- Former Gov. James C. Shannon indicated to Republican, party leaders at a luncheon here today that he was a candidate for renomination at the party's convention next July.

NORMAN, Okla., Jan. 17 (AP)-- Notre Dame and Oklahoma, the nation's two top college football teams of 1949, will meet in a homeand-home series in 1952 and 1953, it was announced here today.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17--Dr. Grace M. Fernald, nationally known educator, died of a heart attack in her home last night at the age of 70.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 17-- Preparations for a broad scientific study designed to promote the reclamation for agricultural purposes of 6,000,000 acres of some of the country's richest soil are now under way on a woodland tract thirty miles south of this port city.

WICHITA, Kan., Jan. 17--Henry J. Allen, former United States Senator from Kansas and one-time Governor, died at his home here early today after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

Comfort and convenience were emphasized in the 1950 line of automobiles shown yesterday by the Cadillac division of the General Motors Corporation at a meeting of national distributors at the Plaza Hotel.

The spotlight will be on Fred Wilt and John Joe Barry as the indoor track season enters its banked-track phase this week-end with The Philadelphia Inquirer games at Convention Hall on Friday and the Massachusetts Knights of Columbus meet at the Boston Garden on Saturday.

Samuel Putnam, author, translator and critic, who had translated into English more than fifty Spanish, Italian, French and Portuguese works, died on Sunday of a heart attack at his home in Lambertville, N.J., at the age of 58.

GENEVA, Jan. 13--Three-quarters of Switzerland's population of 4,300,000 is covered by insurance against sickness and accidents despite the fact that such insurance is obligatory for only a few groups in the population.

A remarkable loan exhibition of paintings, drawings and etchings by Rembrandt, dram from private and public collections in America and Europe, will open this evening with a gala preview at the Wildenstein Galleries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--An offer to purchase all of the common stock outstanding of the $77,000,000 Pacific Power and Light Company, Portland, Ore., from its parent, the American Power and Light Company, for $15,000,000 cash was made today by a group of eight investment banking firms.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17--Government prosecutors and lawyers for Preston Tucker and seven others charged with fraud and conspiracy wrangled all day today over instructions to be given to the jury before it retires to seek agreement on a verdict.

The young California pianist, John Ringgold, made his New York debut at Times Hall last night in a program that included Mozart's Sonata in D.K. 311; Beethoven's F Minor Sonata, opus 57, known as the "Appassionata," and shorter compositions by Debussy, Bartok, Griffes and Chopin.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 17--Four hundred of the largest factories and steel mills in this bustling industrial center were notified today that the Duquesne Light Company did not have enough coal to supply them with electric power after Friday night.

The first of about 12,000 Missourians began yesterday to leave lowland homes and farms which Army Engineers may flood deliberately to combat the Mississippi River's worst rampage in thirteen years, The Associated Press reported.

HOUSTON, Jan. 17 (AP)--Glenn McCarthy, a wealthy oil man, wants a loan of $70,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The Washington office of the corporation said today the application was made here in early December by Mr. McCarthy and three of his companies.

In a year-end report Ralph S. Damon, president of Transcontinental and Western Air, said that it appears that 1950 will be an even better year for air travel than 1949, when a general upturn took place.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan declared yesterday he considered Mayor O'Dwyer's proposal that legislation be enacted to legalize betting on sports events as "illadvised."

Current olive oil prices are hitting the lowest mark in ten years. This drastic decline, a spokesman for the industry explains, is mainly because "Americans really don't buy olive oil--they are selling much-needed dollars abroad."

The injury-riddled New York Rangers make their last home appearance before departing on a four-game road trip when they skate against the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden tonight.
