A recent "marked increase" in the number of measles cases in New York, particularly in Manhattan and Staten Island, was reported yesterday by Dr. John F. Mahoney, Health Commissioner. Present indications are that 1950 will be a "high Measles year," he added.
BERLIN, Jan. 17(AP)--West Berlin authorities accused the Russions tonight of having secretly retained a slave labor pool of 400,000 German war prisoners.

Why the double-deck bus involved in Monday's fatal crashes ran wild as it approached the Manhattan end of the Queensboro Bridge remained a mystery yesterday. Official agencies seeking to determine whether man or mechanical failure was responsible found themselves in a maze of contradictory statements.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 17--A ward-by-ward district-by-district rating system of Jersey City property owners was used by former Mayor Frank Hague in the heyday of his administration to keep tabs on the political leanings of the people, Deputy Mayor William J. Flanagan charged today. He likened the system to Nazi Gestapo methods.

Ample evidence is available that taxes restrain output and consumption, particularly in the cigar industry, it was declared last night by Representative A.A. Ribicoff, Democrat, of Connecticut, at the annual meeting of the Cigar Institute of America, Inc., in the Waldort-Astoria Hotel.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 (AP)-- Golf Star Ben Hogan was pictured as "awfully tired" today on the eve of his 18-hole play-off with Sam Snead for the victory laurels of the Los Angeles open tournament.

Wholesalers hold the key to improved distribution necessary for the increased manufacturing capacity of the country, Saul F. Dribben, president of Cone Export and Commission Company, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat, of Georgia, introduced today the Administration's bill to extend the Selective Service Act for three years.

BOSTON, Jan. 17--One of the nation's biggest cash robberies was staged tonight by seven masked men who took "more than $1,000,000" from the vault room of all armored trucking service. Police Superintendent Edward W. Fallon, who made the estimate, said the men left "almost as much more, because they couldn't carry it away."

The opening of a series of redecorated model rooms at Bloomingdale's adds that store to the growing list now presenting in mid-winter showings the recent developments in furniture and decoration. The over-all effect is the most varied and provocative in many years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--Republican leaders expressed hope today they could complete within the next two weeks drafting of a party policy statement for use in the 1950 Congressional election campaign.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 17 (AP)--Szabad Nep, newspaper of Hungary's Communist party, confessed today it had been guilty of "erroneous and harmful thinking" in overestimating the differences among the Western capitalist powers.

The State of Connecticut borrowed yesterday $50,000,000 on short-term obligations for financing public housing enterprises at bids ranging in discount from 0.77 per cent to 0.80 per cent. The issue was sold to the National City Bank and associates.
To tell the truth, "Alive and Kicking," which opened at the Winter Garden last evening, is a mediocre revue in a mongrel style that is never really exciting.

A bill to fix taxicab fares at 25 cents for the first fifth of a mile and 5 cents for each additional fifth, instead of the present 20 cents for the first quarter-mile and 5 cents for each additional quarter, was introduced in the City Council yesterday by Councilman Hugh Quinn, Queens Democrat.

The results of the Presidential elections in Finland, where President Passikivi apparently has been returned to office, are not so important as the fact that a little country on the edge of the Soviet Union has the spirit and the ability to hold a free and democratic election. There can be reservations...

SOMEWHERE in Silesia on a sandy plain surrounded by a pine forest stood the prison camp for British officers known as Stalag Luft III. The men imprisoned there lived in cold, dirty and overcrowded huts, locked in at night. Their diet was inadequate and revolting. There were only six cold-water taps in the entire came for nearly 1,000 prisoners.

Dr. A.L. Goldwater of 70, Central Park West said yesterday that he had made overdoses of morphine available on occasion to incurable patients and that other doctors did the same. The Rev. Dr. Lloyd F. Worley, pastor of the First Methodist Church at Stamford, Conn., said he had prayed for the "merciful release" of such patients.

Lieut. Gen. Lauris Norstad, youngest general of his rank in the Air Force, who is Deputy Chief of Staff for Operations, will be transferred within a few months to an operational command, it was learned yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 17--Contending that the Feinberg law merely prescribed qualifications for teachers, State Solicitor General Wendell P. Brown today asked the Appellate Division to upset a Supreme Court ruling that the act was unconstitutional.
The possible consequences of United States securities selling below par is always a good subject for economic controversy on the top ivory-tower level.
A contract between Bloomingdale's and Local 3, independent, has been set aside and a new representation election among the store's 3,000 employes will be held on March 16, it was learned yesterday.

BELOEIL, Belgium, Jan. 17-- Amid medieval splendor, Princess Yolande de Ligne, daughter of the head of Belgium's leading nonroyal family, was married today to Archduke Charles-Louis of Habsburg, fourth son of the last AustroHungarian Emperor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--Administration and Republican forces in the House Foreign Affairs Committee united informally today on a compromise bill to provide technical assistance to economically undeveloped countries under point Four of President Truman's inaugural.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--The Senate refused today, by a vote of 48 to 37, to forbid the shipment of yellow oleomargarine in interstate commerce.

The stock market recovered yesterday much of the ground lost in last week's sharp plunge. With gains of 2 to 3 points in the pivotal issues, the composite rate rose 1.42 points, the best gain since last Dec. 22.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 17-- The foreign ministers who assembled here last week to devise a way of stemming communism in Asia had a first hand view of how communism works on a tropical island.

John M. Semar has been named sales manager of Rolls Razor, Inc. Keith S. McHugh, president of the New York Telephone Company, and David J. Martin, general manager of the New York Athletic Club, have been named to the board of directors of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--The net working capital of American corporations, exclusive of banks and insurance companies, climbed to a high record of $67,700,000,000 in the third quarter of 1949, an increase of $1,100,000,000 over the preceding quarter, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The statement of principles with which Governor Driscoll begins his second term will be read with interest outside New Jersey for its strong affirmation of the desirability of self-reliance at the lower levels of government.

GENEVA, Jan. 17--Western Germany is in a more favorable position than Eastern Germany for adapting industrial production to the conditions of a permanently split Germany, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe secretariat concludes in a study in the current issue of its economic bulletin for Europe.
A model for the controversial memorial to 6,000,000 Jews who died under Nazi persecution in Europe was shown yesterday in a preview at the Museum of Modern Art.
Dwellings dominate the realty transactions reported in Queens and other sections of Long Island.

The Acme Dorf Metal Door Corporation, of which Morris Dorf is president, has purchased the one and two story industrial building at 1010 East 173d Street, the Bronx, from Mrs. E.J. Metz and Mrs. Olga Under of New Bedford, Mass. The property occupies the ...
CLEVELAND, Jan. 17--Mechanical gadgets, designed to curtail costs, were the main attractions today at the plant maintenance show here.

The Motion Picture Association of America and United Artists, distributors of the Hal Roach production, "Curley," which was banned in Memphis, Tenn., will take the case to the United States Supreme Court, it was announced by the MPAA yesterday.

The membership of the National Maritime Union, CIO, has voted overwhelmingly in favor of the constitutional machinery created last fall by the union's convention to deny membership to "Nazis, Fascists and Communists," it was made known yesterday by Neal Hanley, national secretary of the union.

Entertainers chosen from "Talent Nights" at Skouras and Century movie theatres in Brooklyn will compete for a trip to Hollywood and a screen test in a new full-hour variety series which will make its premiere over WOR-TV Wednesday, Feb. 1, at 8 P.M.
ALBANY, Jan. 17--Two bills were introduced in the Assembly today that would liberalize pension schedules of New York City teachers.

Public utility operating companies raised nearly $52,000,000 yesterday to finance expansion of operations by the sale of new issues of mortgage bonds and common stock. The flotations were sold to investment banking syndicates at competitive bidding as follows:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 17-- Billy Wilder, Paramount writer-director-producer, disclosed today that he and Erich Pommer, producer of films here and in Europe, have worked out preliminary plans for a bilingual independent production, to be filmed in Germany, probably late this year.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York adopted unanimously last night a resolution proposing that the dispute over the China blockade be submitted to the International Court of Justice at The Hague.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--President Truman stepped today into the thick of the Congressional fight over civil rights and the attempt in the House to restore to the Rules Committee the power to bottle up legislation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--The Senate Democrats drew together in a solid party front today to defend the Administration's Far Eastern policy.
Two blows to defense hopes for dismissal of the Coplon-Gubitchev spy indictment were dealt yesterday by Judge Sylvester Ryan.

John Lautner, Communist party official in New York State who was responsible for keeping party ranks disciplined and safeguarding them from undercover agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was expelled by the party yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 17--Senator Elmer F. Quinn of Manhattan and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut of Brooklyn, the Democratic minority leaders of the Legislature, accused the Republican Administration today of procrastination and straddling on the question of state aid for school construction.

ROME, Jan. 17--Premier-designate Alcide de Gasperi's difficulties in his efforts to solve the cabinet crisis brought about by his resignation last Thursday were increased today when he had to face a small revolt of his own party.

PARIS, Jan. 17--The challenge to France's Saar policy by Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Bonn regime, brought from French officials today the retort that this policy had the formal sanction of both the United States and Britain.

TRENTON, Jan. 17--Alfred E. Driscoll, taking the oath of office today for an additional four years as Governor of New Jersey, made the major theme of his inaugural address an attack on the centralizing tendencies and inflationary spending policies of the Federal Government in Washington.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan, 17 (AP)-- The United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals today affirmed the Southern Florida District Court's ruling denying the merger of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad and the Florida East Coast Line.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 17--Secretary General Trygve Lie today reinstated five Secretariat employes who had accused their superiors of anti-Semitism in dismissing them from their jobs in the United Nations.

If you have been wondering why it has been necessary to exert a greater effort and more, skill to haul a mess of fish from a lake or stream, the answer lies in the 1949 fishing license sales, which reached a new high of 15,478,570.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)-- United States District Judge David A. Pine refused today to throw out a claim of Remington-Rand Co., Inc., that it has an option to buy a controlling interest in the General Aniline and Film Corporation.

After boycotting most agencies of the United Nations and sabotaging the work of all of them by its vetoes, Soviet Russia has now extended its boycott to the United Nations as a whole because that world organization has refused to jump to the crack of the Russian whip.

The nation's steelmaking capacity was increased 3,271,870 tons during 1949 to an annual potential of 99,392,800 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 17--The return of Nuri as-Said, central figure in Iraqi politics, from his three-week sea trip to India and the scheduled departure at the end of this week of Foreign Minister and Deputy Premier Muzahim Amid...

The Glidden Company, manufacturers of varnishes, paints and office products, and its subsidiaries reported yesterday in its annual report covering the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, last, a net profit of $6,191,923 after taxes and all charges.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 17--The U. S. S. Missouri, only active battleship in the United States Fleet, ran aground this morning in Chesapeake Bay near Thimble Shoal Light, more than a half mile off the usual shipping route leading seaward from Hampton Roads.
LAKEHURST, N. J., Jan. 17-- Displaying the coolness of a veteran 'chutist, 21-year-old Mary Redfern became today the first regular Navy Wave to make an authorized parachute jump.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--The Truman Administration asked Congress today to bring "practically all" gainfully employed persons under compulsory old age, survivors and disability insurance, a proposal rejected by the House last year in voting to broaden and liberalize the Social Security system.

PARIS, Jan. 17 (UP)--Premier Georges Bidault reported today that two French generals had been relieved of their duties last December for having given a secret report on Indo-China to a former enemy agent.

BERLIN, Jan. 17--United States authorities in Berlin estimate that at least 250,000 individuals would be doomed to reprisals if the Western Allies ever abandoned the former German capital to the Russians.

Lincoln-Mercury Division of the Ford Motor Company will support its official introduction of 1950 models, Jan. 27, with one of its most extensive and aggressive advertising campaigns, it was announced yesterday by Robert F.G. Copeland, advertising and sales promotion manager.

Taking note of the 464,000,000gallon gain in reservoir water storage, the smallest increase in about two weeks, water officials said yesterday that further industrial restrictions in water use would be put in force soon if greater strides were not made toward filling the reservoirs by June 1.

GENEVA, Jan. 17--Drafters of the United Nations agreement covering trusteeship of former Italian Somaliland ran into their first real roadblock today. A six-member subcommittee of the Trusteeship Council is trying to frame the terms of agreement.

Eileen Joyce, British pianist, who has often done the piano-playing for English film stars who have been called upon to enact lady pianists, last night was the central figure in a drama not unlike those she has helped from the soundtrack. She made her North American

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--The body of Gen. Henry H. Arnold, commander of the Army Air Forces in World War II, will lie in state at Washington National Cathedral until the funeral services on Thursday afternoon at Arlington National Cemetery. General Arnold died Sunday at the age of 63 at his home in Sonoma, Calif.

Advent of the 75-cent-per-hour minimum wage, effective next Wednesday, "spells the end of the low-pirice shirt era," Seymour J. Phillips, president of the PhillipsJones Corporation, said last night at the annual meeting of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers in the Hotel Astor.

The New York major appliance distributing branch of General Electric Company has exceeded its January and February refrigerator allotments by many carload orders, C.R. Pritchard, marketing manager of the parent company, revealed yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 17--Furniture and model rooms of every period and type that should suit almost any taste and pocketbook will be found in the furniture show opening this morning on Bamberger's fifth floor.

The second case within recent days involving children who have been allowed by their parents to reach a desperate stage of malnutrition was discovered here yesterday. The case bore some resemblance to that of the Scielzo family.

Enough smallpox vaccine to immunize 500 persons was presented yesterday, "as a token of New York City's good will," to six nurses who are going to Israel to help check the spread of disease in the immigrant camps of Israel.
Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator; declared last night that aid to higher education was the most important problem now facing his organization.

ALBANY, Jan. 17--Replacement of the present system of voter registration by permanent personal registration would cut election costs 34 per cent, Assemblyman Harry A. Reoux, Warren Republican, asserted today on the basis of a study made by the League of Women Voters.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 17-- A bus carrying the Bronxville High School basketball team to the Bellows High School at Rye Neck for a game this afternoon went out of control on Hewitt Avenue, East Chester, and crashed into a tree.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP)--The president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association reminded member institutions today that they must abide by the N.C.A.A. constitution and boycott six Sanity Code violators from schedules.
New York's largest and most enthusiastic celebration of Printing Week reached a climax yesterday with six separate events, in which well over 3,000 individuals participated.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--President Truman was quoted today as saying that he was not "allergic" to using the Taft-Hartley Act, but would do so only in the event of a national emergency.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 17-- Twenty-seven-year-old Zaki Hachian, the United Nations economist who is reported to have lost his 16-year-old sweetheart to Egypt's King, resigned from his job here today. He held a press...

The results of the material aid extended to the European nations by the United States have, in some respects, exceeded all expectations, Arthur G. Syran, director of the transportation division of the Economic Cooperation Administration, asserted last night.

A campaign that dates back almost two and one-half years will come to fruition tonight in the St. Nicholas Arena when Billy Graham, East Side welterweight, faces Tony Pellone of Greenwich Village for the third time.
Prosecution rebuttal witnesses contradicted Alger Hiss and his wife Priscilla on nine important issues yesterday as testimony was completed in his perjury trial.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 18-- Announcement of the engagement of Miss Natalie H. Eisenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Eisenberg, to Morton D. Siegel, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Siegel of Hollywood Beach, Fla., formerly of Yonkers, has been made by her parents.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18--An anti-trust suit asking $4,516,500 in triple damages was filed in Fed eral Court here today against a group of steel companies by the Aero Sales Company of Dallas, Tex., and the Texas Tank Corporation of Los Angeles.

Directors of the Manufacturers Trust Company are "hopeful" that another stock dividend may be paid some time in the future, Harvey D. Gibson, president, said yesterday at the annual stockholders' meeting. Last year stockholders received such a dividend in the amount of 187,500 shares at $20 par value.

The Cunard liner Franconia slipped into New York's fogshrouded harbor early yesterday on her first visit to this port as a luxury passenger liner in more than a decade. Passing harbor craft greeted her with the traditional three blasts of their whistles.

ROME, Jan. 18--The 1950 Vatican Year Book, which has just been published, lists thirty-four residential Archbishops, Bishops or apostolic vicars as incarcerated, deported or exiled by Communist governments. The first copy of the almanac was submitted to Pope. Pius this morning by Msgr. Carlo Grano, Chief of Protocol of the Secretariat of State.
The nation's gasoline stocks last week increased 1,870,000 barrels, according to the weakly figures of the American Petroleum Institute.

In an unprecedented action against racial discrimination in sports, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein moved yesterday to bar the American Bowling Congress from sponsoring tournaments and carrying out other activities in New York State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--In a hitherto unpublished report, Henry A. Wallace as Vice President urged Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1944 to consider the Chinese Nationalist leader, Chiang Kai-shek, only as a "short-term investment," neither intelligent enough nor politically strong enough for postwar China.

The right of the Patriarchal group of the Russian Orthodox Church, affiliated with the Patriarchate of Moscow, to retain possession of St. Nicholas Russian Orthodox Cathedral, 15 East Ninety-seventh Street, was affirmed yesterday by a three-to-two vote of the Appellate Division.

The data in the Moscow statement suggest that Soviet industry in 1949 achieved gross production of about 196,000,000,000 rubles in terms of 1926-1927 prices. This was 20 per cent above the 1948 output of about 163,000,000,000 rubles and about 40 per cent above the 1940 output of 138,000,000,000 rubles. The goal for 1950 is 205,000,000,000 rubles.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 18 (AP)--Bob Feller, the richest but no longer the best Pitcher in baseball, took a pay cut of--possibly $20,000 today at his own suggestion.

Finding themselves trailing twice before the game was half over the Boston Bruins persisted nevertheless in their National Hockey League clash with the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18--The Government in its final argument in the mail fraud and conspiracy trial of Preston T. Tucker and seven associates today asked for a verdict of guilty as charged, contending that any other judgment would be a license for any person or group in this country to perpetrate fraud on the public with impunity.

At the high altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday a Brooklynborn priest, the Most Rev. James Henry Griffiths, was consecrated first American Bishop of the Titular See of Gaza and Military Delegate to Cardinal Spellman.

A new clinic to treat out-patients with psychosomatic stomach ulcers, diabetes, hyperthyroidism and other ailments by biochemical means will be opened next Thursday at Creedmoor State Hospital, Queens.

SAN FRANCISCO. San. 18-- Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, chairman of the Maritime Commission, delighted West Coast steamship men today with an implied stand in favor of a reduction in Panama Canal tolls.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 18--Joe Culmone the teen-ager from Sicily who headed the riding list at the Tropical Park meeting, touched off a major celebration in the ranks of the Culmone Marching and Rooting Society at Hialeah Race Course today. Jockey Joe scored with a 43-to-1 shot.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP)--The Detroit Red Wings, National Hockey League leaders, drove the Chicago Black Hawks deeper into the cellar tonight as they scored a 5-4 victory before 12,814 fans.

Charles Luckman resigned yesterday as president of the Lever Brothers Company because of a disagreement with top executives of the company's two parent organizations, Lever Brothers Unilever, Ltd., of Great Britain and Lever Brothers Unilever, N.V., of the Netherlands.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18-- Yale, the defending champion, remained in contention for the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League title by defeating Dartmouth, 68--54, tonight.
Contracts for gray iron foundry products for the first six months of this year are being renewed by some foundries without advances over 1949 price levels, it was learned here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)-- Major-Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide, was reprimanded sharply today by the Senate committee that conducted last summer's spectacular five percenter inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The Government today sued to compel John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers of America to restore normal coal production. It was an effort to end both the union-ordered three-day week and the total cessation of work by 90,000 soft-coal miners who are said to want a full week or nothing.
LONDON, Jan. 18--cement, insurance and chemical share dropped on the Stock Exchange here today on publication of the Labor Party's election manifesto, containing plans for further nationalization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Ratification by the Senate of the proposed charter for the International Trade Organization was urged today by the National Planning Association's committee on international policy.
MOSCOW, Jan. 18 (AP)--Russia's industrial production level last year exceeded goals set for 1950 and personal incomes rose sharply, an official announcement said today.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 18--Warren W. Nissley, a partner in Arthur Young Co., accountants and auditors with headquarters at 1 Cedar Street, New York, for the last twenty-two years, died here yesterday in Nassau Hospital after a brief illness.

New flight schedules and lowcost air travel on the domestic and international routes of three commercial airlines were announced yesterday. The new changes will involve air travel to Europe, Canada and New York State.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18--A warning that the nation was approaching a "real crisis" with respect to development of basic science was given industrialists today by President Lee A. DuBridge of California Institute of Technology. He spoke at the opening of a three-day general management conference of the American Management Association.

The recent relief cuts in the city should stand, and no increases or decreases in public assistance grants are required at this time, Federal, state and city officials agreed yesterday at an "emergency meeting" called by Mayor O'Dwyer.

Principals of New York City's schools may have felt that their responsibilities were already numerous enough, but they now learn that they will have another, to be "captain" of their "ship" in respect to repair and maintenance problems.

In a deal representing an investment of about $100,000, the sixstory apartment house for twelve families on plot 40 by 100 feet at 12-14 Clark Street, corner of Willow Street, Brooklyn, was sold by ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Secretary of State Dean Acheson placed the United States today squarely behind the French demand for the separation of the Saar from Germany and its economic integration with France.

Traditional antagonism between landlords and tenants has been intensified in recent years as the result of the housing shortage and squabbles arising over rent, controls, and fair-minded leaders in the realty industry now recognize the crying need for action to improve this relationship.

WESTBORO, Mass., Jan, 18-- Admiral Louis E. Denfeld, former Chief of Naval Operations, said tonight he was planning to write a letter "telling my side of the case" in the recent controversy that led to his removal.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18--Late spring and early summer showing of the Affiliated Fashionists of California indicate a season of lively but feminine fashions with emphasis on open necklines and bare shoulders for everything.

MADRID, Jan. 18--Some basic change in the Spanish Government, possibly involving the appointment of Generalissimo Francisco Franco as regent, is believed impending. Reports on the change differ radically, but many sources feel that something important--which they cannot pin down--is being considered.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--President Truman will be urged on Friday to support the convocation of a Federal convention of the democracies signatory to the North Atlantic Pact to explore the possibility of union among them, it was announced today by former justice Owen J. Roberts, president of the Atlantic Union Committee.

PARIS, Jan. 18--Specially trained spies parachuted into the northern mountains of Albania by Italy's intelligence service are alleged to have succeeded in organizing and accomplishing the assassination of the political secretary of the Albanian Communist party in the Mirdita region.
John Noah Landberg, who developed a stock fraud technique that won grudging admiration from the Wall Street firms that he bilked, was in the hands of the law again yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 18--Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio assailed the Federal old age and survivors insurance program as "unsound" today and asserted that establishment of some other system should be considered.
MOSCOW, Jan. 18 (AP)--The United States, British and French Ambassadors made a joint statement to the Soviet Government tonight on the deadlocked Austrian independence treaty talks.

There is no question of the need for sex education, but merely "cramming youngsters with facts will not eliminate undesirable sex behavior," Dr. Percy E. Ryberg, assistant psychiatrist at the Vanderbilt Clinic, Presbyterian Hospital, said yesterday.

PINEHURST, N.C., Jan. 18 (AP) --The football rules committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tonight, in effect, acknowledged that the two-platoon system is here to stay and also acted to curb what it termed "the tendency toward viciousness which has no place in the game."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--President Truman today accepted the resignation of Myron C. Taylor as personal representative of the President to the Pope, a position he had held since President Roosevelt created it amid the storms of war at Christmas, 1939.

One "Morgan myth" was exploded yesterday. George Whitney, president of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., denied at the annual meeting that it requires $1,000,000 or any fabulous sum to be able to do business with the famous Wall Street banking institution.

Stockholders of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company at their annual meeting yesterday gave a virtual vote of confidence to the bank's youthful president, Barnard Townsend, despite continuing uncertainties in the earnings outlook.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 18 --Reinhold Maier, Premier of the State of Wuerttemberg-Baden in the United States zone, told the Landtag, or parliament, in Stuttgart today that he had asked Karl Stroele, a minister without portfolio in his Cabinet, to remain at his post despite charges of corruption in the denazification program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18-- The United States took steps today to recover forty-two cargo ships sold to the Chinese Nationalists in 1947 and 1948 on which nearly $19,000,000 is asserted to be several months ovedue.

Wholesalers will have to prove their case of lower distribution costs to manufacturers who are operating on a dual selling basis, Henry Matter, executive vice president of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The leaders of all the factions in the House of Representatives are putting on the best show of recent times in the maneuvers to restore its old power to the Rules Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18--It became apparent today that the recent collapse of the All-America Conference, its absorption by the National League and the subsequent naming of the new circuit the National-American League had not resulted in the anticipated professional football peace. On the contrary, indications were strong that an old-fashioned brawl was in the making.
The City of Chicago sold yesterday an issue of $5,000,000 of waterworks system revenue bonds due from Feb. 1, 1965 to 1967, to a banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.15 for 2s.

William N. Enstrom, chairman of the board of the Irving Trust Company, informed shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday of the bank's strong capital position and expressed the hope that "we will be able to raise the dividend in time to come."

Undefeated in fourteen rounds after losing her only game on the opening day to Mrs. Gisela K. Gresser of New York, Mrs. Ludmilla Rudenko, one of the four Russian contenders, won the women's chess championship of the world in Moscow yesterday when she scored a draw in the fifteenth round, according to a report from London.
Hearings before trial of the Coplon-Gubitchev spy case ended yesterday in Federal Court.
The Colonel Williams estate at Lloyds Harbor near Huntington, L.I., has been purchased for development by the Sterling Investing Corporation from the Brooklyn Trust Company as trustee.

The Tri-Continental Corporation in its twentieth annual report, released yesterday, put the net asset value of the company's common stock on Dec. 31, 1949, at $13.87 a share, compared with $10.88 a share at the end of 1948.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 18--Local officials of the United Mine Workers expressed fear tonight that Federal injunction proceedings against the John L. Lewis union would block their efforts to get 90,000 striking miners back to work next Monday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The Senate adopted today, with only minor changes, the bill to repeal taxes on oleomargarine that the House passed last year. The vote was 56 to 16.

GENEVA, Jan. 18--The drafting committee of the United Nations Trusteeship Council completed today the second and final reading of the agreement to govern the Italian administration, under a United Nations trusteeship, of former Italian Somaliland.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18-- Adoption of a uniform carloading and unloading tariff for the major West Coast ports, to be effective on Friday, was announced today by Matson Terminals, Inc., the stevedoring subsidiary of the Matson Navigation Company.
Following is the text of the hitherto unpublished report on China made by Vice President Henry A. Wallace to President Roosevelt in 1944:

Billy Graham, East Side welterweight, pounded and battered Tony Pellone, Greenwich Villager, through every one of ten rounds last night at the St. Nicholas Arena, but, by a weird decision, he was fortunate to get the verdict on a split basis.

The "poignant problem" of New York's homeless boys from 16 to 21, long discussed by social agencies but still unsolved, was put before the public yesterday at an open meeting to which representatives of civic-minded nonprofessional groups were invited.
BOSTON, Jan. 18--Rewards totaling $150,000 were posted today for the nine bandits who staged a $1,500,000 holdup on Brink's, Inc., armored car service, last night.

A man who fell or leaped to his death under a BMT subway train at the Bowery station at 5 P.M. yesterday caused a fifty-minute tie-up that delayed thousands homeward-bound from lower Manhattan to Brooklyn and Queens.
This is a big year for foxhunters, according to reports from several Catskill and Adirondack counties, and apparently there are more hunters as well as foxes.

ALBANY. Jan. 18--Senator MacNeil Mitchell of Manhattan and Assemblyman E. Herman Magnuson of Jamestown, Republicans, introduced a bill today to create a temporary nine-member commission to survey the long-range highway needs of the state and to make recommendations for financing such a program.

The Government took official cognizance for the first time yesterday of the six and one-half months' old dispute in the coal industry. It did not enter that controversy, however, primarily in response to the recently mounting clamor for intervention on behalf of the nation's coal consumers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--General of the Air Force Henry H. (Hap) Arnold will be buried tomorrow at Arlington National Cemetery with highest military honors. The body of the wartime chief of the nation's vast air striking forces arrived here this morning on a four-engined transport plane from the West Coast.
The directors of the Oak Manufacturing Company have elected Elof Sandstrom as chairman, Robert A. O'Reilly as president and William Bessey as vice president and secretary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Top leaders of the Republican party from the National Committee, the Senate, the House and three State Governors met today for the first time in an effort to agree on and draft a policy statement for presentation to voters in the 1950 Congressional elections.
The Army yesterday rolled in the heavy equipment it might use to smash a safety-valve levee to relieve pressure along vital areas of the swollen Mississippi River, The Associated Press reported.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 18-- Columbia handed Navy its first basketball defeat of the season on its home court today, pulling away in the last half to win, 45--37, for its eleventh victory of the season.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 18 (AP)--A well-informed source estimated today that West Germans might pay about $600,000,000 in goods for what had been extorted by Hitler from the Jews who lived in Western Germany under the Nazis.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18--The capacity of industry to modernize its plants and equipment is being held back, John Hancock, partner, Lehman Brothers, New York bankers, told the third annual conference of the Research Council of the Chamber of Commerce of Philadelphia at the Warwick Hotel.

THE Football Giants have been severely handicapped for the past few years by pronounced weaknesses at the tackle and guard positions. They never would have been in such difficulties if Al Blozis, the colossus from Georgetown, had not been made of the stuff from which heroes are made.

ALBANY, Jan. 18--The Brannan plan for Government assistance to agriculture if adopted would lead inevitably to collectivized farms, Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, of New York, told the State Agricultural Society at its annual meeting here today.

HONG KONG, Jan. 18--A Communist broadcast from Peiping heard here tonight gave for the first time the Communist version of the recent taking over of the United States, French and Dutch Government properties in Peiping that once housed the legation guards of these powers.

Increases of $3,000 a year for each of forty-nine magistrates who now receive $12,000 and of $2,500 to the $15,000 salary of the chief magistrate were asked yesterday at hearings in the Municipal Building on 1950-51 finance budgets of city departments and agencies.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 18--The movement for Germany's reunification, never far below the surface of political life, is growing in depth and volume both in East and West Germany and will shortly emerge as one of the most important political problems facing the Bonn Government.

"The Barrier," which had its first performance at Brander Matthews Hall of Columbia University last night, is a powerful stage work. This new opera, with libretto by Langston Hughes and music by Jan Meyerowitz, was put on by the Columbia Opera Workshop in a production that would have been a credit to a professional theatre. It proved once again, if further proof be needed, that opera in America is on its way.

Net earnings of the Joy Manufacturing Company in the quarter ended on Dec. 31, last, were $450,860, compared with $1,897,190 cleared in the 1948 period, reflecting the drop in sales to to $9,184,000 from $17,007,102, the company reported yesterday.

Lyle D. Andrews, former owner of the Vanderbilt Theatre and oldest member of the Treasurers Club, made up of box-office men, to which he had belonged for fiftyeight years, died Tuesday night in the Meadowbrook Hospital, Hempstead, L.I., at the age of 79.

Most of us have a way at the vegetable counter of selecting the same stand-bys week after week, even though the family is bound to make some such comment as, "What, carrots again?" That particular complaint may be neatly avoided by combining the carrots with anise, a celery-like root with a delicate licorice flavor.

While surface developments in Washington appear adverse to speedy action on excise tax reductions, it is almost a certainty that the 20 per cent retail levies will be cut in half, well-informed trade sources predicted yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 18--Asserting that the City of New York was being "short changed" by the state in reimbursements for relief, including expenditures for hospital care of indigent persons, two of the city's Assemblymen proposed today that the state be required to pay 80 per cent of all municipal relief expenditures.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland, Chairman of the Armed Services Committee, announced on the floor of the Senate today that action would be held up on the confirmation of Admiral Forrest P. Sherman as Chief of Naval Operations until his committee had time to look further into the matter.

High above Eighth Avenue 3,000 young New Yorkers gather each week to learn how wet ink, blank paper, and hot lead can be combined and transformed into one of society's most valuable resources and history's most powerful weapons--the printed word.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (AP)-- Ben Hogan's gallant come-back to golf creaked slowly to a walk and then was stopped cold by Sam Snead today. The titans of golf met in a delayed, dramatic eighteen-hole play-off medal match, and the result was soon evident.
The peripatetic performances staged by the Soviet delegates in the United Nations are being repeated with equal frequency on the other side of the world in Tokyo.

The nation's first "televisionshow train" will make its initial run Sunday when the New Haven Railroad gives its passengers a special round-trip service from Hartford to New York to see the Fred Waring program as it is presented in the theatre.

GEORGE ORWELL's generation of English novelists, children of this unquiet century, have a common malady. They write remarkably well but they write about remarkably little. In their Obsessional School they tear minor and obscure passions skillfully to tatters without giving much warmth or light or pleasure. On their left they are shepherded by Cyril Connolly; on their right by V.S. Pritchett; ...
The three terminals here and other Atlantic Coast outports of the New York Port of Embarkation shipped 6,288,371 measurement tons of cargo overseas last year, it was announced yesterday.
A display of new automobiles in a setting that outlined the advance of motor transportation over half a century was presented yesterday in a preview at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The Army announced, today that it planned a major overhaul of the organized Reserve Corps aimed at improving its combat readiness.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today there was nothing in prospect, not even the development of a super-bomb by the United States, that would lead this country to modify its demand for full international control of atomic energy.

Jean Giraudoux' "The Enchanted" is a whimsical discussion of the spirit world. Nothing about the play, however, is so whimsical as the fact that it lacks spirit. To lovers of "The Madwoman of Chaillot" "The Enchanted" is likely to be a disappointment, for it contains none of the raffish and solid humanity of that divine rumpus in faubourgs, and it substitutes talk for improvisation.

BOSTON, Jan. 18--A large share of the serious condition which prevails in various areas of the shoe and leather business can be "chalked up" directly to the discrimination and inequity against the United States which has been and still is practiced abroad.

ALBANY, Jan. 18--Governor Dewey and the Republican legislative leaders have agreed tentatively to a broadening and strengthening of the existing clause against racial and religious discrimination ink public housing. The move was taken in connection with a revision of the housing law to be undertaken this year.
LA DUE, Mo., Jan. 18--Dr. and Mrs. William Mahlon James have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jo Ann, to George Wesley Smith 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith Jr. of Middletown, N.J.
COOSA PINES, Ala., Jan. 18 (AP)--Newsprint from southern pine began rolling out of the $32,000,000 paper plant here today.

This afternoon in a thirteenthfloor room in the United States Court House the Guild Theatre-- Fifty-second Street, west of Broadway--will be sold. Unless someone tops a bill amounting to $617,491 the theatre that was built for the Guild will go to Dorsar Enterprises, Inc., controlled by J.J. and Lee Shubert.
There was a surprise guest yesterday at a special meeting of the New York division of the United Daughters of the Confederacy.

Last November a special committee composed of two physicians, two chemists and two engineers found evidence of serious air pollution in some parts of Staten Island. Residents of Rossville, across the water from industrial towns in New Jersey, complained of ill effects from smoke.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 11, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Business at Ovington's Gift Shop on Fifth Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street has declined to such an extent that the company voluntarily filed a petition in Federal Court yesterday to reorganize under Chapter 10 of the Chandler Bankruptcy Act.

The Government yesterday sought a Taft-Hartley injunction in Federal Court to end the three-day week in the coal mines and to bring resumption of normal coal production. The court set hearings on NLRB. Counsel Denham's application for a week from today. [1:8.] Local union leaders feared that the injunction plea would block their efforts to get 90,000 striking miners back to work. [14:3.]
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 18 (AP)-- Old Rockport and Citation shared honors at Santa Anita today--the former for the race he won, the latter for merely tuning up.
The construction industry was accused yesterday of having ignored the risks of earthquakes in planning new buildings for the country's multi-billion dollar new construction program.
DETROIT, Jan. 18--The United Automobile Workers, CIO, served a seven-day strike notice today on the Chrysler Corporation, with which it has been attempting for months to negotiate a pension plan.

A combined exhibition of the painting's, sculpture and inventions of Samuel F.B. Morse, commemorating the 125th anniversary of the founding of the National Academy of Design by the artist and inventor, opened last night in the American Museum of Natural History.

More ground was gained yesterday by the stock market, but late selling reduced the scope of the advance and the close was mixed. Buying was fairly insistent among the steels in the morning, but even this section proved vulnerable later. Few changes of a point or more occurred, and the composite rate rose only 0.20 point.

The Yankees yesterday made a commendable start in the serious business of rounding up their expensive array of World champion performers, although there was one disturbing note. It may be that signing Joe DiMaggio will not prove so simple as it was a year ago when the Clipper, after little discussion, accepted a flat salary reported to have been $100,000.

The Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad consolidated yesterday the bonded debt remaining from its 1947 reorganization into an issue of $55,000,000 of first mortgage sinking fund bonds which will come due in thirty years and bear interest of 2 7/8 per cent.

ALBANY, Jan. 18-Outlawing of the "shape-up" system of hiring longshoremen in New York City to wipe out what he called "an unholy social menace" was proposed today by Assemblyman John R. Brook, Republican, of Manhattan.

LONDON, Jan. 18--Winston Churchill and the men most closely identified with his wartime leadership of Britain met again at his London house today to plan the Conservative party campaign and draft issues on which it will be fought.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18-Grain prices dropped rapidly on the Board of Trade today after announcement that the Government would sell some of its surplus products obtained through price-support programs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18--American housewives, restaurant patrons and other users of quick frozen fruits, vegetables, meats and other foods served 2,000,000,000, pounds in 1949, representing a 38 per cent increase in the national consumption.

An industry-wide survey of welfare agreements that cost $6,000,000 annually and affect 100,000 building trade craftsmen and their families has been undertaken by the Building Trades Employers Association of New York, it was reported Yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 18-- Fred Zinnemann today concluded a deal with Arthur Loew, chief of Loew's International, to direct "Teresa," an independent production which Mr. Loew will finance personally. The photoplay, written by Alfred Hayes and Stewart Stern, deals with an American soldier who marries an Italian girl and brings her home to New York.

BERLIN, Jan. 18--In reprisal for the Western German police seizure of the railway administration building in the United States sector last night, Soviet and Eastern German officials cut in half traffic on all elevated lines throughout the city today.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 18-- Complete returns today showed that Juho K. Paasikivi had won reelection as President of Finland.

Secretary of State Acheson made a valiant and laudable effort at his press conference yesterday to soothe ruffled French feelings about the Saar. The Paris Government has been under some criticism for moving too fast and too far in attaching that rich and contentious province to France.

The Americanization of the latest immigrants to this country-- 122,067 of Europe's displaced persons--is proceeding so fast that they are different from older residents only in their stumbling English.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 18--The delegates of the Soviet Union and three satellite countries walked out of another commission in the United Nations today in the largest concentrated exodus since Russia's Deputy Foreign Minister Jacob A. Malik set off the current walkout series eight days ago.

An indicated slight rise in water consumption in the first two days of this week compared with a week ago caused Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, to observe yesterday: "New Yorkers are getting careless."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--United States exports to the soviet Union dropped below $50,000 last November, the first time in twelve months, while exports to Yugoslavia soared to $2,500,000, more than triple the previous month's total and the largest amount in more than a year, the Commerce Department reported today.

LANCASTER, Pa., Jan. 18 (AP) --Edward Lester Gibbs, Franklin and Marshall College senior from Pitman, N.J., tonight signed a statement admitting the slaying of Marian Baker, 21-year-old college stenographer, Capt. Fred Gleason of the Pennsylvania State Police said.

ALBANY, Jan. 18--Mayor Erastus J. Corning of Albany eliminated himself completely today as a possible Democratic candidate for Governor or other sate office next fall. He is the first potential candidate to do so.
Horace W. Stokes of Vinyard Haven, Mass., former president of the Frederick A. Stokes Company, publishers, died yesterday, of natural causes, in his room at the Yale Club.
The two-story brick and steel building occupied as the Ansonia branch postoffice at 205 West Sixty-ninth Street has been sold by the 205 West Sixty-ninth Street ...

A capsule preview of the Easter Parade of 1950 was presented last evening in Hampshire House by John Walther Fabrics, Inc. There were about thirty suits and coats from some of the leading designers showing off the variety of tiny colorful plaids, textured worsteds and lightweight tweeds that are among the smartest new fabrics of the season.

"Hap" Arnold will be buried today in Arlington, almost beneath the shadow of the Pentagon, where he directed, in our war-time yesterdays, the growth and strategy of the greatest Air Force the world has ever known.

The Canadian-born tenor, Joseph Laderoute, who is well known as a fine oratorio singer, appeared at Town Hall last evening and proved that he is just as fine a recitalist. With his resonant and beautiful voice and his enlightened musicianship, he made an excellent impression in a program that contained a number of interesting novelties.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture today tossed millions of dollars worth of Government-owned surplus farm products on the export market at prices below cost.
Daniel W. Janover, president of S. Gumpert, Inc., producers of processed food products, died Tuesday in his home, 1185 Park Avenue, after a brief illness. His age was 61.
PARIS, Jan. 18--Janette Colombier is featuring a becoming profile cloche. The right side curves far down, the shorter left side merely frames the face without concealing it when viewed from the side.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The House Democratic leadership agreed suddenly today to bring a voting showdown Friday on whether the Committee on Rules should be restored its old powers to block Administration legislation from floor consideration.

An enthusiastic throng of 1,500 paying guests crowded the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, at the preview last night of one of the outstanding art events of the season, the all-Rembrandt exhibition of paintings, drawings and etchings for the benefit of the Public Education Association.

The week's third opening, a "shocker" entitled "The Man," written by Mel Dinelli, will be unveiled this evening at 8:20 o'clock at the Fulton Theatre. It is Kermit Bloomgarden's second entry of the season and marks a departure for the producer from his usual weightier theatrical fares, which have included "Death of a Salesman" and "Montserrat."

The close bidding yesterday for the first major issue of railroad bonds to come to market in nearly fourteen months was taken in the financial district to mean that the investment world again has railroad credit in food focus.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 18(AP)-- The Chinese Nationalist Air Force and Navy have wrecked a Communist junk fleet, making invasion of Hainan "impossible," the commander of that South China island asserted today.

ATHENS, Jan. 18--Paul R. Porter, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration's mission in this country, has rebuked the Greek Government for delays in the distributing of Marshall Plan supplies, which are lying on the waterfront at the port of Piraeus. Mr. Porter threatened to suspend the right of Greece agencies to order Marshall Plan goods if corrective steps were not taken.

H. Edward Bilkey of 145 East Ninety-second Street and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., head of the H. Edward Bilkey Corporation, an insurance brokerage firm at 55 Liberty Street, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. His age was 59.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 18--Dr. Aleksander W. Rudzinski, counselor to Poland's United Nations delegation, has resigned his job with the charge that Soviet pressure is stripping his country of freedom and diplomatic independence.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 18 (UP)-- The Army was trying tonight to get the Navy off a mudbank. The Army dredge Comber was digging away at the mud holding the battleship Missouri prisoner on a bank where she ran aground yesterday.

Federal deficits prudently in curred in times of unemployment tend to be deflationary rather than inflationary so far as the purchasing power of the dollar is concerned, Beardsley Ruml, economist, told the joint luncheon meeting of stockholders of the Savings Bank Trust Company and Institutional Securities Corporation yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

With a mile race that has Ireland's John Joe Barry and Fred Wilt as its principals, the sixth annual Philadelphia Inquirer games tonight will inaugurate bankedtrack competition and also launch one of the busiest week-ends the spiked-shoe set will experience this indoor season.
Announcement of the dates and the itinerary of the New York Yacht Club cruise next summer was made yesterday at the first generals meeting of the year by Commodore Henry S. Morgan.

New York emphasized the intense interest in new cars with an outpouring of visitors from the five boroughs yesterday at a premiere of the General Motors auto show "Mid Century Motorama" at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. From morning until the closing hour the exhibition was crowded with an attendance estimated at 50,000.
A fact-finding mission of six Christian leaders, just returned from Jerusalem, announced yesterday its conviction that internationalization of the Holy City was "dangerous and unnecessary."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)-- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dean Acheson's letter to Chairman Tom Connally of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on United States policy toward Spain:
Seems there is no end to the laurels showered on the Yankees. Joe Page moved into the spotlight yesterday as the latest in line for signal honors.
LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 19--All the manuals about how to win friends and influence people will have to be rewritten in the light of the great Soviet walkout of 1950.

A far-reaching $400,000 educational project to improve and strengthen the teaching of American citizenship in the public schools will begin next month in eight school systems in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania. The program, under the direction of Teachers College, Columbia University, will be conducted on a two-year experimental basis.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 19-- Henry Morgenthau Jr., chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, visited some of Israel's immigration camps today after an absence of fourteen months and was "shocked" by what he saw.
Budd Looms, Inc., retailer of carpets and linoleums, to the Alfred Paul Berger Company, Inc., both of New York. Sidney Rosendorf is account executive. Newspapers and direct mail will be used.

The stock market had a difficult time finding its bearings yesterday. A mixed to slightly lower trend during the morning gave way to a rally of limited proportions in the afternoon but final prices were not of a nature to indicate any change from the character of the last few sessions.

MENDHAM, N.J., Jan. 19-- Robert McKean Thomas, chairman of the board of directors, founder and former president of the Thomas Betts Company, Elizabeth, N.J., manufacturer of electrical equipment, died on Monday at his home here after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

PARIS, Jan. 19--The United States Government has now been advised by Yugoslavia that Marshal Tito's regime will soon embargo all flights over its territory by aircraft belonging to nations of the Communist Information Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Industry was accused today of unwarranted prejudice against older workers, with the result that the Senate Finance Committee agreed to ask industrialists for an explanation upon their appearance as witnesses on social security expansion.

A project for which $1,000,000 has been allocated as part payment was shown in its first stages at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday, when officials announced plans for increasing man's knowledge of himself through his physical environment.

LONDON, Jan. 19--British funds continued their modest recovery in a quiet session on the Stock Exchange here today. The advance of gilt-edge issues by another quarter point, and more the spectacular rise of Japanese bonds, particularly those in which interest is optionally payable in dollars, were exceptions to the sagging movement in most markets.

The Chase National Bank has established an initial $10,000,000 loan fund to participate with its correspondent banks in extending loans to small business in their communities throughout the nation, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman, announced yesterday.
The first-night brigade will assemble at the Royale this evening to appraise "Dance Me a Song," the week's second revue. The management urges promptness, as the curtain will go up at 8 on the dot.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Unless it can be assumed that the Secretary of Defense will challenge a national policy announced by the President, or that the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff will say or imply that a fixed policy of the Commander in Chief risks...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19-Gen. Henry H. Arnold, first General of the United States Air Force, was buried this afternoon on a snowswept knoll in Arlington National Cemetery.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 19--The Yugoslav Parliament will reconvene tomorrow afternoon in a brief session to pass new laws amending and extending the oldage pension and social insurance acts. Amendments to the electoral law will also be voted to prepare for elections to the next Parliament, scheduled to take place at the end of March.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19--The twelfth national housewares and home appliance exhibit, said to be the largest array of home accessories and appliances ever assembled, opened here today, covering 150,000 square feet of floor space at Navy Pier with about 25,000 products of 519 manufacturers. The show will run through next Thursday.

Claude B. Cross, attorney for Alger Hiss, asked the jury to "put the stamp of honesty and innocence" on his client when he summed up the defense against two perjury charges yesterday. The case is slated to go to the jury this afternoon.

DETROIT, Jan. 19--The equivalent of a wage increase of 11 cents an hour to establish a pension and welfare program was demanded of the Chrysler Corporation today by the United Automobile Workers, CIO.
ROME, Jan. 19--Premier-designate Alcide de Gasperi announced today a ten-year plan for development of southern Italy and other depressed areas.
Robert Grant 3d and Clarence C. Pell Jr. opened the defense of their national amateur racquets doubles championship yesterday with an uphill fight to victory at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19--Swift Co. has revised its basic policy on dividends and a special payment of 75 cents has been voted, Herbert H. Swift, chairman of the board, informed stockholders today at the annual meeting.

Prices for coffee futures sagged on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday after showing strength in early trading. Final levels for contract S were 4 to 14 points below Wednesday's close. Activity in contract D was largely confined to the transfer of hedges into the S contract. Closing prices for the D contract were 10 to 40 points above Wednesday's levels.

Scotch whisky shipments to this country and Canada can only be maintained by severe restrictions of shipments to other world markets, P.J. Woodhouse, secretary of the Scotch Whisky Association, disclosed last night. He spoke at the annual dinner of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, Inc., held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The following figures as of 8 A.M. yesterday give the number of gallons of water in the city's reservoirs. The difference in the two days is the net after intake and the day's consumption:

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19--Thousands of striking coal miners in Pennsylvania and West Virginia spurned back-to-work pleas by their union leaders today, but the union still hoped to get many of the struck mines in operation by Monday.

The underwriting managers for Wednesday's offering of 640,000 new shares of Middle South Utilities Company withdrew yesterday the unsold part of the offering as the market for the stock on the New York Stock Exchange drifted down to a spread of 5/8 point from the public offering price of 19 1/8.
A remedy for the winter-weary was offered by Russeks yesterday in a story of spring navy and white, combined of Paris originals, adaptations and crisp American designs.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 19--The master plan prepared by experts for the United Nations to ward off world unemployment through an international system of counter steps, to be automatically set off at an agreed danger point of idleness, brought skeptical reactions today from several delegations at the opening debate on the Economic and Employment Commission's major item.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 19--Failure to reach a fair solution of the Saar problem will "complicate" Western Germany's whole attitude toward membership in the Council of Europe, Dr. Konrad...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--In a major blow to Administration policy in the Far East, a coalition of Republicans and southern Democrats in the House, hitherto in prevailing combination only on domestic issues, defeated today a bill to provide $60,000,000 in economic aid for the Republic of Korea.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 19 --John Noah Landberg, who could not resist trying once more to make a profit on stocks without investing cash, was sentenced here today by Acting City Judge Seymour Robinowitz to serve one year in the Westchester County Penitenitary at Eastview.

PARIS, Jan. 19--Maud Roser's millinery collection abandons the round for a shallow square crown in a collection of charming youthful shapes, all very small. Fitting well down in back and tilted off center, these low crowns are set onto brief brims that rise high on one side where they ripple, but dip down to the ear on the other.

The controversy over the merits or demerits of having an American diplomatic representative to the Vatican should not be allowed to obscure the spendid record that Myron C. Taylor has made in the past decade.

Landords seeking rent rises under a regulation initiated July 29 must be prepared to give a full picture of their operations for 1943 and for the current year, John J. Pendergast, Regional Housing Expediter, warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--President Truman stepped today again into the House fight over proposed restoration of power to its Rules Committee to pigeonhole legislation. He reported that word from Capitol leaders indicated that Administration forces would defeat the movement, perhaps tomorrow.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 19--Favorites were unable to keep the faith in the co-features at Hialeah race course today. Calumet Farm's De Luxe, at 1 to 2, finished out of the money in the first division of the six-furlong sprint for 4-year-olds and upward, and the Jerry McCarthy Stable's Eagle Eye, at a bit over 6 to 5, was the runner-up in the second section.

The bumper crop of post-war babies appears to have been deliberately planned and invited to a greater degree than any previous generation, a report by the Planned Parenthood Federation of America indicated yesterday.
Metal products manufacturers and warehouses are absorbing much more of the recent mill price increases on steel than has been officially reported, New York industrialists revealed here yesterday.

The Rev. Francis X. Quinn, assistant pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Clare of Assisi, Rhinelander and Pauldlng Avenues, the Bronx, and winner of a rare Congressional medal for bravery, died, on Wednesday in St. Francis Hospital, the Bronx, after a brief illness. His age was 49. He resided at the rectory, 1918 Paul-, ding Avenue.

In case you want to be scared by someone who is psychopathic, "The Man," which opened at the Fulton last evening, may very well be what you need. Mel Dinelli, an old hand at shudder-shows, has written this one with diabolical precision. Dorothy Gish, one of our most...

BUFFALO, Jan. 19--A state legislative committee making a study of whether truckers should pay more to use the highways heard today a complaint here from the railroads that out-of-state truckers operated over the highways in New York State "without necessarily paying a dime for the use of these roads."

The cuts in relief allowances that went into effect Monday decreased food and clothing grants for ninety-three per cent of the 328,469 persons on the public assistance rolls. The following two cases were interviewed yesterday as typical of those who are affected.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Segregated education for Negroes in Texas was denounced today by a committee of 188 law professors preparatory to arguments on this subject before the Supreme Court in March.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Commenting today on the announced decision of James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, to run for Governor of South Carolina, President Truman said that Mr. Byrnes was a free agent and could do as he damn pleased.

Although there is a likelihood that curtailment of nylon yarn shipments to the hosiery industry will continue through the balance of 1950, there is an ample supply of nylon hosiery available for current needs, it was pointed out last night by Warren A. Beh, director of sales, nylon division, E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

A mural made of Steinberg sketches cut from a book and pasted on the wall, seat cushions covered with sections of an old patchwork quilt, and draw draperies suspended from bamboo poles in the center of the ceiling to assure privacy for individuals shar-...

Young women headed by Miss Joan Schuyler Leeming are serving on the junior committee that is assisting the executive committee in furthering the sale of tickets for the performance of "Now I Lay Me Down to Sleep," a new play by Ludwig Bemelmans, with...

After their first general increase in more than a month, retail meat prices failed to advance again this week, remaining at the levels reached last Friday, homemakers will be glad to hear. Notwithstanding this, chicken is still a thriftier selection for the Sunday dinner than such classic choices as rib roast, leg of lamb and smoked ham.

HOUSTON, Jan. 19--The law dean of the Texas State University for Negroes here charged that a group of 1aw school professors filing a Supreme Court brief in the Texas educational segregation case "are letting irrelevant factors creep into the issue."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--The Bulgarian Government has demanded the immediate recall of the United States Minister in Sofia, it was learned today.

HONG KONG, Jan. 19--The State Department's decision to speed the repossession of merchant ships sold to Nationalist China but not paid for promised today to give Hong Kong authorities another awkward problem in their relations with Communist China.

BERLIN, Jan. 19--Implication that restrictions on interzonal railway lines might develop in connection with the current East-West dispute over the custody of the railways building featured developments today in Berlin's worsening traffic situation.
Changes in the sailing schedule of the Holland Interamerica Line were announced yesterday by Frederick R. Wierdsma, general man'ager of the Holland-America Line.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19-- "Whiteface," a novel by Tom W. Blackburn, to be published this spring by Doubleday Co., has been purchased for the screen by Warner Brothers, it was learned today.

The new standard-bearer of the American Merchant Marine, which is to be built for the United States Lines, moved closer to realization yesterday as it became known that her keel would be laid down on Feb. 8.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19--A belief that the Government's offer to resell some of its surplus commodities obtained through price support programs would have little effect on the general export demand was largely responsible for the grain market's developing a strong undertone on the Chicago Board of Trade today.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP)--The sharp-shooting Mrs. Babe Zaharias, clicking off pars like clockwork, led by two strokes at the end of the first round of the Tampa women's open golf tournament today.

LONDON, Jan. 16--The Far Eastern policies of the Atlantic powers and their friends are in a rather dismal tangle. They all apparently intend the same thing but they are moving at so different a pace that they are jerkily out of step.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--The Middle West Corporation, Wilmington, Del., which once had assets of more than $78,000,000, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan for the divestment of its remaining securities and assets, valued at about $10,000,000, and the eventual dissolution of the company.

ALBANY, Jan. 19--The State Water Power and Control Commis sion today announced its approval of New York City's petition for the right to take 100,000,000 gallons of water a day from the Hudson River as an emergency supplement of its water supply.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)-- A group of economists put the nation's affairs under the microscope today. About the only agreement was that prospects for the first half of 1950 look good.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 19 (AP)--Par was an elusive goal today as the $10,000 Long Beach Open Golf Tournament got under way with the lesser knowns of the game in action and the name players withholding fire until tomorrow.

The Board of Education approved yesterday a record budget request of $232,016,241 for the operation of the city's public schools in 1950-51. The special session was marked by a bitter exchange between two members over the operation of the school system's division of housing.

Dimitri Mitropoulos arranged a delightful program for the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, when Zino Francescatti, appearing as soloist, played the Saint-Saens B minor concerto. This program, of a properly unponderous and not over-pretentious nature, was probably grouped about the famous old violin concerto, and it was admirably done.

All of the first four prizes in the women's tournament for the chess championship of the world in Moscow were taken by the Russian players in consequence of results recorded in some of the adjourned gamas yesterday, according to a report from London.

A few bright spots appear on the ski horizon for this week-end, but the general outlook still remains gloomy. While most areas possess the needed frost and some have a few inches of base, only a half dozen report skiing that would tempt the snow-starved metropolitan enthusiast.

James P. Warburg, long active in foreign service and in writing on subjects in that field, last night assumed the role of a hyphothetical visitor from Mars and expressed himself as horrified at the foreign and defense policies of the United States.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19--Counsel for Preston T. Tucker, accused with seven associates of mail fraud and conspiracy in a $28,000,000 promotion of mass production and distribution of a rear-engine automobile, called today for acquittal on the ground that the defendants had worked in good faith to produce a car as advertised.

Hayes appeared the same yesterday as he delivered his Modern European History lecture at Columbia University: self-assured, occasionally sarcastic, pacing briskly before his map of Europe. CLEVELAND, Jan. 21--The Townsend Plan for national insurance, which attracted nation-wide attention in the Nineteen Thirties and then dropped into virtual obscurity during World War II, is staging a comeback. These open-end investment concerns had 842,000 shareholders on Dec. 31, a gain of 120,000 in the year.
