WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The Communications Workers of America, CIO, warned today of a strike in the telephone industry by more than 250,000 members. It then asked "the 6,000,000 members" of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to jam the automatic telephone equipment by over-use and to make "all the telephone calls ...

Some of the difficulty which, it had been bruited about, would assail Dan Topping and Dell Webb in signing their Yankee baseball players dissolved with amazing rapidity yesterday under the persuasive influence of General Manager George Weiss.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23-- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, told the Board of Overseers today in his annual report that there was a "present serious crisis in medical education."

ROSLYN, L.I., Jan. 23--When William Cullen Bryant, author of "Thanatopsis," lived peacefully by the side of a picturesque lake and wrote nature poems beneath weeping willows or under the great oaks by the side of the road, he little dreamed of the controversy now centering around the library he gave to Roslyn.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 23--The resignation of Frederick H. Osborn, who has been deputy United States representative on the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission since March, 1947, was accepted in Washington today by President Truman.

The entire sixth floor at 385 Madison Avenue has been leased by the General Foods Corporation to accommodate its sales executive force and part of its sales division. The lease was negotiated by Webb Knapp, Inc.

A survey recently completed among a representative group of women in the age group of 16 to 29 indicated that better than one out of every three plan to buy a coat or suit this spring, according to Bertha Korbholz, director of the Institute of Fashion Research.

PARIS, Jan. 23--Increasing hints are being broadcast by communism's international propaganda apparatus that Mao Tze-tung's Chinese Government is about to extend its sovereignty across the ancient roof of the world and take over the mysterious Central Asian land of Tibet.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 23-- More than half of the Protestant population in twenty-three representative metropolitan communities is concentrated in the Methodist, Northern Baptist, Presbyterian and Protestant Episcopal denominations, a statistical survey prepared for the National Convocation on the City Church disclosed here today.

TOKYO, Jan. 23--Premier Shigeru Yoshida told the Diet today that disarmed Japan had not renounced the right of self-defense and intimated strongly he would rely on the Western democracies for protection even after a peace treaty in view of the Communist menace in Asia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The Metropolitan Edison Company, Reading, Pa., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $7,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due 1980, and 30,000 shares of $100 par value cumulative preferred stock.

A vote of thanks is in order for Hershy Kay, who conducted the New York Chamber Orchestra in Times Hall last night. He not only presented a program of freshness and vitality, but made of it an event that will not soon be forgotten.

The League of Composers presented the first of a series of four concerts of contemporary music to an invited audience of interpreters and composers at Carl Fischer Hall last night, with the co-sponsorship of the firm of Carl Fischer, publisher of the works, heard.

Due partially to increased coffee prices, tea sales are making definite inroads on coffee sales, officials of the Tea Bureau, Inc., contended here yesterday. The bureau here presents the world's major tea interests.

MELTON MOWBRAY, England, Jan. 23--Three miles from the prosperous Midlands city of Leicester lies the tiny English hamlet of Hungerthrope nestled in a vale. Politically Hungerthrope dozes between elections, but now with a new campaign starting in Britain, political interest is beginning to stir in the village's hundred odd small homes and its little shops.

A jet engine for commercial use that is more efficient than the present power plants of the British de Havilland Comet and the Canadian Avro is available for American jet transports, C.W. LaPierre, manager of the General Electric Company's Aircraft Gas Turbine Division, announced here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23--New housewares, everything from coffee pots through shower curtains to electric irons and carving sets, that the homemaker soon will find in the stores, are on display at the Navy Pier here. The array is the Twelfth National Housewares and Home Appliance Exhibit. The products of more than 500 entrants are on view, but the show is for the trade only.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The controversial bill to establish the Fair Employment Practice Commission phase of President Truman's Civil Rights program was shunted aside in the House today in favor of measures designed to give statehood to Alaska and Hawaii.
Spokesmen for industries most affected by the excise taxes generally were dissatisfied with the extent of relief as proposed in the President's tax message yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Secretary of the Navy Francis P. Matthews accused President Truman's naval aide, Rear Admiral Robert L. Dennison, today of "irregularly"...

An offering of 168,695 new shares of common stock of Southwestern Public Service Company is being made to stockholders from today until Jan. 31 fit $31.50 a share, with a syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., managing the underwriting.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 23-- Monogram Pictures has announced plans for a film titled "A Modern Marriage." The scenario, written by George Sayre and Sam Roeca and "based on the files of the American Institute of Family Relations," has been approved by the Production Code Administration and will go before the cameras on Feb. 1 with Paul Landres...

IF we try hard we can shut our eyes and anesthetize our minds so that we can temporarily forget the nature of the age in which we live. No one could contemplate the uses to which science is now put, the infamous record of the Third Reich and the horrors of the Russian robot state all day long for many days and remain completely sane.
ROSELLE, N.J., Jan. 23-- Hyym Elias Buc, organic chemist, died here on Saturday in his home at 620 Locust Street. His age was 69.

American equipment manufacturers throughout the country are sounding out international industrial investors in foreign manufacturing plants to find new ways to cut red tape on using more new American cost-cutting equipment and methods in plants in England,...

Lenci dolls beamed Italian sunshine yesterday and warmed the hearts of young and old with the unique costumes and matching facial expressions that for thirty years have spread their fame from the streets of Turin to the playrooms of children on four continents.

The nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 147-151 West Seventy-fourth Street has been resold after a short ownership by Louis Glickman, operator, to a client of Leon, Weill Mahoney, attorneys. Globus Realty Corporation was the broker. Arthur Richenthal was attorney for the seller.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 23--Allied and German sources here insisted today that FrenchGerman trade treaty talks were continuing in Paris.

TRENTON, Jan. 23--A general reorganization of welfare services in New Jersey to concentrate supervision in a single state department with county units for local administration was proposed today by the Council of State Governments.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Jan. 23 (UP)--Roger T. Sermon, perennial Mayor of Independence and a life long friend of President Truman, collapsed of a heart attack in front of the City Hall late today and died shortly afterward.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 23 (AP)--Snow and international ski stars arrived here simultaneously today. A two-inch snowfall raised hopes of ski officials and local business men who have been worried for some time about the scarcity of the white stuff.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 23 --The number of unemployed in Western Germany jumped by 224,673 in the first two weeks of this month and today, with 1,783,142 persons unemployed, the Bonn Government faces a major internal problem that, if not solved, will have important political consequences.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP)-- Senate Republicans today chose two New England and two Midwestern Senators to work with GOP House members in drafting a party policy declaration for the 1950 Congressional election campaign.
Technical means for effective conservation of the world's resources are "at hand" to meet demands for higher standards of living for more people, Prof. Carter...

The Dominican Republic is negotiating the purchase of additional merchant tonnage to handle increased traffic in bananas and general cargo between Ciudad Trujillo and United States Atlantic ports, it was reported yesterday.

WOR-TV will add a new halfhour dramatic series with a novel approach to its Thursday schedule, when it introduces "Night Book" on Feb. 2 from 8 to 8:30 P.M. The dramatizations will cover mystery, fantasy, romance and adventure, themes as told by the night elevator operator of a Manhattan skyscraper.

The Boston Braves on July 19, 1914, were running a sorry last in the National League, 11 games behind the leading New York Giants. The next day, after being in the cellar for 97 of the season's first 100 days, the Braves emerged from the dungeon and started rolling.
The construction of Peter Cooper Village and Stuyvesant Town has resulted in a marked improvement in the business streets fringing the old "gas house" district, site of the two housing projects.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 23--Air brakes of a heavily laden milk truck failed here today on Westchester Avenue hill and the vehicle plunged through seven blocks of the village's business center as pedestrians and motorists dodged.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 23-- Dr. Rajendra Prasad, 65, former English professor, lawyer and Nationalist leader, will be unopposed in the election of the first President of the Republic of Indian.

CONSHOHOCKEN, Pa., Jan. 23 --Built at a cost of $9,000,000, the first hot-rolled strip mill in eastern Pennsylvania was placed in operation today as an addition to the 123-year-old Alan Wood Steel Company's plant here.

On the second bill of her season at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre last night, Martha Graham presented the first performance of a new solo called "Gospel of Eve," with music by Paul Nordoff, setting by Oliver Smith, and costume by Miles White.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The Equal Rights Amendment was urged on the Senate floor today by Senator Harry P. Cain, Republican, of Washington, as a matter of having the "woman of tomorrow" if necessary in the front lines of the "war of tomorrow."

That remarkable combination of Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d is the sponsor of "The Happy Time," a comedy by Samuel Taylor, based on the novel of the same name by Robert Fontaine, which opens tonight at the Plymouth Theatre at 8 o'clock. The Messrs. Rodgers and Hammerstein will be offering their seventh attraction since the establishment of the firm in 1944.

The theme of "Design for a Stained Glass Window" deserves a finer play than the one William Berney and Howard Richardson have written. Dipping back into the bloody history of Elizabethan England, they are dramatizing the martyrdom of Margaret Clitherow, who was persecuted by the Queen's Men for her belief in Roman Catholicism.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 23--Dr. Isador Lubin of the United States told the Economic and Employment Commission of the United Nations today that the American economy had shown greater shock resistance to bad times and recessions than ever before.

The committee appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer to arrange a survey of the city government in the interests of economy and efficiency agreed at a meeting in the Municipal Building yesterday to assign specific projects to subcommittees of three or more and to retain the full-time services of a paid executive director.
PARTS, Jan. 23 (Reuters)-- Corinne Luchaire, French stage and film actress, died here last night, in a hospital, of tuberculosis. She was 28 years old.

The stock market found no elements of surprise yesterday in President Truman's tax recommendations to the Congress. In fact, the movement of prices before and after the President's special message varied little from last week's pattern. The list was somewhat jumpy throughout the session with alternate strength and softness, and closed on a rallying note but lower on balance.

The first "Children's Guide to New York," a manual for parents of things-to-do and things-to-see with their children, has been written and published by a retired Marine officer who has two small children of his own.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 (AP)-- Pro football put its house in order today by deciding the make-up of the two divisions of the NationalAmerican League on the votes of twelve of the thirteen members.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Cuts in some excise taxes were asked by President Truman in a special tax message to Congress today. He threatened to veto any reduction that was not balanced by the closing of tax loopholes to make up for the revenue lost.

ALBANY, Jan. 23--Governor Dewey today nominated Thomas G. Young of New York City, an executive of the National Urban League and a labor union leader, and former Mayor Frank J. Costello of Syracuse as members of the State Commission of Correction.

LONDON, Jan. 23--Probably the least important of the major issues in the coming British general election will be foreign policy. In particular, relations with the United States will not be a subject of great dispute between the two principal parties.

Women headed by Mrs. Desmond FitzGerald are assisting the sale of tickets for the performance of Shakespeare's "As You Like It," with Katharine Hepburn in the leading role, on the night of March 2 at the Cort Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Child Education Foundation.

A new hide futures contract, which in effect constitutes a complete revision of the contract under which the Commodity Exchange has conducted trading in hides since 1934, has been prepared by the Exchange, it was announced yesterday.

GENEVA, Jan. 23--Britain withdrew today her demand for a special article in the Somaliland trusteeship agreement to cover compensation for and restitution of war damage or sequestered property belonging to United Nations nationals.

TRENTON, Jan, 23--Legislation to clarify powers of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority to acquire land for its toll highway and to finance the project passed the Senate tonight, showing a split within the Democratic minority.

Parents are as strong as ever in their opposition to comic books but their attempts to do anything about them are being discouraged by the stalling tactics of groups responsible for taking action, Dr. Hilde L. Mosse, psychiatrist, said yesterday. Dr. Mossc discussed "The Destructive Effect of Comics on Children" at a meeting at the Emerson School, 12 East Ninetysixth Street.
The world's tallest building--the Empire State--will reach skyward another 199 feet with the installation of a multiple-use television tower, which is expected to be completed some time this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Curtis E. Calder, chairman of the board of the Electric Bond and Share Company, New York, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that he was opposed to a bid by B.J. Van Ingen Co. and associates for the 500,000 outstanding common shares of stock of the Pacific Power and Light Company.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23--Main problem for the students of form at Hialeah U. today was a sixfurlong run for 3-year-old fillies. The students didn't have much luck in solving it. For they made Honey's Gal, the morning line favorite, the second choice at post time, and Honey's Gal proceeded to run off with the winner's share of the $4,500 purse.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 23--Captain W.D. Brown of the grounded battleship Missouri today called the stranding of his vessel the result of "an unusual and unfortunate chain of circumstances."

For the third successive day the city's Catskill and Croton reservoirs showed a storage loss yesterday. Figures given out by water officials showed that at 8 A.M. the reservoirs held 106,190,000,000 gallons, or 9,000,000 gallons less than on the previous day.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)-- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan reiterated today that farm prices were now "without question unfairly low."

Lamp buyers are seeking quick delivery of merchandise for filling out stocks of home furnishings, according to manufacturers at the New York Lamp Show in the New Yorker Hotel. The show drew 1,300 buyers on the opening day yesterday. More than 360 lamp manufacturers are exhibiting their wares.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Jan. 22--France does not seek ownership of the coal mines of the Saar, but will urge that the peace treaty give these property rights to the Saar Territory, Gilbert Grandval, French High Commissioner of the Saar, said in an interview with this correspondent today.

Lotte Lehmann, the renowned lieder singer, has taken to the paint pots. Her visual renderings of the song-poems which make up two of the most famous lieder cycles-- Schubert's "Winterreise" (The Winter Journey) and Schumann's "Dichterliebe" (Poet's Love)--are presented to the public today at the Schaeffer Galleries, 52 East Fifty-eighth Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 23 --New laws to enable town governments in Westchester to regulate the speed of motor vehicles and determine the need for such highway items as full-stop signs were asked of the State Legislature today by the County-Board of Supervisors.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23--The association of Harry R. Bridges and the Communist party was likened today by the defense at the union leader's perjury-conspiracy trial to the wartime association of the United States and Soviet Russia, "a cooperation for immediate ends."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Administration stalwarts hailed today the tax proposals President Truman sent to Congress but strong elements of dissatisfaction within the Democratic rank and file, quite apart from open hostility among the Republicans, gave promise of rough sledding for the program.

Coffee futures opened slightly lower yesterday on scattered selling on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, but brisk demand appeared later from both trade and producer interests. Volume was moderate, with selling on a scale up. Contract S closed at about the high point of the day, with final prices 40 to 57 points above Friday's close.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)-- President Truman met with his top military command today for what the White House called a briefing on progress being made on new weapons.

JAKARTA (Batavia), Indonesia, Tuesday, Jan. 24--A private guerrilla army attacking the new United States of Indonesia left Bandung suddenly yesterday afternoon after having taken over most of the town a few hours earlier.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23--The Government's anti-trust suit against the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company was attacked today by Dwight B. Austin; president of A.'s middle western division, in an address before the annual conference of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association.

TOKYO, Jan. 23 (AP)--Highly competent United States military authorities predicted today that French Indo-China might become the pivotal point in a projected Communist march across Southeast Asia.
Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, denied flatly yesterday that the Federal Reserve System was attempting to "whittle away" the dual banking system.

The final major contract for construction of the $20,000,000 Van Wyck Expressway will be let tomorrow and the highway will be in service between Queens Boulevard and New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, late this year.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP)--The American Bowling Congress, under attack for alleged racial discrimination in its membership, declared today that it had a right to select its members.

If he played unevenly, Vladimir Horowitz never played more prodigiously than he did at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall to an immense and excited audience, and further marking the occasion by a premiere: the first performance in New York of Samuel Barber's piano sonata in E flat minor. This sonata, between the quality of the performance and the quality of the music, had also a prodigious success.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 23--The Norwegian Government's budget for the year beginning in July of 2,562,000,000 kroner ($358,680,000) was presented to the Storting (Parliament) today. It shows a decrease compared with the current budget of 69,000,000 kroner.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 23 (AP)--Notre Dame's basketball team, loaded with sophomores, downed Kentucky's Wildcats tonight, 64--51, before 5,000 fans. It was the Irish five's eleventh victory in the sixteen-game series.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)--A Congressional staff report said today the net income of fifty steel companies increased $277,560,594, from $264,525,016 in 1946 to $542,085,610 last year.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 23--More attention to public welfare in the training of social workers was urged today by Helen Russell Wright, dean of the School of Social Service Administration of the University of Chicago.

Capt. William M. McGuire, who retired recently as marine inspection officer of the Third Coast Guard District, has been named director of ferries of the Department of Marine and Aviation, it was announced yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 23--Revision of all Civil Service eligible lists to reflect the changes in preferences for veterans provided in the recently approved constitutional amendment was proposed tonight.

American union bricklayers may look with jaundiced eye upon a report from Belgrade that one of their Yugoslav counterparts lays 8,000 bricks a day and thus has become one of the wealthiest men in Tito's country.

ALBANY, Jan. 23--Senator Pliny Williamson, Westchester Republican and chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, introduced a constitutional amendment tonight to permit the use of the Missouri Plan for the selection of judges.

Net earnings of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company for the fiscal year ended with last October were $9,014,647 after taxes and all charges, according to the annual report, issued yesterday for publication today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The Administration opened today before a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee a campaign to have the genocide convention, or treaty, ratified by the Senate at the session of Congress.

LONDON, Jan. 23--The first London couture fashion parades to be held since the pound sterling was devalued began today. Judging by the increased orders placed by overseas buyers after the first showings, the couture houses would appear to stand a good chance of at least retaining their dollar exports, if not increasing them.

The mildness of this winter makes ice cream a much likelier subject for discussion and degustation than it ordinarily would be in January. The discussion is apropos, too, because of a new device just appearing here.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23--Laboratory progress has been accomplished in the use of radioisotopes to discover the secret of photosynthesis, the mysterious growth process of the plant world, Dr. Paul C. Aebersold, chief of the Atomic Energy Commission's Isotopes Division at Oak Ridge, Tenn., reported today.

Anyone listening to the moans of Long Island surfcasters last season would have decided that hardly a fish had been taken along their beaches, but the announcement of the winners of the Jones Beach Surf Fishing Club awards indicates that some really nice fish were brought in.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 23 (UP)--Sharpshooting Fred Haas Jr. showed near-perfect control with his irons and putter today to take the $2,000 first prize in the Long Beach invitational golf tournament with a six-under-par 65 and a 72hole total of 268. His four-round total was 16 under par.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 23--Observers declared today that the most likely successor to Premier Vassil P. Kolarov, dean of the Bulgarian Communists, who died at 1:45 A.M. today, would be Vulko Chervenkov, Vice Premier and party secretary.

ALBANY, Jan. 23--Unless state aid is given for school construction, children in certain financially distressed school districts will be deprived of adequate educational opportunities, the Department of Education said today.

The Board of Higher Education voted last night to include in its 1950-51 budget request an item of $750,000 for salary increases to the instructional and supervisory staffs in the four municipal colleges.

MOSCOW, Jan. 8--Do you need a baby-sitter? Are you too busy to take home all the things you bought at the Mostorg department store? Do you need tickets on the Red Arrow express for Leningrad in a hurry?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The House Committee on Un-American Activities, reopening its inquiry into wartime shipments of atomic materials to Russia, will seek to prove that forty-five pounds of uranium metal were transmitted as late as June, 1944.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 23--Declaring that the Federal wartime tax on transportation is a major contributing factor in the increased cost of distribution of foodstuffs, members of the National Food Brokers Association here today called for the elimination of both the transportation and communications excise tax.

The Port of New York Authority has asked Congress to approve a $5,250,000 budget allotment for maintenance and improvement of the channels serving the Port of New York, through which passes 25 per cent of the country's foreign commerce.
Charles Evans Hughes Jr., who died in this city Saturday night, had to live up to being the son of a famous father.

LONDON, Jan. 23--Prices of leading industrial issues strengthened slightly in London's stock markets today in sympathy with continued bouyancy in British Government securities. The turnover, however, remained on last week's limited scale.
ROME, Jan. 23 (AP)--It snowed so hard in Capracotta last week that Armando Gaito of Jersey City didn't learn until today that he was a father.

Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind denied yesterday a motion to convene a three-judge statutory court to test the legality of the city's Sharkey Rent Law. He also turned down an application for a temporary injunction restraining the city from enforcing the law pending a decision by the proposed court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--An attempt to restore the sixty-year-old Sherman Anti-Trust Act to its "original intent" to end John L. Lewis' control of coal production through the union-ordered threeday week was initiated in the Senate today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 23--The Netherlands Government was reported tonight to have decided to give the Indonesian Government all assistance short of ordering Dutch troops into action to suppress the revolt led by Captain Westerling.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP)-- The Federal Court of Appeals ruled today that the Federal Communications Commission might deny a license to a radio station applicant if it found that approval would tend to create a news monopoly.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Jan. 23 (AP) --A mountain avalanche today swept part of a railway train into a lake, carrying two-men to death, as wintry weather held its grip on British Columbia.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23--Fewer than 30,000 of the 90,000 striking members of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers heeded the call of their leaders to return to the pits today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner for Germany, said after conferences at the White House and State Department today that he hoped soon to produce a method of settling that country's pre-war indebtedness to lift the ban on private foreign investment there.

Canice Neary, 52 years old, who once was a probationary patrolman in the Police Department here, came back to New York yesterday after twenty-one years in a New Jersey prison.

BERLIN, Tuesday, Jan. 24 (AP)-- Col. William T. Babcock, deputy United States commandant of Berlin, died here early today in an Army hospital after suffering a heart attack at a premiere of the motion picture "Francis." He was 52 years old.

ALBANY, Jan. 23--The New York State Association of Colleges and Universities endorsed today the establishment of eleven twoyear community colleges proposed by the trustees of the State University as part of a tentative master plan for the expansion of higher-education facilities.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23--The grain markets made a strong finish on the Board of Trade here today after a weak start, when all deliveries of rye sold at new seasonal lows.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP)-- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican, of Indiana, demanded today that President Truman "apologize" to the people for calling the Alger Hiss spy investigation a "red herring" during the 1948 election campaign.

Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien told the Queens Chamber of Commerce yesterday that his department urgently needed 25,000 men, but he would settle for 20,000 now. The present roster of the department is 18,600.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)-- The Justice Department has withdrawn all but one of its exceptions to an examiner's report recommending that the Civil Aeronautics Board let Pan American World Airways buy American Overseas Airlines for $17,450,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 23--Republican legislative leaders, following a conference with Governor Dewey, tonight assailed President Truman's proposals for easing wartime excise taxes as inadequate and charged that these imposts were responsible directly for mounting unemployment in New York.

LONDON, Jan, 23 (AP)--England's Freddie Mills makes the first defense of the light heavyweight championship he won 18 months ago against Joey Maxim, clever Cleveland boxer, in Earl's Court tomorrow night.

Proof that lamps can be lovely to look at as well as to see by is presented in some of the examples now to be found in shops around New York. New bases that are decorative as well as functional may be found in a number of materials--in wood or pottery or stone--and are treated with a simplicity that makes them equally adaptable to traditional or contemporary rooms.

The failure of tugboat operators and workers to reach an agreement on seniority resulted last night in a request by Local 333, United Marine Division of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, for intervention by the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)-- Gov. Roy Turner of Oklahoma said today he believed the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Oklahoma Turnpike Authority were near agreement on a $33,000,000 loan for the proposed Oklahoma City-Tulsa toll road.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The United States Steel Corporation disclosed today that immense iron ore deposits, which may have twice as much tonnage as the famous Hull-Rust mine in the Mesabi Range in Minnesota, had been discovered in Cerro Bolivar Mountain in Venezuela.

JAKARTA (Batavia), Indonesia, Wednesday, Jan. 25(AP)--Indonesian military police raided a secret arsenal in Central Jakarta early today and captured a store of arms after a gun battle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--A fiveto-five tie vote of its Rules Committee today again blocked consideration by the House of the civil rights bill to establish a Permanent Fair Employment Practice Commission. The vote, however, was not final. Another vote may be taken at a committee meeting Thursday.

Charles E.C. Freyvogel, a vice president of the Bankers Trust Company and a specialist in foreign banking, died yesterday of a heart attack in the bank's office at 16 Wall Street. He was 61 years old, and lived at 277 Park Avenue, and at Sunset Hill, Redding, Conn.

ALBANY, Jan. 24--William Reid, New York City's Deputy Mayor, told the Moore Committee today that New York was planning a major change in fiscal policy--reducing the term of the bonds it issues for capital improvements from forty years to twenty years.

MERION, Pa., Jan. 24--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Dudley S. Smith of Wallwood of the engagement of their daughter, Gwendolyn, to Charles W. Patton Jr., son of Mr. Patton of Indianapolis, and the late Mrs. Patton.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The Pan American Airways today failed to Win permission to operate daily transatlantic flights in the summer between New York and Rome to carry pilgrims to the Holy Year observances.

LONDON, Jan. 24--American business men here heard a complaint today from Wallace B. Phillips, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in London, that increased trade between Britain and the United States seemed to be "all a one-way street."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 24--A group of Protestant urban church leaders urged here today that the administrators of both public and private large-scale housing programs in every part of the country apply the "principle of nonsegregation" to all home-building projects.

The last half century brought a greater drop in the dollar's buying power than any comparable period since 1820, the year compilation of living cost data started, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday.

Dr. Hideki Yukawa of Kyoto University, Japan, winner of the Nobel Prize in physics in 1949, presents in the current issue of The Physical Review, published yesterday, a new general theory on the nature of the elementary particles of the nuclei of atoms.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The Senate without dissent confirmed today the nomination of Admiral Forrest P. Sherman to be Chief of Naval Operations.

With the slogan, "A real boy makes a better man," the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, have come to the public seeking to raise $2,000,000 both for operating needs in 1950 and for rehabilitating and expanding camping facilities.

ONCE upon a time Jimmy Dykes was showing off--as is his wont--but the only person he was trying to impress was his young son. Jimmy was a brash and cocky performer with the Philadelphina Athletics two decades ago and he crashed drive after drive into the distant stands in batting practice.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)-- Officials of the Public Service Commissions of Washington and Oregon today challenged the proposed sale of common stock of the Pacific Power and Light Company of Portland, Ore., to a syndicate of New York bankers.

In a move to combat the "scuttlebutt" gossip and rumor that pervade ships voyaging in foreign waters, the Seafarers International Union, AFL, is now sending an onion-skin, airmail publication called The Bulletin to 325 ships at least once a week.

Threatened with a strike of 2,462 workers at midnight Friday, operators of 700 Manhattan and Bronx garages asserted yesterday that they were unable to meet union demands because of "unfair competition by the city."

Rehabilitation of 800 alcoholics by the Department of Welfare's Bureau of Alcoholic Therapy has saved the city $737,577 in the last two years, Edward J. McGoldrick Jr., director of the project, asserted yesterday in a report to Mayor O'Dwyer and Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard.
The market for Government securities sagged again yesterday to new low levels for the current movement.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 24--The Government of the West German Federal Republic today appealed to all Germans to oppose nationalism with determination wherever it appears.

If Case Goes to Supreme Court Three Justices Are Expected to Disqualify Themselves Alger Hiss, convicted of perjury when he denied giving State Department secrets to a pre-war Soviet spy ring, will be sentenced today. The former State Department official faces a maximum penalty of ten years in prison and a $4,000 fine.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 24-- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today announced plans for a new war film dealing with the fighting record of the Army's American-Japanese contingent, the 442d Regimental Combat Team, in Italy and France.

LONDON, Jan. 24--Judging from headlines in some of Britain's popular newspapers, one of the major issues in the present election campaign is not how this country is fed but whether Western Germany is eating well or not.

Faced with a new Soviet offensive on all fronts, including the possibility of another Russian blockade of Berlin, the Western nations are making commendable efforts to deflate Franco-German differences over the Saar of their dangerous potentialities.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 24 (AP)--High Roman Catholic sources said today that the majority of "good and faithful" Czechoslovak priests might be jailed in a few months, and "all depends on God's providence, which directs everything."

DALLAS, Tex., Jan. 24--The election of Lester T. Avery, president of the Avery Engineering company of Cleveland, as the 1950 president of the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers was announced here today at the society's fifty-sixth annual meeting.

MANILA, Jan. 24--Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States Ambassadorat-Large, today left the Philippines and the so-called United States defense perimeter in the Pacific for the real "hot front" in the "cold war."
Water Department officials were "gloomy" over New York's water situation yesterday as the city's reserves declined for the fourth successive day.

The dawn of a new era in commuter service for the 200,000 daily riders on the Hudson Tubes began yesterday when officials of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad unveiled a half-car mock-up of a completely refurbished car.

ROME, Jan. 24--Right-wing Socialists decided this evening to resume their collaboration with Premier-designate Alcide de Gasperi. Thus it became certain that the Italian Cabinet crisis, which has now lasted twelve days, would be solved by the formation of a coalition government composed of Christian Democrats, Republicans and Right-wing Socialists.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- President Truman today nominated Karl R. Bendetsen of San Francisco, a lawyer, to be Assistant Secretary of the Army.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24--The man named by John H. Schomaker, key government witness in the Harry Bridges perjury-conspiracy trial, as having recruited Mr. Bridges into the Communist party denounced Mr. Schomaker as a "liar" today.
Newspaper advertising in 1949, as indicated by Media Records' trends chart, reached a new high record.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Plans of a new steamship company to take over the former operations of Agwilines, Inc. (Clyde-Mallory Lines) and of the Southern Steamship Company, between Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports today came before the Interstate Commerce Commission for approval.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24--Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe signed an order today providing for a comprehensive examination of the affairs of the Tucker Corporation. The company is in voluntary reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy laws.

DETROIT, Jan. 24--With a 10 A.M. tomorrow deadline approaching, officials of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, and the Chrysler Corporation were in session tonight attempting to avert a walkout of 89,000 employes.

Unbeaten Holy Cross came out on top by a wide margin as the country's No. 1 college basketball team in the fourth weekly Associated Press poll.

Samuel Mason, a former general manager of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society, otherwise known as HIAS, died on Saturday after a long illness at his home in Miami Beach, Fla., it was learned here yesterday. His age was 71.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 24-- Carol Paight, 21-year-old college senior, came into Superior Court here today to stand trial for the "mercy" killing of her father, Police Sgt. Carl W. Paight of near-by Stamford.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24--Buying of old-crop wheat futures by mills that will advance the price of family brand flour 15 cents a sack at the opening tomorrow and removal of hedges against export sales of wheat estimated at 1,250,-, 000 bushels resulted in higher prices on the Board of Trade today.
Stanislas Niedzielski, Polish pianist, who has toured Europe extensively, made his debut last night in Carnegie Hall in a program devoted exclusively to the works of Chopin.

ALBANY, Jan. 24--The official position of the Democratic party will be to oppose state legislation to supersede Washington in the field of rent control as long as Federal controls are in force, it was learned tonight.

Twenty-year-old Ralph Edward Barrows was convicted yesterday of first degree manslaughter in the fatal beating of Colin Cameron MacKellar, Canadian textile corporation executive, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Nov. 5, 1948.

Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, yesterday denied that his institution owned or operated any private business concerns, as charged by sources close to the Administration in Washington on Monday.

An early victory for business men who have been fighting for tax equality was predicted yesterday by Joseph F. Leopold, tax specialist, at a luncheon for the Drug, Chemical and Allied Trades section of the New York Board of Trade, Inc., in the Astor Hotel.

Puccini's "Tosca," with Ljuba Welitch in the title role, will be the opera at the testimonial evening for Edward Johnson at the Metropolitan Opera on Feb. 28. It will begin at 8 o'clock to allow time at the end for a special pageant.

There were two New York premieres on Martha Graham's program last night at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, but she appeared in neither of them herself and there will be plenty of time to deal with them later.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., will place on the market today a new issue of $37,500,000 of preferred stock of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company at a price to yield about 4.4 per cent to investors.
Rocky Graziano, Brooklyn slugger who formerly held the world middleweight title, will return as a Madison Square Garden ring attraction March 24 or 31, if negotiations launched yesterday materialize.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24--Koppers Company, Inc., will supervise engineering and construction work under an Economic Cooperation Program in Turkey to cost about $50,000,000, it was announced here today by Joseph Becker, vice president and general manager of the Koppers engineering and construction division.

LONDON, Jan. 24--Joey Maxim of Cleveland took the world lightheavyweight boxing title back to the United States tonight by knocking out Britain's Freddie Mills in the tenth round of their scheduled fifteen-round contest.

Two leading tobacco companies last year chalked up the largest sales and earnings in their history, according to the annual statements for 1949 issued yesterday by the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company and the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 24-- The trend of the economic discussions held during the British Commonwealth Foreign Ministers' conference in Colombo was for continuation of the 25 per cent reduction of dollar imports through the year 1950.

A funeral service was held yesterday in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Riverdale-on-Hudson, this city, for Charles Evans Hughes Jr., former Solicitor General of the United States, who died Saturday night in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after an operation for a brain tumor.
Coffee futures opened easier on commission house selling and scattered long liquidation on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday.

The election of Ferdinand M. Bissell as vice president and senior loan officer of the Pan American Trust Company was announced yesterday by Harvey L. Schwamm, president.

In the first earnings report on results of strike-troubled 1949 to come from a leading steel company, the Crucible Steel Company of America yesterday reported sharp declines in sales and profits.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 24 --In the opinion of many officials of both the Allied High Commission and the International Authority for the Ruhr, the Authority is in danger of becoming a "white elephant" if it is not that already.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--A new Fair Labor Standards Act carrying pay increases for about 1,500000 workers goes into effect tomorrow. President Truman, in a statement, hailed it as a welfare measure dictated by social justice.

The one-story taxpayer building at 175-A to 177 Jefferson Street in Passaic, N.J., containing eleven stores, has been sold by David S. Meister to a group of investors represented by Emil Rogers, attorney.

After eighteen years in Sing Sing Louis Boy's life sentence was commuted by Governor Dewey because he had voluntarily submitted to dangerous medical experiments. Life was to have started anew for him last Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Democratic members of the House Ways and Means Committee, in an unpublicized caucus today, found themselves in general agreement on the advisability of trying to compensate for cuts in excise rates by simultaneous revision of other taxes.

ALBANY, Jan. 24--A bill continuing for another year the Temporary State Commission on Agriculture was passed by a vote of 30 to 23 in the Senate today after several Democrats had criticized the commission's investigation of milk-price spreads.

ALBANY, Jan. 24--A proposal to extend for one year the right of municipalities to set up work-relief programs was among a series of New York City bills introduced today by Senator Elmer F. Quinn of Manhattan and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, minority leaders.

Not having written any works of art for a month or two, the Messrs. Rodgers and Hammerstein have produced a very enjoyable family comedy, "The Happy Time," which was happily acted at the Plymouth last evening.

John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, is definitely scheduled for the post of Chief City Magistrate when the retirement of Edgar Bromberger becomes effective on Feb. 14, it was learned last night.

SAARBRUECKEN, The Saar, Jan. 24--Nothing is contained in the proposed French-Saar agreements that should disturb good relations between France and Germany or in any way prevent the integration of Germany into Western Europe, Johannes Hoffman, Premier of the Saar, declared today in an interview.
The Guild Theatre, 243 West Fifty-second Street, was bought at public sale yesterday by the American National Theatre and Academy (ANTA) for $627,500.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Top labor leaders here today expressed "chagrin" and "deep disappointment" with the recent statement by Secretary of State Dean Acheson that the United States was now ready to support a United Nations resolution freeing each power to restore normal diplomatic relations with the Franco regime in Spain.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 24--The snook once more are moving up the St. Lucie, the blues are moving in to the beach, the sailfish are showing in the Gulf Stream, and the big large mouths are showing an interest in surface bugs. In brief, now that the anglers don't have to lean 30 degrees into the wind to stand upright, the fishing in these waters is returning to normal.

In its first change of ownership in thirty-one years, the Hotel Wales, a nine-story building on plot 62 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Ninety-second Street, has been sold by the Bon Ray Hotel Corporation to John Malacoof for investment, it was announced yesterday.

The following dispatch is by Wayne Richardson, Associated Press correspondent at Hong Kong, who was aboard the United States freighter Flying Arrow when a Nationalist gunboat riddled her with shot off Shanghai.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--A British representative today lodged an official protest with Marshall Plan authorities over alleged discrimination against British electrical equipment by an American city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--A bill to permit 320,000 displaced persons to enter this country by June 30, 1951, was approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee tonight. The total includes about 124,000 who have already entered.
Formation of the Washington Square Committee, to preserve historic Rhinelander House and the beauty and atmosphere of the Square and Washington Arch, was announced yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady on the close yesterday, with final prices 4 points higher to 5 points lower than on Monday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP)-- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan warned Congress today that farm prices may collapse in "chaos" unless it provides $2,000,000,000 more crop support money.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--United States Steel Corporation executives declared today that the company's recent increase in the price of steel was "modest" but "no mystery."
ALBANY, Jan. 24--A Republican resolution urging Congress to repeal all the wartime imposed excise taxes was passed by the Legislature today, with the single negative vote cast by a Republican.
LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP)--The crowd of 18,000 at the Joey MaximFreddie Mills bout tonight set a British indoor record. It was Mills' first defense of the light-heavyweight title.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)-- The Department of Commerce reported today that corporate profits increased in the third quarter of 1949 after declining in each of the preceding three quarters.

Capt. William M. McGuire, former marine inspection officer of the Third Coast Guard District, became director of the city's ferry services at a ceremony held yesterday at headquarters of the Department of Marine and Aviation.

Prospects of a spirited holdout siege enlivening the waning weeks of baseball's off season collapsed on two fronts yesterday when the two most famous players of last October's world series contenders accepted terms for 1950.
As a result of protests from car owners living in Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the rates for parking under the viaduct of the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Drive were reduced yesterday.

New Yorkers using Times Square subway station in the early morning hours yesterday were startled to hear a voice tell them on what track the next train would depart on the shuttle service between Times Square and Grand Central Terminal.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)--A Texas rural electric cooperative demonstrated today with a $262,648 loan pre-payment check that it is a self-supporting enterprise.

TOKYO, Jan. 24--The new policy statement of the Japanese Communist party published yesterday has given some support to the belief that Communist attention in Asia now is being centered on targets to the south, political observers said today. This coincides with the opinion of United States military quarters that French IndoChina now occupies the first position in the Communist program of expansion in the Orient.
IT was nearly three years ago that a novel was published in this country by an Irish-born English writer named Joyce Cary.

Four organizations and nine individuals were honored yesterday at the annual meeting of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York in the Roosevelt Hotel. Five hundred persons attended the luncheon session.

ALBANY, Jan. 24--Governor Dewey and Republican legislative leaders have reversed their decision of last week to dip into tax stabilization reserves to balance the state's budget for the next fiscal year, it was disclosed today.

Unless continued aid is given to Israel by American Jews, not only will Israel's future be difficult but many advances already achieved may be canceled out, Aubrey Eban, Israeli delegate to the United Nations, declared yesterday.

MADRAS, India, Jan. 24 (AP)-- Miss Gertrude (Gorgeous Gussie) Moran put off marriage and took on another tennis title today.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 24--The American woman stands today confused by a culture that trains her to compete with men for a career, and then expects her to be content with being a wife and a mother, Dr. Florence Kluckhorn of the Department of Social Relations, Harvard University, declared here today.

LONDON, Jan. 24--British Funds led a modest improvement on the Stock Exchange today. Undated and long-term gilt-edge issues were the strongest with old Consols and Treasury 2 per cent were l higher. Both are more than 2 points higher than a week ago.

Tests in ejecting dummies out of an unpiloted mechanism traveling at speeds ranging up to 1,100 miles per hour are being conducted by the Air Force, the Armed Forces Public Information Offices revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The House Committee on un-American Activities learned today that a New York concern that arranged the sale of 1,000 pounds of uranium to the Soviet Union in 1943 was under contract at the time to give the United States the first chance at all it could get.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--This Government has entered important reservations to the European currency union plan now being developed between the Economic Cooperation Administration and the Marshall Plan governments in Paris.

Endorsement of Point Four legislation introduced in the House of Representatives in identical bills by Representative John Kee, chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and Representative Christian A. Herter was voiced yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.

ALBANY, Jan. 24--Lack of employer cooperation and insufficient funds for administrative work were cited today by officials of the Division of Placement and Unemployment as the principal reasons for fraud in the payment of unemployment insurance claims.

Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard appealed yesterday for help in finding temporary foster homes for 500 children under city care in institutions.

A propeller-driven airplane that can fly at the speed of sound, but still have a low fuel consumption rate at slower speeds over long distances, is being developed by the air arm of the Navy, Rear Admiral C.M. Bolster, assistant chief of research, Bureau of Aeronautics, announced yesterday.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 24 (AP)-- Unrest and some hunger strikes were reported today among Formosans being conscripted to defend this Nationalist island from Chinese Communist attack.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 24--Foreign Minister Edvard Kardelj told the Executive Committee of the People's Front today that maximum manpower would have to be mobilized in 1950 if the Government was to carry out its export trade program upon which it relied for its essential imports.

An exhibition illustrative of the taste and culture of the urban middle class of Japan in the period from the early seventeenth to the middle of the nineteenth century has opened at the Brooklyn Museum.

LONDON, Jan. 25--Winston Churchill, Conservative party leader, returned to London today after a long week-end at Westerham, Kent, pleased with the reception the Conservative manifesto had received in the British press.

ATHENS, Jan. 25--An armed guerrilla band, forty to fifty strong, crossed into Greece from Bulgaria on the night of Jan. 22-23 and sacked the Greek village of Paliouri in the Didymoteichon area after setting fire to dwellings on the village's perimeter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Senator Arthur Vandenberg of Michigan is resigning from the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee just at the time when its members are engaged in a most serious discussion of the hydrogen atomic bomb problem.

A minor mystery in shipping circles is the fate of the "White Star" of Cunard White Star Line. The big British shipping company, which operates the largest fleet of transatlantic passenger ships, recently announced that Cunard White Star, Ltd., had been absorbed by the parent company.
A proposal designed to end the long-standing uncertainty about the financing of the Welfare Council of New York City was submitted yesterday to its 300 members.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 25-- Seven more Fairfield County residents, all of them parents, were selected in Superior Court here today to sit on the jury that will try Carol Paight for the "mercy" killing of her father, Carl W. Paight, a Stamford police sergeant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--The fight in the House of Representatives over consideration of the Civil Rights Bill to establish a permanent Fair Employment Practice Commission took a new and bitter turn today. Two New York members, Representatives Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat-Liberal, and Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat, set off the latest explosion.
Welfare organizations announced yesterday that they would continue service to military groups here and abroad despite the scheduled deactivation of the United Service Organizations.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 25 (AP)-- Sam Snead held the favorite's role today for the $10,000 Ben Hogan open golf tournament as he fired a 3-under-par 68 in the preliminary pro-amateur event.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 25-- American Protestantism was warned here today to guard against a growing secularization of society that had already "contaminated" and "stultified" the church itself.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested yesterday three men described as the "nucleus" of a ring that over the last four years allegedly had stolen furs valued at $1,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The Senate today adopted the Equal Rights Amendment, by a 63-to-19 vote, but with a rider retaining protective laws for women.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25--The outlook for business in the months immediately ahead is one of optimism tempered with restraint, Kenton R. Cravens, vice president of the Merchantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company, St. Louis, and chairman of the Credit Policy Commission of the American Bankers Association, said here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The Bureau of Labor Statistics estimated today that factories added 250,000 employes between July and December, 1949. Soft goods, chiefly textiles and apparel, led the rise.

PARIS, Jan. 25--Simone Cange's hats from small to cartwheel all thrust forward. Felt is avoided in favor of Baku, smooth Paillassons, ribbon and such exotics as raffia, chair caning and rigolo, a strawlike ribbon of wood pulp.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 25--A choir of 2,500 sang "The' Internationale," artillery salutes boomed and planes circled overhead as Premier Vassil Kolarov was interred here today.

GENEVA, Jan. 25--A Jerusalem settlement that will meet the essential demands of Israel and Jordan and yet conform to the General Assembly's resolution of December, 1949, can be found, Roger Garreau, president of the United Nations Trusteeship Council, said here today.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 25--The Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion of New York and Cincinnati, became the only American Jewish Reform seminary today when the merger of the HUC and the JIR was completed at the first meeting of the consolidated board of governors.

ALBANY, Jan. 26--Two Republicans in the Legislature proposed today that the blanket exemption from jury duty now afforded women in the judiciary law be repealed. They proposed instead that women be exempted from jury service only when such service would cause hardship because of the presence in the household of school-age children or older persons who were ill.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 26--The Israeli Government has decided to send a representative to the United Nations Trusteeship Council when it begins its deliberations on the future of Jerusalem in Geneva next month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--President Truman was urged today by a subcommittee of the House Small Business Committee to impose quota restrictions on foreign oil imports, contending that they were damaging the domestic oil industry.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26--As shown by California Apparel Creators, the new late spring and summer fashions place greatest emphasis on sheers such as dotted Swiss, voiles, nylons, handkerchief lawns, batistes, dimities and tissue ginghams. Also important are sheer silks, all silk shantungs and pongees, sheer and suiting-weight linens, and cottons that look like wools and are fashioned into town suits of cooling texture.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26--In the first action of its kind in United States courts since the Communist regime assumed control in China, the People's Republic of China today took steps aimed at keeping money belonging to the Bank of China from being delivered to representatives of the Chinese Nationalist Government.

One of the rare instances when Roman Catholics and Protestants have siudied together mutual problems in the field of secular education under religious auspices took place yesterday afternoon at a luncheon at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park.

Mr. Rose and his wife, the former Eleanore Holm, star swimmer, estimated the value of the loot at more than $100,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 26--The master blueprint that was placed before the United Nations recently by five outstanding experts to combat world unemployment through a series of bold, integrated steps, including fluctuating tax rates, ready-and-waiting legislation and reversible social security systems, was unanimously commended to the member governments today for "serious and detailed" examination.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26-- The Harry Bridges perjury-conspiracy trial took an excursion today into the field of labor-management relations.
Issues of temporary loan notes totaling $9,285,000 to finance public housing projects of municipal authorities in Massachusetts and New York were sold at public bidding yesterday to banking groups.
From a towel into a swim suit, beach dress or coat, is the long stride terry cloth has taken into the fashion scene.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 26 (AP)-- Mighty Citation's comeback campaign hit a snag today as the great triple-crown king of 1948 bowed in defeat to a 14-1 shot from Argentina.
One of--the first large-scale modern communities on Long Island giving recogaition to the pressing housing problem of minority groups will be opened to the public tomorrow at North Amityville.

Two bronze medals of honor were awarded last night by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, one to a dog who saved the lives of several families in a fire, the other to a person who rescued his blind mascot from drowning. The awards were made at the annual meeting of the ASPCA at the Roosevelt Hotel.

George L. McAlpin of 375 Park Avenue, a real estate and insurance broker associated with Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., of 15 East Forty-ninth Street, committed suicide, according to the police, by shooting himself in the right temple in his third-floor room of the private pavilion of Roosevelt Hospital yesterday morning.

British maritime unions have arranged a meeting with Minister of Health Aneurin Bevan this month to discuss an alleged failing in the British socialized health plan as it applies to seamen away from home for long periods.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 26-- Four prosecution witnesses testified in Superior Court here today that Carol Paight appeared calm and cool but very pale a few minutes after she shot and killed her father on Sept. 23 as he lay in Stamford Hospital, suffering from an inoperable cancer.

Possibility of early establishment of convertibility of European currencies is remote and it does not appear likely that this objective will be attained by June 30, 1952, termination date of the Marshall Plan, according to Thomas K. Finletter, former chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission to the United Kingdom.

Acceptance by Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. of Mayor O'Dwyer's invitation to replace him as a speaker at tomorrow night's $100-a-plate dinner at the Commodore Hotel was viewed yesterday by leading Democrats as indicating that Mr. Roosevelt is an active aspirant for the Democratic nomination for Governor and that the Mayor looks with favor upon his candidacy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--President Truman, in philosophical mood at the death of an old friend, and the marriage of a young one, tonight told the twenty-fourth Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense he was ready to "pass on happily" if he could achieve his one ambition as President--to see peace in the world.

ALBANY, Jan, 26--This state will soon undertake a pioneering program looking to the reclamation and rehabilitation of sex offenders, Governor Dewey indicated today, following a conference with a special committee that has been studying the problem for two years.

The stock market held its ground yesterday and even managed to show a measure of selective improvement near the close as a result of modest bidding. The session, however, was not conclusive in providing a clue as to the next ...

MONTREAL, Jan. 26 (AP)--The National Hockey League's one-two teams, the Detroit Red Wings and Montreal Canadiens, opened a twogame series tonight by playing a 1-1 tie before 13,650 fans. They clash again Saturday.
MOSCOW, Jan. 26--Diplomatic interest in Moscow was focused today on Southeast Asia.

PARIS, Jan. 26--After having listened all day to divergent views on the next step in reducing trade barriers, the Ministerial Steering Committee of the Marshall Plan Council tonight adjourned discussion until tomorrow.

The International Harvester Company, leading farm machinery producer, achieved record earnings during its fiscal year ended with last October, despite somewhat lower production, sales and employment than the year before, according to the annual report of John L. McCaffrey, president, issued for publication today.
OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 26--To the accompaniment of four blasts from the San Francisco Ferry Building siren, the Irish Plane, first Irish-flag vessel ever to enter the Golden Gate, docked here today.

Discovery and development of a powerful new drug, effective in animal tests against a wide variety of infectious diseases, is reported in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, by a team of eleven scientists from the research laboratories of Charles Pfizer Co., Inc., of Brooklyn.
The National Industrial Conference Board, at a dinner meeting last night at the Astor Hotel, heard a triple-pronged attack on the budgetary program of the Truman Administration.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP)--Jesse Owens, the greatest track athlete of the past half-century, today is a philosophical business man with three daughters, one a freshman at his alma mater, Ohio State.

For the first time in months an armed band has crossed the Bulgarian border into Greece, raided and sacked a village and raised the familiar specter of war in a countryside just beginning to breathe again after years of terror and devastation.

An Austrian squad of eighteen skiers, including seven women, arrived yesterday aboard a Scandinavian airliner at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, their hopes for honors in the world Alpine championships at Aspen, Col., Feb. 13-18, as high as the unseasonable temperature of 70 that greeted them.

One-hour flights to Europe and jet-propelled helicopters for intercity travel were among the predictions made yesterday by four men who received honorary Doctor of Engineering degrees at exercises commemorating the twentyfifth anniversary of New York University's Guggenheim School of Aeronautics.

Committees representing tugboat owners and workers in this port moved close to a new agreement yesterday afternoon when they achieved concurrence on a seniority issue that has been one of the principal stumbling blocks in almost a month of negotiations.

Increased borrowings by sales finance companies, and on tobacco and other commodities, were the principal factors in an unseasonal expansion which lifted commercial loans made by New York City banks $16,000,000 during the week ...

Agriculture is New York State's largest single industry and more than half of the state's acreage is given over to farming. In recent years gross dollar receipts by New York farmers from marketing their products have run toward the billion-dollar mark. Milk production in 1948 exceeded 8,000,000,000 pounds, and nearly half the farm income of the state came from milk and the by-products of dairy farming, cattle and calves.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 26--Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was invited by the Western Allies today to send consuls general to London, Washington and Paris "without delay" and thus establish the first official and permanent West German representation abroad.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has authorized a $30,000,000 construction project at its Sparrows Point (Md.) plant to increase by 900,000 tons annually its shipments of flat-rolled products in the eastern market, E.G. Grace, chairman, disclosed yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 26--The number of idle because of the strike against the Chrysler Corporation by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, rose above 110,000 today when the Briggs Manufacturing Company disclosed that it had furloughed 23,000 workers.

After the band plays "Home Sweet Home" for departing crowds and glaring lights drowse into blinking clusters, a new life begins under the "Big Top" of the General Motors "Mid-Century Motorama" at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)-- The Federal Power Commission said today consolidated hearings will start here on March 7 on eight applications, three of which involve natural gas service to New England.

Equalization of local real estate assessments is the state probably will not be completed in the threeyear, period set for the task, but it will go forward without regard to political expediency, according to speakers yesterday at the State Bar Association's Municipal Law Section. The group met at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 26-- How to get men coaching girls to teach their teams girls' rules is a problem the New York State Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation will tackle this year, Miss Marie R. Schuler, a former president, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--During the week ended Jan. 25, member bank reserve balances decreased $68,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Widespread destruction of highways was attributed yesterday to overloading of freight-carrying vehicles by "unscrupulous operators" in talks at the opening of the eleventh annual meeting of the National Council of Private Motor Truck Owners at the Commodore Hotel.
Budget-minded homemakers can find six suggestions for furnishing with well-designed contemporary furniture at less than $500 a room in a series of model rooms opened yesterday at Abraham Straus.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Miss Edith Cook Snyder, daughter of the Secretary of the Treasury and Mrs. John W. Snyder, was married today to Maj. John Ernest Horton of Wichita, Kan., in a cathedral ceremony that drew a cosmopolitan throng and made social history. President and Mrs. Truman attended.

The best thing that can be said about the new Displaced Persons bill which has finally been reported to the Senate is that it affords a basis for further action. As it has come from the committee the measure is far from satisfactory. The whole purpose of revising the present restrictive DP law is to liberalize it--as the House bill would do.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Panama will pay $350,000 to the United States in settlement of claims made by this Government as far back as 1915, the State Department announced today.
The campaign of active floor members of the New York Stock exchange to gain greater representation on the board of governors finally has proved successful.

ALBANY, Jan. 26--Legislation to require the semi-annual inspection of the 3,000,000 motor vehicles of the state at state-operated inspection stations was placed before the Legislature today under the sponsorship of the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicles.

The New York Rangers, in the slough of a seven-game losing streak, will have one of their injured players back in action when they oppose the Bruins in Boston tomorrow night. Allan Stanley, dependable defense player, who has been out with a sprained ankle, ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)-- Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat, of Georgia, predicted today that any new draft legislation approved by the House Armed Services Committee, of which he is chairman, would give the President "only very limited" power to order men inducted into the armed services.

It will amaze you.' I wish you wouldn't be so lazy. You have the record books.
Yesterday, all along the northern Atlantic Coast, was the hottest January day ever recorded by the United States Weather Bureau.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced yesterday that six corporations and seventy individuals, all members of the Watch Material Distributors Association of New York, Inc., had consented to anti-monopoly injunctions.
WARSAW, Jan. 26--The work of the Polish press is being hampered beyond forbearance by they recently decreed Official Secrets Act, the newspaper Trybuna Robotnicza (Workers' Tribune) has reported.

STOCKHOLM, Jan. 26 (U.P.)--A clarinetist died last night soon after he participated in a rehearsal for a performance of Tchaikovsky's "Pathetique" Sixth Symphony, and another "Gloomy Sunday" legend appeared in the making.

A program to break up organized diamond smuggling rings is being prepared by the Diamond Manufacturers and Importers Association of America, Inc., it was declared yesterday by George Fine of Max Fine Sons, Inc.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 26-- The National Congress on Home Missions was urged here tonight to "call for the unconditional, complete and permanent abolition of race prejudice."

Reynolds Co. and other underwriters will offer to investors today a block of 177,028 shares of common stock of ABC Vending Corporation, seller of confections, popcorn and other products, at $9.375 a share.

Entries for the metropolitan intercollegiate indoor track and field championships to be held next week closed yesterday with 216 varsity nominations from nine colleges and 145-freshmen from eight. The games will be in two sections. The track events will be in the 102d Engineers Armory, Broadway and 168th Street, next Friday. All field events except the high jump will be on Thursday at Columbia's South Field.

AT the end of 1940 Hitler had realised that Britain could not be destroyed by direct air assault. The Battle of Britain had been his first defeat, and the malignant bombing of the cities had not cowed the nation or its Government.

The proposed merger of the Congregational Christian churches and the Evangelical and Reformed Church was blocked yesterday in a decision by Justice Meier Steinbrink in Brooklyn Supreme Court. The merger, which had been set for next June, would have resulted in the formation of a United Church of Christ with nearly 2,000,000 members.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The President's Civil Rights proposal to establish a permanent Fair Employment Practice Commission had two more setbacks in the House of Representatives today.

LONDON, Jan. 26--Labor party leaders are watching with undisguised glee the growing split in the Conservative ranks in the rich middle-class London suburb of Hampstead. So serious has the division become that the Labor candidate may snatch victory in what has long been a "centerpiece" of Conservative strength here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Miss Alice Paul, chief strategist for the Equal Rights Amendment long sponsored by the National Woman's party, today said that the next move would be an attempt to have it approved by the House Judiciary Committee without the Hayden rider.

Planning for parenthood is as vital to mental health and social welfare as to physical well being, Dr. Earl L. Koos, professor and chairman of the Department of Sociology, University of Rochester, declared yesterday.

VIENNA, Jan. 26--Assurance that arrangements have been made to obtain raw materials for Hungarian heavy industry, and particularly the armament industry, surreptitiously from the Western states despite United States discouragement of such shipments was recently given to industrial administrators and experts by the Hungarian Foreign Trade Ministry, according to reliable advices from Budapest.

An investigation into the operations of auctioneers in the Times Square area was started yesterday by License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey. Summonses were served on eighteen men to appear for hearings next week at the Department of Licenses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, said today President Truman's health insurance plan was basically different from the British system, which he recently studied at first-hand.

LONDON, Jan. 26--In the opinion of economic experts here, some of the greatest difficulties of the British recovery effort and of the whole European Recove Program still lie ahead and may result in friction between Britain and the United States.

Yesterday's warm weather made it harder for small-fry consumers of coal to think of the coal situation as an emergency. A glance at the thermometer may have confirmed President Truman in his belief that there is not yet, in fact, an emergency, though he did tell Senator Kilgore of West Virginia that he was working as hard as he could and hoping for the best.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 26 --The importance of efforts now being made by the United States High Commissioner's Office to strengthen the reorientation and re-education aspects of the occupation is emphasized by an official report picturing German resistance to school reform.

GENEVA, Jan. 26--The task of building a viable Western European economy has been set back seriously by the seemingly trivial incident of the rejection by the city of Seattle of British bids for installing some electrical generating equipment.

Seventy-nine Long Island home builders are cooperating in the redesigned and streamlined display of their latesthouses opening on Monday on the first floor of the main office of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26-- In a dispute which may end in legal action, Robert Young has withdrawn from the leading male role in "The Story of a Divorce," which Jack Skirball and Bruce Manning are scheduled to produce at RKO early next month, with Bette Davis as the star.

LONDON, Jan. 26--Considerable pressure is being brought to bear on the leaders of the Liberal party to reconsider their decision to enter nearly 400 candidates in the British general election on Feb. 23. In the Conservatives' view the Liberals have only the slightest chance of increasing their present representation of ten members of Parliament and in many constituencies they may split the antiLabor vote to the advantage of the Labor candidates.
