Beginning on Feb. 14, Britain's Ministry of Food will reduce the allocation of raw coffee for British consumers 20 per cent, according to cables received from London's Coffee Exchange yesterday by the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The coffee market here showed little reaction.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26-- A.P. Giannini, founder of the Bank of America, the world's largest bank with assets of $5,765,000,000, left an estate of only $600,000, according to a list of his holdings filed in San Mateo Superior Court today by James A. Lee, state inheritance tax appraiser.

Parents are more determined than ever to "clean house" on they comics, Mrs. James J. McGuire, chairman of resolutions for the Queensboro Federation of Mothers Clubs, representing 60,000 mothers and 136 schools, declared yesterday.

The death toll in all but the most serious airplane accidents could be materially reduced if a higher degree of "crashworthiness" were built into airplanes and into the seats and safety belts of passengers, William I. Stieglitz, design engineer of the Republic Aviation Corporation, told the eighteenth annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences which ended yesterday.

JAKARTA (Batavia), Indonesia, Jan. 26 (AP)--Indonesian Federal troops, seeking to crush a West Java rebel movement, shot it out with an armed band of deserters from Dutch service in downtown Jakarta today and hauled off two truckloads as prisoners.

Net income of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York in 1949 totaled $658,042, against $601,656 in the previous year, Nugent Fallon reported to stockholders yesterday during their seventeenth annual meeting, at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. Gross income of the bank in the respective periods, he ...

LONDON, Jan.26--Britain's 82year-old Queen Mary, mother of King George VI, made her contribution today to the nation's drive to earn more dollars. She has given to the nation a ten-foot two-inch by six-foot nine-inch needlework carpet of her own making with the express wish that it be sold in North America and the dollar proceeds turned over to the national exchequer.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 26-- Dr. Arthur H. Morse, obstetrician, who for thirty-five years was a member of the Yale faculty, died of a cerebral hemorrhage today while driving his car near his home in suburban Hamden. He was 69 years old.

Rocky Castellani, middleweight boxer from Luzerne, Pa., will oppose a hard hitter at Madison Square Garden tonight when he faces Ernie Durando of Bayonne, N.J. The pair will meet in the scheduled ten-round battle that will serve as the star attraction.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Angry criticism of Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, and of the Administration in general, over the Alger Hiss case rose today in the House.

There's no doubt in designer Klaus Grabe's mind that people have to play around with a hammer. The rapid success of his makeit-yourself furniture has proved it. To make it doubly easy for homemakers with the construction urge to obtain his plywood kits, he is opening this morning a new retail shop at 730 Lexington Avenue.

Dr. Herbert Eustis Winlock, archaeologist, of North Haven, Me., died yesterday while on a vacation in Venice, Fla., according to word received here. A director emeritus of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, he would have been 66 years old on Feb. 1.

The United States and the rest of the world have reached a critical point in history at the halfway mark of the Economic Cooperation Administration program, William C. Foster, deputy administrator of the ECA, declared last night.

Sir Gerald Campbell, who spent twenty-five years in this country as British Consul General at New York, Minister in Washington, and in other diplomatic posts, arrived here yesterday on a special mission for the British Board of Trade.

The jury in the spy trial of Judith Coplon and Valentin A. Gubitchev was told yesterday that it must decide whether the odd behavior of the Government girl and the Soviet engineer at three of their meetings was caused by a tortured romance or the technique of espionage.
Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan appealed to industrialists to aid national acceptance of the principle of price support for farm products produced by 27,500,000 farm people, yesterday.

Edward W. Foley, president of the E.W. Foley Associates Company, Inc., 16 Court Street, Brooklyn, well-known contracting firm, died yesterday in his home at 70 Remsen Street, Brooklyn. His age was 74.

A dream came true for Barbara Busch yesterday in the form of a letter of admission from New York University. Slight, blonde, and 21 years old, Miss Busch contracted poliomyelitis last August when she was a counselor at a convalescent home for disabled and handicapped children.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26--Mr. and Mrs. Henry Carnegie Phipps' Wheatley Stable barely missed getting two 3-year-old fillies out of the maiden class in the same race at Hialeah today.

PARIS, Jan. 25--Neat little sailors, pillboxes and a few cloches with beautifully tailored detail introduce spring at Suzy. In two colors, contrasting white and cherry red or emerald green, the top of the shallow square crowns belonging to the sailors is in one tone, the side of the crown and the brief bumper brim in another.
St. John's basketball team, a 17point favorite, made good last night by defeating St. Francis, 65--46, in DeGray gymnasium. This was the thirty-sixth meeting of a series which began in 1922.

TRENTON, Jan. 26--Conversion of most of Sandy Hook, no longer an active coastal defense installation, into a New Jersey seafront park, comparable to Jones Beach on Long Island, was recommended today by a special state park study committee.

The Langwell, a twelve-story and penthouse hotel containing 365 rooms at 123 West Forty-fourth Street, on plot 100 by 100 feet, one-half block east of Times Square, has been acquired by a syndicate of hotel operators represented by Frank N. Morgenstern, it was learned yesterday. The property was sold on Tuesday in the Vesey Street Exchange in a foreclosure action against Langwell Associates. The assessed valuation is $700,000.

Three new films will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the Roxy, the attraction is "Twelve O'clock High," Twentieth CenturyFox drama dealing with wartime exploits of the Eighth Air Force. Gregory Peck heads the cast, with Hugh Marlow, Gary Merrill, Millard Mitchell, Dean Jagger and Paul Stewart among the principals. Henry King directed and Darryl F. Zanuck produced from a screen play and novel by Beirne Lay Jr. and Sy Bartlett.

A 51-year-old widowed mother of two sons will be graduated from Hunter College next Tuesday after a three and one-half year college career.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 26--Describing Governor Dewey's housing program as superior to any so far proposed by the Federal Government, Herman T. Stickman, New York State Housing Commissioner, called upon organized labor today to take a more active part in solving the nation's housing problem.

The Hercules Powder Company last year had a net income, after taxes and all charges, of $9,951,960, third largest in its history, as were net sales of $120,976,915, according to the annual report of President Charles A. Higgins, released today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The Lone Star Steel Company, Dallas, Tex., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 592,185 shares of $1 par value common stock.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Republicans were blocked by a parliamentary ruling today in attempting to force an immediate House showdown on a reduction of excise taxes.

Lower prices on large grade A eggs, a few meats, vegetables and fish are the good news on the food front this week-end. The consumers' service division of the Department of Markets in its weekly survey of retail stores found that, in addition to these declines, small turkeys had dropped 6 cents to an average of 59 a pound.

Control of the A. DePinna Company, Fifth Avenue specialty shop, has been purchased by Julius Garfinckel Co., Inc., Washington, D.C., fashion shop, it was announced here yesterday. The purchase price was not revealed.

The United States was caught flat-footed at Pearl Harbor because of two psychological reasons, Vice Admiral Frederick S. Sherman, retired, declares in "Combat Command," his own review of the war to be published today.
A plan to provide for the water needs of this and near-by cities until "beyond the year 2000" will be presented today to the Governors of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 26 (AP)-- Jimmy Demaret shot a hole-in-one and equalled the competitive course record here today to lead the $10,000 Ben Hogan open golf tournament by a single stroke over Hogan and Johnny Palmer of Badin, N.C.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Accusing the steel industry of trying to make labor the scapegoat for the recent price increase in steel, a spokesman for the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, said today that the real reason for higher prices was the industry's "determination to take outrageously higher profits from the American people."

The British Tories today are by no means as conservative as their forebears. The party manifesto for the Feb. 23 general election, "This Is the Road," will not only make Lord Randolph Churchill, Winston's father, turn in his grave but would have shocked even such a good Liberal as the Herbert Asquith of 1911.

Representatives of fifty-eight national organizations will meet tomorrow and Sunday at the Astor Hotel at an "All-American Conference" to form a united front against communism, the American Legion announced yesterday at its headquarters, 1 Park Avenue.

Five independent FM stations in the metropolitan area have set up a network to stimulate interest in the medium through special pro grams. Their first venture will be the broadcasting of five Fordham University basketball games which are to be played away from home during February.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 26--Marshal Tito received the new United States Ambassador, George V. Allen, at the White Palace today.

John Wallace and Louis G. Loeber have been elected vice presidents of Cox Kitchens, Port Chester, N. Y., according to John P. Cox, president. Both men have been associated with the company for fifteen years and will continue as executives in the sales field.

BERLIN, Jan. 26--The commandants of the three Western sectors of Berlin protested to the Soviet authorities today against "Soviet interference" with truck traffic between Berlin and Western Germany. They asked for "immediate" removal of "these abnormal restrictions."

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26 (AP)--The medalist, Miss Marlene Bauer, won her most decisive victory thus far in the eighteenth annual Helen Lee Doherty women's amateur golf tournament today by defeating Miss Claire Doran of Cleveland, 7 and 6.

A new book project will be started by the Literary Guild of America this month, A. Milton Runyon, president of the book club, announced yesterday. To be called The Fireside Theatre, it will distribute current Broadway plays in book form.
ROME, Friday, Jan. 27--When he left his office just before last midnight Premier designate Alcide de Gasperi had filled all but one of the posts in his sixth Cabinet.

Operations last year of the Mathieson Chemical Corporation resulted in the largest sales and earnings on record. Thomas S. Nichols, president, informed shareholders in the annual statement issued yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 26 --Determination to seek methods to hold down the cost of foods, maintain quality, and still make a profit is drawing the largest attendance of food producers ever attracted by a trade show here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The highest military authorities declared today that Formosa, to which President Truman has refused further military aid, would be of "strategic significance" to the United States if it fell to "an enemy."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)-- Legislation to put a limit on cotton acreage cuts for 1950 was cleared by the House Rules Committee today for House consideration, probably tomorrow.

HONG KONG, Jan. 26--Communist troops in Central China have begun a general movement toward the coastal provinces of Fukien and Chekiang, according to Chinese military sources here. These reports, supported by Chinese press dispatches from Canton, provide the best evidence so far that the Communists may soon launch an invasion of Formosa.

NEWARK, Jan. 26--A half-century of Archbishop Thomas J. Walsh's priesthood in the Roman Catholic Church was celebrated today with a golden sacerdotal jubilee in the Newark Archdiocese, which he heads.

BOSTON, Jan. 26--John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner for Germany, said tonight that there was a "strong basis for hope" that the problems of Western Germany could be solved, despite "some evil embers lying about."

Many Westchester taxpayers will be surprised to learn that in the last fifteen years they have accumulated $40,000,000 by gradually reducing the county's bonded debt to that extent. Like paying off a mortgage on a home, the amortization process will extend for many years and the full effects will become noticeable slowly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Technical experts from the United States, Great Britain and Canada will meet in Harwell, England, next month to discuss possible changes in their joint code of secrecy for atomic energy information in the light of the Russian atomic explosion of last September.

Although no 1950 contracts have yet been mailed to Dodger athletes, who by now are doubtless burning up with feverish impatience, Branch Rickey continues to pursue his own persuasive tactics in corralling his more important players and yesterday brought another key performer into the fold.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 26--One of the things which attracts anglers to this fishing community is the variety, for when it is too rough to go after sailfish you can always fish the inlet, the waterway or the river, and after one look at the white caps off the breakwater we decided in favor of the inside fishing.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)-- The National Petroleum Council said today the United States has enough oil to meet "all demands of the foreseeable future."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Former Vice President Henry A. Wallace repeatedly denied before the House Committee on Un-American Activities today that he ever influenced any shipment of fissionable materials to the Soviet Union, or that he ever violated security in connection with the development of the atomic bomb.

If it is not ungallant to say so, Rosalind in "As You Like It" is not Katharine Hepburn's best part. Under the protection of the Theatre Guild, she has brought the character and the play to the Cort, where Shakespeare's rustic revels were performed last evening. Gorgeously attired in some stunning finery designed by James Bailey, Miss Hepburn is lovely to look at, and she plays the part with pride and modesty.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 26--A drastic decree freezing workers to their jobs with labor contracts for a period of three to six months to increase production for the export program was announced today.

ROME, Jan. 26--A comic-opera war between two southern Italian cities took a serious turn today. Twenty persons were injured in a police charge in Catanzaro, which is contesting with Reggio for the honor of becoming the regional capital when Parliament gets around to creating the region of Calabria.
After long negotiation the city has concluded, with considerable profit, a pier lease arrangement involving two steamship lines, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)-- The American Power and Light Company wants to get out of the power business in the Pacific Northwest and intends to do so.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 26--To win the approval of this Government, proponents of a European currency union will have to show conclusively that the plan will promote rather than hinder the convertibilty of members' currencies into dollars and hasten a return to multilateral world trade, including that of the dollar area.

The eighty-third annual exhibition by the American Water Color Society will open tomorrow afternoon with a reception and preview for members and guests in the galleries of the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, from 3 to 7 o'clock.

Striking coal miners in West Virginia and Pennsylvania continued yesterday to reject union pleas to return to work, despite indications that their refusal might provoke President Truman to seek an injunction under the national emergency provisions of the TaftHartley Law.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 27-- Hopes ran high early today that the original program of world Nordic skiing championships-- jumping and cross-country-- would be carried out. The temperature dropped to 10 above and snow started to fall. The flakes came down heavily.

Coffee futures were moderately active and slightly lower on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. The market opened with prices a shade easier ered hedges in the near-by delivery mand, but renewed scattered selling toward the close found support scaled down.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27-- Jay Drattler, who sold his crime melodrama, "The Miami Story," to Warner Brothers in 1948 and subsequently bought it back from the studio, has made a deal with RKO to produce the film, with Robert ...

BOSTON, Jan. 27--Two trucks owned by one of the several companies sharing a garage with Brink's, Inc., armored car service, were seized today by investigators as a new development in Boston's $1,500,000 robbery.
During the past two years the free nations of Europe, with the help of the United States, have made great strides toward recovery.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP)--Miss Marlene Bauer advanced to the semi-finals of the eighteenth annual Helen Lee Doherty amateur women's golf tournament today when she rallied to beat Miss Marjorie Lindsay, 1 up.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--President Truman indicated at his press conference today that no decision had been reached on whether and when this country would proceed with construction of a so-called "super" hydrogen bomb.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Jan. 27-- Forty-four persons are missing aboard a United States Air Force C-54 transport plane unreported since it was last heard from yesterday over the wild, blizzardswept Yukon country.

The Palais Royal, a seven-story apartment house occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet and containing 225 rooms at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and 113th Street has been purchased by the Northchester Corporation from Mrs. Linda Reiss in a deal negotiated by Schimmer, Kerner Feder and Holdeen-Cushing-Murray-Holden, brokers. The assessed valuation is $160,000.

Arms shipments from this country to its European associates under the North Atlantic Treaty may start about March 1 following the signing of bilateral agreements yesterday by eight nations that had requested such assistance.

Italy has a tradition of "democratic dictators"--Depretis, Crispi and Giolitti especially come to mind. Premier Alcide de Gasperi, who has just formed his sixth coalition Government since 1945, might well qualify for a place in that line, although history may rank him higher than any of those three and ...

Delegates to the fifty-sixth annual meeting of the United States Golf Association will assemble at noon today at the Waldorf-Astoria to elect a new staff of officers and to set the pins on the course of the organization for 1950.

A new gallery made an auspicious start this week. The Catherine Viviano Gallery at 42 East Fifty-seventh Street opened with a handsome display of work by five contemporary Italians, all but one of whom was represented in the Museum of Modern Art's comprehensive Italian show last summer.

Definitions of trade practices were adopted yesterday by the pickle packers of America, marking the first action of its kind in this industry. At their winter meeting, more than 120 members of the National Pickle Packers Association at the Roosevelt Hotel unanimously approved a twelvepoint set of definitions to cover buying and selling pickles in brine or in the green stage.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27--The Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. announced today the appointment of a special commission that will endeavor to clarify the rules and standards of the denomination on marriage, divorce and remarriage.

PARIS, Jan. 27--The disciplined machinery of international communism, directed by Moscow, these days is carrying out perhaps the most brilliant example of global political warfare so far known to history by draining the potential strength of France in Indo-China's civil war and thus accomplishing a...

BALTIMORE, Jan. 27 (UP)--The value of this year's Preakness Stakes, second jewel in racing's famed Triple Crown, has been reduced to $50,000, it was announced today by Henry A. Parr 3d, president of the Maryland Jockey Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--President Truman stood firmly behind his Civil Rights recommendations today in the face of Congressional battling over whether the House would consider establishment of a permanent Fair Employment Practice Commission, and amid continued...

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 27-- Congress and the Attorney General were urged today by the Westchester County Federation of Women's Clubs to be "mindful of the welfare of the people" in dealing with problems involving governmental restrictions of free trade.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP)-- Nine horses were named today to race in the $100,000 Santa Anita Maturity tomorrow and the Calumet Stable's one-two punch of Ponder and Two Lea dominates the field. The Maturity, a mile and a quarter run for 4-year-olds, is expected to attract 50,000 spectators to Santa Anita Park.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and final prices were 6 to 19 pints net lower than on Thursday.

A steady reorder business has been the chief sustaining factor for coat and suit manufacturers in the women's apparel trades, it was learned yesterday. Popular price and low end dress business has shown some decline, but manufacturers are anticipating another round of spring buying which they say will begin next week.
Opposition to toll roads and the need for countrywide uniformity in motor vehicle laws were emphasized yesterday by Charles B. Bowling of the United State Department of Agriculture.

BERLIN, Jan. 27--For "technical reasons," the Ministry of Interior of the Eastern German Dem ocratic Republic issued tonight a directive demanding that special passes be obtained for travel to the territory of "Greater Berlin" and return.

Alfred Beers Sturges of 305 Chestnut Street, Nutley, N.J., a charter member and former officer of the New York Curb Market Association, now the New York Curb Exchange, died Thursday in Passaic (N. J.) General Hospital after a brief illness. He was in his eiehtv-second year.
Six years of litigation over the proposed consolidation of the Long Island Lighting Company with its subsidiaries ended yesterday when the Public Service Commission approved the merger.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 27--A record attendance marked the opening today of the food conventions in the huge convention hall here. Displays of more than $5,000,000 worth of the newest foodproducing and processing machinery were spread over a seven-acre area.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation served notice yesterday that its contract with the United Electric, Radio and Machine Workers, covering 50,000 employes, would not be in effect after April 1.

Orders written in the last five days by the majority of manufacturers exhibiting at the annual local winter furniture market in the New York Furniture Exchange were ahead of last January and above expectations. This was the consensus yesterday of manufacturers' representatives and dealers.

The Senate Labor Committee, on a vote which followed party lines, decided yesterday to shelve a resolution asking that President Truman invoke the emergency provisions of the TaftHartley Law to restore full coal production. The plain fact is that, while undoubtedly well-intentioned, the resolution now condemned to languish in ...

The Government's move against a counterfeit ring, beginning early yesterday morning with the arrest and arraignment of four men here, struck into other areas yesterday afternoon with four arrests reported in Los Angeles and three in Buffalo.

It is better for the British people as well as the United States that Britain earn the dollars it needs by exports rather than save dollars by reducing imports, it was emphasized yesterday by Sir Cecil Weir, chairman of the British Dollar Exports Board. He spoke at a luncheon of the British Commonwealth Chamber of Commerce in the Plaza Hotel, where he gave a detailed outline of the specific objectives of the board.

ROME, Jan. 27--Pope Pius XII will announce on March 2 that the place where the Apostle Peter was buried has been found under the pavement of St. Peter's Basilica, Vatican circles said today. March 2 will mark the eleventh anniversary of Pius' election as Pope.

The results of "dry Thursday" were so "very satisfactory" that next Thursday will be another "dry day"' for water conservation, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner Stephen J. Carney of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Eletricity.

CLIFTON, Jan. 27--Stockholders of the Bank of Allwood have elected three new directors. They are: Albert W. Lindholm, vice president of the Falstrom Company, Passaic; Allan J. Blair, president of Blair Aldous, Passaic plumbing supplies dealers, and Paul-Densen, vice president and general manager of Eastern Corrugated Container Corporation, Clifton.

By virtue of a legal technicality, some 40,000 investors in Group Securities, Inc., a mutual fund with about $75,000,000 invested in more than 500 types of securities, were assured yesterday that the men who guide the investment policies will continue at the helm for another decade.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 27-- Classroom teachers must be made aware of the broad scope of physical education, delegates to the twelfth annual conference of the New York State Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation declared today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27--The grail markets turned reactionary in the late trading on the Board of Trade today at final sales, except on nearby deliveries of soybeans, were at about the bottom. Trading in the aggregate was light and the market easily influenced.

A week-end party? Grossinger's takes over the dessert department for the home cook. Cookies, cakes, pastries or, with twenty-four hours' notice, a luscious frozen dish. The ice cream cakes, logs and snowballs are virtually synonymous with Grossinger's with those who know this fourteen-yearold bakery at 337 Columbus Ave-- nue.

The stock market managed with some difficulty yesterday to hold its ground until the early afternoon when a flurry of bidding in the steels and rails inspired buying in other sections. Interest again was dulled by the strike of the Chrysler workers and the coal mine shutdowns.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 27--We finally managed to break our largemouth bass jinx this afternoon, but in order to accomplish it we had to throw away the book, turn to local fly patterns, and fish the most unlikely spots on the lake.

HOLYOKE, Mass., Jan. 26--Independent printing experts, as well as persons connected with the development of paper-manufacture from bagasse, the waste of sugar cane, today expressed satisfaction with the results of a test conducted in the pressroom of The Holyoke Daily Transcript-Telegram.

Ralph Branca, the big righthander who in the course of a season can just about be a manager's greatest delight and biggest headache all rolled into one, yesterday became the third top-ranking Dodger to fall under Branch Rickey's persuasive spell, although player contracts have yet to go out to the rank and file.

Dutch quinine producers have decided to launch their first consumer advertising campaign in the United States, it was announced yesterday by the Russet M. Seeds Company, Chicago, which has been appointed an agency. The move is prompted by declining demand for quinine in this country, it was said.

Canada, which has been completely dependent on foreign suppliers for its stainless steel sheet, is preparing to produce its own requirements. Atlas Steels, Ltd., has started to install the country's first stainless steel sheet rolling mills at its works in Welland, Ont. Production at the mill is expected to begin in September, R.H. Davis, president of the company, announced yesterday.

TRENTON, Jan. 27--Three New York lawyers; removed as defense counsel for three of six Trenton Negroes awaiting trial for murder, failed in Federal District Court today to obtain an order restoring them to the case.

SAY a dozen American planes, each carrying an atomic bomb, had set out to plaster Hiro shima. And say that only one plane gotpast the Japanese anti-aircraft fire to the target. The distinguished people who are now blandly telling us that the latest defensive devices make it devilishly difficult to carry many packets to an alert and well-guarded opponent could triumphantly say:

Although the weather has turned the flower market topsy-turvy, florist shops are managing to display their customary midwinter assortment. Greenhouse-grown carnations and roses are most plentiful. Tulips, daffodils and iris, however, give a spring-like air to the windows and refrigerators full of blossoms.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 27 (AP)--The University of Pittsburgh's everbubbling football kettle boiled over again today as head football coach Mike Milligan turned down a yearto-year contract.

Fifteen hundred veterans and their families who live in the State Emergency Housing Project on North Brother Island in the East River must continue to pay a 10cent. round-trip fare on the cityowned ferry connecting the island with the Bronx, Justice Henry flay Greenberg ruled yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court.

ALBANY, Jan. 27--The State Banking Department announced today it had approved an application of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, 175 Broadway, for premission to move its branch office from 320 Broadway to 199 Church Street.

PARIS, Jan. 27--France has given a formal pledge to the Saar Government that she will not seek the region's political attachment or annexation to France, Johannes Hoffman, Premier of Saar, told this correspondent in Saarbruecken yesterday.

The annual report of the New York Curb Exchange and its operating affiliates, the New York Curb Exchange Realty Associates, Inc., and New York Curb Exchange Securities Clearing Corporation, disclosed yesterday total income of $1,357,146 for 1949, against $1,419,927 the year before.

Wendell Phillips, 28-year-old explorer, said yesterday that the American Foundation for the Study of Man, which he set up last month, has received $650,000 in cash and equipment to carry on archaeological studies in Egypt and Arabia.
DETROIT, Jan. 27 (UP)--Art Houtteman, ace right-handed pitcher of the Tigers, quickly spiked holdout rumors today by signing his contract for a reported salary boost of $5,000.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 27--ProAdministration Democratic leaders from the not-so-solid South banned tonight any discussion of civil rights or other controversial "regional" issues from their fifteenstate party conference, which will convene here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--A fox hunt, minus pink coats and horse, raced through downtown Washington today and ended only when the wily beast was brought to bay on the lawn of the Treasury Building.

Negotiations for a new contract for the tugboat industry bogged down again yesterday afternoon over manning scales and a pension plan. A speedy settlement had been indicated at the previous day's meeting when the seniority issue was settled.

With the moderate income family in mind, Lord Taylor is introducing two Henredon bedroom suites noteworthy for their luxurious finishes and reasonable prices. One is contemporary in design and the other is Regency.

PARIS, Jan. 27--In the midst of an uproar precipitated by a rain of insults from the Communists, the National Assembly started debate today on ratification of accords that would endorse the establishment in Indo-China of the regime of Bao Dai, former emperor of Annam.

Berl Senofsky, American violinist who won the Naumburg Award two seasons ago, gave his third local recital last night in Carnegie Hall. He was attended by a sizable crowd of young and enthusiastic listeners.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--President Truman tartly refused today to comment on the conviction of Alger Hiss for perjury as a demand arose for a nonpartisan in vestigation of the loyalty record of the former State Department official and of all others named as participants in the alleged Communist espionage conspiracy.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 27--The Securities and Exchange Commission rejected today both bids made recently for all of the outstanding common stock of the Pacific Power and Light Company that is held by its parent, the American Power and Light Company.

Child training practices in this country have gone through a revolution in the last twenty years, but "there appears to be considerable question as to whether the new doctrine is any sounder than the old," according to Dr. Celia B. Stendler of the College of Education, University of Illinois.

Retail trade here this week was affected by unseasonably high temperatures which checked the sale of many types of seasonal merchandise. Despite this handicap, however, estimates indicated the decrease in department store volume under a year ago might be held to 3 to 5 per cent.
Rocky Castellani, Luzerne, Pa., middleweight, gave Ernie (Rock) Durando, Bayonne, N.J., slugger, a thorough boxing lesson last night in the ten-round feature bout at Madison Square Garden.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 27-- Princeton University disclosed today that it had penetrated far into the secrets of jet propulsion and supersonic flight, as Harold Willis Dodds, president of the university, and Rear Admiral Thorvald A. Solberg, chief of naval research, dedicated a new wind tunnel back of Palmer Stadium.

The theatre's most eagerly awaited annual event, "ANTA Album," the entertainment comprising some of the great scenes from recent stage history, will be given for a single performance tomorrow evening at the Ziegfeld Theatre under the auspices of the American National Theatre and Academy, the Congress-chartered organization devoted to promote the theatre on a national basis.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP)-- The Federal Reserve Board reported tonight industrial production increased nearly 3 per cent in December to reach the highest level since last April.
Brooklyn and Manhattan turned in winners yesterday in the first day of competition of the Middle Atlantic figure skating championships at the Iceland Rink of Madison Square Garden.

The long-range significance of Secretary Acheson's charges against the Soviet Union, backed up by the recently issued "background material" on aggression, is larger than a political and polemical move in the contest of ideas called the "cold war." Superficially, these charges lay upon the Soviet Union the burden of anneaationist imperialism, the same charges ...

MELBOURNE, Saturday, Jan. 28 (AP)--Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., defeated Miss Doris Hart of Jacksonville, Fla., today in the women's singles final of the Australian tennis championships. The score was 6--4, 3--6, 6--4. Miss Hart was defending titleholder.
MOSCOW, Jan. 27--The Soviet press said today that "the hour of final liberation" of Tibet was not far distant.

HELMSTEDT, Germany, Jan. 27 --As twilight closed down tonight on this strategic spot on the superhighway between Berlin and Western Germany, more than 300 freight trucks remained stalled on either side of the Soviet zone border.

Two gunmen who had robbed a dry cleaning establishment of $540 three months ago and boasted that they would return, made good their threat yesterday. But they were arrested before they could escape in a waiting automobile with the company's payroll of $890.
Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson declared yesterday that he would not include in the 1950-51 finance budget any salary increases for city employes except those that are mandatory.

The 'cellist, Joseph Schuster, who left his post at the first desk of the Philharmonic-Symphony in 1948 to devote his full time to concert work, appeared at Town Hall last night, much to the satisfaction of his large and well-deserved following. Mr. Schuster is a fine and sound musician, and his beautiful' cello tone is remarkably free of the fuzziness that is so often characteristic of the instrument.

A dispute over an injured longshoreman's welfare fund claim, which resulted yesterday morning in a four-hour work stoppage at Pier 84, North River, was settled in negotiation between officials of Local 824 of the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association, it was announced later in the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--However the matter may appear to Europeans, the Economic Cooperation Administration is thoroughly satisfied that the low bids of two British companies to supply electric transformers to the city of Seattle were rejected because they failed to meet the specifications fully.

The underlying financial position of American consumers as a whole remains impressive despite the record spending boom of the postwar period, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday. The institute's analysis was based on figures compiled by the Federal Reserve System in dealing with the distribution of assets and debts among the nation's 50,000,000 families.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--An agreement to resume coal negotiations eased pressure on the White House today.
Milwaukee County, Wis., announced yesterday that it would receive bids an Feb. 20 on an issue of $5,600,000 of tax-exempt bonds dated Feb. 1, 1950 and due on Feb. 1, 1957.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, whose confirmation as Chief of Naval Operations had been held up by the Senate while the legality of his appointment was debated, was formally sworn in today and received a commission document assuring him that he had the job.
It is all very pleasant to read in the newspapers that another weather mark has been broken.

Ezzard Charles, Cincinnati Negro who is recognized by the National Boxing Association as the world heavyweight champion, yesterday signed articles of agreement for his third defense of the N.B.A. title.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--A.B. Homer, President of the Bethlehem Steel Company, said today that the recent $4 a ton increase in steel prices was necessary to meet "substantial increases" in costs and to realize a profit rate in 1950 that would not be "substantially below" the 1949 rate.
LONDON, Jan. 27--For the showing of his spying tailored collection, Digby Morton invited the overseas buyers and fashion journalists tonight to a full-dress rendezvous in his Grosvenor Hill salon.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 27 (AP)-- Jimmy Demaret took a firmer hold on the $10,000 Ben Hogan open golf tournament lead today.

BUFFALO, Jan. 27--A strong plea for additional two-year community colleges, to provide more youth with an opportunity for higher education, was voiced here today by Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 27--A series of recommendations designed to reshape the furture course of the Protestant missionary enterprise in this country, was unanimously adopted here today at the closing session of the National Congress on Home Missions.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27--Hialeah's sun-tanned children got three features for the price of one today. The main event, a $4,000 sprint for 4-year-olds and upward, was split into three sections. The winners, in the order of their appearance, were Robert McGowan Smith's one-horse stable, Sagittarius, at $7.20; the Warbern Stable's Mirabeau, at $11.60, and John Marsch's stakes-winning OI' Skipper, at $6.50.

Albert G. Borden of 204 Vose Avenue, South Orange, N.J., former second vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, died here Thursday night of a cerebral hemorrhage at the Drug and Chemical Club, 85 John Street, where he had been attending a faculty dinner of the Insurance Society of New York, of which he was a president and director. His age was 71.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 27 --Harry C. Harper, State Labor Commissioner who was defeated Tuesday in the special primary election for nomination of candidates for the Seventh Congressional District seat recently made vacant by the jailing of Representative J. Parnell Thomas, declared today that he would run again in the regular primary in April.
Two Government agents, who testified that they saw Judith Coplon keep a rendezvous in Washington Heights on Jan. 14, 1949, ...

Former Senator John Foster Dulles yesterday termed our loss of China to the Soviet sphere "the worst defeat the United States has suffered in its history" and asserted that success for our foreign policy could not be achieved without a change in domestic policy.
Seven hours before a midnight strike deadline a walkout by 2,500 Manhattan and Bronx garage workers was averted yesterday by an agreement to arbitrate differences with management.

SINCE the days of Nelson Malta has stood a faithful British sentinel guarding the narrow and vital sea corridor through the Central Mediterranean. Its strategic importance was never higher than in this the latest war.
AMES, Iowa, Jan. 27 (AP)--Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt asserted today that "you just couldn't hold back scientific knowledge," in commenting on the controversy over construction of a hydrogen bomb.
GENEVA, Jan. 27--In a late session tonight the United Nations Trusteeship Council unanimously approved the agreement under which Italy will administer former Italian Somaliland.
WALTHAMSTOW, England, Jan. 27--Prime Minister Attlee's personal opponent in the British general election of Feb. 23 will not be Winston Churchill, as some Americans might imagine, but three...
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Jan. 27 (AP)--Ronald Yinger, father of the "mid-century twins," must come back to Missouri to serve his prison term, Gov. Forrest Smith decided today.

PARIS, Jan. 27--Jules Moch, Socialist Vice Premier of France and Minister of the Interior, pledged today that all arms and munitions shipped to France under the United States military aid program would be unloaded in French ports upon arrival without obstruction from Communist saboteurs.

LONDON, Jan. 27--Britain made it plain today that she could not undertake "any further substantial commitments" for mutual military aid among the North Atlantic pact powers without endangering her economic recovery.
LONDON, Jan. 27--The imminence of the British general election is having a depressing effect on efforts of the European Marshall Plan Council meeting in Paris.
The Ambassador Hotel, on the Park Avenue blockfront between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets, came in with a "gusher" yesterday in its month-long search for water.

HONG KONG, Jan. 27--The official Communist Liberation Daily in Shanghai reports that 1,000,000 persons out of a population of 5,300,000 in the Suhsien area of North Anhwei are starving and that 3,500,000, or more than half of the inhabitants, are suffering from famine conditions.

Can anyone beat Don Gehrmann in the Wanamaker Mile? That is the question that most intrigues the 15,000 foot-racing devotees who will pack Madison Square Garden tonight for the forty-third annual games of the Millrose Athletic Association, the famed invitation carnival that raises the curtain on banked-track competition among the nation's stars in New York.

The cost to the government of ship operating differential subsidies about which President Truman expressed "serious concern" in his budget message has been greatly exaggerated, according to Frank Reil, director of information of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered railroads to raise their rates on commodities moving in carload lots from various far inland points to South Atlantic and Florida points, effective on April 20.
PARIS, Jan. 27--The leaders of the European Marshall Plan Council wound up a two-day meeting tonight with the differences among them more conspicuous than the small areas of agreement.

Market uncertainties have held hazards for the flotation of new issues of both bonds and stocks this week and sentiment in Wall Street is on the cautious side for the period immediately ahead. The continued drift in the prices of Government securities, with several of the shorter-term obligations ...
Foreclosure on Gardner School, 1055 Fifth Avenue, to satisfy a $60,000 second mortgage was ordered yesterday by Herbert Lowenthal, bankruptcy referee of the Federal District Court.

LONDON, Jan. 27--Sir Andrew McFadyean, president of the British Liberal Party Organization, predicted today that if either the Conservative or the Labor party should win the general election of Feb. 23, there would be another election within two years.

Mr. Justice Jackson penned some very notable words on the subject of security vs. human liberty in his vigorous dissent in a recent case in the Supreme Court. In essence, the issue was whether the wife of an American citizen, a "war bride," could be denied admission to the United States on security grounds without a hearing.

TROY, N. Y., Jan. 27--Gen. Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, declared here today that "no scientist should withhold his discovery because he fears the use to which it will be put."

Volunteer workers for the Young Men's Christian Association exceeded the goal required to meet the disbursements of the current year by collecting $422,714 in cash and pledges, it was announced yesterday at the final meeting of the campaign, held in the Commodore, Hotel.
Two hundred and fifty contributions, amounting to $408.10, were received yesterday by THE New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. This brought the total so far contributed to the fund to $306,402.03.

Somewhere--the newly married couple would not tell where--Mr. and Mrs. John J. Bradford of Waltham, Mass., are on their honeymoon today. Their wedding went off without the proverbial hitch, but only because of the alert action of two New York detectives who saved the wedding wardrobe.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 27-- A Stamford surgeon testified in superior court here today that Carol Paight was not sane at the time she shot and killed her father, Police Sgt. Carl W. Paight, last Sept. 23.

ALBANY, Jan. 27--A bill appropriating $3,000,000 for child care centers will be introduced in the Legislature Monday evening under Republican auspices, Senator MacNeil Mitchell of Manhattan, sponsor, said today.

Mrs. Harriet Wheeler Phillips Fisher, widow of Thomas R. Fisher Jr. and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rowley W. Phillips of 1220 Park Avenue, formerly of Waterbury, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Edgar H. Redington Jr., son of Edgar H. Redington of Philadelphia, and the late Mrs. Redington, in the Park Avenue Methodist Church by the Rev. Paul N. Otto.

A five-and-a-half-mile ambulance run to take a woman with a gashed throat three blocks to the nearest hospital was said by the police yesterday to have saved the life of Mrs. Anna Entes, 54 years old, of 860 Forty-seventh Street, in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

At first the Allied commandants wished to believe that the tie-up of road traffic between Berlin and the Western zones was due to inefficiency. They explained, hopefully, that there was a change of the guard at the Soviet check posts and the new inspectors might not yet know how to handle the ...

Five afternoons a week between 3 o'clock and 4:30 a very feminine woman slips on a baggy gray sweater and a pair of jeans and takes over a man's job--coaching the rifle team of Abraham Lincoln High School.

BOSTON, Jan. 27--Americans apparently spend more on gambling than they do for medicine, housing or private education and research, the Citizens Committee of Massachusetts, Inc., reported today after a nation-wide survey.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 27 --Westchester is so prejudiced against Paul Robeson and his leftwing followers that a fair trial of damage suits arising from the Aug. 27 and Sept. 4 riots near Peekskill cannot be obtained in the county, Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis was told here today.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 27-- Following an unusually emotional address by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, the West German Bundestag passed a resolution today calling for an "awakening of world conscience" in the matter of German prisoners of war still held by the Soviet Union, Yugoslavia, Poland and Czechoslovakia.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 27--Two more members of the United Nations Security Council--Egypt and Ecuador--may withdraw recognition next month from Nationalist China and supply the necessary votes to seat a delegation of the Chinese Communist regime, it was reported today in United Nations circles.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 27-- Netherlands officials said today that any Dutch national taking part in the West Java uprisings against the United States of Indonesia was acting completely against orders and, if a military man, was liable to severe punishment.

LONDON, Jan. 27--Britons may get little or no meat in the next couple of weeks as a result of a new row between the butchers and the Government over the latter's announced intention to cut down the butchers' profits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--President Truman proclaimed the North Atlantic joint defense plan in effect today and eight Western European Governments immediately signed agreements enabling them to receive $1,000,000,000 in Unitd States arms and equipment.

Frederick Brown has purchased the one-story taxpayer occupying the blockfront on Bergenline Avenue between. Thirty-third and Thirty-fourth Streets in Union City, N. J., from the Kaymar Realty Corporation. Darling McDonald were the brokers. An A. P. super market is one of the seven tenants of the property, which has an adjoining parking lot.

An Italian youth who offered to put up his life as his bond if allowed to remain in this country, will spend instead thirty days of that life in Federal jail and then be deported, a Federal judge ordered yesterday.
The New York State Bar Association yesterday rejected by a vote of 192 to 67 a resolution that would have condemned testimony by judges as character witnesses.
The annual March of Dimes Fashion Show, held in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, will be televised over the CBS video network on Tuesday from 1:45 until 3 P. M.

Dr. and Mrs. Virgil G. Damon of 830 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Marshall, to Allen Farish Maulsby of New York, son of Mrs. David Lee Maulsby 3d of Baltimore, and the late Mr. Maulsby.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--Frazer A. Bailey, president of the National Federation of American Shipping, warned today against subordinating or weakening the American merchant marine in formulating mutual defense arrangements with other Atlantic pact nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 27--Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended Jan. 24, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 150.7 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.3 per cent below four weeks ago and 5.5 per cent below the comparable week of 1949.

TOKYO, Jan. 27--The Japanese Government has asked the Allied command for permission to arm the patrol boats of the post-war coast guard fleet as a result of the seizure of Japanese fishing vessels by China, Korea and the Soviet Union, the Diet was told today.

The seventh annual emphasis on programs in celebration of Youth Week will start tomorrow in churches of the nation under the auspices of the United Christian Youth Movement and its forty member denominations, thirtyeight state councils and eighteen national youth-serving agencies. The theme this year is "God Designs--Youth Builds."

LONDON, Jan, 27--Although week-end business dwindled still further, the stock markets here maintained a reasonably firm appearance today British Government securities gained another one-eighth point or so, leading industrial shares rose a few pence, South African gold-mining stocks made a general, if modest, advance and most of the other principal sections were at least steady.
MARSEILLE, France, Jan. 27 (AP)--More than half the jewels seized from the Aga Khan and his wife last Aug. 3 were turned over to the police today in a brown paper package.

Employes of the United Nations, who for the last three years have been commuting to makeshift quarters in a converted factory at Lake Success, will get their first look next week at a sample office suite designed to demonstrate that bright things are ahead in their glass-and-marble world capital here.

Closer integration between the work of public health and mental health workers was urged yesterday by Dr. Robert H. Felix, medical director of the Mental Hygiene Division, United States Public Health Service.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Ivan Wichfeld of 1 Sutton Place South and John Balfour Clark of 1021 Park Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosalie de Goicouria Clark, to Richard Farnsworth Hunnewell, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Melville Hunnewell of Boston.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27-- Henry Schmidt, a longtime associate of Harry R. Bridges in West Coast longshore unionism and a co-defendant in the present perjury-conspiracy trial, denied today every aspect of testimony linking him with Communist Party membership and meetings.

Prof. Harold C. Urey of the University of Chicago, who won the Nobel Prize in chemistry for his discovery of heavy hydrogen, the basic substance that makes the hydrogen bomb possible, said last night that the United States had no choice but to develop and build the H-bomb as otherwise we would intentionally lose the world by default to Russia.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27--The cost of Federal housing, aid to education, socialized medicine, liberalized social security, the Brannan farm subsidy plan and federalization of electric power would increase the present estimated average family tax load of $1,128 annually 33 to 75 per cent, Carrol M. Shanks, president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, said today.

The medical profession is holding back the development of psychotherapy in this country by insisting that a medical degree is necessary for the practice of "the art of psychotherapy," it was charged last night by Dr. Robert Lindner, a prominent psychologist.
JAKARTA (Batavia), Indonesia, Jan. 27 (AP)--The Cabinet of restive West Java resigned today and a parliamentary move developed to place the state's problems in the hands of the federal Government.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. will observe his seventy-sixth birthday today with little or no deviation from his regular routine.

A TENTATIVE truce in the long, sometimes bitter, war between traditionalists and modernists in the home furnishings field was strikingly apparent at the recent Chicago and Grand Rapids markets. Differences between the two schools of decor, that had once seemed irrecon cilable, were surely, if gradually, dis appearing as the antagonists cautiously raided each other's camps for ideas.

The supply of water in the city's up-state reservoirs increased by 280,000,000 gallons in the twentyfour hours ended at 8 A. M. yesterday. This brought the total storage supply up to 107,863,000,000 gallons, or 42.6 per cent of capacity. On Jan. 28, 1949, the reservoirs were 80 per cent full with 202,618,000,000 gallons on hand.

Mary Garden, the operatic singer who came out of long retirement for a lecture tour of the United States, sailed for home yesterday, conceding that her twentyeight lectures here had been twenty-eight signal triumphs.

PARIS, Sunday, Jan. 29-- France's accords on the Indo-Chinese states that form the basis for the regime of Bao Dai were ratified just after midnight in the National Assembly by a heavy majority of 401 to 193. Only the Communists and groups affiliated with them voted in the opposition.

What may be the largest and richest iron ore deposit in the history of the world will soon be feeding the furnaces of the United States Steel Corporation. This fabulously rich ore body is in Venezuela in an area south of the Orinoco River.

A Grand Jury investigation of overcrowded conditions in the New York City penitentiary on Rikers Island that "endanger the safety of correction officers and serve to nullify sound penology" has been requested by the City Island Civic Association, it became known yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 28 (AP)-- John L. Lewis reaches his union's retirement age Feb. 12 but no applicants seek his $50,000-a-year job. It is believed that the United Mine Workers' executive board will take advantage of a constitutional provision to keep him as president.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 28 (UP)--American bobsledders, seeking a title which never has been captured by the United States, held second and third places today after the first two of the four heats for the world twoman championships.

BERLIN, Jan. 28--An end to the truck tie-up at the Soviet check point at Helmstedt before tomorrow morning was indicated tonight. Since the early hours of this morning the pace of clearance of both eastbound and westbound traffic has been gradually improving.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 29 --Officials of the National Canners Association passed resolutions here today at Convention Hall condemning the Brannan Plan, asking that wartime excise taxes on transportation be lifted and criticizing the Government's anti-trust suit against the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.

ALBANY, Jan. 29--Governor Dewey has arranged to submit his annual budget to the Legislature on Wednesday. Advance indications are that he will ask for appropriations that will be at least $50,000,000, and possibly more, below last year's record total of $939,600,000.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Jan. 29-- The engagement has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Karl C. McMahon of their daughter, Mary Marsden, to Dr. John Edward Connolly, son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Connolly of 53 East Eighty-seventh Street, New York.

Five prominent American women physicians received yesterday the Elizabeth Blackwell Citations for 1950 for their significant contributions to the practice and teaching of medicine.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 29--The tugboat strike hampering ship movements in Baltimore harbor neared a month's duration today with strikers and employers still deadlocked over terms and no settlement in sight. The walkout was called Jan. 4.

YONKERS, Jan. 29--John J. Ryan of 61 Hildreth Place, a retired electrical engineer who had been employed for thirty years by the Consolidated Edison Company, died here today of a heart attack while attending mass in St. John the Baptist Roman Catholic Church. He was 68 years old.

PARIS, Jan. 29--The United States, according to authoritative sources, will shortly grant diplomatic recognition to the three Indo-Chinese states of Viet Nam, Laos and Cambodia, with which the French National Assembly ratified new agreements late last night.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 29-- Morale in this last important remnant of Nationalist China seems good. New officials from the mainland have resolved their principal disagreements with the native population.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, Democratic floor leader, offered today a change that some Senators thought bettered the chances for Senate passage of a constitutional amendment to share electoral votes among Presidential candidates in proportion to their popular votes.

Bowing to the edict of the State Athletic Commission, Jake La Motta, Bronx ring veteran who holds the world middleweight championship, yesterday submitted to the International Boxing Club a signed contract for the defense of his title in the Yankee Stadium or the Polo Grounds next June, against a recognized challenger for the crown.

The spring and summer collection of Castillo, designer for Elizabeth Arden, was seen yesterday at the Pierre. The occasion was a benefit, under auspices of the Memorial Hospital Social Service Committee, for the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop.
