An $861,722,633 budget was sent to the Legislature by Governor Dewey yesterday. The sum was $77,565,011 less than the current budget, economies coming mainly from cuts in new public works and welfare aid and from no provision for new school construction.

President Truman's budget for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1951, recommending increased government psending and taxing, has embarked the nation on "a perilous course." the monthly letter of the National City Bank of New York, issued yesterday, warns.

Seventy-two Swedish naval cadets arrived in New York yesterday in search of the Empire State Building and Chicago jazz, only to wind up at a luncheon that featured smorgasbord, schnapps and their own native drinking songs.
TOKYO, Feb. 1 (AP)--The United States must throw more air, sea and land power into its Pacific line if it is to hold back Asia's Communist tide, the Joint Chiefs of Staff were told today.

Two structures of Quonset type were put into use yesterday as auxiliary school buildings in the Jamaica Bay Veterans Housing Project in Brooklyn, marking the first time these temporary units have been used by the Board of Education.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1-- Nancy Davis and James Whitmore, both of whom were imported from Broadway last year by MetroGoldwyn-Mayer, will be co-starred in Dore Schary's 1950 production at the studio, "The Next Voice You Hear," it was learned today.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Feb. 2--The National Assembly yesterday rebuffed a powerful group that had sought to almost double the price charged peasants for their land under the land reform law.
BERLIN, Feb. 1--The hard core of resistance to communism in the Soviet zone is melting steadily, according to authoritative United States and British sources here.

Lieut, Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, commanding general of the First Army, officiated yesterday at the dedication on Governors Island of an enlarged, renovated library that now combines the First Army reference library with the Fort Jay fiction library.

The first major snowfall of the season dropped a 2.2-inch layer of wet, white flakes on the city early yesterday, but by afternoon the wintry coating had dissolved into slush. Sleet as well as snow, however, made driving conditions hazardous in many sections of the suburbs.

Seven writers, four artists and a composer have been selected from among distinguished contemporary Americans by the National Institute of Arts and Letters for membership in that body, Douglas Moore, president, announced yesterday.

It was considered unlikely in banking circles yesterday that any more than one bid will be submitted for the issue of $375,000,000 of Commonwealth of Pennsylvania bonus bonds scheduled for sale on Feb. 16.

One night last week the auditorium of Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Welfare Island echoed to excited laughter as a professional radio quizmaster took 150 patients' minds off the crippling chronic diseases with which they live from day to day.

ROME, Feb. 1--While British Foreign Secretary Bevin was driving through the streets of Naples this morning, after landing from the cruiser Birmingham, on his way back to London from the Commonwealth Conference in Colombo, Ceylon, some rotten eggs were thrown at him. Five persons, described as neo-Fascists were arrested.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1--Gov. Earl Warren today declared himself a candidate for a third term, insuring a political battle that will focus national attention on Cali fornia.

Helen Traubel and Kirsten Flagstad will both sing at the Metropolitan Opera next season and they will have equal status, Rudolf Bing announced yesterday. This came out at the crowded press conference at which he outlined the plans for his first season as ...

Plans for a new midtown business building were announced yesterday in connection with the resale by Nathan Wilson, operator, of the southwest corner of the Avenue of the Americas and Thirty-ninth Street to K.B. Weissman. Sigmund I. Natanson was the broker in the deal.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 1--Admiral William Henry Purnell Blandy, retiring from the Navy after forty years of service, turned over all his ships "afloat" today to Admiral William Morrow Fechteler, his successor as Commander-in-Chief, Atlantic and Atlantic Fleet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Civil Aeronautics Board, which in December announced that it wished to encourage charter flights to Europe this summer to accommodate Holy Year pilgrims to Rome, denied today a second application to operate such service.
Advertising of antihistamine preparations as "cold stoppers" was vigorously condemned yesterday by Dr. Morris Fishbein, former editor of the Journal of the American Medical Association.

BEDFORD, England, Feb. 1-- A young man who served his political apprenticeship under Winston Churchill arrived in Bedford today to start his campaign for election to Parliament as the Conservative party's candidate.

Former Secretary of War Kenneth C. Royall advocated yesterday that the United States enter into free commercial intercourse with Communist China to create "direct contact with the Chinese people and commercial sources of imports and exports upon which China will come to depend."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)-- Spokesmen for the United States textile and rubber industry today protested changes sought by Cuba in its tariff agreements with this country.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--New York City's share of $510,974,000 in appropriations recommended today by Governor Dewey for state assistance to local governments will be $256,979,000, an increase of $17,096,000 over the amount it receives under the current budget, it was disclosed here.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP)--Earl L. (Curly) Lambeau, dean of professional football coaches with thirtyone years as leader of the Green Bay Packers, today became head mentor of the Chicago Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Securities and Exchange Commission postponed again today for twenty-four hours further hearings on the proposed sale of 500,000 shares of common stock of the Pacific Power and Light Company, Portland, Ore., by the latter's parent, the American Power and Light Company, New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Administration's chief foreign policy spokesman in Congress, Senator Tom Connally of Texas, asserted today that he favored an attempt at new negotiations with the Russians toward international control of atomic weapons.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 1--A Polish move to keep Southern Korea's application for membership in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization off the agenda of next week's session of the Economic and Social Council was defeated today in a preliminary vote of 3 to 1.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 1-- The world ski championships (Federation Internationale de Ski), delayed two days, were opened today with brilliant sunshine and clear skies pitching in with a brilliant array of athletes in the jumping phase of the Nordic combined event, which also includes the 18kilometer cross-country test.

Many reservations have been received for the bridge and canasta party on the afternoon of Feb. 17 in the Colony Club for the benefit of the Ladies Helping Hand Association, which is marking the eighty-fifth anniversary of its ...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Congress was advised today that "energetic measures" were needed to strengthen the country's stockpiling of critical materials required in the event of war. The Munitions Board warned that any slackening in the procurement of key materials such as occurred last year would put the entire defense program in jeopardy.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1--The nation's leading meat packing concerns today denied they held monopoly powers in the industry. The denials were contained in answers to an anti-trust suit instituted by the Government in Federal District Court here.

The Board of Transportation approved yesterday a ten-year contract under which Sugar'N Spice, Inc., of 21 East Fortieth Street will sell baked goods and packaged ice cream on the mezzanine of the Eighth Avenue and Forty-second Street station of the IND division of the city subway system.
Twenty-five thousand laundry workers in the New York area have won what amounts to a guaranteed annual wage, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Soviet Ambassador Alexander S. Panyushkin proposed to the United States today that Emperor Hirohito and several other Japanese be tried as war criminals in an international court.

Promotion of trade with Europe in general and Germany in particular is a necessary adjunct to peace, Charles E. Bingham, former director of the foreign trade division of the Joint Export-Import Agency (JEIA) at Frankfort, declared yesterday.

Any woman who wants to get married today can find a husband, "unless she is deaf, dumb and blind." Dr. Margaret Mead, associate curator of ethnology at the American Museum of Natural History, declared yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 1 --The entire decartelization division of the United States High Commissioner's Office is to be strengthened and reorganized with a new chief, deputy chief and expert personnel, it was learned from authoritative sources today.

Newspapers again led all media in national advertising linage gains during December, it was reported yesterday by Printer's Ink. Outdoor was the only other medium to top its national volume for December, 1948.
Disposition of the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railway was postponed yesterday by Federal Judge Edward A. Conger until June 7.
Ray Robinson, world welterweight champion, will defend his title in Madison Square Garden before the end of the indoor season, if present plans materialize.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1--Defense counsel today told Federal Judge George B. Harris, "You ought to be ashamed of yourself," accused the court of misconduct and vainly demanded a mistrial as the Harry R. Bridges perjury-conspiracy trial approached a record mark for turbulence.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 1-- Gov. James H. Duff of Pennsylvania and five other Republican Governors joined in a demand today that the Republican party abandon "backward-looking" and "back-sliding" policies. They proposed a twelve-point rebuilding program along "progressive" lines.
Erik Braagaard's spring collection of hats was shown yesterday afternoon in his salon at 10 East Fifty-sixth Street. It offered a group for the young as well as a group for the mature woman.

S.H. Kress Co., which operates throughout the country a chain of 256 stores handling a variety of merchandise, had net earnings in 1949 of $10,048,204 after all charges, equal to $4.27 a share, the annual report, showed yesterday.
TRENTON, Feb. 1--Six persons, including two yound brothers from New York, were killed when two automobiles collided in the mist and rain at 7:15 P.M. today, on Route 25 near here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Senate approved today, by a vote of 64 to 27, three more than the necessary two-thirds, a Constitutional amendment to divide Presidential electoral votes among the candidates in proportion to their popular votes.

ON BOARD U.S.S. MISSOURI, Feb. 1--The U.S.S. Missouri, with battle ensigns flying and the ship's band playing the "Missouri Waltz," "Anchors Aweigh" and "Nobody Knows the Trouble I've Seen," was towed clear of Thimble Shoal shortly after dawn.
Charles C. Marrin of 120 West 183d Street, a member of the New York Bar since 1907, and a former Municipal Court justice in the Bronx, died yesterday in the Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Welfare ...

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 25--Leaders of the United States economic and diplomatic missions here are concerned over the trend toward centralized authority in the Korean Government. They often communicate that concern to leaders of the regime.

Whether the recent currency devaluations by Latin-American countries will help their economies to achieve a closer balance-in-payments relations with the United States will depend largely on the internal measures, fiscal and monetary, which those countries adopt, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York points out in its Monthly Review, issued yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 1--The beautifully tailored clothes shown at Robert Piquet's opening yesterday are, in his own words, "designed not to astonish but to please." His 1950 silhouette is stripped of all wings and points.

The private utility industry charged yesterday that the Tennessee Valley Authority's operations since 1933 have resulted in a "total loss of $119,579,000." For the fiscal year ended June 30, 1949, the loss was said to be $6,218,000.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1-- The American Federation of Labor laid plans today for the political campaign of 1950, confident that "the farm revolt will help us."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Civil Aeronautics Administration acted today to suspend the licenses of the flight crews of two commercial airliners involved in midair collisions. Two pilots and two copilots were charged by the CAA with "careless and reckless" flying.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1--Scattered liquidation developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, with all deliveries of rye selling at new seasonal lows. Long May wheat came into the pit persistently and there was a lack of aggressive buying at times, but with some stop-loss orders uncovered on the way down.

Pope Pius XII, President Truman and Governor Dewey sent messages to Fritz Kreisler last night that were read at the dinner at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in honor of the violinist's seventy-fifth birthday, which is today.

A lively debate between a Yale anthropologist and a Roman Catholic priest over tolerance of premarital sex relations and a priest's ability to give reliable sex guidance marked the thirty-seventh annual meeting of the American Social Hygiene Association yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel.

Commending the Tax Commission and its president, William E. Boyland, for showing "the most realistic and rational approach to the assessment problem in recent years," the Real Estate Board of New York yesterday said the new tentative assessed valuations for the city probably would result in a reduced number of court actions for review.

It has been estimated conservatively that about 57,000 Brooklyn school children need some form of psychiatric help. Of that number a little more than 1,000 are receiving the aid they need. Since it is not possible to produce the required number of additional clinics overnight, it is essential that ...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--President Truman started today a farreaching reorganization of the Panama Canal and requested Congress to complete the process by unifying its operation under a single new Panama Canal Company and allowing it to retain ship transit tolls.

Four new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. At the Victoria, the attraction is "The Third Man," a British-made melodrama featuring Joseph Cotten, Alida Valli, Orson Welles and Trevor Howard.

BERLIN, Feb. 1--Erratic handling of interzone truck traffic today at the Soviet zonal border check point at Helmstedt produced a tie-up of 170 vehicles this morning. Of the vans, 120 were eastbound and 50 west-bound.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Feb. 1-- The National Lutheran Council adopted a resolution late today calling upon Congress to pass an "amended and extended" displaced persons law that would include provisions for governmental payment of transportation costs within this country.

The so-called "February" sales of furniture in New York home furnishings stores have been uniformly successful so far, Manfred I. Behrens Jr., executive vice president of Ludwig Baumann, reported yesterday. He said most stores running the events during, the last two weeks had exceeded last year's figures.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Peace moves developed in the House today as Southern Democrats staged another roll-call "filibuster" to postpone or block a showdown on the civil rights bill to establish a permanant Fair Employment Practices Commission.

PARIS, Feb. 1--The European Marshall Plan Council adjourned today after what was generally considered its least productive session. The further steps toward freer trade and payments that had been asked by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, were left vague and for the future to determine.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 1--Having obtained pledges of loyalty to the regime from Roman Catholic priests, the Communist authorities of Czechoslovakia will concentrate during 1950 on political education of the clergy.
Shot-putters, weight throwers, pole vaulters and broad jumpers will settle their titles today in the outdoor phase of the metropolitan intercollegiate indoor track and field championships.

Norman C. Urquhart has been elected a director of Quemont Mining Corporation, Ltd., to fill the vacancy created by the death of the late J.H.C. Waite. At the same time, the election of H.L. Roscoe as president also was announced.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--Charges on the Senate floor today that insurance companies were discriminating against Negroes in the issuance of insurance policies led to a warning by Democratic legislators that a state insurance fund might have to be set up to provide residents of Harlem with the opportunity to buy adequate protection.
Russian recognition of Ho Chi Minh in French Indo-China brought an upswing yesterday in the prices of raw rubber in world markets.
Coin-operated train telephone systems are being developed for the nation's leading railroad lines and motor-generators for these installations are being made now.

The issue posed by the hydrogen bomb is whether we can run the spiritual risk of slaughtering others, rather than the physical risk of being slaughtered by the bomb, a group of thirty Christian theologians, ministers and educators declared here yesterday.

The first nation-wide drive by the liquor industry for equal consideration on removal of wartime excise taxes was started yesterday. The tax council of the industry met at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel with representatives from eight Eastern states and the District of Columbia in the first of six regional conferences to be held in key cities throughout the country.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 1 --The Citizens Committee of Westchester County Opposing New Gas Rates, Inc., said this afternoon it was ready to send rate experts before the Public Service Commission to contest the present gas charges of the Westchester Lighting Company and that the fight might be extended to electric rates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The overwhelming register of approval, by Congress, Bernard M. Baruch and others prominent in the national defense program, of the President's announcement yesterday that he had ordered the Atomic Energy Commission ...

WARSAW, Jan. 31--A thinly disguised announcement by the Minister of Public Administration. Wladyslaw Wolski, that the church and state talks had failed was followed today by the first overt step in the campaign aimed at converting ...

A question of perjury was raised yesterday by the defense in the Coplon-Gubitchev spy trial after a Government agent's admissions concerning wire-tapping were checked against testimony he had given in a Washington court last May.

Saks-34th imbued the waldorfAstoria with a springlike air yesterday with such highlights of the season as checks, the cape costume, shirtwaist frock, chemise dress with cover-up jacket and navy frosted with white. Topping off the array were two Molyneux originals presented with the store's own budget-wise copies.

Foreign traders were urged yesterday to refrain from doing business with the North China Import Company, a Communist agency. The recommendation was made by John F. McKiernan, director of the New York regional office of the Department of Commerce at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau in the Statler Hotel.

The House Foreign Affairs Committee has approved by a vote of 17 to 1 a new bill authorizing the expenditure of the $60,000,000 remaining in this year's program of aid for Korea. The committee's action is the first move in ...

Much of the friendly spirit that had marked the negotiations between tug boat owners and workers here was dissipated early yesterday when, at the close of an all-night meeting, the union representatives threatened a walkout on Sunday night.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance of "La Boheme" on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Manhattanville College Scholarship Fund. Miss Carmen de Arango of New York ...

The net worth of national and local unions in the American labor movement is probably $3,000,000,000 to $4,000,000,000, an economist reported yesterday after a survey of union statements and other data.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 1-- A Stamford psychiatrist testified in Superior Court here today that Carol Paight went insane instantly when she heard that her father suffered from an inoperable cancer and that she still was insane when she shot and killed him later the same day, last Sept. 23.

Lower income taxes and greater use of excise taxation--in the form of a flat-rate purchase tax--to produce an equal proportion of Federal revenue were urged yesterday by Dr. Harley Lutz, tax consultant to the National Association of Manufacturers.
Although the volume of trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderate yesterday, prices held steady and were unchanged to 8 points higher at the close than on Tuesday.

HAVANA, Feb. 1--Shillalah, sailed by E.W. Etchells of the West Long Island Sound Fleet, crossed the finish line first today in the second race for the Cuba Cup of the nineteenth International Star Class Regatta.

A national campaign for public subscriptions to build a $500,000 all-religion chapel at the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., as a permanent memorial to merchant mariners lost in war service, was announced yesterday by a committee of shipping officials and other business men.
The State of California sold yesterday $25,000,000 of war veterans' benefit bonds maturing from Feb. 1, 1952, to 1971 at an interest cost of about 1.655 per cent.

Plans for the erection of a new building with luxury apartments to replace a vacant East Side structure were disclosed yesterday when the sale of 4 to 10 East Eightyninth Street by the Fifth Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street Corporation, a subsidiary of the City Investing Company, to the Nearpark Realty Corporation, Leon Lane, president, was announced.

Demand for United States Steel shares at the opening of the stock market yesterday generated a short-lived boom in prices. Once the buying slowed, the list turned easier and remained so through to the close.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Secretary of State Dean Acheson made it plain today that Britain's proposed embargo on dollar oil imports was unacceptable to the United States Government. He suggested measures could yet be devised to conserve British dollar resources without injury to legitimate interests of United States companies.

The old story of the beggar dying and leaving a lot of bank books showing big deposits was told again yesterday, but with a new twist. This beggar, who had admitted he was a professional panhandler, died in Bellevue Hospital ten days ago without signing the will his lawyer had had in preparation for two years.
Is Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler preparing his guns for a broadside against certain major league clubs that may be "cutting corners" on the March 1 spring training restrictive regulation?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)-- Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson today ordered eighteen military hospitals in the United States closed or changed in status. He estimated the move would save $25,000,000 a year.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--Governor Dewey today submitted to the Legislature a budget calling for new appropriations of $861,722,633 for the next fiscal year, a reduction of $77,565,011 from the amount voted for the current year. The state's fiscal year runs from April 1 to March 31.
Senate approval yesterday of the constitutional amendment to alter the procedure of electing the President was a progressive step in modernizing our political structure.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1--Mutual confidence between investor and recipient country is the key to a favorable climate for American private investment in Latin-American countries, Edward G. Miller Jr., Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said here today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 1--Cornelius Clarkson Vermeule, former public works engineer for the Republic of Cuba and designer of many municipal water systems, died here today in Middlesex Hospital. He was 91 years old.

In spite of the intermittent rain and snow that pelted the city yesterday, precipitation during the day in the Catskill and Croton watershed was described as "negligible." Water officials described the day's water gains as "very disappointing."

"Arms and the Girl," the new musical which the Theatre Guild is producing in association with Anthony Brady Farrell, will open this evening at 8 o'clock at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. Nanette Fabray and Georges Guetary are co-starred, and John Conte and ...
The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York opened its 1950 campaign yesterday morning with a breakfast at the Astor Hotel for 500 men and women who will lead the drive.

Lifting of the "freeze" on the authorization of new television stations by the Federal Communications Commission was urged last night by David B. Smith, vice president of the Philco Corporation. He declared that two-thirds of the country's population was being denied video because expansion of the industry had been stopped nearly seventeen months ago.

Dr. M. Maxim Steinbach, a specialist in pulmonary diseases, and a research associate in bacteriology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, died yesterday in his home at 88 Central Park West, after a brief illness. His age was 57.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Henry F. Grady, United States Ambassador to Athens, predicted today "new records" in production and reconstruction would be made in Greece this year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Youth must be helped to grow into maturity of mind for sheer survival, Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau, told the Advisory Committee on State and Local Action of the Mid-Century White House Child Conference today. The conference will be held in December.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 1--When he returned from Changteh in midDecember, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek turned over to Premier Yen Hsi-shan the entire Chinese Nationalist gold reserve, "enough to last more than one year at the present expenditure rate," with instructions to "use it prudently and wisely for the benefit of the nation."

LOUIS PASTEUR (1822-1895) is a Bronze Beard on a monument now. In the popular American imagination he is the other great French scientist, since he obviously is not one of the radium-wreathed Curies. We honor him, in an absent-minded way, when his name comes up in an evening's talk, and remember him, dimly, ...

The first distinguished service medals of the United States Lines to be awarded since the war were presented yesterday to the master, second officer and twelve members of the crew of the cargo ship Pioneer Sea in a brief ceremony aboard the vessel at Pier 17, Staten Island.

In a "hot" nuclear reactor a fraction of a second in timing spells the difference between a disastrous atomic explosion and the controlled release of the great power within the atom for the benefit of mankind.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--The Assembly Agriculture Committee killed all bills today that would have lifted the state ban against the sale of colored oleomargarine. It also rejected a suggestion for public hearings on the repeal proposals.

Sales by New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an average decline of 5.5 per cent in January, compared with the corresponding month last year, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

SALERNO, Fla., Feb. 1--Shark fishing never seems to come under the heading of sport except when the Mako is involved, and it is surprising how many of the common, garden variety of sharks are identified by rod and reel anglers as "Makos."

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1--On Dec. 15 at Tropical Park an Argentinebred 4-year-old named Chicle II made his first North-of-theEquator start with a $7,500 claiming tag on him, J.H. (Slim) Pierce, trainer for the Palatine Stable, liked his looks and put a slip in the box for him. Now there's another stakes-winner in the Palatine barn.

Asserting that the present functions of the City Planning Commission represent only a small fraction of those intended for it, Jerry Finkelstein, chairman of the agency, asked yesterday that his staff and budget be more than tripled to permit proper planning for a city "in a critical stage of its development."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Feb. 1-- John Chase, a vice president and a director of Pease Elliman, Inc., real estate firm at 660 Madison Avenue, New York, died today at the Huntington Hospital after a brief illness. Mr. Chase, who was 71 years old, resided at Fernwood, his estate at Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--In estimating the State's tax revenues for the new fiscal year that will start April 1, Governor Dewey has assumed there will be more cigarette smoking, liquor consumption and automobile driving than in the preceding year.

Eight months of negotiations between officials of the Bethlehem Steel Companys shipbuilding division and workers in eight of its East Coast shipyards came to a successful close early yesterday morning with the announcement that an agreement had been reached on pensions and welfare.

In a quick turnover after a brief ownership, two eleven-story loft buildings on plot 75 by 120 feet at 830-34 Broadway, between Twelfth and Thirteenth Streets, have been resold by Henry Goelet, operator, to the Bennington Corporation, manufacturer of undergarments, who plans to use large space in the structures.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 (AP)--The New York State Commerce Department today issued this report of winter sports conditions:
ALBANY, Feb. 1--New York City firemen renewed their efforts today to pave the way for increasing their permanent salary schedules by means of a referendum.

The prison walls close in on the unhappy citizen of Czechoslovakia, once a friendly and gregarious fellow in lively correspondence with his brothers and cousins in Chicago and London, Paris and Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--A Far Eastern economic assistance bill, embracing aid for both the Repubic of Korea and the Chinese Nationalist Government in Formosa, was cleared to the House floor today by the Rules Committee after a strong bipartisan appeal was made for it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 25, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--John L. Lewis and soft coal operators tried bargaining again today while fighting each other in court. The negotiations were fruitless and the court case was continued until next week.

Governor Dewey holds the line and even reduces somewhat the costs of operating the state government in his new budget for 1950-51. This is a sizable achievement in these times, on any level of government, won by selfrestraint and a resolute closing of the door against the temptation to new adventures ...

This is a sizable achievement in these times, on any level of government, won by selfrestraint and a resolute closing of the door against the temptation to new adventures ...

ALBANY, Feb. 2 New York City would be authorized to set up a parking authority for the construction of parking facilities under a bill introduced in the Legislature today at the request of Mayor William O'Dwyer.

PARIS, Feb. 2 Even after the end of the Marshall Plan the dollar shortage will compel Western Europe to limit its imports from North America, according to the annual report of the European Marshall Plan Council. The report was made to Paul G. Hoffman,...

ALBANY, Feb. 2 Ways to get around the decision yesterday of the Assembly Agriculture Committee to scrap all proposals to repeal the state's ban against the sale of colored oleomargarine were chartered today by legislators incensed over the committee's action.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 2 New regulations to curb automobile thefts and sex crimes were advocated today by the November grand jury of Westchester in a resolution filed with County Judge Elbert T. Gallagher.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2 Ol' Skipper, owned by John Marsch of Chicago, did another Handsome bit of front-running at Hialeah Park today. He covered six furlongs in 1:10, fastest time of the meeting, en route to a seven-furlong victory in 1:23, only three-fifths of a second slower than the track record.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 2 Freedom of the press is being defended, and not attacked, in Argentina by the special Congressional commission that has closed more than fifty daily papers, Democracia, a leading Peronista newspaper, declared today.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP) Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth, Tex., and Miss Bea McWane of Birmingham, Ala., won their firstround match in the women's international four-ball golf tournament today. They defeated Miss Carol Diringer of Tiffin, Ohio, and Miss Mary Agnes Wall of Menominee, Mich., 2 and 1.

Accessories are more important, possibly, to the fashion world this year than ever before. With dresses shorter, slimmer and barer, jewelry, flowers, colorful sashes, long gloves and separate stoles are integral parts of the spring and summer wardrobe. This was the...
Downstairs in the dance studio of the New School, 66 West Twelfth Street, a dozen little boys and girls beat on drums, jangled bells, shook tambourines and assorted rattles.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 2 About fifty Prague businessmen, including the proprietors of some of the city's few remaining deluxe restaurants, have been arrested and sent to labor camps.

The Democratic State Committee has awarded seven interneships to college students throughout the state in a new program designed to acquaint young persons with the procedures of a political party, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, chairman of the committee, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Creation of a country-wide system of private banking corporations devoted exclusively to meeting the financial needs of small or independent businesses was proposed in a bill introduced today by Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat, of Wyoming.

Directors of A. DePinna Company, at a special meeting yesterday, elected John C. Wood president of the Fifth Avenue specialty store, which was purchased last month by Julius Garfinckel Co., Inc., operators of the Washington, D.C., department store.

A detective with a penchant for Chinese miniatures posed as an antique dealer to bring about the arrest of a self-styled surrealist artist who, it was alleged yesterday in Felony Court, had stolen $1,000 worth of rare books from Brentano's.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 2 Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion has sharply rebuked eleven American national rabbinical and religious organizations that had cabled him demanding immediate action to revise the policy in immigrant camps which they contended had been anti-religious.

Lack of picture rights isn't a drawback to Shepard Traube whenever he feels the urge to do a play he likes. Notwithstanding the absence of potential revenue, he went ahead with such a thriller-diller as Patrick Hamilton's "Angel Street," which rewarded him with a marathon...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 All but two cash bids, one for $16,125,000 and another for $15,125,000, made for 500,000 shares of the common stock of the Pacific Power and Light Company, Portland, Ore., were rejected today by the letter's parent, the American Power and Light Company, New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 A plan designed to strengthen the power of the United Nations by by-passing the veto in the Security Council was urged on a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee today.

The Rembrandt loan exhibition at the Wildenstein Galleries, being held for the benefit of the Public Education Association, will be open to the public on Sunday from noon to 5:30 P.M. The admission charge is 60 cents.

Duluth, Minn., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Feb. 15 on $2,400,000 of independent school district bonds dated June 1, 1949 and due June 15, 1956.

The League of Women Voters of New York is going "barnstorming" little-theatre style to put over its battle for permanent personal registration, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 28, 1950, amounted to 636,415 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

TOKYO, Feb. 2--The United States naval forces in the Pacific will be made as "strong as possible with the means available," Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, Chief of Naval Operations,... said today. Admiral Sherman made his statement at a press conference today for Japanese and foreign correspondents, at which the four United States Joint Chiefs of Staff on an inspection trip here spoke.

T. Arthur Pyterman, a retired vice president of the Chase National Bank and a former deputy superintendent of the New York State Banking Department, died yesterday in his home in Northport. L. I. He was 62 years old.

Several passengers using the trains on the Oyster Bay and Greenport branches of the Long Island Rail Road charged that their train service was inadequate at a Public Service Commission hearing yesterday. Examiner Harold N. Olmsted presided.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 President Truman nominated Paul L. Styles, of Huntsville, Ala., today to serve a five-year term as a member of the National Labor Relations Board.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 2 Disclosures of bribery and favoritism in denazification courts around Stuttgart have caused such a stir that the United States High Commissioner's Office will step into the case next week, following the return of High Commissioner John J. McCloy from the United States, it was indicated today.

William S. Kies of 430 East Fifty-seventh Street and Scarborough, N.Y., a vice president of the National City Bank of New York, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital, where he had been taken after becoming ill in his office on Wednesday. His age was 72.
SANTIAGO. Chile, Feb. 2 (AP) President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla issued an ultimatum tonight to Chile's thousands of strikers to return to their jobs tomorrow morning.
PARIS, Feb, 2 Balenciaga presents a spectacular and colorful collection, with the accent on white cotton, pique and shantungs for suits and dresses and lace and taffeta for afternoon and evening.
Missing since Christmas Eve, Louis Chazen, 39-year-old bookkeeper, was indicted yesterday in a fifty-count true bill that alleged he had stolen $252,918 from his employers over the last two years.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 (AP) Ralph Kiner, Pittsburgh's homerun clouting outfielder, today signed a two-year contract at $65,000 a season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 The United States threatened today "counter measures," including a renewal of the airlift, against the Soviet Union's transport restrictions on road and rail traffic moving between Western Germany and Berlin.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 The annual silver sailfish derby, sponsored by the West Palm Beach Fishing Club, is now in full swing, and despite the inclement sailfishing weather the anglers are turning out and are bringing in quite a few nice fish.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Feb. 2--With few exceptions, every displaced person brought to this country under the auspices of the National Lutheran Council has turned out to be "generous, industrious and pleasant," it was reported here today at the council's thirty-second annual meeting.

The dignity of man needs reaffirmation in the arts, and poetry will be the "mouthpiece of that restored dignity, Robert Hillyer, Pulitzer Prize poet, declared last night at the fortieth anniversary dinner of the Poetry Society of America at Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue.
PINCONNING, Mich., Feb. 2 (AP) A daring pilot, flying a light plane in gusty weather, today snatched twelve stranded ice fishermen from possible death on a floe in Saginaw Bay.

Isaac L. Kashdan, co-champion of the United States with Samuel Reshevsky in 1942, will not play for America against Yugoslavia in the chess match by radio, Feb. 1114, it was announced at a press conference at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday.

New York University has come up with a new football coach, one whose status in the game indicates that the gridiron fortunes of the trampled Violets may soon improve.
Dividend action on the common stock of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway was deferred by directors yesterday until their meeting scheduled for May 25, it was announced.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 2 (AP) Nine college ski teams will have their first major test of the winter tomorrow and Saturday in competing for the Dartmouth Winter Carnival title.

A "strike" of the city's public high school athletic coaches started yesterday when two of them refused to participate in the first basketball game of the spring term. Their action is expected to be followed by other coaches today when twenty-one scheduled games are played.

With Manhattan favored to dethrone New York University in a close varsity team battle, the eighth annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track and field championships will bring upward of 300 varsity and freshman athletes into spirited competition at the Third Engineer Group Armory tonight.

Stebbins Jr., chairman of the board of trustees, announced Dr. Greene's resignation and the appointment of Jerome H. Bentley, treasurer of the college, as acting president.

Starting Monday morning, careless citizens who are found littering mid-Manhattan streets will be summoned to "tell it to the judge."

Hope of averting an operating deficit on the municipal transit lines in their second year of operation at the higher fares in effect since July 1, 1948, were dimmed yesterday when the Board of Transportation reported a deficit of $1,467,828 for the six months ended Dec. 31, 1949.

Saigh, president of the Cardinals, said today he would protest to Baseball Commissioner Albert Chandler the signing of Paul Pettit, 18-year-old high school boy, by the Pirates for a reported $100,000 bonus. Saigh described the action of the Pittsburgh Club as an "outrageous evasion" of the baseball bonus and high school rules.

Morgan Stanley Co. heads a group of seventy-six underwriters for an offering today of 454,457 common shares of the Consumers Power Company to 22,000 stockholders and 7,000 employes, to net the company $15,156,140.

Wadlin, Republican, of Ulster, chairman of the Labor Committee.
The city's fifth water holiday yesterday appeared to have resulted in a city-wide consumption of 837,000,000 gallons, 5,000,000 gallons more than on last week's Dry Thursday.

LEICESTER, England, Feb. 2 A large part of the solid hope behind the Conservative leaders' prediction of success in the forthcoming British general election obviously springs from their faith in a greatly expanded and professionally directed party machine, which will be rolling out this week-end in constituencies throughout the country.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 2 This pleasant industrial city, which in 1895 pioneered in providing electric power, soon will decide whether to make a public utility of the milk business. If the choice is affirmative, the city will process and deliver fluid milk, ice cream, cottage cheese, chocolate milk and possibly other dairy products in this vicinity.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 President Truman has told all departments and agencies who know anything about the hydrogen bomb to lock their files and button their lips.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Senator Pat McCarran. Democrat, of Nevada, introduced two restrictive amendments to the Displaced Persons Act today. He served notice in a Senate speech that he would press for their adoption when a pending bill to liberalize the present statute came up for action.

PARIS, Feb. 2 Christian Dior returns to straight lines, stripped of all projecting phenomena, in his spring collection, shown yesterday. But with this simplicity in line he returns also to the fine detail and fabulous workmanship legendary with the French couture.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Feb. 22 With the British general election only three weeks away the political campaign in Scotland still is in low gear. The country's 3,400,000 electors are showing such singular lack of interest in the general issues that they have the political leaders somewhat worried and the forecasters puzzled.

Mrs. Clara DeWolf Ward of 26 Metropolitan Oval, the Bronx, who had been a nurse, teacher and settlement house worker, died on Thursday in New York Hospital after an illness of three months. She was 71 years old.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 5-- Dr. Charles Seymour, president of Yale University, told his alumni bluntly today that the university was in serious financial straits and needed funds to prevent its "excellence" from slipping into "mediocrity."

Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard disclosed yesterday that in the last month he and his family--six in all--had been living on a "relief food budget." He also announced that of its $124.50 "allowance," the family had saved $28.54, thus actually spending only 95.96 for food.

LONDON, Feb. 5--South Africa recently has passed through a severe economic crisis but it looks here as though the devaluation of sterling is going to nave an important effect in the country's return to economic health, despite failure to induce the United States to raise the dollar price of gold.

Four men and five women, gathered about a luncheon table yesterday, lifted their glasses in a toast to Aaron Burr. They wished that he might rest in peace. But they admitted it might be a difficult task for so maligned a soul to accomplish.

Miss Janet MacRorie of 17 East Eleventh Street, a leader in the establishment of standards for the acceptability of radio scripts, died in the Wickersham Hospital on Saturday night. She was 60 years old.
In its 1950 appeal for funds the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross presents a call for aid that no resident of this city will want to ignore.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 5 --In blistering language, the Economic Cooperation Administration Mission for Germany denounced West German economic plans for a second time, describing the leaders of the Bonn regime as lacking the experience, foresight and courage to achieve recovery.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 5--The Government officially unveiled today a development plan envisaging Israel as a nation of 2,500,000, including 1,000,000 in the cities of Jerusalem, Tel Aviv and Haifa, 1,000,000 in smaller cities in Galilee and the Negeb, and 500,000 in agriculture.
The amount of water in the city's reservoirs declined by 137,000,000 gallons in the twenty-fourhour period ended at 8 A.M yesterday.

The contract bridge masters en tered the fifth and last long session of play for the life masters' and senior masters' individual championships in the American Contract Bridge League's tournament at the Park Sheraton Hotel last night. The play continued into the early hours this morning.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 5--Appointment of Dirk U. Stikker, Dutch Foreign Minister, as political director of the organization for European Economic Cooperation, has been welcomed to Amsterdam financial quarters.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5--Accidents in 1949 claimed the lives of 91,000 men, women and children in the United States of whom 31,500 were killed in motor vehicle mishaps, according to an announcement today by the National Safety Council.

The changes that the Senate Judiciary Committee made in the Houseapproved Displaced Persons bill were almost entirely to the bad--although, as we have previously noted, it is encouraging that the measure is now at least out of the committee's clutches and can be debated and improved on the Senate floor.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 5 (AP)--A daredevil United States team careened down the treacherous Cortina course in record time today to retain the world four-man bobsled championship.
Adoption of a stronger policy for peace was urged on President Truman yesterday in a letter signed by 159 prominent citizens in twenty-eight states and the District of Columbia.

PARIS, Feb. 5--Imports of crude oil in 1949 by France, according to official figures, totaled 11,783,000 tons, of which 53.5 per cent was paid for in dollars, 40.2 per cent in pounds sterling, while 6.3 per cent is the share of France in the output of the Iraq Petroleum Company and was obtained with francs.
Persons who are looking for indications of how the Point Four program for aiding the peoples of underdeveloped areas can be worked out will attach some importance to recent reports from Liberia.

Fewer buyers were in the market last week, with the bulk of buying already completed for spring, but warm weather brought requests for earlier deliveries, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
RICHLAND, Wash., Feb. 5 (UP) --Cancellation of a business lease in this Government-controlled atomic-energy city was announced yesterday by William (Bill) Simonds, head of the Richland Motor Company.

THE Baseball Writers Association performed a public service at the Waldorf last night. Aware of the fact that most of their dinner guests had been unable to buy tickets for the smash Broadway theatre hits, they brought the mountain to Mahomet. They gave them glimpses of such productions as South Pacific, Detective Story, Death of a Salesman, Where's Charley and Mister Roberts. Naturally, there were trifling changes made in dialogue, characters, lyrics, locale and what-not.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 30--The administration of this 3,500-squaremile British crown colony of strategic importance in the eastern Mediterranean asserts that within a radius of 1,000 miles no people are as well governed or as well off as the Cypriots, numbering 450,000 and rapidly growing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--President Truman was reported preparing tonight to invoke the Taft-Hartley Act tomorrow in the soft coal dispute and appoint David L. Cole of Paterson, N.J., as chairman of a board of inquiry.
TRENTON, Feb. 5 (AP)--Democratic party leaders today invited residents of New Jersey to "express their views on legislative matters" at a hearing in the State House on Feb. 15.

Only the "united impact" of the churches of Christ will be able to prevent the destruction threatened by the scientific inventions of man, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, minister of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, warned yesterday.
HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Feb. 5-- Walter Frederick Hoffman, rector of St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church here since 1928, died today of a heart attack at his home, 23 Gurnee Avenue. He was 58 years old.

One hundred and fifteen works contributed by 103 contemporary American artists and valued at $30,000 went on display yesterday in the brownstone home of Mrs. Clarence Day, widow of the author of "Life With Father," at 166 East Sixty-first Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)--A group representing United States business interests filed strong objections today to the proposal for Government guarantee of American "point four" investments abroad.
Five new films, including Italian and Russian importations, are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP)-- The Agriculture Department said today the world hunger problem now had reached the point where marketing, rather than production, was the biggest headache.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5--General liquidation developed in the grain markets on the Board of Trade last week, with September and December wheat and corn and all deliveries of rye selling at new seasonal lows. May wheat, meanwhile, dropped to the lowest price since last September, breaking out of a narrow range for the first time in six weeks.

The year-and-a-half-old "freeze" by the Federal Communications Commission on the authorization of new television stations may soon jeopardize the jobs of thousands of New Jersey workers, according to Dr. Allen B. Du Mont, president of the video laboratories bearing his name.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 5-- Some 6,000 automobile dealers and other representatives of the automotive industry from all parts of the country were pouring into this resort today for the annual convention of the National Automobile Dealers Association which opens tomorrow and the equipment exhibition of the N.A.D.A. which opened today.
In keeping with the trend to shorter skirts and the emphasis on accessories, the shoes in Saks' spring collection would make the foot a focal paint of any woman's ensemble.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 5--Dr. Allison Williams Bunkley, an assistant professor at Princeton University and a brilliant young authority on Hispanic culture, shot and killed himself late last night while demonstrating the macabre game of Russian roulette.

The marriage of Miss Anna Mae Melvin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman C. Melvin of Baltimore, to Charles Bingham Boies Penrose, son of Boies Penrose of Devon, Pa., and Baroness Louis de Chollet of Paris, will take place on Feb. 18 in the Franklin Street Presbyterian Church, Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy is considering the possibility of having Dr. Klaus Fuchs extradited to this country to answer charges that he delivered atomic secrets to the Russians, including secrets of the hydrogen bomb.

RUMFORD, Me., Feb. 5 (AP)--Martin Lundstroem, Olympic champion at 18 kilometers (11 miles), gave Sweden such a big edge in the third lap of the world ski relay today that his country ran off with the prize.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)-- Pan American World Airways told the Civil Aeronautics Board today that its proposed purchase of American Overseas Airlines would save money and strengthen the "competitive pattern" across the Atlantic.
Federal Mediator Cyrus S. Ching came here yesterday to direct efforts being made by the Government to avert the threatened walkout Wednesday at 6 A.M. by 320,000 telephone workers in the nation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)--Colonial Airlines announced tonight that it would drop a fight in the Supreme Court to keep TransCanada Airlines from competing with it on the New York-Montreal route.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 5-- Discharge of general cargo at the port of Providence will be revived Feb. 14, when the John B. Waterman is scheduled to call here and unload 2,300,000 board feet of...
By bringing the inspiration of God into everyday affairs, the world will revert to the status it once knew and enjoyed, Msgr, Fulton J. Sheen said yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

MIDDLETOWN, N.J., Feb. 5-- A new $15,000 Sunday school and recreation hall adjacent to historic Christ Protestant Episcopal Church on Kings Highway here will be dedicated formally tomorrow night at Leeds Hall in honor of William Leeds, a wealthy planter two centuries ...

A delegation of the International Seamen's Recreation Committee has asked Deputy Mayor William Reid for permission to use a cityowned vacant lot at Thirty-sixth Street and Second Avenue in Brooklyn as a playing field for seamen's sports events, it was announced yesterday.

In its first change of ownership since 1923, the six-story apartment house for fifty families at 222 East Fortieth has been sold by Mary G. West to Kingwood Estates, Inc., represented by Emil Rogers, attorney.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Noted psychiatrists, meeting here today under the auspices of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, pronounced mental health this country's "No. 1 health problem." They agreed that mental health in the United States affected "more people than all other types of illnesses combined."

John J. McCloy, American High Commissioner in Germany, made a major policy speech in Stuttgart yesterday, criticizing sharply the recent revival of German nationalist and even nazist tendencies. He warned that the West-...

Members of the International Longshoremen's Association. AFL, returned to work on the Cunard erminal at West Fourteenth Street at 10 A.M. yesterday, after a fiveday strike in protest against the alleged shifting of a freighter to the company's West Fiftieth Street pier.

Rex Harrison has withdrawn as the director of the Erik MartinCharles Colhy comedy, "House on the Cliff." The official reason given by the press department was that Mr. Harrison had been ordered by his physician to "take a complete rest."

The office phone rings and the newspaper reader asks, "Is cooked lamb, which was refrigerated three clays ago, still safe to eat?" Our home economist hesitates. Even though she receives more questions on the storage and subsequent edibility of perishables than on any other subiect, she still finds them

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 President Truman invoked the TaftHartley Act against John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers today as the soft-coal strike became almost complete and virtually ended bituminous production.
RUMFORD, Me. Feb. 6 (AP) Gunnar Eriksson,never a Champion in his native-Sweden,became the world ski marathon titleholder today.

A deportation hearing against Mrs. Beatrice Siskind Johnson, educational director of the New York State Communist party, was completed yesterday after she took the stand in her own defense and declared that the party did not advocate the forcible overthrow of the Gover nment,

PARIS, Feb. B Maggy Rouff shows the middy blouse silhouette in a few suit jackets and twopiece frocks. The jacket, of course, buttons up the front but three buttons low on the side seams draw attention to the fact that the jacket hugs the hipline but not the waistline.
ALBANY, Feb. 6 Governor Dewey signed today a bill to extend the life of the Temporary Commission on Agriculture for another year, a move that had been vigorously opposed by the Democratic minority.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 6 Britain proposed today that the United Nations revoke the privilege of nine international organizations to place topics on the agenda of the Economic and Social Council after charging that one of these agencies the World Federation of Trade Unions had abused the privilege for "propaganda" purposes.

The City College baseball team opened preseason practice yesterday at the college's Tech gymnasium. Thirty-three players, including eleven letter men, reported to Coach Sol Mishkin for the start of seven weeks of indoor training.

Advertising and printed matter generally play a key part in determining management decisions on purchases of industrial supplies and equipment, according to a survey covering eight industries presented yesterday at a meeting of the Industrial Advertising Association of New York in the BelmontPlaza Hotel.

The current trend to increase the Federal Government's controls over banking and credit policies could lead to efforts to attain expanded regulatory powers over the trust business and to "confiscatory rates of estate taxes," F. Raymond Peterson, president of the American Bankers Association, warned yesterday.

PARIS, Tuesday, Feb. 7 Premier Georges Bidault will seek Parliamentary approval today for a revamped Cabinet, with former Premier Henri Queuille, a Radical, as Minister of the Interior, to succeed Jules Moch, Socialist.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 High Commissioner John J. McCloy's "straight from the shoulder" message in Stuttgart today was viewed here as a correct statement of official United States thinking on Germany and the Germans.

The $25,000,000 ship repair appropriation that failed to achieve passage at the last session of Conhress is now the object of a combined drive by maritime industry management and labor and various Government officials, it became known yesterday.

Reporting on operations last year of the National Distillers Products Corporation, Seton Porter, chairman, and John E, Bierwirth, president, informed its 38,405 shareholders that sales had expanded over the previous year's volume but that earnings declined about 10 per cent, chiefly because of larger selling costs.

IN many of its aspects at the time it was fought the Battle of Crete was unique. Nothing like it had even been seen before. It was the first large-scale air-borne attack in the annals of war. The German Air Corps represented the flame of the Hitler Youth Movement and was an ardent embodiment of the Teutonic spirit of revenge for the defeat of 1918.
The Sadlers Wells Ballet from the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, London, will return for a second American season, beginning at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sept. 10.
BOSTON, Feb. 6 The Waltham (Mass.) Watch Company gained today a temporary respite when Federal Judge George C. Sweeney deferred for ten days action on a reorganization plan presented by the concern.

The Federation of American Scientists has called upon President Truman to re-examine this nation's position in the matter of international control of atomic energy and to "matte a fresh start, looking toward a policy which offers some real hope of breaking the present stubborn deadlock" between Russia and the West.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J., Feb. 6 The Continental Paper Company announced today that it was closing its $16,000,000 plant here as the result of a labor dispute that had kept it idle for the last seven months. Five hundred employes are affected.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 Assemblyman Sharon Mauhs, Schoharie Democrat and a Guernsey cattle breeder, tonight defended the action of the Assembly Agriculture Committee in Killing all bills that would permit the sale of colored oleomargarine in New York.

Sales of New York and Brookyn department stores showed a decrease of 5 per cent for the week ended Feb. 4, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the four weeks ended on that date the decline under a year ago was 4 per cent.
A Department of Justice official told a jury yesterday how he had helped bait the trap for Judith Coplon, one of his aides, twelve hours before her arrest on charge of spying for the Soviet Union.

The stock market found it extremely difficult yesterday to chart a definite course, and, for the first time in more than a week, expressed price-wise concern over the nation's dwindling coal supplies.

Developments in the long-drawn-out coal dispute had reached the point yesterday where President Truman literally had no choice but to invoke, as he did, the so-called emergency provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act.

STORRS, Conn., Feb. 6 (AP) Arthur L. Valpey today was named the University of Connecticut's new head football coach, effective March 1. He had served in a similar capacity at Harvard for the last two seasons.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) Attorney General McGrath today announced a blanket indictment at Kansas City charging a criminal anti-trust conspiracy in the sale and distribution of used storage batteries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 The declaration of Republican party principles which was issued by a drafting committee today reveals on inspection the flaws of diction that inevitably appear when author ship is multiple. The document also is devoid of light touches.
ALBANY, Feb. 6 (AP) The State Commerce Department today reported good skiing at three centers and fair at five others.
QUEMOY ISLAND, China, Feb. 6 Mme. Chiang Kai-shek flew to the warfront today bearing fold, cigarettes and New Testaments for Nationalist China's troops and wreaths for the braves of soldiers.

A sixteen-day postponement of the threatened strike affecting 320,000 telephone workers hung in the balance last night. Acting on a proposal of Cyrus S. Ching, Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service director, the executive board of the Communication Workers of America, CIO, was being polled across the country on whether to accept the delay.

James E. Craig, former chief editorial writer for The New York Sun, has been named managing editor of The Protestant World, national interdenominational weekly newspaper scheduled for publication early next fall, it was announced yesterday.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Feb. 6 (AP) The first new coach in thirty-one years signed a three-year contract today with the Green Bay Packers.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 6-A general strike in the country's soft coal fields was the reply given by members of the United Mine Workers today to President Truman's request for voluntary restoration of "normal" coal production.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Eugene J. Earley, who was assistant to Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, during the second World War, died here Saturday in George Washington University Hospital. His age was 53.
