BUENOS AIRES, Feb 6 Two United States citizens and an Englishman were under arrest here today under mysterious circumstances, which added to the already increasing belief that the Government was on the verge of announcing a new conspiracy.

The Port of New York Authority told the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday that it strongly recommended mail, passenger and express service by helicopters in the metropolitan area. It offered to provide a landing area atop the new bus terminal it is building on Eighth Avenue between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets.
A red-hot Wagner basketball team turned back the favored Fordham quintet, 57-53, in a contest staged before 1,000 at the Rams' gymnasium last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6-President Trttman endorsed today a proposed change in the Securities Act of 1934 that would make some of the major provisions of the act applicable to all unregistered corporations having assets of at least $3,000,000 and no less than 300 stockholders.

The contract bridge masters assembled in New York for their annual national championship tournaments entered their fourth day of play yesterday. Twenty-eight pairs were competing for the life masters' pair championship at the Parlc-Sheraton Hotel, and fifty-two teams were entered in the Harold S. Vantlerbilt Cup contest for the national knock out team-of-four title at the Pierre.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6 The International Association of Machinists, which left the American Federation of Labor five years ago, will be invited to reaffiliate unconditionally after sixty days, the AFL Executive Council decided here this afternoon.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 6 Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's views on the hydrogen bomb narrow down to a simple choice, he indicated today. Asked at a press conferenre to comment on the superweapon, he said:
UPTON, L.I., Feb. 6 Workers in atomic energy installations and research laboratories are good insurance risks at standard industrial rates, speakers reported here today.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 In a special message to the Legislature Governor Dewey tonight requested that the State Youth Commission be continued in existence for another three years and that it receive broader powers to combat juvenile delinquency.

Erna Berger's song recital last night in Carnegie Hall, when she made her American debut as a concert singer, had been preceded by her triumphs as Sophie in "Rosenkavalier" and Gilda in "Rigoletto" at the Metropolitan,...

Coming to the support of the city's special-subjects teachers in their fight with the Board of Education over the increased teaching load, the faculties of five high schools have voted to take no part in voluntary extracurricular activities, it was learned yesterday. Other school faculties were reported considering similar measures.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Community property laws of the states are not applicable to payments to beneficiaries of National service Life Insurance for war veterans, the Supreme Court ruled today.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 6 Greater conservation of water was called the key to the development of the country's river valleys at the opening of the annual convention of the Mississippi Valley Association today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 United States diplomatic-personnel are getting out of China just as fast as offices can be closed and transportation arranged, the State Department declared today.

A sharp increase in orders since the beginning of 1950 was reported yesterday by C.J. Reese, president of the Continental Motors Corporation, in announcing the company's annual statement to stockholders. About 33,000...

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 6--The Communist newspaper Pravda of Pilsen reported indignantly today that stories were being circulated about a vision seen by various persons in which the Virgin Mary appeared waving an American flag followed by American troops and even tanks.

The first test of stockholder reaction to pension agreements made by the nation's steel companies last fall to settle the labor strike will be held today when shareholders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation meet in Wilmington, Del.
I am glad to be here today to help open the new home of the Amerika Haus in Stuttgart. It is well to state at the outset what purpose such a house is intended to serve.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb.6 The Assembly of Municipal Court Judges in Connecticut today adopted a code of judicial ethics to cover the conduct of 130 minor court judges and other court employes in sixtysix cities and towns.

Brooklyn College's high-flying basketball team stretched its winning streak to ten straight by overcoming Manhattan, 78 to 77, in the loser's gymnasium last night. It was the first setback for the Jaspers on their home floor since February, 1947, and the first time that the Kingsmen have taken the measure of Manhattan since 1939.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 6 William B. Widnall, a Republican lawyer from Saddle River, tonight won a two-to-one victory in the special Seventh Congressional District election to choose a successor to J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, jailed for payroll padding.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 6 The proposed sale of American Overseas Aulines to Pan American Airways was attacked today as a "monopolistic" move that would ultimately give Pan American complete control of transatlantic air traffic.

The Isaaeli Government is compelled to use funds needed for defense purposes to take care of the newly arrived refugees, Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury, said here last night. He spoke at a testimonial dinner given in his honor by the...

In a statement issued late yesterday at City Hall, Controller Lazarus Joseph announced that he would ask the Board of Estimate at its meeting Thursday to renew the lease for the New York City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., in the city owned building at 131 West Fifty-fifth Street.

A 41 year old organizer for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, was arraigned in Lower Manhattan Court yesterday on a charge of having been one of three men who assaulted Richard Diego Panzica, 22, of 2007 Clinton Avenue, the Bronx, on April 29 in a dress shop.

Jose Luis Bustamante y Rivera, who has never resigned as President of Peru although deprived of that office by a military coup d'etat late in 1948, said here yesterday that there could be little hope for a moderate regime anywhere in South America as long as the people remained "uncomprehending" and the politicians lacked scruples.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 6 (AP)-- High race track taxes threaten the whole racing industry, the Naional Association of State Racing Commissioners of the United States heard today.

TOKYO, Feb. 6--Leaders of Japan's major political parties with the exception of the extreme left have become convinced as a result of the visit here by the Joint Chiefs of Staff that this nation should grant air, naval and army bases to the United States in return for a protective guarantee under the peace treaty. There are indications they believe that the view would be supported by a large majority of the post-war Japanese electorate.

The marriage of Miss Ellen L. Sulzberger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Sulzberger of 1111 Park Avenue, and Saranac Lake, N. Y., to R. Peter Straus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Straus of New York, and White Plains, N. Y., took place last evening in the Cottage of Hampshire House. The Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise performed the ceremony.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 6 A year ago at a time when it appeared that no solution would ever be found for the Berlin blockade, Premier Stalin used an interview with a United States news agency as a means or issuing a veiled invitation to the United States to open direct negotiations.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6--Grain markets made a Strong finish after a weak start on the Board of Trade today. General short covering developed after May wheat had sold at a new low since mid-September and all deliveries of rye had gone to new seasonal lows.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland, appealed to President Truman today to call a world conference for disarmament, in conventional as well as atomic weapons, to "end the world's nightmare of fear."

The first cooperative showing of i domestics and Linens drew 400 buyers to the Commodore Hotel yesterday. Sponsored by a new nonprofit organization called the Allied Linens and Domestics Association, Inc., the show exhibited lines of 126 manufacturers and importers of sheets, pillowcases, table linens, bedspreads, comforters, blankets and other domestics. It will continue through Friday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) The Government's key witness testified today in the Harold Christoffel perjury retrial that the defendant had been a member of the Communist party.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 6 The West German Government has decided to curtail steel shipments from the Ruhr to the Soviet zone, it became known today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 The Mississippi Power Company of Gulfport, Miss., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $3,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due March 1, 1980, to be offered at competitive bidding.
Six defense counsel at last year's Communist trial asked the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday to reverse Judge Harold R. Medina's action in convicting them of contempt of court.

LONDON, Feb. 6 For the first time in the British general election campaign, foreign policy issues were discussed at length tonight by the two men probably best qualified to expound them Ernest Bevin, Foreign Secretary of the Labor Government, and Anthony Eden, who held the same post under the previous Conservative administration.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Feb. 6 Mrs. Kingsland T. Rood of Briarcliff Manor and Brunswick, Me., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Margaret Elizabeth, to Thomas de Quartet Richardson 4th, son of Mrs. C. Fahnestock Richardson of Greenwich, Conn., and Thomas de Q. Richardson 3d of Los Angeles.

Ljuba Welitch sang Salome for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, and it was, if anything, a more incandescent performance than the one she gave last year in her American debut. This was the creature of Richard Strauss' imagining possessed, abandoned, childishly violent, utterly demoniac.
Striving to make New York a cleaner city, the Sanitation Department issued summonses yesterday to 194 alleged violators of the Sanitary Code in mid-Manhattan.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb, 6 P.L Grissom's Sun Herod, a one-time Brookmeade Stable runner, beat the Broohmeade-owned Dart By and eight others in Hialeah's best race today. Dart By was the favorite in the nine-furlong run over the grass course; Sun Herod was the $13.70-for-$2 fourth choice.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6--When you hear a charter boat captain announce that he'd like to see a strong norther blow for three or four days you can figure something is radically wrong with the fishing, but if you hang around the Marina dock an hour so you'll hear several skippers expressing their views on the prevailing warm winds.

LONDON, Feb. 6 Lady Violet Bonham Carter, leading woman Liberal, gave a sharp tongue lashing to Sir Stafford Cripps today for his recent broadcast, in which, she asserted, he gave Britain a "wholly false picture" of the country's economic position.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 6 Snowstorms and below-zero weather unprecedented in living memory took a toll today of five lives in immigrant transit camps and hit the economy of the infant state that is fighting bankruptcy.

Italian troops are starting for Somaliland to take over their former colony from the British administrators, The event deserves to be noticed, for it signifies much more than the resumption by Italy of the role of an African Power.

Northeastern lumber mills are swamped with business as a result of heavy bookings by furniture manufacturers to meet orders received at Chicago and other markets, R. E. Broderick, executive secretary of the Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association, reported yesterday. He said most...

WASHINGTON, Feb, 6 John W. Cutler Jr., an employe of the Displaced Persons Commission, told the Senate Judiciary Committee today that Army, counterintelligence reports unfavorable to refugees seeking to come here were disregarded unless they were proved.

As water shortage in the city's Catskill and Croton reservoirs dipped by 134,000,000 gallons yesterday, the third successive day of storage losses, water officials issued an urgent appeal to the public to reduce water use "in every possible way."

Pierre Etchebaster, world court tennis champion, was put to a rigorous test yesterday as he and Esmond B. Martin defeated Robert L. Gerry Jr. and Bunny Gannon, Tuxedo professional, in the proamatear doubles tournament at the Racquet and Tennis Club, 8-6, 8 6.
The Transport Workers Union, CIO, got its long-sought opportunity yesterday to start presenting to Mayor O'Dwyer's fact-finding board its case for higher wages and improved working conditions.

The premiere showing of the film version of Noel Coward's play, "The Astonished Heart," will he given next Monday night at the Park Avenue Theatre for the benefit of the Mary MacArthur Memorial Fund for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. The entire proceeds will be donated to the beneficiary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee heard today details of a plan to set up a world police force under the United Nations, with or without the consent of the Soviet Union. The proposal is backed by eleven Senators.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 6 The nation's retail automobile dealers are now confronted with a socalled "buyer's" market and return of vigorous competition for the first time since 1941, it was emphasized here today by speakers addressing the thirty-fourth annual convention of the National Automobile Dealers Association at Convention Hall.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6 Floyd B. Odlum, president of Atlas Corporatidn, giant "special situations" investment company, is expected to announce either tomorrow or Wednesday the completion of negotiations for the sale of his company's 45 per cent stock interest in Barnsdall Oil Company to Sunray Oil Corporation, it was learned today.

ALBANY, Feb. 6--A bill authorizing two additional Supreme Court justiceships in the Ninth Judicial District was approved tonight by the Assembly without discussion. The measure now goes to the Senate for concurrence.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6--Art Fletcher, who participated in fourteen world series--four as a shortstop for the New York Giants and ten as a baseline coach for the New York Yankees--died of a heart attack here today while driving his car. He was 65 years old.

The city's Traffic Commission is one year old, and whether or not we accept at full value the official denials of reports that it is "beset by internal rows," it must be admitted that things have moved mighty slow.

A lively controversy over the potential benefits of the Unified State Building Commission, the agency established last year by the Legislature to promulgate a statewide building code, developed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Association of Towns of the State of New York at the Commodore Hotel.
STUTTGART, Germany, Feb. 6 The United States will use all its power to fight a revival of nazism in Germany, John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, asserted today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered from an early slight dip in prices and closed 1 to 5 points net higher.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 6 (AP) Ohio State's Western Conference basketball leaders came from 10 points behind to nip Indiana tonight in the last three minutes, 56-55.

The Idaho Power Company, an $80,000,000 utility serving more than 100,000 customers in the Snake River Valley section of Idaho, Oregon and Nevada, reported yesterday that net income for 1949 amounted to $3,015,845, equal to $2.72 on each of the 900,000 common shares outstanding, compared with $2,736,680 or $2.77 a share in 1948, when there were 700,000 shares outstanding.
The betting is six-two-and-even that the Yankees will engineer a trade either before or during the spring training campaign, possibly involving three other American League clubs.

KHORRAMSHAHR, Iran, Jan. 24 This crossing point for Iraqi Jews leaving the country is getting a steadily heavier traffic as Jews in Baghdad, principal center of Jewish population in Iraq, in Basra and the adjoining southern areas close out their affairs and prepare to leave the country.

Combined net assets of the ten Keystone Custodian Funds on Dec. 31, reached $198m612,500, a new high to that date, it was noted yesterday in the annual reports of the keystone Funds B1 and K2. The keystone Company of Boston, which published the reports, announced also that on Jan. 6 assets passed $200,000,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 Fourteen members of the Japanese Diet, who are visiting the United States to study American government, were welcomed to Albany today by Governor Dewey and the Republican and Democratic leaders of the Legislature.

BOSTON, Feb. 6 (AP) Willie Pep, featherweight champion, scored a knockdown with either hand while out-pointing aggressive Roy An drews of Lowell in their 10-round non-title boxing bout tonight beg fore l,259 at the Boston Garden.

"My Favorite Possession," a repeat performance with a new twist of "My Favorite Heirloom," a popular exhibition staged last year at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, will open again to the public tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) William Dudley Pelley, 60 years old, the Silver Shirt leader convicted of aiding the Germans with his speeches and writings, obtained a parole today after serving about half of a fifteen-year wartime sedition sentence.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 The Republican party policy makers today proclaimed "Liberty Against Socialism" to be the major domestic issue of the 1950 Congressional elections.

Leopold Teraspulsky, young New York 'cellist, who made his debut here in 1943, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. It was his first New York appearance in six years and during part of the interval he had studied in France under Pablo Casals.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 Robert Schroeder, member of the board of directors and secretary of the Philadelphia Athletics American League baseball club, died last night at his home in Alden Park Manor, Germantown, after a long illness. He was 59 years old.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 6 (AP) Lieut. Comdr. Harwood Hull, USNR, retired, newspaper man and former public information officer for the Eighth and Tenth Naval Districts, died last night at the age of 65.

The Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation, which has either lost money on its gas business or its margin of profit has been very low in recent years, predicted yesterday that sale of the manufactured fuel to about 37,000 customers in the mid-Hudson Valley of New York would be converted to a profit within the next, few years.

The Westminster Kennel Club's annual dog show in Madison Square Garden will be televised by WOR-TV next week on two successive evenings. The schedule calls for coverage on Monday from 9 to 10 o'clock and on Tuesday from 10 until the conclusion of the dog show.
Bishop Charles K. Gilbert bade formal good-by last night to the laymen of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)--A powerful new aircraft rocket, nicknamed the "Mighty Mouse," has been developed by the Navy for air-to-air combat in any future war.
Thanks to a special arrangement by which the Veterans Administration is tatting piecemeal possession of its new hospital at Fort Hamilton, the first patients are to be received there Thursday.

Fifty-six young women were graduated last night from the Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing. The sixty-seventh annual exercises were attended by 350 relatives and friends in the hospital auditorium at Fifth Avenue and 100th Street.

The Kansas Gas and Electric Company yesterday announced effectiveness of a stock exchange offer whereby holders of the 76,361 shares of 7 per cent and $6 preferred stocks may exchange such shares for a new issue of 4 per cent cumulative preferred stock on a share-for-share basis.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $1.50 a shag a on the common stock. Last year the corporation made three quarterly payments of $1.25 a share and a yearend disbursement of $4.25 a share.
Directors of the W.A. Sheaffer Pen Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of $1.15 a share is addition to the regular quarterly of 10 cents, payable to common stockholders on Feb. 25.

DUBLIN, Feb. 2 The treaty of friendship, commerce and navigation signed recently between the United States and the Republic of Ireland opens the way for American enterprise and capital to come to Ireland to help in the development of the country's resources.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Dr. Klaus Fuchs, the naturalized Brit ish scientist held in London as an accused spy, was officially said today to have "transmitted vital secret information to the Soviet Union" and as a man with a long record of "sympathy with Communist ideology."

With year-end inventories completed, buyers of notions are in a position to buy for replenishment of stocks and add new items to their departments, according to George English, manager of the Notions Show at the New Yorker Hotel. The show, which will be open through Friday, drew 600 buyers on the opening day to see the exhibits of 230 notion suppliers.

Four Cornell men in their seventies will meet for dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Thursday to renew for the eleventh time a pledge they and twenty-four fellow undergraduates made at the university in Ithaca, N.Y,, fiftysix years ago.

It used to be that homemakers searching for inexpensive bookcases or cabinets for some inconspicuous corner almost automatically turned to unpainted furniture. Today, however, increased emphasis on quality and variety in unfinished pieces has made them food looking enough to be used anywhere in the house.

Ten thousand questionnaires are being distributed to retail grocery stores and markets this week for reports on prices charged for bread, John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, announced yesterday.

A special group of twenty-five persons representing a cross-section of the member agencies of the Welfare Council will study the changes proposed for the council by the Greater New York Fund and submit recommendations for action at the delegate body meeting on March 6.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 More than 1,000 questionable or outright fraudulent schools and colleges in this country are fleecing unsuspecting students of millions of dollars annually. At least 100 are nothing more than "diploma mills" where one can buy a bachelor's degree for As little as $25 and a high-sounding doctorate for less than $50.

A warning to this year's college graduates that competition for employment next summer would be "severe" was given yesterday in the annual report of Robert F. Moore, director of Columbia University's Placement Bureau.

LONDON, Feb. 8 Main activity in the London stock markets centered today on dealings in the new Southern Rhodesian loan. Buying opened at a premium of to a point above the issue price of 98 and narrowed by the day's end.

The Lane Wells Company has declared a quarterly dividend of 50 agents on the common, payable on March 15. In 1949 the company Paid dividends of 40 cents each in the first three quarters and 80 cents in December.

Continued buying of crude rubber by Soviet Russia gave additional strength to world rubber markets yesterday bringing upswings in quotations in New York, Singapore and London. The Singapore price of 17.50 cents (U.S.) a pound was the highest registered there since 1928.

BAYONNE, N.J., Feb. 6 Angered by the transfer of twentythree teachers from Daniel P. Sweeney High School and Bayonne Junior College to elementary grade schools, 300 students at the high school went on strike this morning, refusing to attend classes and picketing the building.

Promotions and appointments affecting 173 officers and firemen, effective March 1, were announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle. The changes will add twelve deputy chiefs to the roster.
LONDON, Feb. 6 A spokesman of the British Foreign Office enthusiastically applauded the plainspoken speech on German policy made by Mr. McCloy in Stuttgart today.
Douglas Campbell, senior partner in the law firm of Campbell, Goodwin, Glenn Danforth, 44 Wall Street, died yesterday in his home at 17 East Sixty-first Street. His age was 76.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)--The Association of American Railroads estimated today that the major railroads have, on the average, coal reserves to last 14.8 days.

A recommended monthly food allotment for a family of four persons on relief was made public yesterday by Welfare Commissioner Raymond F. Hilliard.

THEY were clearing away the debris from the Baseball Writers dinner yesterday and there was at least one thing which lingered in memory. At one point in the show an actor bobbed and weaved and ducked across the stage. He was a puzzling figure until the master of ceremonies identified him. "That," he said, "was merely Happy Chandler dodging the reserve clause."

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 6 Three warnings were transmitted to the battleship Missouri's bridge while the vessel headed for shoal water Jan. 17, Comdr. George E. Peckham, executive officer of the ship, told a court of inquiry here today.
Bingham-Herbrand Corporation December quarter: Net profit, $31,768, equal to 42c a common share, compared with $304,985, or 98c a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1948.

Members of the advisory committee of the Institute of Fine Arts, New York University, have lent examples of impressionist and post-impressionist painting from their own collections for an exhibition at the Knoedler Galleries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The new long-range method of fixing New York's fluid milk prices to farmers was formally announced today by the Department of Agriculture.

SZCZECIN (Stettin), Feb. 7-- The second Frenchman and the first of four Polish defendants today pleaded guilty before a military court to charges that they had gathered political economic and military data on behalf of French intelligence.

Coffee futures drifted lower yesterday in quiet trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. After a dull opening, prices eased on scattered commission-house selling. There was some trade demand and hedge-lifting but turnover was light.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 7--Dr. Hernan Santa Cruz, Chile's permanent representative in the United Nations and new president of the Economic and Social Council, today described the triple walkout of the Soviet Union, Poland and Czechoslovakia from the meeting...

Newbury Frost Read, secretary and a director of Geo. R. Read Co., 30 Nassau Street, a real estate firm established in 1884 by his father, the late George Rowland Read, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital after a brief illness.
The Third Avenue Transit System announced yesterday afternoon, shortly after an arbitrator had granted $1,100,000 in back pay to its 3,800 union employes, that it would seek a 10-cent fare.

MONTREAL, Feb. 7 (UP)--Ted Lindsay and Sid Abel of the Detroit Red Wings continued to hold the National Hockey League scoring spotlight today, while Montreal's Maurice Richard moved back into third place.

"The Heiress," last of the NewYork City Theatre Company's four fortnightly revivals, will get under way at 8:15 this evening at the City Center. The final bill was to have been William Saroyan's "The Time of Your Life," with Eddie Dowling as director and star.
CHICAGO, Feb. 7--Grains closed with a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade today after being higher early.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7-- Harry Renton Bridges took the witness char in Federal Court here today to fight a new threat of deportation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)--The Civil Aeronautics Administration today announced the distribution of $7,800,068 in Federal aid funds for ninety-five airport projects in twenty-five states.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 7--Dr. Arna E. Rides, who last Saturday quit her job with the British Council, issued a strident denunciation of the council and the British Government for reactionary...
PARIS, Wednesday, Feb. 8--By a vote of 225 to 185, Premier Georges Bidault early today obtained the confidence of the National Assembly for his newly reorganized Cabinet.
Two Holmes Protective Agency guards, answering a burglar alarm shortly after midnight yesterday, found a pixieish intruder in a client's office who quickly vanished out an eighth-floor window.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 7-- With rejection of a series of Socialist amendments, the Chamber of Deputies limped forward today toward a vote approving the Government's bill for a national referendum on the question of King Leopold's return to the Belgian throne.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7 (AP)-- Federal Reserve Board counsel today moved to strike certain defense exhibits at the hearing into Transamerica Corporation and the hearing was recessed to give time for a ruling.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The board of inquiry appointed by President Truman began its hunt for the facts in the soft-coal dispute today by conferring informally with John L. Lewis and three of the mine operators.
Dean Millicent C. McIntosh of Barnard College reported yesterday that the financial deficit of the school's residence halls had been met, and that they were now operating on a small profit.

The young violinist, Arnold Eidus, who appeared in Carnegie Hall last night, made something of a name for himself three years ago when he won the coveted Jacques Thibaud award in Paris, and after hearing his brilliant technique and...

A Sharp difference of opinion on divorce and sex education in the schools marked the discussion last night between Mrs. Maisie Ward Sheed, former chairman of training for the London Catholic Evidence Guild, and John Mason Brown, associate editor of The Saturday Review of Literature, on America's Town Meeting of the Air.
Governor Dewey told 2,000 upstate town officials yesterday that wider acceptance of the theory of town government would give the American people greater takehome pay and better government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson disclosed tonight that he had discharged his $10,000-a-year special assistant, Harold F. Ambrose, for perpetrating a scheme that took large sums from "speculators" in false deals in United States stamps.

Hollis Powers Gale of 68-60 108th Street, Forest Hills, Queens, inherited approximately $5,000,000 yesterday and announced that he would like to "spend more time in the future helping in what ways I can to improve our foreign relations."

ALBANY, Feb. 7--Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens, chairman of the Temporary Rent Commission, promised the Assembly today that his group will recommend an effective program for controlling residential rents in time for action at the present session of the Legislature.

A week or so ago the Government invited us to eat more chicken. Now it asks that appetites focus on eggs. Specifically, and on a nation-wide basis, during the period that starts tomorrow and ends Feb. 16.

A lagging tank program and deficiencies in airborne development and in tactical air power are some of the problems that the Research and Development Board, under a new chairman and with new members, must shortly face.

Judith Coplon was portrayed yesterday by a former associate in the Department of Justice as an eager girl who asked that investigative reports dealing with Russian espionage be sent to her desk even after she had been taken off such work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, hinted to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that he would ask somewhat less than the $3,100,000,000 suggested by President Truman for the third year of the Marshall Plan.
Representatives of teachers of special subjects met with city school officials more than an hour yesterday, but failed to reach an agreement in the controversy over the increased teaching load.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 7--India complained today that Pakistani troops still occupied parts of Kashmir and warned that there could be no plebiscite in the princely state until conditions returned to normal.

LONDON, Feb. 7--London newspaper reviewers generally had much more complimentary things to say about the acting of Jessie Royce Landis than about the comedy "Larger Than Life" in which she opened here tonight at the Duke of York's Theatre.

Policy-makers of the Republican party have come up with the slogan "Liberty Against Socialism" as their idea of the issue for this year's Congressional elections. It is a neat phrase, but we agree with Senator Lodge (who cast his vote in opposition) that it overstates the case.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 7 --The Yugoslav Government today decentralized control over heavy industries in the first phase of the plan drawn up by Foreign Minister Edvard Kardelj to implement the Yugoslav concept of what the Communist state should be as opposed to the Soviet concept of centralized dictatorship.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 7 --Attempting to bolster its position, somewhat shaken after blunt criticisms made by United States High Commissioner John J. McCloy at Stuttgart yesterday, the West German Government tonight issued a soothing statement about today's conference between Mr. McCloy and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.

In the presence of consular representatives of seven of the challenging nations and with Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the Unitad Nations, officiating, the draw was made yesterday for the Davis Cup competition in 1950, the fiftieth anniversary of the international tennis team championship.

The stakes program at the spring meeting at Jamaica will be the same that was presented at that track a year ago, it was announced yesterday by the Metropolitan Jockey Club. A total of $270,000 in added money will be distributed for the twelve stakes that will be run.

David E. Lilienthal's resignation as Chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission will supposedly take effect a week from today. Now the President has a second place to fill on the Commission, with the resignation yesterday of Lewis L. Strauss after nine years of diligent and conscientious service in public office.

A.C. Allyn Co., Inc., and Bear, Steams Co., successful bidders for the common stock of the Pacific Power and Light Company, have caused the utility industry to conjecture on the future of private ownership of utilities in the Pacific Northwest.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 8 (AP) --The Chinese Communist radio today asserted 1,000 persons had been killed in Monday's Nationalist air raid on Shanghai. The Peiping broadcast said the raiders were twelve B-24 and two B-25 bombers accompanied by two P-51 and one P-38 fighters.

Not government regulation but discriminating readers can help develop responsible newspapers in this country, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told 500 teachers yesterday. He addressed the first session of the sixth annual inservice...

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 4--The communist-led government of North Korea is preparing what some observers here believe to be an intensified offensive to overthrow from within the United States-supported regime of President Syngman Rhee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)--The Government announced today it would continue to buy eggs, although it already had about $100,000,000 worth and did not know what to do with them.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 7--The City of Newark today asked that Elizabeth consider a proposal to permit it to annex six acres of land here as part of a site for a public housing project near the Elizabeth-Newark line.

In what may be regarded as a reply to American criticism, the European Marshall Plan Council has issued a new report which gratefully lists the achievements of that plan but appeals to the United States to cooperate with Europe not only in continued dollar aid but also in establishing a new trade pattern which will permit Europe to stand on its own feet in a new world.
With the trade winds dying down after a brief blow during the past day or two, all three local baseball clubs returned to the business of announcing player signings yesterday.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Feb. 7--Six hundred and seven persons, who paid a total of $2,700,000 for their passage, were aboard the Holland-America Line's flagship Nieuw Amsterdam when she sailed from the line's Fifth Street Pier here...

The United States must substantially increase imports from friendly countries within the next two years or become isolated behind a "paper curtain" as communism triumphs in these nations, members of the Export Managers Club of New York were warned at a luncheon...
LONDON, Feb. 7 (UP)--The British Liberal party proposed today that the hydrogen bomb and all other atomic weapons be outlawed throughout the world.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 7--This island's economy is being licked into shape gradually, but indications are that its final form will be far different from that left by the Japanese. Sugar crop and exports will be smaller.

Issues of $2,500,000 of bonds of the Montebello Unified School District, Los Angeles County, Calif., were bought at public bidding yesterday by a banking group headed by the National City Bank of New York at an interest cost of 2.3948 per cent.
ART FLETCHER died of a heart attack at the age of 66 on Monday, and he'd have been the first to admit that the last twenty years were on borrowed time.
A national telephone strike, set for 6 o'clock this morning, was postponed yesterday for sixteen days at the request of the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, one of those who counseled President Truman to order production of the hydrogen bomb, submitted his resignation as a member of the Atomic Energy Commission today and the President accepted it in a letter of high praise for his service.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7--Dr. Frank Gouldsmith Speck, author, outstanding authority on the American Indian and Professor of Anthropology at the University of Pennsylvania, died last night in the University Hospital at the age of 68.
The City Club of New York, a men's "social club with a civic purpose," has decided to disband after fifty-eight years of agitation for municipal reform, it was announced yesterday.

Fifty-seven baseball candidates vote on hand at the Columbia University Hall gym yesterday to help launch Coach Andy Coakley's thirty-sixth year as the head of the Lion squad. Only six members of the large turnout, however were letter winners.

Advertising in the seven major New York City newspapers during January totaled 11,739,731 lines, a gain of 6.96 per cent over the like month of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Linage of the defunct New York Sun for January, 1949, did not figure in the comparison.
Abraham M. Bowman, a real estate broker here for fifty-seven years, died yesterday in his home at the Beekman Hotel, 575 Park Avenue, after a month's illness.

WILMINGTON, Feb. 7--Stockholders of Bethlehem Steel Corporation today overwhelmingly approved the $100 a month pension agreement which ended the steel strike last year, at a special meeting held in the offices of the Corporation Trust Company here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP)-- The United Stages Maritime Commission announced today that world-wide legal proceedings had been started against the operators of Chinese merchant ships who had defaulted on American-held mortgages.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP)-- The Secretary of the Treasury, John W. Snyder, said today that the nation's economy had "safely" made the change-over from postwar inflation to a buyers' market. Currently, it is in a strong condition for "long-term economic progress," he added.

CARVILLE, La., Feb. 7--Fifty per cent of the patients undergoing treatment for leprosy in the United States Marine Hospital here are now showing negative reports in clinical and bacteriological tests, and 20 per cent were permitted to go home for Christmas last year on "vacations" of fifteen to thirty days.

LONDON, Feb. 7--Mrs. Clement R. Attlee, who is starting off tomorrow to drive her husband, the Prime Minister, on his election tour of Britain, said in an interview tonight that she was not wholly confident of the outcome of the election on Feb. 23.
The severest set-back in a month was sustained yesterday by the stock market as a small but steady stream of offerings depressed prices well beyond a point in a representative list of issues.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 7--On the strength of a three-for-four racing record that included a ten-length triumph in his last previous start, Gustave Ring's 3-year-old Quick Fire was the 2-to-5 favorite in the main event at Hialeah today. It's a sad story, mates.

Existence in the Dominican Republic of extensive magnetite deposits, capable of producing 1,000,000 tons of high-grade iron ore annually "for many generations," is confirmed officially in an interim report issued here yesterday.

Three prominent executives of the frozen food industry agreed yesterday that there was a good prospect for doubling last year's business this year. They addressed a luncheon in the Biltmore Hotel attended by about 300 members of the Eastern Frozen Foods Association.

SAGINAW, Mich., Feb. 7 (UP)-- Bishop William Francis Murphy, spiritual leader of more than 100,000 northwestern Michigan Roman Catholics, died today at his home here after a long illness.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be hostess to world leaders and famous dignitaries in a new weekly discussion television series which begins over the National Broadcasting Company Sunday afternoon from 4 to 4:30 o'clock.

ALBANY, Feb. 7--The State Insurance Department has recommended that the Legislature double the required liability insurance coverage of New York automobiles.

The United States Securities and Exchange Commission is ready to "crack down" on partisans of the Mao Tze-tung regime in China who are peddling here part of a $100,000,000 issue of so-called "People's Victory Bonds."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The Democratic leadership of the House tonight was anticipating a stiff battle to keep aid for Formosa in the Far Eastern Economic assistance Act, but the general feeling was that, with a final vote set for Thursday, victory was assured.

The nation's shipping industry is facing "unnecessary" Government competition from Army and Navy tonnage in addition to the normal opposition of vessels of foreign-flag lines, Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, asserted yesterday in his annual report.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 8 --The Yugoslav Federal Government will proceed in the near future with the second phase of its program to decentralize control of the national economy by transferring the cement, glass and food products industries to the Constituent Republican Governments.

With the getaway for the spring training camps less than three weeks away, both the Yankees and Dodgers stepped up their signing pace yesterday and fetched up with a total of six players who have accepted terms for 1950.

The "sociological advances" of the Magistrate's Courts were described yesterday as "our greatest satisfaction and our highest reward" by Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in his final report before retiring from office on St. Valentine's Day.

Charles H. Keel, a partner since 1926 in Bartlett, Eyre, Keel Weymouth, 36 West Forty-fourth Street, a law firm specializing in patent and trademark matters, died on Tuesday in a New York hospital after an illness of several months. Mr. Keel, who was 66 years old, lived at 18 Park End Place, Forest Hills, Queens.

MOSCOW, Feb. 4--Smena, organ of the central committee of the Komsomol youth organization, today charged Americans with deliberate suppression of the fact that Soviet scientists had made major contributions in the atomic field and warned that "this will not stop the progress of Soviet science."

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 8--The nation's automobile dealers today urged car manufacturers to immediately correct their present system of distribution of new cars and trucks in order to combat the steady growth of bootlegging of these vehicles by non-franchised dealers in many areas of the country.

A sharp comparison between the youth of the Western democracies, enjoying "our most precious possession--freedom" and those of Russia and its satellite countries was drawn yesterday by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Pictures Association.

The Havana Charter is an obstacle to world reconstruction, Michael A. Heilperin, economic adviser of the Bristol-Myers Company, told more than 250 members of the Synthetic Organic Chemical Manufacturers Association at a foreign trade meeting at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)-- The Independent Natural Gas Association of America today opposed legislation to give the Federal Power Commission authority to regulate securities of certain natural gas companies.

A 4 -year-old leukemia victim who has been receiving treatments of the new drug, ACTH, at Bellevue Hospital, has responded favorably and will be sent home in a few days, his physician reported yesterday.
Ambrose Casner and Ralph Hirschberg of New York won the "life masters" pair championship in the tournament of the American Contract Bridge League at the Park Sheraton Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Representatives of the New York Stock Exchange and the Investment Bankers Association of America endorsed with minor reservations today a bill to extend the protection of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to investors in 1,118 companies not now covered by the act.

LONDON, Feb. 8--A sharp contrast to Winston Churchill's pic ture of economic and social progress in Britain between the wars was provided tonight by James Griffiths, Minister of National Insurance, in a nation-wide radio broadcast on behalf of the Labor party.

LONDON, Feb. 8--The relapse in British Government securities spread today to most sections of the stock markets. British funds fluctuated but were steadier at the close when losses of about or 1/8 point had been incurred.

PARIS, Feb. 4--With the colossal task of resettling European Jewish victims of war and persecution now in its advanced stages, overseas officials of the American Joint Distribution Committee disclosed plans here today for a greatly expanded relief program in behalf of thousands of impoverished Jews in the Moslem world.

New York's state welfare laws and the degree to which they have taken the administration of relief and assistance programs away from town officials came in for some sharp criticism yesterday at the annual meeting of the Association of Towns of the State of New York at the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Dr. Earl J. McGrath, Commissioner of Education, asserted today that Communists should not be allowed to teach in United States schools, but neither should "the emboldened forces of reaction" be allowed to take over the school system.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8--Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today, with professional operators expressing mixed views concerning the ultimate price trend of wheat and other grains. The markets as a whole paid little attention to news developments.

CIHOST, Czechoslovakia, Feb.8 --A "miracle" has brought fear but also glory to this Bohemian village of 300 flax farmers and woodcutters tucked away amid snowdrifts in the hills fifty miles southeast of Prague.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--An ultra-sensational claim to the discovery in cosmic rays of sixteen elementary particles of matter hitherto unknown in the world has just been made in a Russian scientific journal.

The paralyzing effects of the national coal strike crippled new sections of American industry yesterday, forcing cancellation of 300 more steam passenger trains and a 25 per cent cut in coal-burning railroad freight service.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 8--The Economic and Social Council agreed unanimously today to ask all member countries to report back periodically to the United Nations and explain what they have done or failed to do in carrying out the Council's decisions.

ALBANY, Feb. 8--An important break in the forces of the butter and dairy industries battling proposals to repeal the state's ban against the sale of yellow-colored oleomargarine came today as an official of a leading butter manufacturer urged approval of the repeal measure.

DETROIT, Feb. 8 (AP)--Gerry Priddy, the Detroit Tigers' new second baseman, signed his 1950 contract today for an estimated $28,000.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 8 (UP)-- Two men carrying a garbage can between them walked out of the Bank of Douglas here today with $16,250, their haul in an early morning holdup. Nobody paid any attention to them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP)-- Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson said tonight that Joe Adonis, self-styled "big time" New York gambler, was one of those caught in a $400,000 stamp deal worked out by a former $10,000-ayear assistant to Mr. Donaldson.

Soft coal operators and the union failed in bargaining yesterday under the eye of the Presidential fact-finding board after the board had stated that the public was entitled to have a contract or to know the reason why agreement was impossible.

A significant shift in advertising strategy of the Sinclair Refining Company--based on a localization of selling in preferred markets --was announced yesterday at a meeting of newspaper representatives and company officials in the University Club.

Operations last year of the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, Inc., resulted in a decline of $2,491,706 in earnings from those of 1948, James Decamp Wise, president, reported in the preliminary annual report.

At the annual meeting of the United States Leather Company on March 8, shareholders will vote on amending the certificate of incorporation to change each share of Class A convertible stock of no par value into three shares of common instead of into one share, as at present.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)--The staff of the Federal power commission sprang a surprise today in its attack on the Ohio Fuel Gas Company's application to raise its wholesale rates.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Feb. 8-- New treatments in making highspeed steel-cutting tools increase their working life by 100 per cent, with some analysts claiming as much as 500 per cent, or more, Joseph B. Armitage, vice president, Kearney Trecker Corporation, declared today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--President Truman believes that Thomas E. Dewey will probably run for Governor again next November, according to Representative John C. Davies, Democrat, of New York, and they both expressed belief today that a good Democratic candidate could beat him.

"All You Need Is One Good Break," a play by Arnold Manoff produced by Monte Proser and Joseph Kipness, in association with Jack Small, will make its local debut this evening at the Mansfield Theatre. The opening night curtain is announced to rise at 8:30 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The Government dipped into its bulging stock of surplus foods today and offered to give the nation's needy $115,000,000 worth of dried eggs and milk it has accumulated in the last two years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- Twelve outstanding Boy Scouts, representing the country's 2,579,515 Scouts and leaders, were received by President Truman at the White House today, the fortieth anniversary of the Boy Scouts of America.

ALBANY, Feb. 8--A series of alternative proposals for revising the court system of New York City to reduce delays in reaching trial and for speeding the administration of justice was submitted to the Legislature today. WEST SAYVILLE, L.I., Feb. 8 --Tobias F. Miller of Cherry Avenue, a piano tuner and service man for Steinway Sons, New York, for forty-eight years, died of a stroke yesterday at his home here. Mr. Miller, who was 77 years old, had continued his work until a few weeks ago.

The importance of the science of navigation to government and industry in war and peace will be the principal theme of a two-day symposium starting today in Washington, it was announced here yesterday by Capt. J.K. Galleher.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The Administration stood firmly today upon its decision to bar military aid to the beleaguered Chinese Nationalists on Formosa.

The Boston Metropolitan District sold $1,872,000 of refunding bonds yesterday to a banking syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co., at a bid of 101.94 for interest of 2 per cent. HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 8-- Princeton defeated Dartmouth, 82-54,, tonight in an Eastern League basketball game. In a contest that appeared to be a foulshooting affair for the first five minutes, Dartmouth managed to net only thirteen out of twentyfive free throws.

ALBANY, Feb. 8--The Stephens rent commission is on the verge of recommending that the state take over control of residential rents from the Federal Government by May 1 of this year, it was disclosed today.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 8--The actual reform of Argentine economy is now complete and the nation has entered the final or "stabilizing" phase of a revolutionary program, President Juan D, Peron declared yesterday.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 8--The battleship Missouri, fully repaired, headed out to sea today on a twoday trial run, while Capt. William D. Brown, her skipper, and two top officers remained here for sessions of the Naval Court of Inquiry that has been investigating why the battleship went around Jan. 17.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 8 (AP)--GMan Fred Wilt, New York Athletic Club's distance ace, tied a meet record tonight when he successfully defended his title in the national invitation mile at the fourth annual 175th Regiment-South Atlantic Association track meet.

When St. John's faces Canisius tonight as collegiate basketball returns to Madison Square Garden after a three-week lapse, a good deal of attention will be focused upon Bob Zawoluk, the Redmen's center.

J., Feb. 8--Hearings on petitions to the National Labor Relations Board by the newly organized International Union of Electrical Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, for elections to choose bargaining agents at the Camden and Pulaski, Va., plants of RCA-Victor were completed in a City Hall courtroom here today.

Man o' War, a mighty race horse whose blazing speed cut down his rivals thirty years ago and captured the imagination of the sports world, is the greatest thoroughbred since 1900, it was revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Secretary of State Dean Acheson asserted today that agreements with the Soviet Union were worthless unless they were based on strength and backed by force.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 8--In biting cold, firemen stretched 1,700 feet of hose and crawled from barge to barge over improvised ladder bridges here early today to reach a blazing tugboat moored in the Arthur Kill off Port Avenue.

PARIS, Feb. 8--Premier Georges Bidault got a respite today, which he used in trying to strengthen his Government, shaken by the events of the past few days and particularly by yesterday's bitter debate.
DETROIT, Feb. 8 (AP)--John Kaliszewski, convict, declared today that his story about the Walter Reuther shooting was not another of his many admitted lies.

ALBANY, Feb. 8--Declaring that the serious water shortage and the scarcity of wood products made immediate legislative action urgent, Assemblyman Jeremiah J. Ashcroft, Democrat, of Utica, introduced a bill today to give the state control over the cutting of all merchantable timber in New York.

Fleming-Hall Tobacco Company will promote its Sano denicotinized cigarettes in an expanding campaign reaching, initially, fifty major cities throughout the country, it was announced yesterday.

The two main non-Communist Italian labor federations have at last united. This news could be packed into a small item from Rome yesterday but the implications are large. Italy remains one of the major bulwarks of democracy against communism.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Harvey of London of the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Camilla, to Donal McDonnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert McDonnell of 320 Park Avenue and Greenwich, Conn. The wedding will take place in the spring in London and the couple will make their home in this country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Dr. Harold C. Urey, atomic scientist, warned a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee today that the threat of atomic warfare might be used this year to alienate one or more nations signatory to the North Atlantic Pact.

The organization of a committee to plan a new arts center at Columbia University to provide "a gathering place for the promotion of mutual interests of the drama, music, painting, sculpture, architecture and associated arts" was announced yesterday. Richard Rodgers, composer and producer,

LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP)--The British Labor Government publicly rebuked the new anti-Laborite Government of Australia today for having derationed gasoline, thereby risking more outgo from the sterling area's common pool of dollars.
Women must find their own way out of their dilemmas, Lawrence K. Frank, director of the Caroline Zachry Institute of Human Development, declared yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 8--Sir Mohammed Zafrullah Khan, Foreign Minister of Pakistan, told the United Nations Security Council today the princely state of Kashmir was bound to his own country by ties of geography, economics, tradition and security.

Pierre Etchebaster, world champion, and Esmond B. Martin of New York reached the final of the pro-amateur court tennis doubles tournament yesterday with the Philadelphia team of William L. Van Alen and Jimmy Dunne, Racquet Club professional.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The way was cleared today to start payment of cash benefits averaging $600 to the 120,000 members of the United States armed forces incarcerated in German and Japanese camps in World War II.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 8--The discovery of a plot directed from abroad, with a view of spreading confusion and discord in the Argentine Government, was announced tonight by the Federal police.
PARIS, Feb. 8--Abandoning barrel lines, Mad Carpentier turns her mastery of bias cut to straight or flared lines in handsome clothes lovely in coloring and utterly devoid of trimming.

TENAFLY, N.J., Feb. 8--Mr. and Mrs. William Eugene Baker of Cotswold, Tenafly, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Madeleine Helene, to Crowell Hadden, son of Mrs. Crowell Hadden of Glen Cove, L.I., and the late Mr. Hadden. The wedding will take place the latter part of March.
HONG KONG, Feb. 8--One of the largest evacuations of United States nationals from Communist China is expected some time in March, if arrangements now being negotiated in Shanghai materialize.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 31--The partiality of Hollywood notables for Mexican divorces has focused interest here on how valid these quick matrimonial dissolutions may be in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--William Webster, executive vice president of the New England Electric System of Boston, Mass., was nominated by President Truman today to be chairman of the Research and Development Board.

Coffee futures opened slightly easier yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and continued to decline in early dealings on scattered commissionhouse selling. After declines ranging from 40 to 50 points, the market rallied sharply on hedge covering and demand from producer interests.

SLAMORADA, Fla., Feb. 8--A bright sun and faint breath of wind provided perfect conditions for fishing the flats that stretch from Arsenic to Little Rabbit Keys. And with a little cooperation from the bonefish it would have been a perfect day.

Stockholders of D.A. Schulte, Inc., at the annual meeting yesterday elected as directors Joseph A. Neff, Howard G. Strauss and Irving I. Rosenbaum to replace George R. Coughlan, Edwin H. Koehler and Max Meyer, who resigned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The Louisville Gas and Electric Company, Louisville, Ky., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration stament covering 101,297 shares of no par value common stock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The House approved tentatively late today a proposed $131,700,000 annual increase in postal rates in many categories, ranging from postcards to catalogues and heavy parcel post packages.

Representatives of two groups of transit police charged yesterday that the crime rate on the city's subway system was increasing because of the "inertia" and "indifference" of the Board of Transportation.
LONDON, Feb. 8--Mr. and Mrs. Clement R. Attlee set out in their 12-year-old family car today on an eight-day campaign tour to gather votes for the Labor party.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--John J. Scanlan, an officer of the State Department for thirty-five years, died at Georgetown Hospital today at the age of 57.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Robert L. Garner, vice president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, said today that the bank was "making progress" in negotiations for a loan to Yugoslavia and was also investigating the possibility of bolstering Turkey's economy through private enterprise.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., Feb. 8--Production and consumption of consumer goods have decreased drastically in the Soviet Union in favor of turning out producers' goods, Dr. Naum Jasny, former Soviet and German statistician, told a University of Notre Dame symposium on the Soviet Union here today.

ROME, Feb. 8--The first contingents of the Italian police force sailed for Somaliland late this evening after the Senate had approved the bill apropriating 6,000,000,000 lire (about $9,600,000) for the expenses of administering that former Italian colony under United Nations trusteeship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Dr. E.W. Engstrom, vice president in charge of research for the Radio Corporation of America Laboratories, gave a demonstration today of color television electronically controlled so as to be fully compatible with present black-andwhite telecasts.

CARDIFF, Wales, Feb. 8--Here in the capital of Wales, where miners' memories of the years between the wars are still as black as the coal they dig from the Rhondda Valley, Winston Churchill attempted today to erase the impression that the Conservative party in those days had been guilty of economic oppression.

Manufacturers of neckties in Cuba, Mexico and Europe have voiced a desire to affiliate themselves with the Men's Tie Foundation, it was announced yesterday by Myron H. Ackerman, president.

Heart-shaped baskets for molding coeur a la creme come again from France, to sell at Hammacher Schlemmer, 145 East Fiftyseventh Street, for 30 to 65 cents each, depending on size. A large one, to give a dozen or more portions, is made here by blind workers; of sturdier construction than the imports, it costs $2.50.
A third company seeking to operate helicopter mail service in the New York metropolitan area was represented at the Civil Aeronautics Board hearing at 233 Broadway yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb.8--Mr. A.B. was the favorite and Liberty Rab was the second choice in the threefurlong Florida Breeders' Stakes at Hialeah today. They made a one, two finish at the head of the field of ten Florida-foaled 2-yearolds and gave Miami's Christopher family plenty of reason to whoop it up.

Pairings for the dozen relay races that fifty-six college, club and school teams will run at the New York A.C. Games in Madison Square Garden Saturday night were announced yesterday by Edward M. Swinburne, the Winged Foot's chairman of athletics.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 8 (AP)-- The Chinese Nationalists today warned populations in the Communist capital of Peiping and nine other cities to get ready for air raids.

The fantastic never-never land in which privately operated transit abides in New York City was never so well illuminated as by the arbitration award of Prof. Emanuel Stein of New York University. The Third Avenue Transit System already owed its employes $1,100,000 in retroactively increased pay for work done as long ago as late 1947.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 8--Two United States citizens, Mormon missionaries, disappeared from Olomouc, in Moravia, ten days ago, the United States Embassy disclosed today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8-- Harry Bridges told a Federal court jury today that any time he thought it would "do the union any good" he never had hesitated to "call upon any official or functionary of the Communist party at any time."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)-- Tennessee Gas Transmission Company, Houston, Tex., told the Federal Power Commission today that it wanted to expand, by 50,000,000 cubic feet, to 250,000,000, the daily capacity of the pipeline system it planned to build for gas service in Ohio, New York and New England.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--President Truman today appointed Mrs. George Hamlin Shaw, New York social worker, and Francis Keppel, Dean of the Faculty of Education of Harvard University, as additional members of the President's Committee on Religion and Welfare in the Armed Forces.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 8-- The Commission on State Government Organization recommended to the General Assembly today that Connecticut's 184 state departments and agencies be consoliated into fourteen departments and three service agencies for better efficiency and economy.
A proposal to increase the insurance that taxicab operators must carry was opposed sharply yesterday by the spokesmen for the industry here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The British Government has proposed in a memorandum to the State Department to limit to 4,000,000 tons a year the amount of United States refined petroleum that would be displaced by British production throughout the sterling area under its substitution program.
RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 8--Mrs. Emma K. Vernell, who will be 75 years old in August, is observing her thirtieth anniversary this week as New Jersey's only woman fireman.
A mongrel dog was rescued yesterday by a 27-year-old patrolman from the ice-covered water of a Central Park lake as 200 persons looked on in freezing temperatures. The animal died soon afterward.

In a bristling National Basketball Association game that went to two overtime periods, the St. Louis Bombers beat the Knickerbockers, 84--82, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night before 2,500 fans.
Purchase of Sagamore Hill, the estate of President Theodore Roosevelt at Cove Neck, L.I., for a national shrine to the late President was announced last night by the Roosevelt Memorial Association.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Feb. 9--Another attempt to negotiate a soft-coal wage agreement ended in failure early today and President Truman's board of inquiry announced it would go ahead with its formal hearing at 10 A.M.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 8-- Dr. Charles Seymour, president of Yale University, tonight warned privately endowed universities against dependence upon Government benefactions if they sought to maintain their traditional freedom.

A Navy pilot went down with his jet fighter plane yesterday when, apparently because of engine trouble, it plunged into Jamaica Bay. The pilot, who was alone, was identified as Jack J. Conrad, Chief Aviation Pilot. His name was disclosed after naval officials had notified his wife, Ruth, of 459A ...

Retailers appear to be ready to take decisive action in ordering late spring and summer dresses; manufacturers here reported yesterday, In better lines stores have not carried over large inventories of resort merchandise, it was declared, because they had underbought on such lines.

Last night's performance of Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" at the Metropolitan Opera House marked the first appearance of the distinguished European baritone, Paul Schoeffler, in the part of Hans Sachs.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Preparationg for its part in this year's International Ice Patrol are being made by the United States Coast Guard, its headquarters said today.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Feb. 8 The greatest merchant ship ever ordered for this country had her official beginning here today in the plant of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company.

IT'S been a mighty long time since New York University well-wishers could cheer wholeheartedly at a football game. For the better part of a decade at least they have had practically nothing to root for. A restrained, "Noble effort, old chap," could have applied either to a cricket game at Lords or a gridiron contest involving N.Y.U.

DETROIT, Feb. 8--Lynn McNaughton, retired automotive executive, who was a leader in the industrial growth of Detroit from the turn of the century, died early today in the Henry Ford Hospital at the age of 68. He had been suffering from a heart ailment for ...

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L.L., Feb. 8--A plan that calls for 43,000 volunteers to man air-raid warning posts in the industrial Northeast was announced here today by headquarters of the First Air Force.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 9 (AP) --Fred Haas Jr. of New Orleans anti Johnny Palmer of Badin, N.C., fought chilling north winds and unpredictable greens today for three-antler-par 68's and a tie for the first round lead in the $10,000 Texas open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--A Federal District Court found today that John L. Lewis' major demands in the soft coal contract dispute, other than wages, were unfair labor practices. Judge Richmond B. Keech said he would issue an injunction to stop them.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 9--Chancellor Konrad Adenauer proposed today the spending of 3,400,000,000 Deutsche marks, approximately $810,000,000, to fight unemployment in Western Germany, now nearing the 2,000,000 figure.
Mental illness is a "scourge" comparable in deadliness to the weapons of mass destruction, Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, president of the United Nations General Assembly, said yesterday.

A "disappointing" result of yesterday's sixth water holiday led Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, to announce that if the present trend of growing water consumption and light rainfall continues, new restrictions on water use will go into effect by March 1.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The House passed and sent to the Senate today the bill designed to increase postal rates in many mailing categories to produce $131,000,000 more revenue a year.

The introduction of new methods in practical teaching was made known yesterday at Barnard College. In cooperation with Dean Millicent C. McIntosh, the sociology, government and economics departments are expanding their provisions for supervised field work.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP) --Miss Mary Agnes Wall of Menominee, Mich., pulled a major upset in the fortieth annual Palm Beach women's golf championship today, defeating the defending champion. Miss Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, 5 and 4.
Added safety and comfort are emphasized in the 1950 Hudson Super and Custom Commodore models presented yesterday by the Hudson Motor Car Company.

Sales and earnings of the United States Rubber Company declined last year as a result of unfavorable selling prices, particularly on tires during midsummer, and the general downward trend in business, the fifty-eighth annual report to stockholders declared yesterday.

A one-year emergency program designed to prepare college graduates for certification to teach in elementary schools in New York City and state again will be offered this year by City College and Brooklyn College under the sponsorship of the four municipal colleges, the Board of Higher Education announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The Atomic Energy Commission told the nation today in grim detail what to expect should atomic bombs start to fall among its cities and advised the Governors of the states how little protection was offered by most of the buildings in which the population worked and lived.
Plans for an apartment building on upper Broadway to cost $1,500,000, were among sketches filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. Details of these and other plans follow:
Four more signed contracts were checked off yesterday by Greater New York's three major league ball clubs.
Gum wrappers, paper napkins, bags of garbage and other expendables that they had strewn about Manhattan cost 230 men and women $710 in fines yesterday in Lower Manhattan Court.

CLEARWATFR, Fla., Feb. 9-- Until the big tarpon arrive, in about two months, the majority of the West Coast anglers are content with what some of the sailfish, marlin and tuna specialists call "small fry," but moving up the Gulf Coast from the Everglades to Clearwater we encountered few angling complaints.

ALBANY, Feb. 9--Bills to create a $100,000,000 state debt to provides housing-project loans for middle-income families were introduced today by Senator James J. Crawford, Democrat, of Brooklyn, and Assemblyman Leonard Farbstein, Democrat, of Manhattan.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 9--Eight 4year-old fillies and a pair of 5year-old mares furnished the action in the main guessing game at Hialeah Park today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 10-- Governor Dewey of New York declared in his second lecture tonight at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs that "it must have been some very clumsy Republican" who tried to pin the label "welfare state" on the Truman Administration.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 9--Yale University announced today that after a five-year search it has received as a gift from the 14year-old Dalai Lama a 99-volume block-printed edition of the Kagyur. A collection of the sacred scriptures and canons of lamaisms, known to American scholars as the Kanjur, it contains nearly 1,100 separate works, a great part of them attributed to Buddha himself.

With the arrest of two men on charges of assault, robbery and burglary and of a third man as an alleged receiver of stolen property, the police announced yesterday that the $25,000 jewel robbery from the Beekman Place home of Billy Rose, restauranteur and newspaper columnist, was solved.
The creative forces of writers and artists provide powerful allies in the constant effort to remove racial or religious prejudice, Robert R. Patterson, former Secretary of War, declared yesterday.
One hundred and one ideas for easier and more attractive homemaking can be had just for the looking at Abraham Straus' gala Homemakers Carnival, which will open Monday for two weeks.
Those angels who hover over Broadway on wings of dollar bills were attacked yesterday as a menace to the theatre.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Francis Adams Truslow, president of the New York Curb. Exchange, said today that the Exchange favored the general principle of a bill to extend the coverage of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 but he expressed "misgivings" about the proposed deletion of Section 12(F)3 of the act.

THIS has been a rather strange track season. There have been breakdowns in such mechanical gadgets as starting gates, which is bad enough. But far more alarming is the fact that there also has been a mass breakdown of the officials, a much more serious matter. Machines can be repaired but once those spinning wheels in an official's noggin begin to sputter and throw off sparks there is no hope of redemption.

The late President Franklin D. Roosevelt would have engaged in a "more direct contact with the Russians than President Truman has," Samuel I. Rosenman, former Presidential adviser, declared yesterday.

Eight contract bridge teams won their way to the quarter-finals in the tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup at the Pierre Hotel last night. They were the survivors of fifty-two teams that started play Monday night.
