WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)-- Senators heard today that the power tariff of the Bonneville power administration would have to be increased. The Senate Interior Committee was told yesterday that if sixteen additional plants were built and their power added to the Bonneville pool, the rate would have to be $21.57 for each "kilowatt year."

The Board of Estimate formally approved yesterday the $60,250 appropriation requested by District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County to enable him to expand and continue for at least six months his pending investigation of organized gambling and racketeering in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Presilent Truman today urged Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of New York, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, to "go ahead full steam" with his investigation of concentration of economic power in, several industries.

Diversion of highway funds and opposition to a resolution in the State Assembly declared to discriminate against truck users were outlined yesterday at the annual convention of the New York State Motor Truck Association at the Statler Hotel.
The Department of Hospitals took its second major step yesterday in its five-year program to revitalize out-patient clinics in the city's thirteen general hospitals.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 9 --Edward Granville Theodore, former Premier of Queensland and Commonwealth Treasurer, and one of the most colorful and most controversial figures in Australian politics, died in Sydney today after a long illness. He was 65 years old.
MANILA, Feb. 9 (UP)--The Senate minority leader, Camilo Osias, demanded to know today how far the United States would go to defend the Philippines.

The New York City Ballet Company will play an engagement of six weeks at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. London, at the invitation of the British Arts Council, beginning, appropriately enough, on July 4.

An imaginative use of new materials was apparently the quality that appealed most to the jury that selected the 1949 award winners in the fourth annual home furnishings design competition sponsored by the American Institute of Decorators.

Delayed by Atlantic storms and winds of gale force that added twenty hours to her normal sixday schedule, the French liner, Ile de France, docked at 1:30 P.M. yesterday at Pier 88, North River, with 1,124 passengers.

An interesting problem has been placed by David Dubinsky before the executive council of the American Federation of Labor. Mr. Dubinsky was one of the few important labor leaders in this city to support Newbold Morris for Mayor last fall in the face of combined AFL-CIO backing for Mr. O'Dwyer.
Cities and towns in many parts of the country prepared yesterday to revive wartime "brownout" regulations to conserve their vanishing coal supplies.

ABADAN, Iran, Jan. 23--The International Labor Office committee organized as a result of the 1948 petroleum industry conference of the organization with representatives of the oil producing states and labor in the petroleum industry is now investigatins in the Anglo-Iranian fields the charges made at that meeting.
PROVIDENCE, R.I. Feb. 9 (AP) --F. Ellis Jackson, 70-year-old Rhode Island architect known the nation over for his colonial buildings, collapsed and died this morning of a heart attack.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Franz Bluecher, Vice Chancellor of the West German Federal Republic, asserted today that "no German" would deny the right of France to the industrial production of the Saar.

TOKYO, Feb. 9--Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today that the Japanese Government had been authorized by the United States to establish long-awaited official trade missions in New York, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Honolulu in order to promote the commercial and travel relationships which this nation has been deprived of since the war.

The Hapag-Lloyd Travel Bureau, for many years before the war one of the largest and best-known travel agencies in Europe, has reestablished its branches throughout the Continent and opened an intensive drive to promote and further American tourist travel in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--By a voice vote, the Senate approved today a $500,000,000 authorization for construction at 174 military and naval installations at home and abroad. The same vote passed an authorization for construction of some 7,000 homes for married personnel of the Army, Navy and Air Force and more barracks for single men.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 9-- RKO has concluded a deal to borrow Lizabeth Scott from Hal Wallis for two pictures this year, the first of which will be "The Wall Outside," a photoplay by Ketti Frings which Wallis at one time held under an option. John Houseman will produce the film and John Cromwell will direct.

Throwing sharp emphasis on the size of utility company expenditures to meet the unrelenting demand for electricity, the past two days' news revealed that four utilities will have spent more than $486,000,000 by the end of next year on plant construction.
The rare occurrence of a defeat for Pierre Etchebaster was witnessed yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

An able authority has estimated that New York State is one billion dollars behind in the expenditures it should have made on highways. Charles H. Sells, former State Superintendent of Public Works, says that 86 per cent...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Administration forces in the House of Representatives closed ranks today to pass the Far Eastern Economic Assistance bill. The vote was 240 to 134.
In the first place, let us pay homage to Bruno Walter for his matchless performance, with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, of Gustav Mahler's First Symphony.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)-- President Truman said today that he did not know of anything that can be done to save the Waltham Watch Company, now closed down because of financial troubles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--A Senate subcommittee called today for "immediate" consideration of a $500,000,000 program of loans and technical assistance for the development of small business enterprises here and abroad.

MOSCOW, Feb. 9--The Soviet press charged today that the United States had launched a "new wave of war hysteria," but said that attempts to frighten the Soviet people were doomed to failure. Several editorials declared that Soviet science was honorably fulfilling Premier Joseph Stalin's orders not only to equal but to surpass scientific achievements beyond Russia's borders.

The registration committee of the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union will take action tonight on the protest against the procedure followed in determining Don Gehrmann of Wisconsin as the winner over Fred Wilt of the New York Athletic Club in the disputed finish of the Wanamaker Mile at the Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden on Jan. 28.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP)-- Russia has a bigger air force than the United States but this country holds actual "air supremacy," according to John F. Victory, executive secretary of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics.

Opening his hearings to purge the Times Square area of sharp practices by jewelry store auctioneers, License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey heard a witness yesterday tell how he had allegedly been tricked as the high bidder for a diamond ring in a Forty-second Street jewelry store.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 9--The South Korean Government alleged today that the Soviet Union was leasing from the Communist-led North Korean regime several ports in North Korea. The assertion, contained in a summary of recent reports from North Korea, said the lease agreement applied particularly to the harbors of Chongjin, Songjin and Wonsan.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 9--The Hudson County Board of Freeholders today adopted the 1950 county budget. It provides for an over-all expenditure of $20,2$8,809, of which $17,329,392 is to be raised by taxation, $1,005,642 less than for 1949. At the public hearing on the budget no objections were made.

ALBANY, Feb. 9--A proposal for permanent registration plates for the 3,OO0,000 automobiles owned in this state was revived today with the introduction of bills under the sponsorship of the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicles.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 9--A special mission reported back to the United Nations today that it had looked into the marital affairs of West Africa's famed Fon of the Bikom tribe and his 110 wives and had come up with the conclusion that maybe polygamy, at least in Africa, wasn't such a bad idea, after all.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP)--Florida, which boasts at best one Class A baseball team of its own, again is ready to play host to most of the major and top minor league teams. The grapefruit league each spring gives its biggest baseball season to the Sunshine State.

President John L. Lewis felt the teeth of the Taft-Hartley Act closing on himself and his union yesterday. Whether this means that the coal strike is nearer its end, except in the sense that every strike has an end toward which each day pushes it, is uncertain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--President Truman declared today that Russia's apparent possession of the atomic bomb gave her diplomatic bargaining equality with the United States and consequently he felt that our proposals for international control of atomic energy were now more appropriate than when they were first made.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9--Members of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen and the Order of Railway Conductors have voted 95.5 per cent in favor of a nation-wide strike, officials of the two unions announced today.
A police campaign against mugging in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn gained momentum yesterday with the arrest of five more youths in addition to two locked up last Friday.
WHEATON, Ill., Feb. 9--A spontaneous mass confession by 1,500 students of Wheaton College passed the twenty-four-hour mark tonight and showed no sign of a let-up.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The International Brotherhood of Paper Makers, AFL, announced today that it was returning an award given to its official publication, The Paper Maker, by Freedoms Foundation and denounced the Foundation as "a front organization for American reactionaries."

BOSTON, Feb. 9 (AP)--The Holy Cross Crusaders tonight registered their nineteenth consecutive basketball victory after their stiffest fight of the season, downing stubborn, speedy Rhode Island State. 74--69.

Since everyone works very hard in "All You Need Is One Good Break," which opened at the Mansfield last evening, a speculative theatregoer cannot help wondering what they think they are doing. Arnold Manoff has written a tabloid tale about a tenement wastrel.

HONG KONG, Feb. 9--Communist China lashed out at the United States today, blaming it for the heavy Nationalist air raids that the Communists said had almost completely destroyed the American-owned Shanghai Power Company plant and caused more than 1,000 deaths and injuries.

Wielding a ten-inch carving knife, a six-foot three-inch, 230pound longshoreman drove off yesterday in a southbound Broadway bus after forcing twenty passengers and the driver to leave at Forty--fourth Street in Times Square.

NEMESIS personifies "the Goddess of Retribution, who brings down all immoderate good fortune, checks the presumption that attends it * * * and is the punisher of extraordinary crimes."* We must now lay bare the error and vanity of cold-blooded calculation of the Soviet Government and enormous Communist machine, and their amazing ignorance about where they stood themselves.
"My name is Peter Fischel," he said clearly, "how do you do? Give me a kiss, Schnukelchen. Ach Gott, ich hab' Dich doch so lieb! [I love you so much!]."

Father Knickerbockers own recommendation for bringing up baby to the age of two--"New York City's Baby Book, a Handbook for Parents"--has been reissued by the Department of Health and is now being distributed, the department announced yesterday.

Another step has been taken in the painful process of settling the status of King Leopold of the Belgians. There will be a referendum on his return next month. The struggle has not become more edifying as time passes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee completed its hearings today on the treaty that would make genocide, or race murder, an international crime. It will meet soon to vote on a recommendation for Senate ratification of the covenant.

JERUSALEM, FeB. 9--Three Orthodox representatives in the Cabinet boycotted today's meeting and indicated that they would continue to stay away until the Government assured religious education for all Orthodox children in immigrant camps.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (AP)--The New York Rangers took undisputed possession of fourth place in the National Hockey League standings tonight by defeating the cellardwelling Chicago Black Hawks, 5 to 3, before 11,415 fans.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9--One by one Harry R. Bridges today considered from the witness chair a series of so-called closed Communist meetings at which Government witnesses at his perjury-conspiracy trial had placed him.
BOSTON, Feb. 9--Medical researchers at the Massachusetts General Hospital offered hope today of forestalling coronary thrombosis among men around the 40-year age bracket.

NORFOLK, Feb. 9--An inexperienced assistant navigator, whose position plot on the U.S.S. Missouri broke down just as the course grew dangerous, appeared at today's session of the naval court of inquiry here to furnish another link in what the skipper, Capt. W. D. Brown, described as an "unusual and unfortunate chain of circumstances" leading to the battleship's grounding last month.

ALBANY, Feb. 9--Governor Dewey and his policy advisers have given a green light to a revision of the state's inheritance tax laws that will cut the tax liability of a surviving spouse by an estimated 29 per cent.

ALBANY, Feb. 9--Francis T. Spaulding, State Education Commissioner, refused today to order the New York City Board of Higher Education to file formal charges against Professor William E. Knickerbocker of City College for conduct unbecoming a member of the staff because of alleged antiSemitic utterances.

In a garden setting of quince blossoms, pink roses and green foliage, Miss Sue Ellen Mayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold C. Mayer of 885 Park Avenue, was married last night to Robert Rittmaster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Rittmaster of 240 Central Park South, in the ballroom of the Pierre.

PLYMOUTH, England, Feb. 9-- Blood ties and political kinship brought two of Britain's most eloquent and colorful political opponents to this partly destroyed Devonshire port today in quest of votes for their rival parties. They were Winston Churchill, wartime Prime Minister, and Aneurin Bevan who, many think, aspires to that high office.

A cat-and-mouse game, in which twenty-six Government operatives trailed, lost and relocated two spy suspects during four frantic hours last March 4, was described yesterday at the trial in Federal Court of Judith Coplon and Valentin A. Gubitchev.

Gene Rayburn and Dee Finch, the morning disk jockey team on WNEW, will be featured in their first network radio series over the American Broadcasting Company, beginning Saturday, Feb. 18, from 9 to 10 P.M. They will replace Bob Crosby, who has occupied the period for the last five weeks in a show entitled "Crosby's Night Shift."

PARIS, Feb. 9--The Foreign Ministers of the Netherlands and Belgium and the acting Foreign Minister of France met tonight to discuss the desirability of resuming negotiations for a trade bloc composed of their three countries and Italy and Luxembourg, in the absence of any decisive move toward "integration" by the Marshall Plan nations as a whole.
AUCKLAND, N.Z., Feb. 9 (AP)-- Australia's track and field stars equaled one world record and bettered a meet mark todety at the British Empire Games.
In the sophisticated atmosphere of the Carnaval Room at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel, Stern's offered a gay little showing of McKettrick-Williams dresses yesterday at the luncheon hour.

DERBY, England, Feb. 9--Prime Minister Attlee rejected tonight repeated taunts by Winston Churchill and other Conservative speakers that the Labor party's postwar record of full employment was mainly attributable to United States aid.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower gave his full and unqualified approval last night to the manufacture by the United States of the hydrogen bomb. To do otherwise, he declared, would be equivalent to our burying our heads in the sand.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 9--Mem ber states were urged today by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to release their textbooks so as to reflect the "world point of view" and to eliminate narrow, nationconcepts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--A Senate foreign relations subcommittee heard details today of another plan to convert the United Nations into an effective world government, or to form a substitute organization if the Soviet Union refused to participate. It was the fifth in a series of peace enforcement proposals the subcommittee is considering.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 9--A bronze fountain, set in a low granitecurved pool, fifty-three feet in diameter, will be erected in front of the National Gallery of Art in Washington as a memorial to Andrew W. Mellon, financier and former Secretary of the Treasury, who gave the gallery to the nation in 1941.

Only a few price changes were noted yesterday by the Department of Markets in its weekly survey of retail grocery stores. Tomatoes and cauliflower were 4 cents less than last Friday; Florida oranges were up a nickel to 50 cents for five pounds and bananas advanced 2 cents to 17 a pound.

St. John's, under extreme duress for nearly 30 minutes, fought through to a decisive 62-50 triumph over rugged Canisius at Madison square Garden last night. It was the nineteenth victory in twentyone games for the marauding Redskins, who are very much in the running for a post-season tournament bid.

Coffee futures were steady in moderately active trading during yesterday's session on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The market opened steady and gradually worked higher on local trade demand.
ALBANY, Feb. 9--Fire caused by an oil stove explosion resulted in the death early today of an Albany family of five.

Mrs. Christy Tiffany Knight of 1186 Lexington Avenue and John T. Pratt Jr. of Glen Cove, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Christy, to Bayard Cutting Auchincloss, son of Reginald L.G. Auchincloss of 16 East Eighty-ninth Street and the late Mrs. Ruth Cutting Auchincloss.

GREAT FALLS, Mont., Feb. 9-- About 5,200 United States and Canadian troops and 100 planes were concentrated between Whitehorse, Yukon Territory, and the Alaskan frontier today, ready for the beginning Monday of the largest combined sub-Arctic maneuver since the war.

A vacant plot of land, 100 by 100 feet, at the northeast corner of Thirty-first Avenue and Fortyeighth Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by Chevy Stores Corporation from Riker Subdivision, Inc., for improvement with stores. Edward A. Dangler was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 9--The Shah opened the first session of the Iranian Senate and the sixteenth session of the House of Deputies or Majlis this morning with a warning that the time for internal bickering was over and that there was a program to accomplish a change in the status of the Iranian masses.

Ed Danowski, whose Fordham team surprised football fans with its 5-3 record last season, has, signed to coach the Rams for the next two years at "a substantial increase in salary," Jack Coffey, graduate athletic manager, announced yesterday.

A legal wrangle over forfeiture of $110,000 bonds for two alleged members of a travelers' check counterfeiting ring ended yesterday with the attorney for the bonding company being subpoenaed to appear before a Federal grand jury this morning.

Despite the unfavorable climate for business created by a "political economy," the country is in for a good era of full employment and satisfactory volume, according to Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men. Earnings in 1950, he said, will be slightly lower than they were last year, but a slightly reduced volume of business can be counteracted by greater promotional efforts.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9--Firming cash wheat premiums in the Southwest, combined with aggressive buying attributed to mills, resulted in a rapid advance in prices in the last few minutes of trading here, with tho close on tho Board of Trade at the top prices, net gains being 1 1/8 to 2 1/4 cents a bushel.
After two successive weekly rises which brought them up $61,000,000, business loans made by banks in this area dropped $11,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.

LONDON, Feb. 9 (UP)--Scientists of the United States, Canada and Britain opened a four-day conference today--with one delegate missing--on Russia's potentiality in atomic warfare and on means of safeguarding Western atomic secrets.
HAVANA, Feb. 9--Manuel Enrique Rionda, prominent sugar importer of New York, died at his home in the suburb of Miramar of a heart attack this morning. He was 72 years old.

Kid Gavilan, Havana welterweight who is generally regarded as the foremost contender for the world 147-pound crown, will engage Billy Graham of the East Side in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Although Graham's boxing style is of a nature that promises to make trouble for the Cuban, the latter is favored at odds of 5 to 7.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 9--The inquiry into an alleged plot directed from abroad to sow strife in Argentina ended abruptly tonight, when it was announced that because of new evidence all the suspects had been released and the informer himself was being held for trial.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 9--The Yugoslav Government has requested the assistance of the United States Government in getting, at an early date, three loans totaling $36,000,000 from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the International Monetary Fund and the Export-Import Bank.

Recent relief cuts announced by the Department of Welfare have reached "more than the publicized 5 per cent," William T. Kirk, chairman of the New York City chapter of the American Association of Social Workers, declared yesterday at its headquarters, 289 Fourth Avenue.

Negotiations between the Communications Workers of America, CIO, and the Long Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company reached an impasse yesterday, raising anew the possibility of a national telephone strike.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9--Forty-four of the 110 companies whose stocks are listed dually on exchanges in both Chicago and New York have appointed transfer agents in Chicago, Midwest Stock Exchange officials said today.
One or more New York public school teachers who have been accused of being Communists will be brought to trial by the Board of Education, it was announced yesterday at a special meeting of the board.

American Airlines has placed orders for eleven new fifty-two passenger planes and spare parts, valued at $13,000,000, with the Douglas Aircraft Company, it was announced yesterday. Delivery of the DC-6B's will start next February and be completed by mid-summer of next year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--President Truman declared today that there were "real possibilities" of increasing the present water power capacity of New York and of the New England States by 50 per cent. He proposed the formation of a special commission to make a coordinated study of the St. Lawrence and other projects.
The stock market successfully weathered yesterday a new obstacle in the path of a resumption of coal production when negotiations brake down between the operators and miners.

"I HAVE little sense of humor, and suffer a good deal while writing what is supposed to be funny." It is the familiar lament of the comedian who wants to play Hamlet. In this case it is quoted from "Love Story,"* a pleasantly funny book by Ruth McKenney, who has written several other funny books about the delirious misadventures of her relatives and her self.
ANNAPOLIS, Feb. 9--The Ober anti-subversive law, invalidated last Sept. 13 by Judge Joseph Sherbow in two injunction suits in Baltimore, was reinstated today by the Maryland Court of Appeals.

Shows will be prevented from moving in or out of any Broadway house controlled by the Shuberts until an impasse is adjusted with the Theatrical Drivers and Teamsters Union, Local 817, AFL, it became known yesterday. Should the difficulty remain unresolved, it would affect the switch on Monday of "The Velvet Glove." starring...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)-- The Department of Justice today charged two leading drug-making concerns with trying to monopolize the sale of hard gelatin capsulesused for "vitamin pills" and other medicines. Attorney General McGrath announced the filing of a civil anti-trust action in Federal Court at Detroit against ParkeDavis Co., Detroit, and Eli Lilly Co., Indianapolis.

Protestants in the United States must be prepared to meet the challenge of a rising and powerful political state and decline any favors from it, warned the Rev. Dr. Frederick M. Meek, minister of Old South Church, Boston, last night at the annual dinner of the New York City Congregational Church Association.
The Swedish American liner Stockholm arrived yesterday morning with a new chief engineer, Erik Johan Toll, a veteran of thirty years' service with the line.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 9--Maj. Gen. Pierre Billotte, former French representative on the United Nations Military Staff Committee, urged, before his return to France last month, that the United States warn the Soviet Union against military intervention in Formosa,...

MADRID, Feb. 9--Spanish hopes for the future are pinned largely on a United States loan, and interest centers more specifically today on a mysterious visit of Alfred Barth, a vice president of the Chase National Bank who conferred yesterday with Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--A suggestion that the Federal Government charge fees for special services, and thus in one move cut down costs and add to revenues, may not get serious attention from the Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee, but it should.
WHITEHORSE, Yukon. Territory, Feb. 10 (UP)--All ten survivors of a United States Air Force C-47 crash were rescued tonight from a snow-swept 7,200-foot Yukon mountain.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--The United States has filed a forceful protest to the Chinese Nationalist Government against its "deliberate" and repeated bombing attacks on United States property in Shanghai.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $15,000,000 of forty-year debentures, due on March 15, 1990, that are to be sold at competitive bidding.

Today's events: "The Marriage of Figaro" at 2 o'clock and "Tosca" at 8:30, Metropolitan Opera; National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin, conductor, with students from the High School of Music and Art, Chatham Square and Greenwich House Music Schools, and the Music School Settlement; Michael Rabin, vielin, Carnegie Hall, 2:30.

Fred Wilt, not Don Gehrmann, should have been declared the winner of the Wanamaker Mile at the Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden on Jan. 28, it was ruled last night by the registration committee of the Metropolitan Association A.A.U.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 10--Circumstances surrounding the session of the newly elected Parliament that opened yesterday indicate that this Parliament's attitude will decide whether Iran is to have a dictatorship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--The politically explosive potato surplus, with up to possibly 40,000,000 bushels due for dumping at Government loss while Canadian potatoes invade United States markets, underwent serious review at the White House today.

The Federal tax structure "discriminates against equity capital" and acts as a deterrent to more extensive public interest in common stocks, Robert P. Boylan, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday in his annual report for 1949.

In a sumptuous apartment in East Fiftieth Street last night a group of young and veteran professional players--without benefit of "props" or a proscenium arch-- staged a three-hour rehearsal of Emlyn Williams' stage and motion picture hit, "Night Must Fall."
LONDON, Feb. 10--Dr. Klaus Fuchs lowered his eyes to the ground today when the prosecution read the confession he was said to have made.

The music blared and torchlights flared last night as New York City's Boy Scouts marked Boy Scout Week with a colorful exposition at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue that accented every facet of the scouting movement. It also called attention ...

The Sterling Investing Corporation bought two three-story dwellings, each on lot 17.6 by 99.11 feet, at 62 and 66 East 131st Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, from the Sundel Hyman Estate in a deal reported yesterday by Schimmer, Kerner Feder, the brokers. The property has a combined assessed valuation of $12,500 and was sold for cash.

MANCHESTER, England, Feb. 10--Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee carried dramatically a simple one-man campaign tour into the heart of this great industrial region today, telling the people in one-syllable words why they should vote for his Labor Government. From all appearances they seemed to be agreeing with him.

LONDON, Feb. 10--The doubts and confusion in the mind of Dr. Klaus Fuchs that were revealed at Bow Street Court today find a reflection in the moral uneasiness of a growing number of Britons over the failure of the great powers to find a way to control atomic energy.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Feb. 10 (AP) --More aggressive and responsible reporting on foreign affairs was urged today by James Reston, diplomatic correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 10--William H. Riley, 45-year-old vice president of the Letter Carriers Association, died suddenly yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital, and the most perplexed mourners today were two mongrel dogs that had been "helping" him deliver mail for the last twelve years.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10--The head of the National Council of Presbyterian Men today called for "Christian judgments" on the question of mass bombings of civilians in war.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 10-- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, said today that his organization stood above everything else for the settlement of disputes by persistent negotiation and conciliation, "month after month and year after year."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--The Export-Import Bank agreed today to lend up to $100,000,000 to the new Republic of Indonesia to help finance the purchase in the United States of capital goods needed for reconstruction of the Indonesian economy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--The export license privileges of six New York companies and certain of their officers were suspended today by the Department of Commerce for periods varying from two to four months because of "export control violations."

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 10--The Soviet Union charged officially today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was tapping United Nations telephone wires and was using "responsible" executives of the world organization to get confidential information.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--In seven minutes of desultory discussion, the Senate passed unanimously today and sent to the White House a bill for economic aid for Korea and Formosa.

The Cubs stepped into the baseball limelight yesterday with the announcement that in two separate player transactions, one with the Reds, the other with the Yankees, they had acquired a pair of hurlers who may help Manager Frankie Frisch to climb out of the National League cellar this year.

While the over-all picture in rayon textiles is still one of active selling, certain categories of finished goods have been difficult to sell because of resistance by the dress trade, it was reported in the trade yesterday. Converters of fabrics who carry a general line, it was said, are finding themselves with inventories of staples that are too large for comfort.
Senior partners of two New York law firms yesterday stoutly denied an accsation that they were "charming fellows with big expense accounts" trying to influence the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ASPEN, Col., Feb. 10--Speedsters from thirteen Nations continued today to run the thrilling downhill course and slalom descents to be used when the Federation Internationale de Ski starts its world championships in this mining town Monday.

"A coat is a dress and a dress is a coat" is not as much double talk as it sounds, in terms of fashion this season. So strongly has the coat-dress influenced both fields that coat designers are-fashioning their styles with a dress-like softness and dresses are following coat silhouettes.

A debate over whether state regents examinations for high school students should be abolished sparked the opening yesterday of the annual winter meeting of the New York State Council for the Social Studies in the Statler Hotel.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10--Calumet Farm's 5-year-old Coaltown and 9year-old Armed, who between them have won sixty races, thirtythree stakes, a couple of specials and close to $1,200,000, head the entries for tomorrow's $25,000 added McLennan Handicap at Hialeah Park.

The organizers of the fourth New York exhibition of paintings, drawings and sculpture by the Associated Artists of New Jersey at the Riverside Museum have done well by this group. For though the level of artistic achievement is not extremely high, it is kept even.

Y., Feb. 10 --In St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Caroline Wick Hardenbergh, daughter of Thomas Eddy Hardenbergh of Bedford Hills and Manchester, Mass., and the late Mrs. Hardenbergh, was married to David Ohler, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Richard Ohler of Jamaica

Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, New York, said today that if time will permit he hoped to accept an invitation to go to Canada for a first-hand study of Canadian newsprint operations.

With disease germs as "guinea pigs," chemists are trying to create new molecules that will attack and destroy microbes in the same way that the so-called miracle drugs penicillin and streptomycin operate, it was reported last night at a meeting of the American Chemical Society.

The seventh annual city-wide interdenominational service under auspices of the Interracial Fellowship of Greater New York will be held at 4 P. M. tomorrow, which is Race Relations Sunday, at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 110th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--A bill to reduce premiums on Federal Bank Deposit Insurance by an estimated 55 per cent, and to raise the coverage from $5,000 to $10,000 per individual account was favorably reported today by the senate Banking Committee.

VIENNA, Feb. 10--Two noncommissioned officers of the American military police in Vienna have been arrested and charged with kidnapping a friendly German on behalf of Russian occupation forces in return for 7,000 schillings ($250).

The turbulent politics of the Balkans, where the Tito-Cominform struggle is boiling up, has been duplicated in liberal and leftist Yugoslav-American circles in the United States, it was found yesterday.

The financial and commodity exchanges throughout the United States will be closed on Monday in observance of Lincoln's birthday. The livestock markets will be open as usual. The Canadian securities exchanges, the Winnipeg grain market and the London Stock Exchange will be open.
The world heavyweight champion was sprawled out, apparently helpless, in the laps of front row news men.

Consumption of water in New York hit a new high for a "dry day" on Thursday with 843,000,000 gallons used, 3,000,000 gallons more than on Thursday, Jan. 12, the previous high for a water holiday, officials disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON Feb. 10--Average primary market prices advanced 0.3 per cent in the week ending Feb. 7 the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Tin futures again were active here yesterday, with prices showing further advances. Near-by February and March contracts increased 12 points for the day and the more distant months were up 10 to 30 points.

PARIS, Feb. 10--Secretary of State Dean Acheson's statement Wednesday on United States foreign policy, which he described as seeking to create areas of strength to check Soviet expansion, has had a mixed reception in France.

BERLIN, Feb. 12--Contradictory reports today over the status of George Dertinger, Foreign Minister of the Eastern German Republic, have put political circles throughout Berlin on the qui vive for impending developments.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 12--A Southern Baptist clergyman gravely warned his fellow-churchmen here tonight that Christian civilization "could be nullified in an instant" by the explosive power inherent in the hydrogen comb.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UP)-- Federal internal revenue collections slumped $1,800,000,000 in the calendar year 1949, chiefly because of a 12 per cent drop in personal income tax payments, the Treasury Department reported today.
It's about time for the teenager, or her mother, to get out needle and thread and busy herself on a wardrobe that will take a girl to school, to luncheon, the matinee or to parties.

Sunray Oil Corporation has agreed to buy Atlas Corporation's holdings of the capital stock of the Barnsdall Oil Company for more than $42,000,000, Floyd B. Odlum, president of Atlas announced here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--With the question whether the soft coal miners would return to work complicated by John L. Lewis' birthday, a period of tense watchful waiting set in at the capital today.

Rows of empty red and yellow benches were in place yesterday in the basement of Madison Square Garden waiting to receive the 2,534 dogs that will compete in the seventy-fourth annual Westminster Kennel Club show.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12--Dr. Theodore L. Chase, noted surgeon and donor of $1,400,000 to medical projects of Temple University, died early today in Temple University Hospital. His age was 84.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 12--A former convict and gangster, intent on attacking a Washington University co-ed on a lonely road early today, was captured and savagely beaten by her escort, a football player, who felled the man with a flying tackle after dodging two bullets.

ALBANY, Feb. 12--Using civil rights as a starting point, Gover nor Dewey and the Republican legislative leadership tonight were weighing a strong dissent from the "interim" platform drafted for the Republican party by its National Committee in consultation with the party leadership in Congress.
TOKYO, Feb. 12--Margaret Sanger, world-renowned birth control advocate, has been barred from giving a series of lectures in Japan, a spokesman for the Tokyo newspaper Yomiuri said today.

A FEW days ago in Czechoslovakia the Communist powers that be were denouncing peasants who circulated rumors about visions of the Virgin Mary which were said to have appeared to several persons. As if that were not counter-revolutionary enough, the Virgin was reported to have been waving an American flag before a background of American troops and tanks.

ALBANY, Feb. 13--Under bipartisan sponsorship, a bill was introduced in the Legislature tonight to create a consumers' commission in the executive department to protect the interests of the consuming public.

A touch of winter caught up with the metropolitan area yesterday as the heaviest snowfall of the year was registered here. Abovefreezing temperatures caused the 2.3-inch fall to melt in the midtown section almost as fast as it reached the streets, but the slush and overcast combined to make it a thoroughly "dismal" day--as the Weather Bureau had forecast.

Though poultry consumption is still only about a sixth that of meat, it has increased so in the last decade that a fowl is as likely to appear mid-week on dining tables as on the traditional "every Sunday."

DETROIT, Feb. 13--Fresh negotiations between the striking United Automobile Workers, CIO, and the Chrysler Corporation became snarled today when the union presented 109 new non-economic demands.

New York extended a damp but expansive welcome mat yesterday for fourteen Japanese legislators and officials who are here to study the ways of democracy. Although the weather was anything but hospitable, the visitors got a warm reception all the way from Grant's Tomb to Bedloe's Island.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--Counsel for the International Typographical Union and its Chicago and Baltimore affiliates today filed a petition with the National Labor Relations Board asking it to reconsider some aspects of several cases decided against the I.T.U....

ALBANY, Feb. 13--Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of a special committee to consider a revised scheme for making the proposed $400,000,000 New York-Buffalo Thruway selfliquidating by a variation of the toll system.
RONCO, Pa., Feb. 13--Rain slashed at this mining community today, but it did nothing to put out the fires of revolt that flamed in the breast of Ronco miners.

Industry must assume a greater share of basic medical research costs, or risk surrender of "rights" in this field to Federal domination, L.T. Coggeshall, dean of the University of Chicago's division of biological sciences, declared last night.

CHICAGO, Feb.13--An expanded program of Federal Government old-age insurance must be relied upon to meet the problem of providing financial security for persons beyond working age, Sumner H. Slichter, Harvard University economist, said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13(AP)-- Midwest grain elevator representatives told Senators today they are fearful that the Commodity Credit Corporation will run them out of business.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Feb. 13 --Prime Minister Attlee carried his re-election campaign into Scotland today. It was more like a lecture tour than electioneering, but the middle and working class crowds that thronged to hear the Prime Minister cheered him till the rafters rang.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP)-- The Air Line Pilots Association today accused the Civil Aeronautics Board of "improper" investigating methods and said an independent air safety board would greatly reduce the death toll from air disasters.
The New York Heart Association opened last night its campaign for $750,000, this city's quota in the 1950 national cardiac crusade for $6,000,000. The drive will last for two weeks.

PARIS, Feb. 6--Madame Gres, in a collection eminently couture, keeps fullness in skirts that cover the calf, continues bodices that mold the midriff but abandons Greek drapery, turning her artistry to the combination of fabric and color.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 13-- Parliament passed today a bill empowering the central government to take steps to expel from India's eastern state (formerly province) of Assam nearly 500,000 Moslems reported to have infiltrated into Assam in the past two years from Pakistan's East Bengal province.

As a lawyer interested in city planning for fifteen years, as an active member of the Speakers Bureau, Citizens Charter Campaign Committee of 1936, and as the first secretary to the New York City Planning Commission for eight years (three on military leave), I fully endorse your strong editorial entitled "Showdown on City Planning."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 13--The Israeli Government has supplied data about Egyptian rearmament simultaneously to the State Department in Washington and to the United States Embassy in Tel Aviv, it was learned today. The data are designed to prove that the Egyptians are arming with aggressive intentions.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 13--The embargo on shipment of steel to Eastern Germany, proclaimed a week ago by the Bonn Government, is not operating effectively and about 1,000 tons of steel a day are entering the Soviet zone, it was learned today from authoritative sources.

Governor Dewey's proposal that the New York-to-Buffalo Thruway be completed within three years, through a bond issue financed by a charge on users of the highway, receives our hearty-approval. The cost, which was originally estimated at about $200,000,- ...

LONDON, Feb. 13--A woman member of Parliament addressed the nation tonight in one of five radio broadcasts allotted by the British Broadcasting Corporation to a Labor party speaker. Her talk was to help hold Scotland in line for Labor and to counteract irritation among housewives over rationing.

Eight meet records tumbled last night as local athletes captured the major share of the honors in the National A.A.U. men's junfor indoor track and field championships at the Third Engineers Group Armory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The nation's highest military leaders, the Joint Chiefs of Staff, delivered a confident report today on the state of American defenses in the Pacific. They described progress in the unification of the services and expressed their satisfaction with the combat efficiency of the armed forces stationed in Far Eastern outposts.

Reduction of New York State relief costs by $34,000,000 to $40,000,000 annually by enactment of a one-year residence requirement was proposed yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc. It will recommend the change at an Albany budget hearing tomorrow.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 13--A determination to preserve academic freedom at Vassar College was expressed by Miss Sarah Gibson Blanding, president of the college, in her third annual report. The report will be distributed to trustees, faculty, students and alumnae tomorrow.

The splendor of gold coloring as a decorative tool that has been used for many centuries on all kinds of objects is illustrated in an exhibition entitled "All That Glisters," which opens Friday at the Cooper Union Museum. It will remain on view through April 8.
AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 13--Mrs. Muriel Young Knowlton had announced the engagement of her daughter, Patricia, to Thomas Hooker Paine, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Rodney Paine of Duluth, Minn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The Supreme Court rejected, 5 to 3, today the request for a Federal tax income refund on the basis of a payment made to the Surdna Foundation, Inc., set up by the late John E. Andrus, the "millionaire straphanger" of Yonkers. The foundation bears his name spelled backward.

HARRINGTON PARK, N.J., Feb. 13--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul M. Buhrer of the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Marie, to Gerald Y. Genn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon C. Genn of Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 13--The battleship Missouri, scheduled to sail for Guantanamo, Cuba, tomorrow, surrendered her combat operations officer today as a defendant before the Naval Court of Inquiry investigating the vessel's grounding last month.

The Musicians Guild gave another concert in Town Hall last night, improving, if that is possible, its fine reputation for unusual programs and first-rate performances. The third in a series of four chamber-music programs, it was received with cheers and hearty applause.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 13-- Snow, sleet and rain failed to freeze and wash out the sailing dinghy racing today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. To keep up the record, venturesome skippers went out on the water under conditions that would have kept all others by a fireside.

In an eight-hour session starting the second round of the radio chess match with Yugoslavia, the American team yesterday failed to make any real headway in reducing the lead of their opponents, who had won the first round by 5 --4 .

The death in Florida on Sunday of John Rustgard, a native of Norway who became an author and one of Alaska's outstanding legal and political figures, was disclosed here yesterday. Mr. Rustgard, who was also a prospector and sociologist, died at his home, Villa Sorgenfri in Babson Park, at the age of 86.

The greater part of 2,532 dogs passed before the judges on a dozen green-matted rings in Madison Square Garden yesterday between 10 A.M. and late at night as the seventy-fourth Westminster Kennel Club show began its two-day run.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 13 --Robert L. Gerry Jr. of New York scored an upset today in winning the annual Tuxedo gold racquet court tennis tournament in a fourset match. He defeated Alastair B. Martin, also of New York. The scores were 5--7, 6--3, 6--2, 6--4.

Roland La Starza, undefeated Bronx heavyweight, came down with a cold and a fever yesterday with consequences that reached noisily into the precincts of the Massachusetts State Boxing Commission.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 13-- Undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern League was gained by Princeton tonight as the Tiger quintet fought from behind on four occasions to triumph over Cornell, 51--49.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--Attorney General J. Howard McGrath, until recently chairman of the Democratic National Committee, today directed United States attorneys to use the full power of their offices to prevent vote frauds in the elections this year. They were told to act without regard to party lines.

Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company reported yesterday for 1949 a consolidated net income of $20,230,520 after charges and taxes, equal to $8.40 each on the 2,065,411 common shares outstanding. The net income for 1948 was $24,095,518, or $10.25 a common share.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 4--Teheran is obsessed with the fate of Kuomintang China. This obsession is linked closely to the disappointment that the Shah did not bring home with him from the United States substantial offers of material aid.
TRENTON, Feb. 13--Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll sent an "econnomy" budget for the 1950-51 fiscal year to the New Jersey Legislature, with proposed expenditures of $164,131,075.

BUFFALO, Feb. 13 (AP)--A youth of 19 was charged today with first degree murder in the rifle-slaying of a Buffalo clubwoman. The body of the victim, Mrs. Marion L. Frisbee, 36, was found yesterday morning in a ditch twelve miles outside the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The proposals for taxing the insurance industry advanced by John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, were sharply attacked today by insurance company spokesmen, who, in turn, could not agree among themselves how they would be taxed.

Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey declared last night that "we are now reaping the harvest of careless war and post-war promises, of trifling with communism, of fumbling with containment and of squandering our assets." He spoke at the sixty-fourth annual Lincoln dinner of the National Republican Club at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, Feb. 13--Swirling snow "showers," 14 below zero cold and a brisk wind greeted the 5,200 men participating in Exercise Sweetbriar today as the first combined United States-Canadian Arctic exercise since the war opened.

Market research for British products has a high priority for dollars, according to distributors of English goods in the United States. Expenditures of this type, it was said, are considered a worthwhile investment, even though it is found that the products cannot be sold readily in this country.

Howard S. Cullman, one of the leading investors in New York stage productions, expressed opposition yesterday to proposed legislation requiring 200 square feet of parking area for every ten seats in playhouses of the future.

LONDON, Feb. 13--Although pre-election quietness continued in the stock markets here today, most sections remained firm with gains recorded among leading industrials and British Government securities.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 13--A "small but influential" group of educators was sharply criticized here today for "deliberately" attempting to circumvent week-day religious instruction for children by "having the public school take over practically all of a child's waking hours."

RIPLEY, Tenn., Feb. 13 (AP)--A tornado dealt death to nine persons in the tiny Hurricane Hill community early today and brought to at least forty-seven the number of deaths from week-end tornadoes in four states.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 13-- The Cabinet today debated the question of recognizing the new Viet Nam regime of Bao Dai, and Laos and Cambodia, but failed to reach an agreement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)-- Distribution of the $2,800,000,000 G.I. life insurance refund money is 30 per cent finished, four weeks and a day after mail distribution began Jan. 16.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--A grand jury report issued today charged that a "large, lucrative and well-organized" gambling business was operating here.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Feb. 13 --Mecca for Long Island historians is a small, ivy-covered building here that contains the Pennypacker Long Island Collection and, usually, Dr. Morton Pennypacker. HILLSIDE, N.J., Feb. 13--Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Scarr have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bernice, to Albert L. Kessler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Kessler of Elizabeth. The wedding has been planned for June.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13-- Mel Ferrer and Eugene Iglesias will play the Bello brothers in the screen version of "The Brave Bulls," it was learned today from Columbia. President Truman, in making his address at the annual JeffersonJackson Day dinner in Washington, will be seen and heard on television over the National Broadcasting Company network on Thursday from 10:30 to 11 P.M. Dr. Luther Gulick, president of the Institute of Public Administration and an authority on municipal government, was reported yesterday to be the leading candidate for the post of executive director to the committee appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer to survey the city government in the interest of efficiency and economy.

ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Feb. 13 (AP)--Rafael Sabatini, creator of Captain Blood whose adventures filled three books, died at his hotel here early today at the age of 75.

It was a pleasure to sit through the spring and summer hat collection created by Tatiana du Plessix, which was presented yesterday by Saks Fifth Avenue at the St. Regis Hotel. Suave is the word that comes to mind as being most suitable for the hats, whether large or small.
Forrest U. Lake, faculty chairman of athletics of Tulane University, declared yesterday he besome realistic modification should should be made" in the N.C.A.A.S Sanity Code.

In addition to continued strong support through newspapers, radio and other media, the Advertising Council's campaign on the American economic system has received a notable increase of public interest from a special car card ...

Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Harlem Democrat, declared yesterday that he had a commitment from Joseph W. Martin, House Republican leader, that if the Fair Employment Practices Bill was not brought to the floor before March 1 the Republican leadership would furnish the votes in the Rules Committee to bring it out.

Record quantities of liquor are being consumed throughout the country despite Alcohol Tax Unit figures issued yesterday that show 1949 alcohol beverage revenues to be $486,593,149 below the peak year of 1949, industry leaders said here yesterday.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 13 (UP)--A sweeping State Department report on the political situation throughout Communist-ridden Southeast Asia was taken up today by United States diplomats from fourteen countries in conference here.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 (UP)--A movie about a crooked politician, "All the King's Men," and pictures with battle themes swept the nominations tonight for the twenty-second annual Academy awards.

Mortimer Landsberg was elected chairman of the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange, it was announced last night by Francis Adams Truslow, president, following the annual election held by regular Exchange members. Mr. Landsberg, vice chairman of the board of governors of the Exchange...

COLUMBUS, Ohio,--Feb. 14--A proposal that Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish leaders call an interfaith conference to discuss the hydrogen bomb was advanced here today by Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania.

A bitter clash took place between Vincent R. Impellitteri, President of the City Council, and Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman, at yesterday's Council meeting. Mr. Sharkey fought a resolution asking the State Legislature to give Mr. Impellitteri the right to designate a member of his staff to sit for him on the Board of Estimate.

Dick McGuire, key play-maker of the New York Knickerbockers, yesterday was reported in excellent condition for tonight's game between the Knicks and the Baltimore Bullets at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 14 (AP)--The conference of United States diplomats of the Far East today discussed an Asian alliance against communism and a peace treaty for Japan.

Major developments in the world news result from human conflicts among the two and one-half billion persons who make up the earth's population, Edwin L. James, managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said Yesterday.

Riding high, wide and handsome with a trio of prosperous Broadway ventures, the redoubtable Theatre Guild will usher in its fourth, "Come Back, Little Sheba," at the Booth this evening. Members of the first-night brigade are advised to be in their seats for an 8:20 curtain.

ASPEN, Col., Feb. 14--A 30year-old woodcutter, Zeno Colo of Italy, today cut the fastest and straightest line on the one-mileand-a-quarter giant slalom course carved out of the Silver Queen Trail on Aspen Mountain to carry off the world championship, second decided in the weeklong Federation International de Ski title games here.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb, 14--Before it is too late, the citizens of this country must compel the Government to balance the budget and reduce the national debt, Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, declared here tonight.

The City Traffic Commission, in a report on its first year, listed yesterday "three steps of major importance" it had evolved to alleviate traffic congestion and improve traffic conditions generally in the city.

Among the millions of valentines received yesterday, 500,000 had been sent out by the New York Heart Association in a city-wide distribution, Enclosed with them were little envelopes, to be returned with a requested response.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--President Truman has reconvened his coal inquiry board on the eve of another attempt by operators and miners to settle their long-standing dispute.

Housing activity is keeping construction work in New York at a high level. The importance of this branch of the building industry's operations was emphasized in a report yesterday by State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi Showing...

WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, Feb. 14--Snow flurries and clouds "down to the deck" kept all planes in Exercise Sweetbriar on the ground this morning. A Canadian combat team driving up the Alaska (Alcan) Highway through the heart of the Yukon wilderness made contact with the "enemy" along the frozen Donjek River, 211 miles northwest of Whitehorse.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP)-- The United States removed today some of the red tape that has been hampering imports from dollarhungry countries.
The Appellate Division upheld yesterday the right of 8,000 insurance agents of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to a retroactive pay award of $1,004,000.
The Cleveland Symphony Orchestra, George Szell conductor with Clifford Curzon, pianist, as soloist, played last night in Carnegie Hall, with triumph.

BERLIN, Feb. 14--A blonde American secretary who overstayed her residence permit here has returned to the United States after failing to find a haven in the Soviet occupation zone with her German boy friend, a deputy United States provost marshal said tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 14--The special Congressional commission assigned police last night to the newsprint warehouses of the Presna and the Naci n.
Operating revenues and earnings of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company in 1949 were the largest in its history, the annual report of William G. Maguire, chairman, disclosed yesterday.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 14-- Pink carnations and cybotium ferns made a garden setting here at noon today in the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of the Nativity for the marriage of Miss Mary Heritage Walker, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dudley Pomp Walker of Fire Lane Farm, Bethlehem, to A. Harden Coon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Coon of Kingston.
Cracksmen, described by the police as experts; took $25,000 early yesterday from two safes in the offices of the Union News Company in the Pennsylvania Station.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--A business upturn in December raised the national income total for 1949 to about 210,000,000,000--only some $2,000,000,000 less than the 1948 record, despite a drop of $4,700,000,000 in agricultural income--the office of business economics of the Department of Commerce reported today.

The New York Rangers face an important test tonight when they skate against the Boston Bruins, three points back of the fourthplace Blue Shirts, in a National Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 14-- Thomas A. Unsworth, industrialist, died here late last night at the age of 73. He was president, treasurer and general manager of the E.B. and A.C. Whiting Company, president and treasurer of the Queen City Tulatex Corporation and president of the Burlington Realty Corporation.

The financial structures of two companies seeking Civil Aeronautics Board certificates to fly mail, passengers and express by helicopters in the New York metropolitan area were examined in detail yesterday as the CAB hearings went into their second week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14-The Congress of Industrial Organizations asked Congress today to go beyond President Truman's tax recommendations and "shift present burdens from low-income individuals to the wealthy and to high-profit corporations."

A sharp revival in Brazilian demand for essential machinery and industrial equipment will follow liquidation in the near future of the backlog of Brazil's indebtedness to American exporters, it was predicted in an interview here yesterday by Joao Pedro Radler de Aquino, manager of the Companhia Geral de Materiais, importers of Rio de Janeiro.
The Italian liner Saturnia departed yesterday for Mediterranean ports after completing what American Export Line officials said was her fastest turnaround.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 14--With 370,000 striking soft coal miners continuing their defiance of Government and union back-to-work orders, pickets cut deeper into the country's coal supply today by forcing a shutdown in mines that had signed new contracts on the terms demanded by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers.

ORADELL, N.J., Feb. 14--Alpheus Theodore De La Mare, founder of The Florists Exchange, a magazine devoted to horticulture, died in his home here today at the age of 96. Until five years ago he was still active in his firm, the A.T. De La Mare Printing and ...

SEATTLE, Wash., Feb. 14 (AP)-- Ablaze and coated with ice, an Air Force B-36 bomber with seventeen men believed to be aboard has been forced down north of here, presumably in wind-tossed, icy Queen Charlotte Sound.

SALEM, Mass., Feb. 14--Lieut. Comdr. William H. Bates, Republican, won an easy victory today in a special Sixth District election to fill the seat left vacant by the death of his father, Representative George J. Bates, in an air crash at Washington, Nov. 1.

Almost all of the orders placed at the Chicago and New York lamp shows last month have been confirmed by retailers, it was reported yesterday by Jacob Fogelson, executive secretary of the New York Lamp and Shade Manufacturers Association. He said local manufacturers were assured of a more successful spring season than they had last year.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active and strong yesterday. Final prices were unchanged to 30 points higher than on Monday.

Dictionary and thesaurus soon may become indispensable guides to weather forecasts. Word patterns, as involved as those of hot and cold air masses, are being worked out at the Weather Bureau, it became apparent yesterday after the Weather Man had described the wintry goulash of sleet-rain-snow as "dismal."

Laird Shields Goldsborough of 1200 Fifth Avenue, an editor with an office in Time and Life Building, 9 Rockefeller Plaza, was killed at 6:20 P.M. yesterday when he fell or jumped from a window of this ninth-floor office to the sidewalk of the plaza below. He was 47 years old and was a former Army counter-intelligence official.

A dozen Hudson Valley gentlemen farmers protested yesterday at a Public Service Commission hearing its recent order restricting the sale of multiple-type railroad tickets to seventy-five miles north of the city.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14-- Jean Simmons, the British actress who was seen as Ophelia in Sir Laurence Olivier's "Hamlet," is expected to play Lygia in "Quo Vadis" for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, it was learned today. Mervyn Le Roy, who will direct the film, has made tests of Miss Simmons in London, and the tests have been ....

Commercial paper outstanding on Jan. 31, this year, totaled $258,000,000, compared with $257,000,000 on Dec. 30, 1949, and $268,000,000 at the end of January a year ago, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Since 1940 there have been seven December-January increases and three decreases.
PARIS, Feb. 14--Bruyere abandons matelasse embroidery and uses fabric with greater simplicity in a silhouette slim in skirt but supple in bodice.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The Executive Board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, assembled mainly for the expulsion of four more unions in charges of Communist domination, made a plea for disarmament today and declared it was still opposed to full diplomatic relations with Spain.

The first liquidation to be completed among the enemy-owned banking institutions taken over on the outbreak of the war was announced yesterday by the State Banking Department, which disclosed that a second and final liquidating dividend of $6.75 per share, amounting to $175,000, is being paid to stockholders of Sanco di Napoli Trust Company of New York.

PARIS, Feb. 14--The hydrogen bomb, though not yet constructed, weighed heavily upon many minds in France today. Its fantastic potentialities, as measured in the abstract by presumably competent physicists, were translated into large black type by the newspapers.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 14-- Diplomatically, Secretary General Trygve Lie offered an encouraging word today to fourteen legislators from Japan who wishfully expressed the hope that the former enemy state might some day join the United Nations.

Governor Dewey's plan for liquidating the cost of the proposed $400,000,000 New York-Buffalo Thruway by sale of special license plates to its users was criticized yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York and representatives of two large trucking associations.

The Detroit Edison Company, in its annual report issued yesterday, said that a new high record was made last year in electricity sales and that its investment of $51,000,000 in new construction in 1949 passed the half-way mark in its 400,000 kilowatt expansion program. Total assets of the company exceeded half a billion dollars for the first time.

BERLIN, Feb. 14 (AP)--West Berlin's prostrate economy received another firm shot in the arm today by the release of 100,000,000 West marks ($23,800,000) of Marshall Plan counterpart funds by the Western German Federal Republic.
IOWA CITY, Iowa., Feb. 14 (AP) --Iowa turned over its football fortunes today to a big, pleasant man who never saw a gridiron game until he entered the university in 1923.

The barring of Margaret Webster's Shakespearean company by a Southern college because of the appearance of two Negroes in the cast of "The Taming of the Shrew" was disclosed yesterday by Louis Nizer, attorney for the actressmanager-director.

BOSTON, Feb. 14--A throng, estimated by police at 25,000, stood outside the Cathedral of the Holy Cross in a driving snowstorm today during a solemn requiem mass for Mrs. Mary Curley Donnelly and Leo Curley, daughter and son of former Mayor James M. Curley of Boston, who died within fourteen hours of each other, last Saturday.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 14--P.L. Grissom of Detroit got another 10 per cent return on a race track investment today. His 5-year-old Menow gelding, Almenow, a $21,000 purchase at the sale of the late A.C. Ernst's horses at Saratoga in 1948, won with ease in Hialeah's St. Valentine Purse, a six-furlong sprint that drew a field of six.

The directors of the International Paper Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 62 cents a share on the common stock, payable on March 27. This is the first dividend on the comiron stock since the 2-for-e split effective last Dec. 20. Payments in 1949 on the old stock were $1 a share quarterly and $1 in a yearend disbursement.

ALTER YOUR LIFE, by Emmet Fox (Harper, $2.50). Religious meditations. THE APOSTOLIC FATHERS: An American Translation, by Edgar J. Goodspeed (Harper, $3.75). A new translation from the original Greek of "additional epistles of the New Testament."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Twenty-five days of unbroken, unexplained silence from Sofia has brought about an impasse is diplomatic relations between Bulgaria and the United States that officials here regard as unprecedented.

The Sanitation Department's anti-litter experiment, in which hundreds of extra sidewalk receptacles were recently placed in midManhattan, will be extended tomorrow to congested areas all over the city.

President Truman declared in an interview that he remained unshaken in his belief that world peace could and would be attained, probably in his own lifetime. He held this view despite atomic bomb developments and lack of faith in the good intentions of the Russians.

Rain, sleet and snow during the last two days here has reduced store sales and eliminated any possibility of the week's business breaking even with last year on a comparative basis, merchants reported here yesterday.

A sprint by two spy suspects along Forty-second Street, west of Times Square, was described yesterday by an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation at the trial of Judith Coplon and Valentin A. Gubitchev for conspiracy and espionage.
A new fabric has arrived in the fashion world, called Organzari. It is not organdy, because it is silk; nor is it the sheer used for Indian Saris. This is crisp, unlike chiffon, voile or marquisette.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP)--The Cubs, National League cellar-dwellers for the past two years, reached into the Dodgers' baseball empire today to lure away Branch Rickey's veteran trouble-shooter, Wid Matthews, and install him as director of player personnel.

With the close on Monday of nominations for candidates to Britain's general election of Feb. 23, the campaign now reaches its peak. This is the decisive battle for which all parties have been conserving their strength. Labor is attacking on a narrow front, and it would seem at this distance with much effect.

Murray Goldberg, 27-year-old Bronx father who shot and killed his year-old son and estranged wife on Sunday afternoon in the Bronx Children's Shelter, was captured yesterday afternoon hiding out in a midtown hotel room, where he said he had tried to commit suicide.

Although President Truman left out the amusement industries in his proposed excise tax reductions, leaders of these industries are making a strong fight against the wartime excises. This is particularly true of the motion picture industry, which points out that 76 per cent of general admissions taxes are collected through it.

Albert M. Greenfield, chairman of the board of directors of Bankers Securities Corporation, Philadelphia, announces the election of Anthony G. Felix as president and Alfred Blasband as executive vice president and treasurer at a special board meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--In the age of atomic energy, transmuted into a weapon which can destroy great cities and the best works of civilization, and in the shadow of a hydrogen detonant which could multiply many times that agent of destruction, a serene President of the United States sits in the White House with undiminished confidence in the triumph of humanity's better nature and the progress of his own efforts to achieve abiding peace.

Plans for a new apartment building in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn were announced yesterday by C.B. Grundstein, builder, who bought for the purpose a plot 120 by 100 feet at 1441 Fiftythird Street from a Mrs. Cohen. A. Resnek was the broker in the...
Spring and summer fashions by Peg Newton for girls of 5 feet 8 inches and up were presented yesterday during luncheon at the Ritz Carlton Hotel.
SZCZECIN (Stettin), Feb. 14-- One Pole was sentenced to death and another to life imprisonment today when a military court found six defendants guilty of spying for the French Government.

The main problem faced by today's grandmother--as a grandmother--is how to be helpful but not interfering, how to be available when needed and yet avoid being imposed upon. Modern grandparents have great confidence in their young, people. They waste little time trying to force unasked advice upon them.

With the backing of the president of the Board of Education, the State Congress of Industrial Organizations yesterday accused the city public school system's Board of Examiners of arbitrary and dangerous procedures in denying teaching licenses to qualified candidates.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 14 --The marriage of Mrs. Joan Slutzker Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Slutzker of South Orange, to Dr. David Vincent Sharp, son of Samuel Sharp of Minneapolis, and the late Mrs. Sharp, took place here this afternoon...

The Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada will increase this year's dividend to policyholders, Arthur B. Wood, president, announced at the seventy-ninth annual meeting yesterday in Montreal. George W. Bourke was elected president to succeed Mr. Wood, who becomes chairman of the board.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 14 (AP)-- Lloyd Noble of Ardmore, Okla., prominent oil producer, and Oklahoma Republican leader and philanthropist, died here early today at the age of 53. He was here on a business trip.

BELIZE, British Honduras, Feb. 14 (UP)--Angry anti-British elements turned down today a government compromise plan to eliminate the singing of "God Save the King" when British royalty visits here Feb. 23.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP)--The former world champion, Irving Crane of Binghamton, N.Y., captured the pocket billiards lead and Joe Chamaco of Mexico City solidified his No. 1 three-cushion spot in national competition at Navy Pier tonight.

Karl Guthe Jansky of 57 Silverton Avenue, Little Silver, N.J., radio research engineer with the Bell Telephone Laboratories since 1928, who discovered radio waves of extraterrestrial origin in 1933 died yesterday in the Riverside Hospital, Red Bank, N.J., of a heart malady. He was 44 years old.
ROME, Feb. 14--The Chamber of Deputies voted its confidence in Premier Alcide de Gasperi's sixth Cabinet tonight, 314 to 189, after one of the worst fist fights in Italian parliamentary history.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 14 (AP)--Viet Namese Premier Nguyen Phan Long promised today to defeat what the French say are the Communist-led Nationalists in six months if his Government got United States military and economic aid.

Governor Dewey has asked and obtained sweeping powers to deal with the growing coal shortage as it affects New York. In a special message to the Legislature yesterday the Governor declared that coal stocks in this area were close to rock bottom and warned that if the bituminous strike lasted longer than a few days more the state would be facing a catastrophe.
Governor Dewey issued a proclamation here yesterday designating next Sunday as Jewish Child's Day throughout the state.

In an early start for this year's drive for funds for the New York City Cancer Committee, thirty-five leaders in the merchandising field met yesterday to map the strategy for the campaign by business and industry.

Yesterday the New York Giants won the pen-and-ink pennant when Dave Koslo, the lone unsigned player, agreed to terms in a telephone conversation from his Menasha, Wis., home with Charles (Chub) Feeney, club vice president.

Death has struck twice within a little more than a month at Lutheran clergymen, displaced persons from the former Baltic States, who had found a haven here after years of hardship in Europe, it was made known yesterday by the National Lutheran Council.

The trial of three persons under indictment as participants in a nationwide American Express Company travelers' check counterfeiting ring began in Federal court yesterday while five others under the same indictment pleaded guilty to the charges.

Charles Benenson, operator, has purchased the two-story garden type apartment house at 261 Central Avenue in Lawrence, L.I., known as Lawrence Gardens, from Morris Schwartz and Anna Jankoff. The property occupies a plot 285 by 260 feet and is assessed at $220,000. James Felt Co. were...
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 14 (AP)-- Initial contracts in Pittsburgh's multi-million-dollar downtown development program were signed in City Council today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 14 (UP) --Syracuse University's basketball team registered an impressive victory over New York University at the State Fair Coliseum tonight, 61--49. It was the thirteenth victory in eighteen starts for the Orange this season.

ALBANY, Feb. 14--A proposal to relax the penalty provisions of the Condon-Wadlin Anti-Strike Law was put before the Legislature today by Senator William F. Condon, Republican, of Yonkers, one of the sponsors of the act.

It's good to learn during a winter storm that down where it's summer, in Chile and Argentina, orchardists expect the biggest crops on record. The fruits of their labors include the fresh peaches and honeydew melons that two chains are featuring at a season when such delicacies used to be stocked only by fancy fruiterers. One then bought them as bon voyage gifts or for convalescing aunts.
