PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14--Extension of the city's income tax to revenue from investments and corporate profits was declared invalid today by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court.

Retailers are depending on the late spring and summer season for reviving business in their dress departments, it was pointed out yesterday by manufacturers of medium and high priced lines. Members of the Fashion Originators Guild who are opening summer lines this week reported active buying and requests for quick delivery which indicate a need for fresh merchandise.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Feb. 14 --Winston Churchill appealed here tonight for a new "top-level" attempt to reach as agreement with the Soviet Union for control of the atomic bomb and an end of the "cold war."
Navy blue-dyed furs and button detail on suits were two of the highlights of the I.J. Fox showing yesterday at 393 Fifth Avenue of this shop's original suits, coats and furs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Maritime labor lost another hiring hall decision today under unusual circumstances. The employers apparently had preferred the hiring hall to a union-proposed plan that was found to be legal.

Business and advertising leaders will gather in Washington today for "off-the-record" conferences with top Government officials on what they can do to help solve pressing domestic and international problems now intensified by new atomic anxieties, it was learned yesterday.

BOSTON, Feb. 14--Led by Herb Lyon, who scored 32 points, the University of Pennsylvania basketball team tonight defeated Harvard's quintet, 95--77, in an Eastern League game that opened a double-header at the Boston Garden.

ALBANY, Feb. 15--A proposed constitutional amendment to consolidate nine New York City courts into two was approved by the Judicial Council today as offering the only plan for eliminating congestion of court calendars.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Southern Democrats, with an assist from friends of the Civil Rights bill to establish a Fair Employment Practice Commission, made certain today that House consideration of that measure would be postponed for at least another week.

If we continue our current policy of encouraging economic cooperation in Europe and fostering democratic institutions in Germany there can be no fear for the outcome, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former, commander in chief of United States forces in Europe, said yesterday.

The comedy team of Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis has been reengaged by the National Broadcasting Company for a new weekly television series which is expected to begin late in March. The contract also calls for guest appearances on various NBC radio programs.

After a lapse of almost a year, the railroads recently have been placing sizable orders for new freight cars. Yesterday the New York Central System placed orders for 4,500 at a total cost of $23,700,000. This is the largest order for new cars placed by any railroad since Central ordered 5,350 in December, 1948.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The Securities and Exchange Commiasion annuonced today that the Muter Company, Chicago, had filed a registration statement with it covering 53,000 shares of 50 cents par value common stock, all of which was to be sold by company stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--A bipartisan majority of the Senate Judiciary Committee gave notice today of formidable coming efforts to liberalize the displaced persons bill recently sent to the floor from committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--Thirteen local housing authorities have sold $56,440,000 in short-term notes in competitive bidding, the Public Housing Administration announced today. The successful bids were at interest rates ranging from 0.65 per cent to 0.90 per cent.

The Kellex Corporation, an engineering concern, has leased two floors in the building at 120 Wall Street through Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., broker. The same broker also negotiated leases in 120 Wall Street for John B. Glenn, chairman of the American Trust...

We regret the passing of the City Club of New York, for we feel that the principles of municipal reform for which this organization has stood since its founding in 1892 cannot have too many defenders. Yet we would be remiss if we did not take this occasion of the announcement of the club's formal disbanding to salute its leaders and hail the fine work its members have done here for fifty-eight years.

Sleet and rain driven by blustery winds wire the metropolitan area's lot yesterday and last night while the heaviest snow of the winter fell north of the city line. Snows covered the northeastern states with the exception of northern New England, the Associated Press reported.

JOHNNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 14 (Reuters)--Twelve Europeans and seven natives were in hospital tonight after a wave of race rioting, arson and widespread looting in three Johannesburg suburbs. At least 250 persons have been arrested.

The exhibition of work by Brooklyn artists at the Brooklyn Museum, heretofore an annual, has been changed to a biennial and altered to an all-jury show with good results. A total of 124 examples by as many artists, work in all media has been selected from 686 entries and the level of achievement this year is distinctly above that of previous exhibitions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14-- Harry R. Bridges testified under cross-examination today that he had consulted Communist party officials since the start of his trial on charges of perjury and conspiracy but that he personally lacked the "courage" to be a Communist.

The State of Iowa announced yesterday that it would receive on March 9 bids on a fourth issue of war service compensation bonds amounting to $8,750,000 and due Dec. 1, 1964 to 1968. Early last month Iowa sold a like amount of bonds maturing serially to 1963 at an interest cost of 1.247 per cent.
Police Commissioner William J. O'Brien ordered his department yesterday to survey the city's coal stocks and to report back on them "soon."
INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 14 (AP)-- William Dudley Pelley, former Silver Shirt leader paroled from Federal prison at Terre Haute today, was ordered back to North Carolina to face a prison sentence.

John Foster Dulles told the eightieth anniversary dinner of Hunter College Alumnae last night that, for the first time, the nation was in "immense and imminent" danger. Communist propaganda, false though it be, has swayed or is swaying 85 per cent of the manpower and natural resources of the world, the former Senator declared.

The immortal words of the Declaration of Independence that "all men are created equal" resounded yesterday through the Great Hall of the New York State Chamber of Commerce at 65 Liberty Street for Bill of Rights Day.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14--In its annual report, the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania announced today that it spent $67,155,000 for gross construction, new developments and equipment in 1949.

The American Legion and three of the other national veterans' organizations have launched a campaign against the proposed reorganization of the Veterans Administration recommended by the Hoover Commission. TRENTON, Feb. 14--Mayor Michael U. DeVita of Paterson was cleared today by the Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court of a charge of directing a police officer to give false testimony in a gambling investigation.
Among the 1,503 passengers who arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary after a stormy crossing from Southampton was Gen. Albert Orsborn, world leader of the Salvation Army.

The Fermoy Realty Corporation bought from Sadie Fish for investment the apartment house at 360 East Fiftieth Street, southwest corner of First Avenue, subject to a first mortgage of $112,000 held by the Excelsior Savings Bank, in a deal negotiated by Charles Friedenberg, broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 14--Lieut. John E. Carr, U.S.N., who yesterday testified he could not believe his radar scopes when they showed the U.S.S. Missouri on the verge of running aground last month, was contradicted today by his own quartermaster at the Naval Court of Inquiry investigating the battleship's stranding.
Telephone operators in fifteen New Jersey locals of the Communication Workers of America, CIO, will take a strike authorization vote today against the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company.

The cigar industry will press its fight before the House Ways and Means Committee for a new basis for computing excise taxes on cigar sales, Edward J. Regensburg, president of the Cigar Manufacturers Association of America, announced yesterday.

MEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 14 (AP)-- The re-instatement of Boston College into the good graces of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Sanity Code compliance committee was announced tonight by its chairman, Clarence P. Houston of Tufts College.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14--Arbitration of the wage and hours dispute between the railroads and their conductors and trainmen was proposed today by the National (Railway) Mediation Board.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 14--The Czechoslovak Foreign Office today informed the United States Embassy that two American Mormon missionaries who disappeared Jan. 28 had been arrested by Czechoslovak security authorities and accused of having attempted to enter a prohibited area.

ALBANY, Feb. 14--The question of increasing the liability insurance requirements for both taxicabs and private automobiles may be left for Governor Dewey to decide through passage by the Legislature of a series of alternative bills.

Assistant Secretary of State Hickerson, who is the American member of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, has emphasized again the well-established fact that the United States (and this is equally true of all the Western-Powers) is willing at any time to sit down with the Russians and to continue the search for effective international control and ultimate elimination of atomic weapons.

Dr. John J. Theobald, president of Queens College, will confer degrees upon 298 graduates tonight in the college's new temporary gymnasium. The chief speaker Of the evening will be Dr. John Cranford Adams, president of Hofstra College.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The need for complete coordination between varied Federal agencies concerned, with natural resources, such as agriculture, water use, land reclamation and soil conservation, to insure adequate wildlife conservation was stressed at today's hearing before the Senate subcommittee to investigate wildlife conservation.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. 14-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Lincoln of the engagement of their daughter, Emily Ames, to R. Minturn Sedgwick of Dedham, son of Henry D. Sedgwick. The wedding will take place next month.

An irregular plot containing more than 13,000 square feet at East Mosholu Parkway and Perry Avenue, the Bronx, has been assembled by Brown, Harris, Steuens, Inc., for the Ciampi Construction Corporation, which plans to improve it with a six-story apartment building. The broker has arranged financing for the project.

EVER since Hughie Devore accepted the football coaching assignment at New York University, speculation has been rife as to the significance of this step. And in every discussion one hears the same, oft-repeated phrase, wonderment as to whether this means a return "to the Chick Meehan era." The tone that's used has a distasteful, unclean sound to it, almost as though John Francis Meehan were some loathsome creature beneath even contempt. That is most unfair.

Irene Watson, contralto from Englewood, N.J., who made her New York debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, has the requirements that make a fine singerwarmth of personality, imagination, intelligence and a beautiful voice.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 14--A special committee established under the United Nations Economic and Social Council to draw up a convention on the legal status of refugees recommended today that member countries re-draft their laws to reduce the number of persons who are stateless and outside the protection of any nation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14--Alfred M. Morris, a New York attorney, brought suit today in Cook County Superior Court asking recovery of $2,500,000 from directors of TruaxTraer Coal Company on behalf of its stockholders. He charged the money was lost through the purchase...

The long-awaited new chapter to Prof. Albert Einstein's famous volume on his relativity theory, in which he presents in mathematical symbols what he hopes will become the long-sought-for masterkey to the universe, was released yesterday by the Princeton University Press.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 14--The test of how far the United States will push its new "show me" line in Germany is visible in the growing United States-German conflict over the denazification scandal in Stuttgart.

LONDON, Feb. 14--In the old parish hall of Dulwich village on the outskirts of London, candidates of the three main political parties in the coming election attempted to defend their platforms today before a group of middleaged and elderly middle-class housewives who form the Dulwich Women's Citizen Association.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14--Programs of corporate labor relations are beginning to place too much emphasis on recreation and politeness and too little on improving working conditions, members of the American Management Association were told today.

Champion Walsing Winning Trick of Edgerstoune, Scottish terrier belonging to Mrs. John G. Winant of New York, reached the peak of American dogdom last night by taking best in show at the seventy-fourth annual Westminster Kennel Club fixture in Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP)-- Secretary of the Treasury Snyder announced today that the Treasury will refund $9,442,765,300 in securities falling due between March 1 and April 1.

An arbitration panel of two employers and two union representatives and one impartial arbitrator denied yesterday a request for a wage increase asked by the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, of this city and vicinity. It also refused a publishers' demand for a decrease in present wage rates.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--A behind-the-scenes battle within the Administration took shape today over the proposal to expand subsidies for the shipping industry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The Jersey Central today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to reject a petition to vacate its order to cut coal-burning locomotive mileage in passenger service. The petition had been filed by the Inter-Municipal Group for Better Rail Service and the Jersey Shore Protective Committee.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Feb. 14 (Reuters)--A state of emergency was proclaimed today after a riot had begun "in a mad fury" by workers armed with cutlasses on the Firestone rubber plantations about thirty miles from here.

MOSCOW, Feb. 14--The Government newspaper Izvestia today gave prominence to reports from Helsinki charging that the Aaland Islands in the Baltic Sea had become the objective of "the criminal game of the Western powers and Finnish warmongers."

ALBANY, Feb. 14--The Legislature authorized Governor Dewey today to ration coal and other solid fuels and to restrict the use of electricity, gas, steam and other products requiring the use of solid fuels in their manufacture.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP)-- Bernard Baruch called today for immediate steps to strengthen the United Nations by curbing the veto power and establishing an international police force strong enough to halt aggression.

A special exhibit of contemporary textiles, ceramics and metal and wood products by American craftsmen will open today at James Monroe High School, the Bronx, and later make a tour of New York's twenty-eight academic high schools during the next five years.
The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company last year had the largest sales and earnings in its history, according to the preliminary annual report, made public yesterday, of Harry B. Higgins, president.

The preliminary annual report of Mack Trucks, Inc., and its subsidiaries disclosed yesterday an estimated net loss for last year of $3,995,000 after all charges and giving effect to a tax carry-back credit of $2,300,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The National Association of Manufacturers said today that it was opposed to a bill that would extend the coverage of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to 1,118 additional companies because it would "hamper and financially burden" small business.

PARIS, Feb. 14--The Moslem republics of Soviet Central Asia are being developed into centers for potential imperialism. As Moscow's dynamism concentrates increasingly upon the Orient, its little known satrap states of the Kirghiz, Tadzhik, Kazakh, Turkmen and Uzbek peoples are being groomed to aid future expansion.

The policy initiated by John M. Murtagh, city Commissioner of Investigation, of inquiring into frauds on the public, no less than into misconduct within the municipal government, will be continued, when James H. Sheils takes over from Mr. Murtagh, both men made clear yesterday.
SHEFFIELD, England, Feb. 14 --(AP)--Prime Minister Attlee continued to hammer away at domestic issues tonight in three campaign speeches for the Feb. 23 election.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 14 --Peter H. Mitchell, hotel man and nationally known clock collector, died today at his home in the Mitchell Inn. He was 82 years old. He had spent fifty-eight years in the hotel business, thirty-eight of them at the Mitchell Inn, which he purchased in 1914.

Mastic Acres, Inc., will spend $200,000 this year for advertising promotion of its 8,500-acre Long Island land development, it was announced yesterday by Walter T. Shirley, president. The campaign budget, largest yet established by the realty concern, calls for extensive use of newspapers.

Jacques Fath, who has designed his third collection for Joseph Hal pert in New York, demonstrated in the presentation held yesterday afternoon at Lord Taylor's that he had gained a good understanding of the American woman's love for the casual in dress.

SEATTLE, Feb. 15--All seventeen men who parachuted from a flaming American B-36 bomber have been located alive and ten of them are being flown to an American airbase, the United States Coast Guard and Canadian Navy reported tonight.

ALBANY, Feb. 15--Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, proposed legislation today for the licensing of cigarette dealers from the wholesaler to the retail level.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--Secretary of State Dean Acheson warned the Chinese people today that their troubles with Moscow had only just begun with the signing of agreements between the Chinese Communist Government and the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--Miners and soft coal operators "shadow boxed" all day and apparently made no appreciable progress toward writing a contract to replace the one that expired on June 30, 1949. Meanwhile, 370,000 miners remained on strike and the coal shortage was reported growing more acute.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 15-- India's policy in the impending penetration of Communist China into the Himalayan region on this country's northern border will be to defend the autonomy of Tibet by diplomatic means only but to meet with force any threat to the sovereignty of the Kingdom of Nepal.

PARIS, Feb. 15--Developments before a Parliamentary committee of inquiry in the past few days have raised the so-called "scandal of the generals" into a factor of leading importance in French politics.

In a suite at the Essex House yesterday, Robert A. Mariotti, 7 years old, who has blond hair, three missing front teeth and a magnetic personality, was preparing a belated Valentine for his mother in Bridgeport, Conn.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 15-- Princeton kept the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League tonight by stopping Columbia, 50 to 48, before a crowd of 3,000 at Dillon Gymnasium.

The thirteenth Berkshire Festival at Tanglewood, near Lenox, Mass., will open on July 8. Serge Koussevitzky will conduct six of the nine concerts to be given in the Shed by the Boston Symphony Orchestra. He will conduct all of the six concerts to be given in the Theatre-Concert Hall.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 15--Nationalist China's chief United Nations delegate charged today that the Chinese Communists had "sold" Manchuria and the province of Sinkiang to the Soviet Union under secret clauses in the Moscow-Peiping treaty.

Two witnesses, one for the Federal Government and one for New York City, were cross-examined yesterday by counsel for the New York Telephone Company at the sixty-fourth session of its hearing before the Public Service Commission for permanent rate increases. The company is asking for a rise of 16 per cent in its intrastate revenues.

A sort of academic Cotton Mather of the Reconstructed Left, he likes to make hackles rise and let the hecklers

Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen asserted yesterday that "all open garbage dumping in New York City will be terminated by 1953 under an accelerated incinerator construction program laid down by Mayor O'Dwyer."

Donald Hamilton McLaughlin, newly elected president of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, told 1,400 persons at its annual convention last night in the Statler Hotel that new minerals and new techniques will be discovered to take the place of America's rapidly diminishing store of natural resources.
EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 15--Edward E. King, one of East Hartford's most prominent residents, died today at the age of 87.

Another program in the current festival of American music presented by Station WNYC was given at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, featuring a variety of talented participants and a number of first performances.

Columbia College's inter-fraternity council, Pamphratria, issued a policy statement yesterday urging the removal "as soon as possible" of all fraternity membership restrictions "based on considerations of race, creed or color."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--An "urgent need" for reducing the spending of this Government in the various international organizations, and especially the United Nations, was reported today by a Senate subcommittee on executive expenditures.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 15-- On the snowy banks of the Bronx River from Mount Vernon to Valhalla it was Thanksgiving in midFebruary today for wild ducks and geese because of feed funds donated by residents of many states and several nations.

NORFOLK, Feb. 15--Repeated danger warnings, sent to the captain of the battleship Missouri by the executive officer just before the vessel went aground last month, probably were not heard because the sailor relaying the messages feared to interrupt the skipper, according to testimony today to the naval court of inquiry investigating the mishap.
PARIS, Feb. 15--Army Blatt's opening at a breakfast party at Rumpelmayer's revealed some interesting combinations of woven fabric with handknit or crochet.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 15--Coal operators abandoned hope today of any substantial return to work this week by the country's 370,000 striking soft coal miners.

At last the Theatre Guild has got round to doing an original play. William Inge's "Come Back, Little Sheba;" which was acted at the Booth last evening, is straightforward and unhackneyed and, in its best moments, terrifyingly true.

MOSCOW, Feb. 15--A strong new effort by the Soviet Union and Communist China for an early conclusion of a Japanese peace treaty was indicated today on the basis of the new Sino-Russian alliance and agreements concluded in Moscow yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP)-- Secretary of the Treasury Snyder said today the Treasury is planning a savings bond "drive" in the spring.

Puccini's "Manon Lescaut" received its fifth performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. There were three singers in roles in the opera that they had not previously sung at the Metropolitan.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. 15-- Franklin Simon, the New York specialty store, formally opened its first Massachusetts unit today in the new Chestnut Hill shopping center. It was the first of eleven stores that will comprise the center.

With courage that rises above despair, the Lithuanian nation today observes the thirty-second anniversary of its independence with ceremonies which will unite Lithuanians everywhere except in Lithuania itself.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 15-- Fordham's basketball team, playing inspired ball in the second half, handed Army its worst defeat of the season, 72 to 50, in the Field House today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 15-- Protestant church leaders attending the twenty-ninth annual meeting here of the International Council of Religious Education expressed unqualified approval today of a proposal to call an interfaith conference on the moral implications of the hydrogen bomb.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Feb. 15--Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of New York City's Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, said here today that he would ask Mayor O'Dwyer ...

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 15--Dr. Samuel Guy Inman, a member of the executive committee of the American Christian Palestine Committee, said today that he was sure Israel and Jordan would reach agreement between themselves on the status of Jerusalem.

LONDON, Feb. 15--Winston Churchill's injection into the election campaign of the suggestion that a Conservative victory might lead to a new attempt to resolve the differences between East and West and end the threat of an atomic war had the Labor party members worried today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 15--Wolfgang Hedler, acquitted on charges of spreading anti-Semitism, walked out of court a free man today into the hottest political conflict the new Western German Federal Republic has known.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Feb. 15--Prime Minister Attlee making his twenty-ninth campaign speech in a week, dropped the political kid gloves tonight and went over to the offensive in the most outspoken criticism he has made of his formidable rival, Winston Churchill.

A special tribute to the agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was given yesterday by Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey, former United States Attorney who led the Government's successful prosecution of eleven Communist leaders.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Feb. 15 --The steady decline of shipyard orders is leading skilled yard mechanics into manufacturing fields far removed from the maritime world.

For the first time in several weeks, water supply officials expressed optimism yesterday over the reports from up-state areas that water levels in the city's huge reservoirs were slowly rising with the heavy precipitation of the last few days.

The southeast corner of Park Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, which was assembled a few years ago by the Aluminum Company of America as the site for a new office building, has been sold by Alcoa to Frederick Brown, the operator, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15--Grain markets were irregular on the Board of Trade here today. Buying of deferred deliveries of wheat against sales of the March and May contracts featured trading in that grain, with the close cent a bushel lower to 1 cents higher, the latter on the July.

The $300,000,000 Soviet credit to Communist China announced Tuesday falls far short of meeting the Chinese Communists' requirements to attain their economic goals, an analysis of China's needs indicates.
A sharp break between food manufacturers and retailers over proposed changes in the Federal Trade Commission's operational code for the industry became evident here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--The average life span in this country lengthened from 66.8 years in 1947 to 67.2 years in 1948, the National Office of Vital Statistics announced today.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 15--Two seven-furlong sprints, one a $5,000 purse for 3-year-olds and the other the $9,630 Colombiana Handicap for fillies and mares, stirred a passel of excitement at Hialeah Park today.

The campaign by business and industrial interests to repeal all wartime excise taxes has met with strong opposition based on recent tax statements by President Truman and Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder.
New Yorkers received assurances yesterday that the coal strike had not yet treated a condition of "extreme emergency" here.

Mrs. Stanley Martineau heads the group of women in charge of the sale of tickets for the performance of "Arms and the Girl" on the night of Feb. 27 at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre for the benefit of the 1950 drive of the New York Heart Association. Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie is honorary chairman, Mrs. Frederick S. Whitlock, vice chairman, and Mrs. Prentice Cromwell, chairman of the Manhattan women's division.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--Congress was urged today by Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, and George J. Burger, vice president of the National Federation of Independent Business, Inc., to strengthen the antitrust laws by providing more stringent penalties for violators.
Two hundred and ninety-eight graduates of Queens College received degrees last night at commencement exercises in the college's new temporary gymnasium.

The City Planning Commission reserved decision yesterday after closing a public hearing on a proposal to rezone Central Park South from residential to local retail use between the Avenue of the Americas and a point 100 feet west of Grand Army Plaza.

The thirty-second annual report of the Associates Investment Company and its subsidiaries, issued yesterday by E.M. Morris, board chairman, disclosed a new high in consolidated net income to $9,057,066 for 1949.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--In the treaty of alliance and friendship between the Soviet Russian and Chinese Communist Governments its fixed term of thirty years is not the least interesting item to the Government of the United States.

HONG KONG, Feb. 15--Reaction here to the new Moscow-Peiping treaty is that China's Communists have simply agreed to extend the Soviet Union's promissory note. With the exception of a loan, the major pledges are promises the Soviet Union made in the 1945 treaty with Nationalist China but did not keep.

The New York Board of Rabbis at its annual meeting yesterday endorsed the President's civil rights program, commended those seeking to maintain the separation of church and state and recommended constant vigilance by the United States Government against the rise of nazism.

While stormy weather abated in and near New York yesterday, snow, ice, winds, rain and floods continued to sweep large parts of the East, Middle West and South. Since Sunday, The Associated Press reported, the storms have killed seventeen persons.

Defendants and the courtroom audience at the Federal trial of three persons charged with participation in an American Express Company travelers' check counterfeiting ring got a demonstration yesterday of how the Federal Bureau of Investigation detects false issues.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 15--The Yugoslav Government announced tonight that its Ambassador in Bucharest, Radosh Jovanovitch, was being forcibly detained by the Rumanian authorities, who had refused to permit him to return to Yugoslavia.

DETROIT, Feb. 15--More than 1,000 automobiles loaded with pickets circled two large Chrysler Corporation plants today in the first such display of union strength since the United Automobile Workers, CIO, went on strike on Jan. 25.
The Yankees and the Dodgers each added one more contented player to their rosters yesterday and either or both of them may win a regular outfield job.

Americans who have the privilege of commenting, with assurance, over the breakfast table about the policies and acts or failure to act of their Presidents might do well to ponder some of the overtones in Arthur Krock's enlightening interview yesterday with Presidents Truman. One theme that runs almost from beginning to end is how hard it was to learn to be President.

Jasper, Ind., with a population of 6,800, will end municipal garbage disposal after Aug. 1 and is giving its residents every encouragement to dispose of their garbage electrically, the General Electric Company announced yesterday.
EN ROUTE WHITEHORSE TO DONJEK RIVER, Yukon Territory, Feb. 15--If you don't want to freeze your lungs, you don't gulp in great breaths of this frosty Arctic air.

The Union of American Hebrew Congregations announced yesterday that it had received an initial contribution of $225,000 from the National Federation of Temple Sisterhoods. The fund will be used to purchase a site and equipment for the House of Living Judaism, national center of Reform Judaism to be erected in New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP)-- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer urged today that subsidies to airlines be labeled as such and not disguised as pay for carrying mail.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP) --On a hot summer day in 1931 some 250 of the nation's leading women athletes gathered in Evanston, Ill., for the national field and track meet and places on the United States' 1932 Olympic team.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--A House filibuster with Southern Democrats apparently firmly in the saddle after four hours was broken suddenly late today by Speaker Sam Rayburn of Texas. The Civil Rights Bill to establish a permanent Fair Employment Practice Commission moved up another notch toward floor consideration.

It has been a trying season for the Baltimore Bullets in their attempts to establish definite ownership, popularize professional basketball in their home town and beat the New York Knickerbockers. Moderately successful in the first two items, they remain an utter failure in the third.

After two months of negotiations the Soviet Government and the Chinese Communist regime now announce their long-expected agreement. Whatever else may be said about it, this pact initiates a new and more advanced phase of the Soviet struggle for the control of Asia.

An increase last week of 1,925,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 129,362,000 barrels, a new peak for this period of the year, compared with 127,437,000 a week earlier and 119,780,000 a year ago.
Civilization's new weapon can no more destroy all civilization than other material achievements alone can "build the dream palace of human happiness," Gen. Albert Orsborn said yesterday.

In what constitutes one of the rare occurrences in the legitimate theatre, "All You Need Is One Good Break" will reopen its New York run on Monday at the Mansfield Theatre, a week after having closed there.

Plans for vacating the twostory building at 2040-50 Broadway northeast corner of Seventieth Street, and its use by several national concerns were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by the Eugene Higgins Estate to the Tishman Realty and Construction Company.

Rayon fabric quality standards for fifty different end uses in men's and women's apparel and home furnishings have been sent out for approval by trade and consumer groups, it was announced yesterday by the American Standards Association.
BERLIN, Feb. 15 (AP)--The Communist "National Front," created to bring Communist rule to West Germany, called tonight for reunification of Germany and Berlin on its terms.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--President Truman pledged unqualified support today to a country-wide campaign against organized crime. Plans for the campaign were drawn later after an all-day meeting of Federal, state and municipal law enforcement officers.
Net income of the General Public Utilities Corporation last year was $17,035,293, equal to $2.25 a share, compared with $15,731,433, or $2.07 a share, in 1948.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 15--Albert Herter, internationally known portrait and mural painter, died today of a heart attack at the age of 78. He was the father of Representative Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts.

LONDON, Feb. 15--Winston Churchill's proposal for "another talk with the Soviet Union upon the highest level" was labeled a "stunt" by Foreign Secretary Bevin tonight.
BOSTON, Feb. 15--Exeter Academy maintained its hockey domination over Andover Academy by defeating its traditional rival, 3--1, at the Arena today.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 15-- Nineteen top-level United States diplomats ended tonight three full days of discussion centered on af firmative steps that the United States could take in Asia in the fields of economic aid, protection from communism and political stabilization.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 (UP)-- American oak trees are being attacked by a killing fungus that could shake the national economy, a scientist said today. So far, no defense has been found for it.

A fully padded "crash" instrument panel and an increased glass area throughout for better driving visibility were among features of the redesigned 1951 Kaiser line of cars announced here yesterday by the KaiserFrazer Corporation.

Three agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, riding in a radio car beside a southbound Ninth Avenue bus on the night of March 4, saw Judith Coplon and Valentin A. Gubitchev seated in different parts of the bus, which carried only six other passengers, the spy trial jury was told yesterday.

Endowments on an increased scale for research in higher religious education as a way to peace were urged by Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein in a sermon yesterday morning at the West Side Institutional Synagogue, 120 West Seventy-sixth Street.

THE United States Air Corps had tens of thousands of planes in operation by the close of World War I. When World War II ended, the Army Air Force was flying several times as many, and they were far more powerful and costly.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 18--A proposal that seven of this couiltry's major Protestant interdenominational agencies join in an inter faith conference to formulate a policy pronouncement on the moral implications of the hydrogen bomb was adopted here today by the International Council of Religious Education.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 18 --Harold E. Stassen proposed here tonight that President Truman request a "major-mid-century conference" with the leaders of Russia at "a neutral location," in an effort to avert "the grim tragedy that would come to all mankind from a third World War." The conference would include Republican participation, he specified.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, while refusing to ease its standards to meet such criticisms as were leveled last week by some delegates of the United Nations, is demonstrating the flexibility of its operations in a $10,000,000 Turkish loan proposal now under study.

DES MOINES, Feb. 18--Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan lashed out at opponents of the Truman Administration's farm policies today as concocting misleading attacks which he said were "merely smokescreens intended to cloud the real issues."

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Feb. 18-- Miss Barbara Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley R. Lewis, was married here this afternoon in her parents' home to Robert Raby Heywood 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Heywood, Jr. The Rev. Edward Flemming performed the ceremony.

SHIPS have played important and colorful roles in the discovery and development of our nation. Here, in superb illustrations by W.N. Wilson and graphic pen-pictures by Helen Mitchell, are the stories of many great ships and the men who sailed them.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 18-- Dartmouth's basketball team lost its ninth straight game by succumbing to a persistent Columbia squad, 74--56, tonight. The Lions broke away to a 7-point lead at the five minute mark, and held that margin throughout the initial period of the Eastern League contest.

The New York City Board of Examiners, which passes on the qualifications of candidates for all teaching and most supervisory positions in the school system, drew new criticism last week over its testing and appeals procedures.

LONDON, Feb. 18--Dr. Klaus Emil Julius Fuchs is for the moment almost a forgotten man in Great Britain. There are few indications that the case of the British physicist now awaiting trial for giving important atomic secrets to a potential enemy will prompt an investigation of the British security program.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 18-- Nearing the fourth aniversary of his election and the second anniversary of the acquisition of the former British railroads, President Juan-D. Per n has reorganized the nationalized rail system with a view to letting the workers share up to 25 per cent of the profits.

Inquiries should be written on one side of the paper only and must contain the name and address of the writer on the page with the query. Requests for copies of poems must be accompanied by postage. The Editor endeavors to publish queries that have the greatest general interest.

THE HAGUE--Devaluation has made the Netherlands a bargain land for American tourists this year and the country's travel officials are preparing for a big season, limited only by the availability of hotel accommodations.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 18-- Dick Shea, a former GI now a yearling at the United States Military Academy, the I.C. 4-A and Heptagonal cross-country champion, established one of the four field house records set by Army's track and field team in the meet with Penn today.

LONDON, Feb. 18--The British election campaign is virtually over. There are twenty-four parties entered in Britain's general election, which will be held next Thursday. It is generally agreed the majority of electors will make their choice between two programs.

LONDON--Provided the American tourist books his room early this season, he is likely to have a more comfortable, cheaper and gayer holiday in London than at any time since before the war. But travel agencies fear that the visitor may find difficulty in getting the exact accommodation he wants if he does not book well in advance.
Charles Munch opened the concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra yesterday, afternoon in Carnegie Hall with Samuel Barber's brilliant and genial overture, "The School for Scandal."

Albert de Camp of Short Hills, this afternoon in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Ralph T. Haas performed the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Ga., Feb. 18 (AP) --Maj. Gen. Lloyd Brown, USA, retired, died here last night after a heart attack. He was 57 years old. A veteran of both World Wars, he commanded the Twenty-eighth Division during the second conflict. Later he was stationed at Fort Benning.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 18-- Harvard's cellar-dwelling hockey team jarred Princeton's title hopes today as the Cantabs gained their first Pentagonal League victory, 7--4, at Baker Rink.

A general travel boom, augmented by interest in Holy Year demand for steamship accommodations far beyond the carrying caobservances in Italy, has created a pacity of the transatlantic passenger fleet, a survey showed yesterday.

Rationing of soft coal will begin here tomorrow on orders from Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien, Solid Fuels Coordinator for New York City.
TEL AVIV--Israel has adequate hotel accommodations for 2,750 visitors and more are now being prepared feverishly to care for pilgrims expected during this Holy Year and for normal expansion.

THE Cleveland Indians have asked for waivers on the fabulous Satchel Paige. Two years after he entered the big leagues at the age of 39, the phenomenal Satch finished that phase of his career, still aged 39. It may not be good arithmetic but it is good Satchel Paige.

THE bark of many fruit and ornamental trees is damaged each year. Trees girdled by animals, stripped of bark, or with bark that has died back from an old wound, are best treated by bridge grafting. Newly cut shoots are used to form a connection between sound tissue above and below the injury, and thus enable the tree to carry on growth processes.

ALONG-AWAITED career in the Hollywood sun got off to a flying start in "Twelve O'Clock High" for a stocky, shaggy-maned graduate of Broadway and radio named Gary Merrill.

This Thursday most of Britain's 34,500,000 registered voters will go to the polls throughout England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland to elect a new Parliament. It will be Britain's first general election since the Labor party won power during the closing weeks of the war in 1945. (British law requires a general election at least every five years.)

GREENSBURG, Pa., Feb. 18-- In Christ Protestant Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Sara Eicher Fogg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Barclay Fogg, was married to Frederick David Foote Jr., son of Frederick D. Foote of Pittsburgh and Castine, Me.

WASHINGTON. PETRONA CERNA DE SANTOS, mother of seven, was a laborer on a farm is El Salvador and a midwife when anyone sent for her to "come quick." One day she heard that in the town of La Libertad, four miles away, a course of study was to be given in how to be a better midwife, and she resolved to take it.

Another full week lies ahead in the off-Broadway sector. Carmelita Maracci gives her season's farewell performance this afternoon at the Lexington Avenue "Y."

BUFFALO, Feb. 18 (AP)--Canisius kept its tournament hopes alive tonight by defeating Manhattan, 52--50, in overtime in the second game of a Memorial Auditorium basketball double-header. A crowd of 6,750 saw the University of Buffalo beat Hawaii, 69--50, in the opener.
PARIS, Feb. 18 (AP)--Santiago Casares Quiroga, Premier of the Spanish Republic in 1936, died here yesterday at the age of 65. His daughter, Maria Casares, is a French stage and screen actress.

Free public education from nursery school through junior college is recommended in a far-reaching statement of policy which has been adopted by the National Council of Chief State School Officers. The statement, prepared over a period of years, is intended to serve as a guide for the improvement of school programs throughout the country.

A VERY cosy picture of the celebrated Dr. Franklin is presented in this correspondence. It begins when the lady concerned was 23, and Franklin was not much short of 50, and continues at intervals until 1789, the year before Franklin's death.

ONE of the areas of most concern to parents is that of interfamily relationships. If brothers and sisters could get along together, unhappiness and anxiety would decrease. A new baby often seems to be the signal for a family upheaval. An older child may display types of maliciousness ranging from temper tantrums and bed-wetting to open attacks on the new arrival.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J., Feb. 18--An industrial vision of achieving labor peace through a new "share-of-production" pay plan lies buried in the abandoned machinery of the Continental Paper Company that after fortyfive years closed its doors for good on Feb. 6.

PARIS--Holy Year lends special emphasis to the religious festivals and pilgrimages to be held throughout France this spring, fall and summer. Travelers from many parts of the world bound for Rome are expected to visit France, an elder daughter of the Catholic Church, to take part in some of the special religious observances and to see her architectural treasure of churches and cathedrals.

LONDON, Feb. 19--Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin said here tonight that the Government was "already discussing with the United States" the situation that might arise when the European Recovery Plan ended in 1952.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 19, --The University of the South at Sewanee and the George Peabody College for Teachers at Nashville have announced final plans for the first music seminar of its kind in the history of the South.

The appointment of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, as cochairmen of the labor division of the National Christian Committee of the 1950 United Jewish Appeal was announced yesterday by Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., chairman of the committee.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 17-- Syria's women's organizations, divided into conservative and radical wings of the women's rights movement, is concentrating on getting a guarantee that the right to vote given them last summer for the first time in the modern Arab world included the basic rights and clauses of the new Syrian Constitution.

The major domestic airlines of the United States made records is all phases of traffic in 1949. Load factors in all categories were well above the respective break-even points, as a rule, indicating a profitable year for them, as well as for most of the minor lines.
Eight new films, including importations from France and Italy, are slated to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

HARLINGEN, Tex. Feb. 19 (AP) --Jack Burke Jr, of White Plains, N.Y., another Texan in the golfing firmament, today ripped in with a six-under-par 65 to capture first money in the $10,000 Rio Grande Valley open by two strokes.

Art Ford, the all-night disk jockey on WNEW, will conduct a three-times-a-week television program over the American Broadcasting Company, beginning early in April. No schedule has been atranged yet, but the show will be presented as a quarter-hour series in a mid-evening time period.

Choral singing of a quality unique in recent local history was heard in Carnegie Hall last night. The concert was presented by the sixty-voice Concordia Choir of Concordia College, Moorhead, Minn., under the direction of Paul J. Christiansen.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 19 --The congregation of the Candia Congregational Church prayed at this morning's service for the acquittal of Dr. Hermann N. Sander, who goes on trial here tomorrow for an alleged "mercy killing."

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 19-- The annual Rollins College animated magazine came to life today with sixteen representatives of the theatre, of journalism, business, literature, the military and of radio reading manuscripts to an audience of more a than 7,000.

A one-story taxpayer building containing ten stores, including a Big Ben food market, at the northeast corner of Fulton Avenue and Clinton Street, Hempstead, L.I. was sold by the Rob-Ton Holding Company to the Mid-Century Managing Company, an investing client of Murray Adler, the broker in the deal.

Outstanding in a week otherwise filled with one-man shows of paintings and sculpture is the exhibition of art treasures from the Vienna collections which opens on Friday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. On loan from Austria, this magnificent assembly of works of art will be on view in New York until May 21.
A bill to create a seven-man board of review to consider cases of teaching applicants to whom licenses are denied by the Board of Examiners will be introduced in Albany tonight.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 19--The United States Legation staff in Sofia has been alerted to make ready to leave the Bulgarian capital on a possible break in diplomatic relations between the United States and Bulgarian Governments, it was learned here today.

Six of the newly crowned National A.A.U. champions, many place-winners and scads of other good varsity athletes, headed by Michigan State's crack string of racers, will be back at Madison Square Garden next Saturday for the twenty-ninth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. championships.

Dollar volume in the children's garment industry will show a marked decrease for spring, it was pointed out yesterday. Manufacturers have written a substantial amount of business in units, particularly on initial orders taken in December and January, but a lower average price has depressed volume and earnings, they said.
SOMERS, N.Y., Feb. 19--Mrs. Alice O'Brien Peirano returned to her home here today after visiting her 100-year-old father in Ireland, a trio raid for by her neighbors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19--An eighty-day Taft-Hartley injunction enjoining the current coal strike is expected tomorrow.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19 (UP)--Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, criticized Andrei Andreyevich Andreyev, one of the twelve members of the ruling Politburo, today for his stand on the farm collectivization question.

ASPEN, Col., Feb. 19--The Federation Internatoionale de Ski, or world Alpine ski championships, officially concluded yesterday, were productive, perhaps, of the finest downhill and slalom competition ever seen.

LOUDONVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 19 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Douglas of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Varian, to Montgomery Boynton Angell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Angell of New York and Garrison-on-Hudson, N.Y.

The dust raised by the Soviet union over the question of recognizing the Chinese Communists in the United Nations tends to obscure the fact that the United Nations has before it a resolution in respect to the Soviet Union and the Chinese situation, submitted by the Government of China.

MOSCOW, Feb. 18--In the present stage of rapidly widening discussion in the United States of international atomic controls and Soviet-United States problems in general, a careful examination of the background against which Moscow is assessing these developments may prove useful.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19--Congressional studies may soon be directed to a California editor's suggestion that the Federal Government charge fees for special services, and thus in one move reduce costs and increase revenues.

UPPER MARLBORO, Md., Feb. 19 (UP)--Representative Fred L. Crawford, Republican, of Michigan, shared a county jail cellblock with a drunken driver and eight other prisoners today because he objected "in principle" to Maryland's bail-fixing practices.
DONJEK RIVER, Y.T., Feb. 19 --Communications, the nerve system of any army, have caused as many headaches here in the combined United States-Canadian Arctic maneuvers as any other single problem.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 19--As expected, preliminary conversations among delegations from India, Pakistan and South Africa have resulted in an agreement to hold a round-table conference "to explore all possible ways and means of settling the Indian question in South Africa."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 19 --Ambassador George V. Allen reiterated today the United States Government's policy of non-intervention in Yugoslavia's internal affairs in an effort to clear the atmosphere of charges made yesterday by Premier Marshal Tito in his pre-election speech to 50,000 Serbians at Titovo Uzice.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19--A keystone of post-war United States foreign policy, the Marshall Plan, starts this week its third annual test for approbation by Congress.

The United States is in its third great period of crisis and for the first time is faced with the danger of defeat, George E. Sokolsky, newspaper columnist, declared yesterday morning at the Middle Collegiate Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street.
Only 57 per cent of the budget increase sought by the City Planning Commission is justified, the Citizens Budget Commission asserted yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 (UP)--The Russians seized twenty-two German trucks carrying metal between Berlin and Western Germany today, in the face of a strong Western Allied protest against Soviet traffic restrictions.
In the last three months New Yorkers have saved 27,000,000,000 gallons of water by cutting consumption 300,000,000 gallons a day.

Fifty-five trolley car enthusiasts and two young women who "personally dislike" trolleys but went along for the ride, loaded into "The Green Lady," officially trolley car No. 1074, yesterday, for the fifth annual Triboro Trolley Tour of the Transit Improvement Association.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 19--Steel sales officials admitted today that some parts of their heavy order backlogs were probably built up on buyers' fears of cutbacks because of the coal impasse. Just how much could be attributed to such fears was unknown.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19-- George Bagnall, United Artists Distributing Corporation vice president in charge of production, has sent his resignation to the United Artists board of directors in New york, it was learned tonight.

ALBANY, Feb. 19--A distinct and sizable drive to have James A. Farley, former Postmaster General and former State and National Democratic Chairman, nominated for Governor on the Democratic ticket this fall has started in various sections of the state.

The New York City Omnibus Corporation is planning to file with the Public Service Commission this week the eight-cent fare schedules authorized by that body last June, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19--Government officials doubted tonight that British Foreign Secretary Bevin had reference to new or formal conferences when he said in London today the Labor Government was discussing a post-Marshall Plan program with the United States.

Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange last week saw prices for the staple moving into new high ground for the season. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts had recorded net advances of 55 points to a decline of 3 points from the previous week.

The United States liner Washington arrived here yesterday after a stormy voyage to Europe, in the course of which her bow was split open on the port side. The vessel, with 1,132 passengers, docked at Pier 61, North River and Twentyfirst Street, at 8:15 A.M. She was three days late.

The New York Americans defeated the Trenton Americans, 4 to 2, in an American Soccer League match at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday, and regained their runner-up position to the champion Philadelphia Nationals.

The conflicts of fastmoving armoured and motorised forces in the Desert present this contrast with the past in an extreme form.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19--Attorney General J. Howard McGrath accepted today the chairmanship of the American committee of the Academy of International Law at The Hague.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 19--Unmoved by the threat of fines and other Federal penalties against the United Mine Workers, most of the country's 370,000 striking soft-coal miners stood firmly today against obeying last week's back-to-work order from their union president, John L. Lewis.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19--Home builders in the United States, whose efforts have been concentrated largely on production of singlefamily residences, are preparing to invade the rental housing field on a broad scale under a program to be inaugurated at their convention here this week.
LONDON, Feb. 19--Although four months have elapsed since the pound sterling was devalued, the full effect of that change on the price level has not yet by any means been experienced.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19--The press continued to be dominated by two major news stories--the Soviet election campaign and the alliance with China. For two days the Soviet papers have devoted a full page to the reaction from China and the People's Democracies to the Soviet-Chinese pact.

The Federal Trade Commission has issued an order prohibiting eleven manufacturers from granting and thirteen retailers from receiving "unlawful brokerage fees in connection with the sale and purchase of women's wearing apparel," it was announced over the week-end in Washington.

MADRID, Feb. 19--The Spanish Government is buying forty-four United States training planes and the only point still under discussion is the disposition of the pesetas that will pay for them, a good source asserted here tonight.

LONDON, Feb. 19--Judging from the sharp recovery that has occurred in the markets in the last few days, one might imagine that the Stock Exchange had suddenly found the answer to its problem of how the election will go.

Maurice A. Dawkins became yesterday the first Negro member of the ministerial staff of the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, where he was installed formally as minister of education.
Eleven happily chattering Japanese women invaded Manhattan Island by ferry boat yesterday, peering about eagerly for the Statue of Liberty.

DETROIT, Feb. 19--Discipline of power groups overshadows all of the nation's economic concerns, it was asserted today at the closing session of the National Study Conference on The Church and Economic Life, conducted by 450 delegates from twenty-two faiths that embrace 29,000,000 Protestants.

SHREWSBURY, N.J., Feb. 19 --Shrewsbury Presbyterian Church, founded in 1732, forty-three years before the Revolution, will begin a year-long celebration on Tuesday in observance of the 200th anniversary of the granting of its charter by King George II of England in 1750.
PARIS, Feb. 19--During 1949 France covered two-thirds of her purchases abroad by exports, which was about the situation that prevailed before the war.

The death a few days ago of Montagu Norman, who headed the Bank of England for almost a quarter of a century before his retirement in 1944, evoked comparatively little comment in this country, or even in the British press.
LONDON, Feb. 19--There are in this country about 10,000,000 to 11,000,000 voters who are unshakeable Conservatives. There are probably about an equal number of faithful followers of Labor.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 19 (AP)--Prosecutor Gyula Alapi marshaled technical witnesses today to testify on the damage done to Hungary by the alleged spying and sabotage of Robert A. Vogeler, United States business man, and six co-defendants.

The handspike politics of the National Maritime Union shattered the Sunday morning peace of Astor Place yesterday when a band of thirty-five men, approaching in automobiles and on foot, endeavored to break up a meeting of the "rank and file committee" of the union, headed by Jack Lawrenson.

GREENOCK, Scotland, Feb. 19 --Hector McNeil, Britain's young Minister of State, whose verbal duels with Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky have marke many United Nations debates, faces a hard fight for re-election here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19--Grain prices except those for corn ranged higher on the Board of Trade last week with March and May wheat acting tight; the former selling within one cent of the seasonal high established in December and reflected.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19--A coordinated fashion promotion for men's clothes, featuring "fantom-weight fashions" for summer and introducing "midcentury tones" for fall and winter wear, was presented here today to the men's retail clothing and furnishing industry at the opening of the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers.

Joseph Szigeti had the stage all to himself for two-thirds of yesterday's new Friends of Music Conceit in Town Hall. He played two selections from that collection of violinistic impossibilities called Bach's Unaccompanied Violin Sonatas--those in C major and G minor.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 19--Miss Katherine Mary Fenster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip W. Fenster, was married here this afternoon to Robert Riesner, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Riesner of Pelham Manor, and New Preston, Conn., at the DeWitt Clinton Hotel. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Wolk of Beth Emet Synagogue.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP)--Willie Hoppe of Drexel Hill, Pa., retained his world's three-cushion billiard title tonight while Willie Mosconi of Barrington, N.J., won his fifth world's pocket billiard crown.

ESKILSTUNA, Sweden, Feb. 19 (AP)--Hjalmar Andersen of Norway won the world speed skating championship today, beating his countryman, Odd Lundberg, and John Werket of Minneapolis in the final point standing.

HONG KONG, Monday, Feb. 20 --Three Chinese Nationalist B-25 bombers smashed the Hsiakwan power plant and its transformer works at Nanking yesterday, according to a broadcast by Taipei, Formosa, early today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 19-- Mr. and Mrs. William Sutcliffe Sagar have announced the engagement of Mr. Sagar's daughter, Lillian Emery, to Frederick D. Forsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Forsch of 14 East Eighty-third Street, New York.

The Citizens Budget Commission gave qualified approval yesterday to pending proposals for a halfbillion dollar expansion of the city debt limit for building the Second Avenue subway. It expressed unqualified opposition to proposals to raise the city's general debt limit from 10 per cent of the assessed valuations to 12 .

Budge-Wood Service, Inc., a hand laundry serving clients in New York, Long Island and Connecticut and several hotels in New York City, has leased basement space in Sutton Terrace, an apartment building under construction at 450 East Sixty-third Street. Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., are the renting agents.

A 60 per cent increase in airplane passenger traffic, and inevitable growth of the air freight business will require expansion of airport facilities in most cities within five years, the Urban Land Institute of Washington forecast in a recent study.

Morison, Assistant Attorney General of the United States, and on the filing of the verified petition of the United States of America, charging civil and criminal contempt of court committed by the international union, United Mine Workers of America, an unincorporated labor organization,

Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan yesterday ordered the trial of Judith Coplon and Valentin A. Gubitchev to be resumed next Monday after denying a request of Miss Coplon's new attorneys for a sixty-day delay to orient themselves.

ALBANY, Feb. 20--Veterans' organizations scored a notable victory here today when a special committee named by Governor Dewey voted unanimously to drop, for the present, all proposals to modify the preferences that veterans now enjoy in their retention of civil service employment.

The coldest weather of the year struck the Northeast yesterday just as the nation, its coal supplies almost completely cut off, was reaching the bottom of the coal bin. It was a bitter, if unnecessary, reminder that the coal operators, the Government and the public had once more been outmaneuvered and led to the brink of catastrophe by John L. Lewis.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 20--Boredom was the only discernible reaction among the country's 370,000 striking soft coal miners to word from Washington tonight of Federal contempt of court proceedings and a new anti-strike in junction.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20-- Questions why Harry R. Bridges espoused an Allied second front, as demanded by the Communist party, as early as August, 1942, and opposed pressure in this country to get Russia to join in the war against Japan as late as March, 1945, helped keep him on the witness stand today for his fifth full day of cross-examination.
BOMBAY, India, Feb. 20 (UP)-- Sarat Chandra Bose, No. 1 political opponent of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, died today in Calcutta.
An American oil man who has been through the mill of arrest and "confession" in Hungary said yesterday that Robert 'A. Vogeler undoubtedly was innocent of any spy activities.

PANAMA, Feb. 20--A declaration today by the political action committees of Guatemalan labor unions that they will support Col. Jacobo Arbenz for President next December may confirm a recent forecast by the Guatemalan newspaper. Hora that Guatemala is headed for a "dictatorship of the proletariat."

Sportsmen's Show highlights. Surf rods, boat rods and bait rods are being turned out in assorted materials these days, but the fly fisherman who follows the ritual and tradition of his sport refuses to be swayed from the handmade split bamboo rod, insisting that no other material provides the weight, action and "feel" of this medium.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin, told the Senate tonight that an individual who once passed highly secret United States information to a known Soviet agent in an important European listening post now was "one of our foreign ministers."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--Reorganization plans being prepared by President Truman would, if enacted, complete the gratifying score of 60 per Cent of the recommendations of the Commission on Organization of the Executive

WE who are dependent upon heat in radiators and water in taps, food in cans and music in boxes, light in bulbs and everything in cellophane, often regard our ancestors with both admiration and shame. We admire their resourceulness and hardihood and feel ashamed of our own helplessness in a world of gadgets, which we can seldom repair ourselves...

PARIS, Feb. 20--The view that the United States and the Soviet Union are socially a good deal alike and are similarly, if not equally, menacing for Europe was forcefully expressed today by a distinguished French novelist and polemicist, Francois Mauriac, in one of his always vehement articles on the first page of the conservative newspaper Figaro.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 20-- Donald Crisp, film actor, filed suit today in the California Superior Court against William and Edward Nassour, film producers and owners of their own studio, for $240,114.84 allegedly due on two promissory notes dated March 28, 1948, and Feb. 27, 1949, respectively.

Commercial standards for water repellent textiles as tentatively proposed by the National Bureau of Standards are not feasible for rayon and synthetic fabrics, according to the Textile Distributors Institute, representing eighty-five suppliers of converters in the uptown New York area.

The Admiral Corporation, television and appliance manufacturers, realized a new high of $8,239,582 in earnings last year on record sales of $112,004,251, according to the annual report issued Yesterday.

Three low-rent housing developments to be built by the New York City Housing Authority with state and Federal funds were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commisssion. Final approval of the projects by the Board of Estimate is expected next Thursday.
BUDPEST, Hungry, Feb, 20--Hungary's Public Prosecutor pleaded guilty to charges of es-

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 20--In a move to break down discrimination on American college campuses, student delegates from seventeen Northeastern colleges and universities, meeting at Cornell University here, announced plans today for a national organization to promote inter-racial and inter-faith activities.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 20--Is There, member of two-quadruped stable owned by C.H. Mayne of Detroit, slipped between horses in the stretch to gain a length-and-a-half decision at $23.20 in the best of Hialeah's nine races today.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 20--Capt. W.D. Brown of the battleship Missouri, figuratively wheeled his defense armor in four different directions today in an apparent effort to share with key officers his responsibility for the vessel's grounding on Jan. 17.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 20 (AP) --New Jersey was threatened with a $2,795,630 cut in Federal aid today, as a penalty for any diversion of highway funds in the 1950-51 fiscal year. The threat came from Washington as the state's joint legislative appropriations committee met to begin reviewing Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's proposed $164,131.075 budget.

The western Maryland Railway borrowed yesterday $2,460,000 on trust certificates to help finance the acquisition of twenty new diesel locomotives. Sale of the equipment serials was made at competitive bidding to Halsey, Stuart Co.,

With extra police guards on hand to quell any violence, fifteen members of the National Maritime Union, CIO, appeared in two courts here yesterday on charges that arose out of a bloody clash between two factions of the union Sunday morning in Tom Mooney Hall, 13 Astor Place.

The Government's proposal for an income tax levy of $93,000,000 retroactive to 1947 on life insurance companies is eminently fair, Leroy A. Lincoln, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, said yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 20--The constitutionality of New York City's Sharkey rent law and the state validating act was challenged in the Court of Appeals today by landlord groups and the Federal Office of the Housing Expediter.

Nearly 80 per cent of the communities in this country lack adequate facilities for children needing special care, Leonard W. Mayo, president of the Child Welfare League of America, reported yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 20--As the British election campaign moved into its final stage, three top Labor party spokesmen, Prime Minister Attlee, Foreign Secretary Bevin and Herbert Morrison, Lord President of the Council, were busy tonight replying to Mr. Winston ChurcHill's campaign charges of the last few days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--PanAmerican Gold, Ltd., Toronto, Canada, was notified today by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it would have to correct a few "deficiencies" in a registration statement filed recently with the commission or the agency would issue a stop order barring public sale of the stock in this country.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 20-- Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Jacob 2d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anita, to Albert Brown Hilton 4th of Dayton, Ohio, son of Mrs. P. Schuyler Church of Dayton, and Albert B. Hilton of Beverly Hills, Calif.

Tolerance and the consideration of fellow-men without distinction of race, rank or religion represent the underlying hope for any solution to world affairs, Council President Vincent R. Impellitteri declared yesterday at a City Hall ceremony marking Brotherhood Week.
A major trade showing of imported giftwares made in handicraft shops in Israel opened yesterday at the Pierre Hotel.

Breaking with educational tradition, the New School for Social Research will open next fall a College of Retired Professors. The faculty will be drawn from the rosters of distinguished retired scholars at leading college and universities throughout the United States.
General Donovan and the American Committee on United Europe have performed a valuable service in collecting the opinions of leading European statesmen on the problem of European unity.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (U.P.)-- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, said today he was not against union hiring halls if they admitted non-union members.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20--The grain markets fluctuated in a nervous manner on the Board of Trade today, with trading relatively light. March wheat was up 3/8 cent a bushel at one time, at $2.21, within 7/8 cent of the seasonal high, but the position closed 1/8 cent lower. The distant deliveries were up 1/8 to cent.

Wayne Kelley, assistant controller of the Armstrong Cork Company, declared last night. He spoke at a meeting of the New York Chapter of the National Association of Cost Accountants in the Governor Clinton Hotel.

Lawrence Tibbett will sing his first television opera role in Verdi's "La Traviata" over the Columbia Broadcasting System Sunday, March, 12, at 5 P. M. Mr. Tibbett, the Metropolitan Opera baritone, will be one of the three principals in the cast, singing the role of Germont.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20--Instead of being content with their old role of running American homes, women have moved to the forefront as planners and builders of postwar houses.

In another effort to avoid a nation-wide strike by 100,000 telephone workers, Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, arranged yesterday for major negotiation sessions to move from New York to Washington. The strike has been set for 6 A.M. Friday.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 20--Edward G, Miller Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, spent three and a half hours with President Juan Peron in two visits today. He will return to the Presidential House in the morning to renew taks with the President and with members of the National Economic Council.

Two children, brother and sister, were killed yesterday, and their mother and grandmother were hurt trying to rescue them when a fire swept the upper floors of their three-story frame dwelling at 29 Van Nostrand Court, Little Neck, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--The market value of the goods and services produced by the United States, described by economists as "gross national product," amounted to $257,000,000,000 in 1949, compared with $262,000,000,000 in 1948, the Department of Commerce announced today.

GENEVA, Feb. 19--Israeli and Jordanian representatives renewed today their refusal to participate in the work of the United Nations Trusteeship Council of elaborating the statute for the internationalization of Jerusalem.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 20--The American Federation of Labor suggested to the United Nations Economic and Social Council today that a permanent group of experts be set up to watch economic developments in the Western world and coordinate anti-unemployment campaigns.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--A Senate subcommittee, dealing with the costs of executive departments, has made some recommendations which appear to possess the rare virtue of pointing the way to lower costs and greater efficiency in government.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Tuesday, Feb 21 (AP)--Nationalist China's longbrewing political crisis neared an explosive climax today.

ALBANY, Feb. 20--A, split between Governor Dewey and Republican legislative leaders developed today over the question of lifting the state's long-standing ban against the sale of colored oleomargarine.

ALBANY, Feb. 20--Governor Dewey, in a message to the Legislature tonight, gave his backing to the report issued last Thursday by his Special Committee on Libraries, which recommended $3,653,000 a year in new state aid for county library units.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 20--The United Nations reported today that slavery was still being practiced in several parts of the world, particularly in China where young girls were bought from their parents for $10 to $20 and sold in Singapore for as high as $2,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--Congress, may be obliged to consider the automobile industry "a hardship case" next year unless excise taxes on automotive products are repealed, spokesmen for the industry warned the House Ways and Means Committee today.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 20--The American Academy of General Practice faced today the question of "mercy killing" as a director of its New England chapter, Dr. Hermann Sander, went on trial for murder in New Hampshire.

Helen Nearing returns today with her husband, Dr. Scott Nearing, to what she calls their "wilderness in a wilderness"; tomorrow they start tapping. In Jamaica, Vt., where they live, there's no question of what one taps. Maple trees, of course.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 20-- Jacob A. Malik, Soviet representative to the United Nations, made public today a letter from Abraham Pomerantz, attorney for Valentin Gubitchev, insisting that telephones of United Nations employes and delegates had been tapped.

TRENTON, Feb. 20--The New Jersey Supreme Court today reserved decision in disbarment proceedings against Andrew O. Wittreich, Jersey City lawyer, after hearing charges that he used funds of a client to restore money improperly diverted from an estate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)-- Representative Fred L. Crawford, Republican, of Michigan, returned to a backslapping ovation on Capitol Hill today after spending two nights in jail to uphold "the principle that Congressmen should not have any special privileges."

The Lenten season of fasting and prayer will open tomorrow, Ash Wednesday, with special services in most churches observing a liturgical form of worship. A number of other denominations will follow the daily series of meditations and prayers as set forth in the annual Fellowship of Prayer issued by the Federal Council of Churches of Chrict in America.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 20--The United Nations placed squarely today before the economically backward regions of the world the issue of stabilizing their regulations to help pave the way for foreign investments under the proposed plan of technical aid to underdeveloped areas.

Jacques Ibert, noted French composer, will join the faculty of the Berkshire Music Center which will open its eighth season on July 3, it was announced yesterday. The summer school will run concurrently with the Tanglewood Festival, scheduled to begin July 8 in Lenox, Mass., to which it will contribute at least forty performances.
