KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 20-- There is no closed season for those who want to fire on the schools, Dr. Thomas H. Briggs, emeritus Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, New York, said here today. He spoke at a session of the National Association of Secondary Principals.

ALBANY, Feb. 20--Representative William L. Pfeiffer, Republican state chairman, today accused Democratic members of the Legislature and their party leaders of attempting to sabotage the state's post-war reconstruction and rehabilitation program.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 20--United States insistence that charged of bribery in denazification proceedings be thoroughly investigated has been hailed by United States representatives in the German, state and county governments as "just the thing we have been waiting for."
JERUSALEM, Feb. 20--Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion came out today unequivocally in opposition to drafting a constitution for the State of Israel.

A preliminary study of the possibility of relieving New York's water shortage by scientific rainmaking will be made by Dr. Wallace E. Howell, a research meteorologist at the Blue Hill Meteorological Observatory at Harvard University, Mayor O'Dwyer announced last night.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 9--One of the great tests that faces the new Iranian Parliament is the reform of the tax system to lessen the burden on the poor and get at Iran's highly concentrated wealth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, today backed legislation that would put a check on the Government's costly potato price support program. He said the action was a "favor to all American agriculture."

A $67,570,000 expansion program for the city's public colleges was presented to the Board of Higher Education last night by a group of independent experts. The board referred the proposals to a committee for further study.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--A series of witnesses, representing patriotic societies, appeared before a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee today to oppose all moves toward world government. They joined in urging that no plan be adopted that involved the cession of any shred of United States national sovereignty.

Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman ruled yesterday that enemy nationals who subsequently became nationalized Americans were not entitled to recover property seized in time of war by the Alien Property Custodian.

Original pictures by the world's most distinguished amateur artist, Winston Churchill, are not for sale but quantities of the statesman's works in reproduction will be on the market soon in prints for framing, on Christmas and playing cards and on calendars.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20--Investigation of housing cooperatives by Congress before it takes final action on the so-called middle-income cooperative housing bill was urged today by the National Association of Home Builders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--One of David E. Lilienthal's recommendations when he left the chairmanship of the Atomic Energy Commission was that United States policy on atomic energy should be directed by a single commissioner rather than by the present fiveman board.

The ill-fortune that found rolypoly Vincent Gambino, Catholic Youth Organization, hammered out of his chance at amateur boxing distinction last year, pursued him last night in the finals of the twenty-fourth Golden Gloves tournament under the auspices of The News Welfare Association in Madison Square Garden.

After a conference with Mayor O'Dwyer, Councilman Hugh Quinn, Queens Democrat, announced yesterday that he would recommend the shelving of a taxicab fare increase bill he introduced last month. His decision made it virtually certain that the Council would not approve any increase.

Champions are slated to defend their titles in all but two of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field events booked for Saturday night at Madison Square Garden. Only one of the athletes, Yale's Jim Fuchs, 220-pound senior, is virtually certain of retaining his crown.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture today pictured a farm financial situation marked by declining income, lowered value of assets and increased debts. Further declines are expected this year, officials said, citing shrinking farm-product prices and overseas markets.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21--Federal housing executives today took the residential builders of the country to task for the "inadequacies" of many of the homes now being produced and for the apparent "failure" of the industry to provide modern shelter within the means of the average American family.

NEWARK, Feb. 21--Housewives, food producers, retailers and distributors exchanged views and grievances here today in the first of a series of public forums sponsored by the New Jersey Agricultural Extension Service of Rutgers University.

LONDON, Feb. 21--Britain's big electoral debate is over. From now until Thursday, when more than 30,000,000 voters will decide the winner, the battle centers in the constituencies where the rival candidates are engaged in a last-minute struggle for votes. I
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP)-- The Army is sending a construction force to the Pacific atoll of Eniwetok to help build facilities for periodic tests of atomic weapons there.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--President Truman will not discuss any proposal to seize the nation's coal mines or make any move in that direction until contempt proceedings against the United Mine Workers are completed next week, it was reported today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 21--Believed to be the oldest World War II veteran now receiving a graduate college education under the GI Bill, 62-year-old Richard E. Lambert has just been decorated for his service to the Chinese Navy during the last war, it was announced today by the editors of The Targum, Rutgers University undergraduate newspaper.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 21--Some observers believe the Bulgarian Government desired and even sought to bring about a rupture of diplomatic relations with the United States Government ever since the death of Georgi Dimitrov in order to remove the most important symbol of resistance to Soviet-power on Bulgarian territory.
Relief from intense traffic congestion here by late 1950 through the completion of several expressways was forecast yesterday by John C. Riedel, chairman of the Traffic Commission.

Harold E. Stassen contended last night that the supposed "Iron Curtain" keeping information of the outside world from reaching the Russian people was a myth. He declared that the curtain, rather than being watertight, was a "sieve" that could be pierced at any time by American ingenuity.

Convertibility of dollars into gold would be a "vicious addition" to the present United States gold policy and would hamper the functioning of a well-managed monetary system, E.M. Bernstein, director of the research department of the International Monetary Fund, said yesterday.

BOSTON, Feb. 21--Columbia University overcame a 10-point deficit to defeat Harvard, 62 to 52, in an Eastern League basketball game in the first half of a college doubleheader at the Boston Arena tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The United States formally broke diplomatic relations with Bulgaria today, making good its threat of a month ago.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 21--Frank Rosen's Palatine Stable, which has had remarkable success with Chicle II, had a front-running winner in today's main event at Hialeah in the remarkable time of 1:48 4/5 for nine furlongs after a mile in 1:35 3-5. The recent McLennan Handicap was won by Three Rings in 1:501-5.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21--Delegates to the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers heard today that nine out of ten men's wear stores were obsolete in some degree and more than 50 per cent were inefficient and out-of-date.
A special fact-finding board in the dispute between the New Jersey Bell System and Division 55 of the Communications Workers of America, CIO, denied yesterday most of the union's demands.

Princeton's trio gained the quarter-final round of the 1950 national intercollegiate indoor polo championship tournament by turning back Harvard, 8 to 5, in a firstround match at the Squadron A Armory last night.
The Fishblatt estate property in Atlantic City, N.J., has been purchased for improvement with an apartment building, Albert M. Greenfield Co., brokers in the transaction, reported yesterday.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 21-- Delegates to the biennial convention of the longlines division of the Communication Workers of America, CIO, voted today to regard non-union workers as "untouchables" Who are unworthy of the friendship and respect of union members.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Senate Democratic leadership formally moved today for--an investigation by the Foreign Relations Committee of charges that "at least" fifty-seven Communists were at work in the State Department.

Howard McGrath today that the Department of Justice was guilty of "departure from our civil liberties tradition" in barring two aliens from this country without giving them a hearing.
ALBANY, Feb. 21--By a unanimous vote, the Senate Committee on Agriculture registered its opposition today to all measures that would permit the sale of yellowcolored oleomargarine in New York.

Supreme Court Justice Benedict D. Dineen will hear argument Friday on a taxpayer's suit against parking fees for residents of Peter Cooper Village, it was learned yesterday.

Further lowering of import tariffs by the United States, a move held to be potentially harmful to the paper and pulp industry, could produce numerous "Waltham" failures, it was declared yesterday by E.W. Tinker, executive secretary of the American Paper and Pulp Association.

Consumption of water in the city jumped to 894,500,000 gallons on Monday, the highest rate of use in one day since Dec. 12, water officials reported yesterday. At the same time, the Catskill and Croton reservoirs showed their first storage loss in many days, 135,000,000 gallons.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 21--The Yugoslav Government announced tonight it had accepted the proposal of Ho Chi Minh, Communist leader of the rebel Viet Nam Government in Indo-China, to establish diplomatic relations. This is regarded here as the most sensational victory, over the Soviet Government since Marshal Tito's split with the Communist Information Bureau.

The one-story industrial building on a plot 300 by 100 feet at 11761186 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Frederick Brown from a client of Simon Kutner, broker in the transaction. The attorneys were Dammann, Roche Goldberg for the seller and Joshua Bernstein for the buyer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP)The House Small Business Committee charged today that many organizations claiming to represent the small business man may often be simply a front "for other purposes."

Consumer demand for premiumgrade liquors throughout the country is greater than ever, W. W. Wachtell, president of the Calvert Distillers Corporation, declared yesterday. He addressed 100 of the company's wholesalers at a meeting....

The United States Supreme Court's deportation decision on Monday has halted temporarily all hearings in the New York area and will undoubtedly result in hundreds of retrials for deportable aliens, including leaders of the Communist party, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, and Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, urged Congress today to authorize a third Marshall Plan appropriation of $2,950,000,000 for European recovery as the most effective weapon for combating Kremlin plans of world domination.
The Electric Power Board of Chattanooga; largest municipal customer of the Tennessee Valley Authority, said yesterday that it saved its 61,760 customers $6,625,835 last year.
SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 21--Dr. Alice Appenzeller, president emeritus of Ewha College and the first white child to be born in Korea, died-here yesterday at the age of 64.

Senator McCarthy of Wisconsin has been giving a good imitation of a hitand-run driver in his attacks on the State Department. He has made the damaging charge that there are "fiftyseven card-holding Communists" on the Department's rolls.

Fifty-three taxicab fleet owners started an action in Supreme Court yesterday to prevent the State Labor Relations Board from holding an election to determine the collective bargaining representative of eleven of the companies. They contend that they carry passengers encased in interstate travel.
Bulgaria left the United States no choice; by our standards we had to break diplomatic relations with a Government that had violated canons of international decency in a steady and atrocious fashion.

Yesterday, the second day of the winter's first cold wave, began with a record-setting mark of 5 degrees at 6:30 A.M. and closed with a snowfall that set in at night. In between, the temperature had climbed steadily until it reached a high for the day of 25 degrees at 6:55 P.M.

The work of reconstructing the center span and roadways of the Brooklyn Bridge will begin March 6, Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen announced yesterday. The project will necessitate rerouting of traffic between Manhattan and Brooklyn.
LONDON, Feb. 21. (AP)--Seretse Khama, the Negro prince who married a white wife, has rejected a British plea to give up his throne for the sake of Empire unity.

President Truman issued an Executive Order on Feb. 6 which set in motion the machinery provided in the emergency sections of the Taft-Hartley Act. Theoretically this offered two approaches to the problem of restoring normal coal production.
All the crisp prettiness that women want in a new spring hat was summed up in the Jeanne Tete collection presented yesterday at Gunther Jaeckel.

HONG KONG, Feb. 21--The rumors and counter-rumors regarding the allegiance of Gen. Lu Han, turncoat Governor of Yunnan Province, appeared to have been ended tonight with the Peiping radio report that Communist troops took the Kunming provincial capital yesterday.
Six hundred ninety-two wire trash baskets--purchased by the city at $10 each--have been snatched from their sidewalk locations since last July l, it was learned yesterday.

Directors of the National Steel Corporation voted yesterday a dividend of $1.50 a share on the capital stock, an increase of 25 cents over last year's rate, and then proposed that the stock be split three-for-one.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--Continued existence of the Metropolitan Opera Company and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra as well as many smaller such cultural organizations throughout the country may depend upon repeal of the 20 per cent Federal admissions tax, Congress was told today.

Icy weather in many parts of the country cut sharply into diminishing coal supplies yesterday. New Jersey dealers started rationing on an informal basis, but major industries managed to defer largescale layoffs and few householders were without heat.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- Chances of averting a widespread telephone strike on Friday suffered a sharp blow today when Western Electric Company, a Bell System subsidiary, rejected a Federal Mediation Service request to negotiate in Washington.

The Legation of the United States of America presents its compliments to the Minister for Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of Bulgaria and has the honor to refer to the Legation's note of Jan. 20, 1950, in reply to the note delivered by the Bulgarian Legation in Washington to the Department of State on Jan. 19, 1950, requesting the recall from Bulgaria of the American Minister, Mr. Donald R. Heath as persona non grata.

I am happy to have this opportunity to appear before you in support of action to continue our full participation in the European Recovery Program.

For the woman over 40, B. Altman's offered a round-the-clock review of spring fashions during luncheon in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel yesterday. The show was a frank recognition of the fire problems and maturity of taste of this age group.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Administration's middle income housing bill cleared a first major hurdle today as the House Banking and Currency Committee reported it favorably by a vote of 11 to 4.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 21--Marshal Tito's week-end preelection speech has become the subject of intensive discussion among the citizens of Belgrade. The meaning of his admonition to the Western governments is being discussed widely.

GENEVA, Feb. 21--The first really embarrassing test of the Western powers' ability to deal with the consequences of the Communist victory in China is expected to come during the meeting of the contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (the Geneva tariff accord), opening here Thursday.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 21--Roman Catholic sources reported today the arrest of three abbots.

ALBANY, Feb. 21--The Senate today approved by a vote of 30 to 21 a bill to bar the construction of the Panther Mountain dam on the south branch of the Moose River. It was sponsored by Senator Walter W. Stokes, Republican, of Cooperstown.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21--Information for prospective bidders is being considerably broadened by the armed services, Gordon Gray, Secretary of the Army, told members of the Smaller Manufacturers Council of Pittsburgh here today.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 21--An indictment against five Bulgarians chaiged with spying on behalf of the United States, which was pubdished here today, asserted that the United States Legation in Sofia had been turned "into a center of plots and espionage against the People's Republic of Bulgaria."

Adoption by the United States of the International Trade Organization agreement, reached at Havana last year, and a change in the customs system from the Hawley-Smoot tariff days were described last night as essential to the economic future of the United States and the world.

Impact of the slow-down in steel production due to the coal strike was felt yesterday by all metals on the Commodity Exchange here. Copper, tin, zinc and lead, which had been showing strong market tendencies for several weeks,

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Interstate Commerce Commission today turned down a plan of the Maine Central Railroad Company for alteration of 30,000 shares of outstanding 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock, on the ground that the railroad had not made the showing required under the socalled "Mahaffie Act."

Lieut. Col. William Watts Rose, USA, retired, died on Monday in the Marine Hospital, Baltimore, after a long illness, it was learned yesterday. Colonel Rose, who resided in Washington, was 66 years old.

Frederick W. Gehle, executive director of the Greater New York Fund, warned yesterday that "the welfare state" would be that much nearer unless New York business concerns "awakened" to their responsibility in supporting the health and welfare services of the city.

KOIDERN RIVER, Yukon Territory, Feb. 21--Jet fighters zoomed through the deep valleys and skimmed over the high mountains of the Yukon Territory and the eastern part of Alaska today as Exercise Sweetbriar--the combined United States-Canadian Arctic war game--neared its climax.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21--The newspaper Izvestia today presented one of the Soviet theses regarding atomic energy--that capitalists in the United States are preventing in every manner the harnessing of atoms for power to lighten mankind's peaceful tasks.

LONDON, Feb. 21--Investors had second thoughts today abouttheir predictions for a conservative victory on Thursday and decided to take their profits. As a result some shares that have been particularly strong in the past week weakened although the undertone as a whole remained firm.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 21 --The rearmament of Eastern Germany has now progressed to a point where 45,000 officers and men, young, tough and drawn from areas with a tradition of military service and success, form the army of the German Democratic Republic, first post-war German Army.
LONDON, Feb. 21--Housing is an important issue in Britain's general election campaign. Next to food and fear of unemployment it is likely to have a big influence on the voting Thursday.
A total of 1,270 vessels entered or cleared the Port of New York last month, an increase of 125 ships over January, 1949, Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs, reported yesterday.

First nighters will assemble at the Coronet this evening to find out what goes on in "The Bird Cage," the new Arthur Laurents play starring Melvyn Douglas. The curtain is announced to rise at 8 o'clock.

GENEVA, Feb. 21--Dr. Fadhil al-Jamali, Iraq delegate to the United Nations Trusteeship Council, said today that Iraq would withdraw her approval of an international regime for the Jerusalem area if the council in any way...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Ohio Edison Company, Akron, Ohio, and the Ohio Public Service Company, Cleveland, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan for the merger of Public Service into Ohio Edison.

ALBANY, Feb. 21--Governor Dewey announced tonight that he would ask the Legislature tomorrow for power to confiscate coal in the hands of dealers and private owners to insure the use of existing supplies only for the most essential purposes.

Beaten only twice in their last ten games, the New York Rangers will be out to increase their undefeated string to seven tonight when they clash with the high-scoring Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League battle at Madison Square Garden.

British Diesel engine and locomotive makers are recommending that closer ties be established with Diesel industries here to adapt American methods of mass output and production planning to British plants.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21--Buying of corn futures in the last few minutes of trading, attributed to cash interests, gave that grain a strong close on the Board of Trade here today, final sales being at gains of 3/8 to 1 cent a bushel.

Dr. Luther Gulick, president of the Institute of Public Administration, has been chosen by city authorities as the executive director of Mayor O'Dwyer's Committee on Management Survey, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The House squared off tonight for what was expected to be the bitterest of its battles over the Civil Rights program. Tomorrow the Administration bill to establish a Permanent Fair Employment Practice Commission is due for a mandatory call to a showdown. Proponents and opponents prepared for a marathon continuous session; if necessary, to pass the measure or defeat it.

After having been in the family of the sellers since 1914, the one-family dwelling on lot 16.7 by 100 feet at 214 Albany Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Mary E. and Catherine A. Quinn to George M. Mayer. It is assessed at $5,600 and was sold for all cash.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 21 --A Hungarian People's Court today sentenced Robert A. Vogeler of New York to fifteen years in prison and his British business associate, Edgar Sanders, to thirteen years on charges of sabotage and spying for the West. Appeals are to be filed soon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Federal Government is financing a sizable part of its budget deficit by borrowing billions of dollars from its own agencies, the Federal Reserve Board reported today in its "bulletin" for February.

The four major networks and WOR reached an agreement yesterday with the Radio and Television Directors Guild for a new contract covering staff directors. Network directors will receive pay increases up to $15 a week, bringing their basic minimums to $145.
A civil anti-trust suit charging the Shubert brothers with monopolistic practices in the legitimate theatre was filed in Federal court yesterday by the Attorney General's office.

LONDON, Feb. 21--The Marquess of Salisbury, who is widely regarded here as the possible foreign secretary should the Conservative party-return to power, added his voice tonight to than of Winston Churchill in urging a direct approach to the Soviet Government for a settlement of the outstanding world differences.

Drastic revision of the Long Island Rail Road's signal system was advocated yesterday by an expert at a Public Service Commission hearing that stemmed from the train collision at Rockville Centre, L.I., in which twenty-nine persons were killed Friday night.

A glorious second-half comeback carried the St. John's quintet to a 66-60 victory over N.Y.U. before 16,000 spectators at Madison Square Garden last night. Down 14 points at one stage in the first period, Frank McGuire's Redmen played top-notch basketball and earned

Georges Revers' report on IndoChina as well as its political portion had been conveyed to Ho Chi Minh, leader of the revolt there.
Landers, Frary and Clark is expanding production facilities substantially and will increase output of electric housewares 50 per cent by the end of the second quarter.

Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, in their statements to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today was interpreted here as meaning that the United States intended to resume its pressure for such a union despite British resistance to the idea.

A wholesale fur jobber, whose year-long splurge of betting $2,000 a day on horse races resulted in a $38,546 loss, was arraigned yesterday on a grand larceny and forgery indictment as four alleged bookmakers were under arrest on charges they had handled at least half of the wagers.

MADRID, Feb. 21--The assassination in Mexico yesterday of Jose Gallostra, Spanish diplomat, is likely to become the nucleus of a series of mass demonstrations of support for Generalissimo Francesco Franco, a well-informed Spaniard predicted tonight.

Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, told the United Nations Economic and Social Council today that the recession last year in the United States and the resulting curtailment of imports were "by no means" the sole cause of the grave dollar shortage throughout the world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP)-- The Civil Aeronautics Board was advised today that helicopter airmail service should be tried in the New York area to round out experiments already under way in Chicago and Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Air Coordinating Committee reported to President Truman today that it was preparing a master plan for the mobilization of the civil air transport industry that would be put into effect in the event of a national emergency.

A group of fundamentalists will hold a conference this afternoon and a dinner tonight to mark the thirtieth anniversary year of the founding of their society, the American Civil Liberties Union.

LONDON, Feb. 21--Although only one full day remains before polling day in Britain, there is still very little external evidence up and down the country that one of the most crucial elections in modern British history is about to be decided.

ALBANY, Feb. 21--The Assembly approved today by a vote of 129 to 7 a resolution memorializing Congress to enact the Federal Fair Employment Practice Act, barring discrimination in employment be cause of race, religion or national origin.

In a five-story brick building at 115 East 106th Street yesterday workmen hurried about hanging bunting, testing light bulbs and setting up American flags. The reason for the activity was that tonight the building will be opened officially as quarters of the New York City Youth Board Good Neighbor Federation.

Mainbocher opened the season for New York couturier collections in his showroom at 4 East Fiftyseventh Street yesterday morning. The fashions, designed for spring in town and summer in the country, were controlled by certain definite characteristics.

William G.Wheeler, secretary of the Building Trades Employers Association, 2 Park Avenue, died there yesterday of a heart attack shortly after delivering his report at the annual meeting of the association. He, was 63 years old.
John Rhodes, 29 years old, a postoffice clerk, shot and seriously wounded three persons last night in an upper West Side apartment house because he was disappointed in love.

The Gioconda smile, somewhat less enigmatic than the famous one in the Louvre in Paris, gleamed out of a canvas that was shown to critics yesterday as another and genuine version of Leonardo da Vinci's "Mona Lisa."

Three of the country's leading authorities on arthritis and allied diseases reassured suffers from these ills yesterday against reports and rumors that the administration of ACTH or cortisone, the two hormones that are enabling arthritic cripples to walk again, would produce permanent side-effects.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Wednesday, Feb. 22 (AP)--A total of 1,240 Indonesian soldiers have been killed defending Tasikmalaja, West Java city, against invaders of Darul Islam, it was reported here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 21--A decision by state and Fed eral defense commands to develop here a permanent filter center to receive and chart air raid alarms from twenty-two counties of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut was announced this afternoon.

ALBANY, Feb. 21--The Democrats proposed legislation today to ease the shortage of medical personnel in rural areas by permitting school boards to engage physicians and dentists to care for school children when they agree to settle in the community.

There is no age limit to brotherhood, a celebration of 200 oldsters demonstrated yesterday at the Home of Old Israel, 70 Jefferson Street.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 21--One aspect of Israel's Cabinet crisis--the boycott of Government meetings by Cabinet Ministers representing the religious bloc--abated today.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was strong yesterday and prices rose 15 to 32 points.

George Washington's birthday will be observed today at several outdoor exercises in temperatures low enough to give participants an idea of the cold endured by the Revolutionary leader and his men at Valley Forge.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--Every debate on the Marshall Plan produces a new theme. In 1948, the Administration was worried about the collapse of Europe. In 1949, it was concerned about the integration of Europe. And now in 1950, it is concerned about the competion of Europe.

A bitter jurisdictional dispute between two American Federation of Labor unions seeking control of a group of Sanitation Department employes flared into the open yesterday when one of the union heads quit his city job in protest against "departmental labor relations."
Minneapolis, Minn., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on March 1 on an issue of bonds amounting to $6,921,362. Dated April 1, 1950, the bonds will be due on April 1, 1951 to 1970.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Thursday, Feb. 23 (Reuters)--The Bulgarian Government in a statement today said breaking of diplomatic relations with Bulgaria by the United States was "a breach of diplomatic practice."

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22-- Eight-hundred gallons of cooling oil surrounding the heavy copper electrical coils of Princeton University's thirty-five-ton cyclotron burst into flame at 1:30 o'clock this morning and by the time the stubborn blaze was brought under control nine hours later the $400, 000 machine was virtually destroyed.

For the second time in less than five months a Maritime Commission trial examiner has upheld the present rate operations of two North Atlantic steamship conferences and recommended to the Government agency the dismissal of charges brought against the groups by the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company, it became known yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 22--Senator Paul Fino, Bronx Republican, has proposed a bill, that Would give New York City immunity from damage suits in connection with experiments to produce rain by artificial means.
LONDON, Feb. 22--Tomorrow is election day in Britain. A new Parliament will be chosen in the first general election, since 1945, when the Labor party was voted into office.
The people of New York State have gained a victory--but have not yet won their objective--in the battle to protect one of their most valuable possessions: the Adirondack Forest Preserve.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 22--In a renewed effort to obtain return to Greece of children now in Czechoslovakia, Col. Leo de Meier of the International Red Cross has arrived here from Geneva for conversations with the Czechoslovak Government.
LONDON, Feb. 22--Sir Max Pemberton, novelist, journalist, playwright, motoring pioneer and contemporary of the late Lord Northcliffe, died in his London home today. He was 86 years old.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Feb. 22 (AP)-- Hand grenades were hurled today in renewed Moslem-Christian rioting, and casualties of the week were reported to have risen to 30 dead and 130 wounded.
Dwindling coal supplies brought enactment of additional emergency measures in many areas of the nation yesterday.

Senator Herbert H. Lehmen declared last night that liberty in this country faces a triple threat, aggression from the outside, subversion from within and finally, self-destruction. Anything we do here to destroy civil liberties, in our efforts to protect ourselves, is marked as a success in Russia, the Senator asserted.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 22--The Norwegian Polar Institute an nounced here tonight that, with the permission of King Haakon, the winter base of the joint BritishScandinavian Expedition in the Antarctic has been named Maudheim, in memory of Norway's late Queen Maud. The name localizes the station as situated in Queen Maud Land [that sector of the Antarctic Continent south of the eastern South Atlantic].

WHITE PLAINS,N. Y.,Feb. 22 --Teachers should learn more about teaching, try to put more of God into science instruction and stop flirting with administrative jobs, Msgr.John's Middleton, secretary of education for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, told 1,100 priests, brothers and sisters of New York, New Jersey, Delaware ,Pennsylvania and Washington here today

With a record entry in the men's singles, the seventh annual Eastern indoor tennis championships began at the Eighth Regiment Armory courts in the Bronx yesterday in a rather chilly setting.
PARIS, Feb. 22--A 25-year-old dressmaker, Alwynn, has aroused great interest during the recent Paris openings, and deservedly so. His collection is homogeneous.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22--Mrs. Emily Fogg Mead, widely known sociologist, civic leader and author of essays on sociological subjects, died yesterday in University Hospital at the age of 78.

"Indulgence" in meeting a baby's demands should result in a more relaxed mother who is happier with her child; but it can defeat its own purpose if carried so far that she worries about whether she is being indulgent enough.

Until last evening we thought there were only two kinds of chefs --those who appear to be in the midst of a nervous breakdown and those who seem on the edge of one. But Alex Chiesi fitted into neither group. He gave the impression of being on easy terms with the world despite responsibilities, culinary and otherwise.
Bad weather curtailed the usual Washington's Birthday observances here yesterday. Almost continuous rain and sleet kept most New Yorkers home for the holiday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--Capt. John G. Crommelin, critic of armed service unification policies, who was severely reprimanded less than four months ago for insubordination, has again been rebuked by the Chief of Naval Operations.

ALBANY, Feb. 22--A bipartisan Brooklyn judicial deal involving places on the Surrogates Court, Supreme Court and City Court appeared in the making today following introduction of a bill to create an additional judgeship in the Kings County Surrogate's Court.

The freighter Alamar, which ran aground at the entrance to New York harbor last Thursday morning and for six days refused to budge, was refloated yesterday and towed to an anchorage off Stapleton, S.I.

LONDON, Feb. 22 (UP)--The man who designed tennis star Gussie Moran's famous lace panties promised "something really sensational" for 1950, and that statement cost him his job today as official host of the Wimbledon tournament.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Feb. 22--The defense advanced by Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania to charges of suppressing human rights and freedom has been described by the United States as a "flimsy pretext that will not stand examination."

Arthur Laurents, who once wrote "Home of the Brave," has now gone to considerable trouble to show that life in a night club is seamy and squalid. "The Bird Cage," which opened at the Coronet last evening, records in meticulous detail the moral depravity of a night-club king.
With the signing yesterday of three pitchers, Jack Banta, Preacher Roe and Clement Labine, the Dodgers pared their unsigned list to four, including the one possible holdout.

ALBANY, Feb. 22--Both houses of the Legislature today blocked efforts to shake margarine legislation from the strangling grip of the Senate and Assembly Agriculture Committees. This eliminated any possibility that the ban against the sale of yellow-colored margarine might be lifted this year.
The Knights of Columbus, New York Chapter, took over Fifth Avenue for half an hour yesterday morning for their Golden Jubilee parade. The procession, led by Po

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 22--Dr. Clarence E. De La Chapelle of New York told the American Academy of General Practice today that there was a sustained demand for post-graduate gaining by practicing physicians.
NORTHWAY, Alaska, Feb. 22-- Almost 5,300 Canadian and American troops rend airmen concentrated around Northway today for the climax tomorrow of the most realistic ten-day Arctic exercise yet staged.
MANCHESTER, N. H., Feb. 22 --An all-male jury, completed this morning, was taken this afternoon to view the scene of the alleged "mercy killing" of a woman patient by Dr. Hermann N. Sander.

Findings of a nation-wide survey of family buying habits, particularly family and individual loyalty toward brand names, will soon be made available to national advertisers and agencies, it was announced for publication today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--The Navy disclosed today the working principles of an emergency device designed to shoot the pilot of a high-altitude jet fighter clear of his aircraft and then float him earthward snugly seated in a parachute-suspended capsule.
Chuck Rayner chalked up another shut-out last night as the New York Rangers defeated the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden. The Blue Shirts set down the invaders, 3 to 0.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 22 --County Judges Elbert T. Gallagher of Westchester and Robert E. Doscher of Rockland were far in the lead today for two new positions of Supreme Court justice in the Ninth Judicial District, which embraces also the Counties of Putnam, Dutchess and Orange.

GENEVA, Feb. 22--Europe's annual worry about what Congress will do the the Marshall Plan is aggravated this year by worry about what the Economic Cooperation Adminiatiation itself, is going to do when and if the plan gets a new lease on life.

In protest against the making of the hydrogen bomb, a mass meeting will be held in the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, tomorrow at 8:30 P. M., it was announced yesterday. LONDON, Feb. 22 (UP)--The Moscow radio said tonight that Winston Churchill's proposal for a Big-Three parley was "a confession of the bankruptcy" of the United States-British peace-time partnership, first urged by Mr. Churchill himself four years ago at Fulton, Mo.

BERLIN, Feb. 22--Georg Dertinger, Foreign Minister of the Eastern German Democratic Republic, attacked today the Feb.6 Stuttgart speech of John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner. In a declaration of foreign policy, Herr Dertinger said Mr. McCloy in his speech "expressly proclaimed the right of the United States to interfere in the politicalproblems of Germany."

Special reports and coverage of the British elections today have been scheduled by radio and television networks and stationa. Most will present hourly news bulletins, beginning early this evening as the votes are tabulated.

All they hear is the grotesque story that the American Minister, the quietmannered and prudent Donald Heath, was deep in a plot with the former Prime Minister, a dyed-in-the-wool Communist executed by his successor.

Samuel Seabury, celebrating 'his seventy-seventh birthday at his home at 840 Park Avenue, told yesterday how he had insisted upon the designation of the late Fiorello H. La Guardia for the RepublicanFusion nomination for Mayor in 1933. He expressed the opinion that New York City was still benefiting from twelve years of honest municipal administration by Mr. La Guardia.

An Ash Wednesday observed yesterday in the shadow of destructive nuclear weapons lent special significance to the day's theme of penitence and to its traditional message: "Remember, man, that thou art dust and unto dust thou shaft return."

LONDON, Feb. 22--Dr. Edith Summerskill, who is now Deputy Minister of Food, has a three-way fight on her heads. She has a Liberal and a Conservative against her. But her real opponent is snoek.

Net income of Marshall Field Co. last year was 22.9 per cent below the 1948 figure, as a result of reduced sales and the lower rate of gross profit in retail stores, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Hughston M. McBain, chairman, and James L. Palmer, president.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Feb. 22 (UP) --The Southeast's first powerful atom smasher, a mighty 86-inch cyclotron, will be ready for use at the National Laboratory here about May 1, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22 -- Grim prospects for future EastWest Cooperation in the control of atomic energy were foreseen today by Frederick H. Osborn,who recently resigned as Deputy United States Representative on the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission.
Winners of the 1949 play competition conducted by the Arts of the Theatre Foundation, Inc., are to be named in sixty days, Edward F. Kook, president of the foundation, announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 22--It is not enough for therapists to understand human behavior--they must also accept responsibility in applying their knowledge to solving contemporary social problems, Marian McBee, president of the American Orthopsychiatric Association, declared today.

With Carl Braun accounting for a new National Basketball Association record for foul-attempts, 26, the New York Knickerbockers conquered the Washington Capitols, 89--81, in a roughly waged contest before 1,000 fans at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. Braun, caging eighteen of his free-tries, netted 38 points, high for the Knicks this season.

As the list of deaths resulting from last Friday night's Long Island Rail Road wreck rose yesterday from twenty-nine to thirty, the line announced that trains operating on the 1,900-foot stretch of "gantlet" track involved at Rockville Centre would be protected from today on by manual "trippers" for stopping trains in emergency.
This city now has abopt 400,000 unemployed workers, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard said yesterday in a report to Mayor O'Dwyer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--Paul G. Hoffmnan, Economic Cooperation Administrator, warned the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today against tieing any new strings to European recovery funds. He said the surest way of defeating economic integration in Western Europe was to use "shotgun methods" in trying to bring it about.

High in fashion favor for spring are topper jackets. They go to all lengths to please. Details typical of this season appear frequently-- the push-up or flaring three-quarter length sleeve, the bloused back, the capelet fold, or emphasis on one of the many collar variations. Longer lengths are indicated as the incoming fashion but briefer styles continue as a strong favorite.

The informal "Hi, teacher!" greeting of the American high school student was the most amazing facet of our educational system to twenty-five students from Asiatic countries, visiting this country for a ten-week stay.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 22--A proposal for a new ArgentineUnited States trade agreement has come to the fore during protracted discussions among Edward G. Miller Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, and President Juan Peron and the Argentine's major aides.
Failing to get definite commitmeats for fall goods from manufacturers of women's apparel, woolen and worsted mills are unable to schedule production for early delivery in volume.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Feb. 23--Civil Rights legislation to establish a permanent Fair Employment Practice Commission was brought before the House of Representatives last night, but was promptly caught in a rough-andtumble fight after having been blocked from floor consideration for nearly six years.
Beer and ale output in this area will reach an all-time high this year, Gerald A. Walsh, executive secretary of the Brewers Board of Trade, predicted yesterday.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 22-- The Rev. Dr. David de Forest Burrell of 250 East Market Street, former pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Williamsport, Pa., died today in St. Luke's Hospital, here, after a brief illness. His age was 73.
MONTREAL, Feb. 22 (AP)--Stock prices were irregular and showed a mired tone on the Montreal Stock Exchange and Curb Market today.

PARIS, Feb. 22--The recent renewal of insurgent military activity in Indo-China, plus the appearance of new tactics and heavier arms was cited in French military circles here today as telling evidence that some kind of tangible support already was reaching the rebels from Communist China.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22-- Staging a rally in the second half, Georgetown defeated Pennsylvania at the Palestra tonight, 78--73, before 2,000 fans.

Mitchell Kennerley, former publisher and president of the Anderson Galleries, Inc., art auctioneers, from 1916 until 1929, was found dead and apparently a suicide by hanging at 4:10 P. M. yesterday in his room in the Shelton Hotel, 525 Lexington Avenue.

Columbia University's Graduate School of Business has undertaken a seminar in economic mobilization planning, believed to be the first such study program ever offered by an American university, it was announced yesterday. The course will last four months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--The Senate unanimously directed its Foreign Relations Committee today to investigate a Republican charge that "at least" fifty-seven Communists were or recently had been in the State Department.

Knocked out in the tenth and final round of his "comeback" bout against Georgie Small of Brooklyn last night, Lavern Roach, Plainview (Tex.) middleweight, was carried unconscious from the ring of the St. Nicholas Arena and removed to St. Clare's Hospital suffering from a brain concussion.
WASHINGTON, Feb.22--Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, said today that President Truman was the chief obstacle to balancing the national budget.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 22-- "Gone With the Wind" was chosen as the best motion picture of the half century, Charles Chaplin as the best actor and Greta Garbo as the best actress by men and women who have worked in the film industry for more than twenty-five years, according to a poll published today by the trade paper, Daily Variety.

An extraordinarily eloquent performance of "Orpheus," with Igor Stravinsky conducting his own score, was the outstanding feature of last night's program by the New York City Ballet Company at the City Center. With George Balan

Far-reaching economic and political aid to the Far East region was proposed last night by Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican, of New York, in an address prepared for delivery before the Park Avenue Men's Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--Charging that "discriminatory" flight rules for small private airciaft at San Francisco municipal airport violate the Federal Airport Act, the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association today demanded that Federal funds be withheld from the field.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--Government aides were reported today pressing Northern coal operators for concessions to end the coal strike. However, a joint mineroperator negotiating conference recessed until 11 A. M. tomorrow on a dismal note.

An icy glaze that covered the metropolitan area last night made both driving and walking hazardous and caused numerous delays in subway schedules. Earlier a 1.6 inch snowfall mixed with sleet and rain had hampered railroad traffic and compelled the cancellation of plane flights.

Richard Aldrich and Richard Myers announced yesterday the acquisition of the rights to a new comedy entitled "The Little Glass Clock," written by Hugh Mills. If a feminine star can be obtained there will be a production this spring either in New York or in London.

This City is in the throes of a traffic nightmare "that will cost billions of dollars and ten to twenty years to dispel, H.E. Hilts, Deputy Commissioner of the United States Bureau of Public Roads said yesterday. He described the congestion in Manhattan as the worst in the country.

The cello recital of Edmund Kurtz last night in Carnegie Hall was not a wholly even performance, but was marked in the sum of it by striking distinctions of style, technical resource and authoritative interpretation.

CANBERRA., Australia, Feb. 22 (AP)--Australia's new Government gave notice today it planned legislation to outlaw the Communist party and to ban future nationalization of industry or commerce unless the voters wished it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--The Foreign Policy Association today cited the progress of Soviet development of four backward countries in Central Asia to demonstrate that President Truman's proposed Point Four program would not necessarily cost "formidable amounts" of money.

Nestled against a hill in Central Park, the long low building at Seventy-ninth Street and Transverse Avenue looks like anything but a nerve center. But that is what it is to the Fire Department, as the complicated machines and alert operators inside reveal.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22--William J. Pilat, president of the Russell W. Allen Company of New York City, told the final session of the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers today that "more than half of all men's furnishing transactions in men's stores are theoretically profitless."

ALBANY, Feb. 22--Governor Dewey approved tonight ewergency legislation giving the State Solid Fuels Administrator power to seize coal from dealers and private owners and to fix price ceilings for coal for the duration of the current crisis.

Net income of the Western Electric Company, Inc., $692,000,000 manufacturing subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, was $42,565,511 last year, or $8,282,487 less than the $50,847,998 rePorted for 1948.

BOSTON, Feb. 22--The thirtyseventh annual Eastern dog club show began its two-day run in a crowded Mechanics Building today with a list of 1,307 canine contestants and a few developments that were outside the usual order of business.

Stichman said yesterday in his annual report to Governor Dewey and the Legislature.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22--The National Association of Home Builders today decided to offer organized resistance to the proposals for direct Government loans for private housing and Federal sponsorship of shelter for middle-income families on a cooperative basis.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22-- A warning against jeopardizing security for the sake of a balanced budget in the light of the tremendous expansion of the Soviet air force was sounded today by W.Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb.22-- Following heated adverse criticism by upper classmen, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, withdrew tonight a proposal advanced by him last week that the university build an eating club to cost $150,000 to augment the facilities of the existing seventeen clubs and thereby insure a 100 per cent coverage of the sophomore class of 788 members.

Underwriting of new preferred and common stock offerings contributed the largest amount in 1949 to the $712,333 gross income of any activity of Harris, Hall Co., Inc., according to the annual report of the investment house issued by Edward B. Hall, president for publication today.
The annual report of the Home Life Insurance Company of New York released today shows an increase in most phases of its business last year over 1948.

Unless $50,000 is raised by Wednesday, the Asia Institute at 7 East Seventieth Street, said to be the only graduate school in the United States devoted exclusively to Middle East and Oriental studies, will go out of existence.
Governor Dewey again called yesterday for the repeal of wartime-imposed Federal excise taxes, which, he declared, "have their most crushing effect upon the people of New York State."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--The CIO Communications Workers of America, answering an appeal by President Truman, agreed today to a sixty-day postponement of the nation-wide telephone strike scheduled for Friday morning.

Long Island University will face Cincinnati and City College will engage Syracuse in the college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. Both contests figure to be close, with the local quintets favored.

Appointment of Dr. Luther Gulick to be executive director of the economyefficiency survey of the New York City government is a happy choice.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22-- Princeton edged out Yale, 51 to 49, at Payne Whitney Gymnasium tonight to tighten its grip on first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 22--Yugoslav officials were jubilant today over a political victory scored by Premier Marshal Tito in east Asia where Ho Chi Minh, Communist leader of the rebel Viet Nam Government, took the initiative in seeking to establish diplomatic relations with the Yugoslav Government--principal enemy of the Communist Information Bureau world.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP) --Eighteen-year-old Adrina Lebel of the Lake Placid (N.Y.) Skating Club and Raymond E. Blum of the Paterson (N.J.) Skating Club won the senior Middle Atlantic outdoor speed skating championships today .

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Feb, 23--The House of Representatives adjourned at 3:20 A. M. today after going on record in favor of a voluntary, rather than a compulsory Federal Employment Practice Act.It did not take final action, however.

The young California pianist, Ralph Pierce, made his third Town Halt appearance yesterday afternoon in an interesting program that featured Beethoven's great "Hammerklavier" sonata, opus 106, and modern works by Schoenberg and Vincent Persichetti.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feb. 22-- Asserting that the United States proposal for control of atomic energy would help all nations. President Truman today barred separate negotiations with Russia. He declared we would confine our diplomacy on atomic problems to the United Nations.
The city's reservoirs gained only 224,000,000 gallons in the twentyfour hours ended at 8 A. M. yesterday, bringing their total content to 118,396,000,000 gallons, or but 46.8 per cent of capacity.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)--A former undercover agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today that Henry A. Wallace once conferred with two wellknown Pittsburgh Communists about support for his third-party Presidential campaign.

KITZINGEN, Germany, Feb. 12 --The United States Army is turning thousands of Negro soldiers into topnotch fighting men at a base, once a German air force installation, on the outskirts of this old Bavarian city.

ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 22 (AP)-- One of the Bauer sisters and a pair of co-medalists were swept out of the international mixed foursome two-ball golf tourney today.

Merchant ships being built on Jan. 1 in the principal countries of the world numbered 870 vessels of 1,000 gross tons or more, according to the Shipbuilders Council of America. The total was 6,758,128 gross tons, of which Great Britain was responsible for 44.6 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)-- Consumer prices declined 2.3 per cent during 1949 and at the start of this year were 4 per cent below their post-war peak, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Sportsmen's Show highlights: With only a few exhibits show ing arms, shooters at the show have been crowding around the Stoeger Arms booth five deep, waiting the turn to look over some of the new offerings in shotguns and rifles.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 22 --The United States High Comsioner's Office in Germany and the Government in Washington stand "firmly" behind Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in any political crisis arising out of the Bonn Government's program to cope with Western Germany's 2,000,000 unemployed, it was learned today from an unimpeachable source.

ROME, Feb. 23--The Vatican would be more than pleased to have the United States Government accredit a permanent diplomatic envoy to the Holy See, but is not desirous of seeing another personal representative of President Truman appointed.

Trading in coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange was mixed Yesterday, but final prices were lower, with Contract S closing 5 to 20 points off from Tuesday. Trading in Contract D was thin and final levels were down 5 to 25 points. Early trading was on a slightly lower basis on scattered selling with a light turnover. Later, prices recovered on demand from local and producer interests.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23-- Stanley Kramer, independent producer for United Artists, has acquired screen lights to "The Burning Court," a 1937 English mystery novel by John Dixon Carr. Kramer paid for the property with frozen sterling, and he will offer the leading role, that'of a publishing house employe, to Kirk Douglas, who starred last year in the producer's first success, "The Champion."

BONN, Germany, Feb. 23--A bill ending denazification proceedings in the Western German Federal Republic was approved in its first reading by an overwhelming majority in the Bundestag today and was sent to committee.

One hundred fifty alumni of Columbia University's Teachers College met on Morningside Heights yesterday for the opening sessions of a two-day work conference. The meeting, the first of its kind, was planned to acquaint the graduates with current activities and future plans of the college.

New York is prepared to relinquish its control of rents and evictions to the state if the latter is "now prepared to take responsibility for an effective program," Charles G. Coster, chairman of the City Rent Commission, said yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 23-- Herman W. Steinkraus of Bridgeport, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, tonight received the "award for distinguished civic service" of the National Conference of Christians and Jews. The presentation was made at a dinner highlighting the observance of Brotherhood Week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that Russia's possession of the atomic bomb "increases the difficulties" of helping Western Europe recover economically and made American aid through the Marshall Plan all the more necessary.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 24-- Prime Minister Attlee, tired but in good spirits, arrived at Labor headquarters with Mrs. Attlee at 4:30 o'clock this morning to see how the Labor party was faring. He had come from Walthamstow, his own constituency, which had elected him to Parliament in yesterday's polling.
LONDON, Feb. 23--British electoral rules limiting the use of automobiles for taking voters to the polls to one car for each 2,500 voters made today's election a horse-and-buggy affair.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 23--The United States has successfully pushed its demands that a meeting of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund be summoned. Some officials and delegations had sought to keep the child welfare agency outside the Soviet-West dispute over Chinese recognition.

The city's eighth water holiday passed into history last night with Water Department officials noncommittal as to whether final meter readings would show greater or lesser savings in water use over the last several dry Thursdays.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--The United States will send a special mission to Southeast Asia next week to study the use of future economic assistance for combating communism in that threatened area.
