The nation's gasoline stocks last week increased 2,285,000 barrels, according to the weekly report issued yesterday of the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, they amounted to 131,647,000 barrels, a new peak, compared with 129,362,000 a week earlier and 122,533,000 a year ago.

MOSCOW, Feb. 23--The Soviet press charged today that Western "warmongers" were threatening the world with a "super-atom bomb" but expressed firm confidence in the ability of the Soviet armed forces to protect not only the Soviet Union but all "peaceloving peoples" from the threats of a new war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--Dr. Raymond Wiley Miller, consultant to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, today urged support of President Truman's Point Four program as a means of raising the status of women in the Far East.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23--After holding about unchanged in the first half of February, business in the Pittsburgh district declined appreciably last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.
HONG KONG, Feb. 23--Under a Hong Kong supreme court decision today, ninety-three planes, paid for largely by United States taxpayers, are being turned over to the Chinese Communist Government.

Referring to the bitter dispute between India, and Pakistan, Premier Nehru issued a warning in Parliament yesterday that although Indian policy is founded on peace "it may be that we shall have to employ other methods."

Directors of the North American Company yesterday authorized the management to draft promptly for the board's approval a program to merge the company into its largest subsidiary, the Union Electric Company of Missouri.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23--Receiver of Taxes W. Frank Marshall, 65 years old, was found not guilty today by the City Council on all eight charges of mismanaging the office he has held since 1943.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 23 --Sheriff Thomas F. O'Brien testified today that Dr. Herman N. Sander on the day of his arrest admitted having killed Mrs. Abbie C. Borroto with air injections "in a weak moment."

Further discussion of a ten-cent wage rise for operating employes of the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railroad and a petition by bondholders to foreclose on the road were postponed yesterday until March 1 by Federal Judge Edward A. Conger.

The Staff Officers Association of America, a newly formed, independent maritime union, has won the right to represent pursers on three major steamship lines operating from New York through elections sponsored by the National Labor Relations Board, it became known yesterday.

MADRID, Feb. 23--Spanish authorities have arrested an undisclosed number of Monarchist leaders in a move that some Spanish sources say is the beginning of an intensive drive to crush all Monarchist anti-Franco activity here. The Duchess of Valencia,
Col. Katherine A. Towle, director of women in the Marine Corps, predicted yesterday that the corps' quota of 1,000 women would be reached next year.

The exhibition of Habsburg art treasures from Vienna collections, lent by the Austrian Government, opened, with a preview for members last evening at the Metropolitan Museum. Shown first at the National Gallery in Washington,

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 23-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru accused Pakistan today of having carried on for months "anti-India and anti-Hindu" propaganda through press, platform and radio, inciting Moslem masses against Hindus in East Bengal. This agi

LONDON, Feb. 23--Although the campaign preceding yesterday's election was what Winston Churchill called "demure"--one of the quietest for twenty-five years--interest in the voting apparently rose to an extratordinary degree when the polls were opened, despite heavy February weather in many sections.

PARIS, Feb. 23--Gen., Charles E. Mast, former French Resident General of Tunisia and director of the School of High Military Studies, disclaimed today before the National Assembly's committee of inquiry all responsibility for the disclosure of a secret report on Indo-China of Lieut. Gen. Georges Revers, former chief of staff.
ASMARA, Eritrea, Feb. 23 (AP) --Fire-fighters saved a whole village today from arsonist burning in Christian-Moslem riots that have killed thity-two and mutilated many more since the outbreak Monday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 23--The way emotionally disturbed youngsters draw pictures of their families can reveal to trained observers how they feel about their parents, their brothers and sisters and themselves, Dr. Wilfred C. Hulse of the Mount Sinai Hospital Child Guidance Clinic reported today at the annual meeting of the American Orthopsychiatric Association.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23-- The defense rested today in the Harry Bridges perjury-conspiracy case and the Government's rebuttal had hardly started before the courtroom became the scene of a wrangle.

First quarter factory shipments of several major appliances to one of the country's largest appliance distributors have been reduced 50 per cent in some instances, a company executive reported yesterday.

A former Department of Hospitals inspector took the witness stand in General Sessions yesterday to admit that he had received a series of $50 bribes to approve painting jobs in city institutions that he realized were not up to specifications.

The rising tide of American music, or certain swirls and eddies of that coursing current, was strikingly in evidence at the concert that Leonard Bernstein conducted as guest leader with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. And think not that this was a negative or amphibious or somnolent occasion.

The formation of a World Organization for Brotherhood was announced yesterday by Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, which is actively engaged in aiding the new group.

Benjamin Milberg, the founder and former president of the Milstone and Hoosick Falls Undergarment Corporations, with offices at 149 Madison Avenue, and the Milbro Mills, Inc., Glens Falls, N.Y. died on Wednesday in Miami Beach, Fla., after a brief illness
The Rev. Urban Nagle, who these many years has contributed much toward furthering the activi ties and reputation of the Blackfriars Guild, is the author of the Catholic group's latest product,

"THE HUNTER,"* a first novel by Hugh Fosburgh, is so good in many respects that it probably does not matter too much that it fails in one important respect. Even so, this short, tense novel is readable and exciting. What is wrong with it, the unsatisfying final impression it creates, becomes apparent only in its closing pages. And by that time your inter

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 23--A great increase in air travel by more Americans in the next five years through the wide use of lower-fair air coach service was predicted here today by Thomas W. S. Davis of Washington, Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

LONDON, Feb. 23--The wisdom of 306 years went into the casting of three votes at Cambridge today. The contribution of Joseph Kester, 102 years of age, was that although he would not say whom he was going to vote for, he would say who he wasn't. He cast a vocal negative against Miss Frances Josephy, Liberal candidate.

The Board of Estimate cleared the way yesterday for the Department of Welfare to establish on Hart Island a shelter and rehabilitation center to accommodate up to 2,000 homeless men now adrift on the Bowery and other "skid row" sections of the city.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23--Extension of residential rent controls for another year is contemplated in an administration bill being prepared for presentation to Congress soon, Tighe E. Woods, National Housing Expediter, said here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--The United States Steel Corporation today asked the Federal Trade Commission to accept a company offer to adopt certain pricing standards and drop its pricefixing conspiracy case against the steel industry.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23--Preliminary proceedings of the Progressive party's second national convention got under way today with the usual news conference clash between party leaders and reporters on the question of Communist influence in the party, and the honesty and integrity of American newspapers.

The Israelis themselves provided $107,700,000 of the $240,800,000 invested in Israel during 1949, or about 17.9 per cent of the country's national income, the economic department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine reported yesterday in an analysis of figures from the Israeli Ministry of Finance.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 23-- Hungary demanded tonight a reduction in the United States and British diplomatic staffs here as a result of the trial of Robert A. Vogeler.

The Board of Estimate authorized yesterday a five-year extension of a lease on the City Center, 131 West Fifty-fifth Street, held by the City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., a non-profit organization which has been presenting popular-priced musical and dramatic entertainment.
ALBANY, Feb. 23--Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of six new members of the State Advisory Council of the Joint Hospital Survey and Planning Commission.

Financing totaling $5,997,000 to be secured by railroad equipment was arranged yesterday in the public market by the Central Railroad of New Jersey, the Central Railroad of Pennsylvania and the Belt Railway of Chicago. The railroads raised the money by the sale of serial equipments trust certificates as competitive bidding, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan for the distribution among the security holders of the North Continent Utilities Corporation, Chicago, all of its assets except its interest in the Great Northern Gas Company, Ltd., Saint Ste. Marie, Ont.

NORTHWAY, Alaska, Feb. 23-- Over the frozen muskeg and the swamps of the Yukon Valley and out of the icy skies of the North, Canadian and United States troops converged on this desolate air strip this morning to end the most rigorous Arctic maneuver in our peacetime history.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 23--Perhaps more clearly than any other circumstance, the visit of Edward G. Miller Jr. has shown up the fundamental nature of the press problem in Argentina--a problem that United States officials privately agree is the greatest single barrier to fully normal relations between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)-- Maritime Commissioner Raymond S. McKeough today opposed pending legislation to provide additional Federal subsidies to the American maritime industry. He said the subsidies would not result in increased ship construction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UP)-- The annual Heywood Broun award of the American Newspaper Guild, CIO, was presented tonight to Herbert Block, cartoonist of The Washington Post, and Ted Poston, reporter for The New York Post.

LONDON. Feb. 23--Twenty-five women, some pushing perambulators other's holding their children by the hand, marched from Penge to Beckenham in London's suburbs today in a silent protest against the hydrogen bomb. The women,
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--President Truman declared today that he was exceedingly hopeful that a great many Republican Senators and Representatives would be defeated this year.

Earning assets of the reporting New York City member banks rose $190,000,000 in the week ended on Tuesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday. Business loans made by the banks declined $21,000,000, however, marking the third successive weekly reduction. Repay
DETROIT, Feb. 23--Dr. Charles L. Spain, vice president emeritus of Wayne University, died today at a nursing home after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

Mrs. Muriel Erickson Johnstone of 5 Beekman Place, daughter of Mrs. Joseph J. Shutta of Little Neck, Queens, and the late Alexander Horton Erickson, was married in her home here yesterday afternoon to Frederic William Howe Jr. of Worcester, Mass., and Little Compton, R.I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Howe of Providence, R.I. The Rev. Laurance I. Neale performed the ceremony.

A coating of ice that brought death, damage, injury and inconvenience melted during a few mild hours yesterday in parts of the city and suburbs, but returned last night when temperatures fell back below freezing. Every form of transport, on land and sea and in the air, was disrupted.

A 6-year-old girl, suffering of poliomyelitis and in a portable respirator, landed yesterday after a delayed flight from London at La Guardia Airport aboard a United States Military Air Transport plane for treatment here. The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, which cooperated with the Air Force for the trip, said the patient was believed to be the first respirator case to be flown across the Atlantic.

VIENNA, Feb. 20--The Vienna State Opera, which has been vying with the Habsburg art collection in bringing Austrian culture to the notice of the world, will in all likelihood be heard in the United States in 1950-51. Dr. Egon Hilbert, ad

The Army service women, within a year, will be as smartly dressed as any civilian, thanks to the combined efforts of the best military and civilian experts and the superb designing of Hattie Carnegie.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday an appropriation of $125,000 to enable the Traffic Commission to purchase and install 1,500 parking meters in congested areas to be chosen by the commission as experimental locations.

Despite the recent storm, grocery stores are amply stocked with fresh foods for the week-end. But shoppers will note that many items are higher in price than last Friday. In its survey of retail shops,

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--Maj. Gen. Lawrence C. Jaynes, who commands the New York-New Jersey Military District, today was named special assistant to the Chief of Staff of the Army for civilian components. He will succeed Maj. Gen. Charles W. Ryder, who is retiring.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--President Truman today branded as false the charges of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Wisconsin Republican, that there are cardcarrying Communists in the State Department.

Sportsmen's Show highlights: The gadget inventors have been working overtime in recent months, and knowing that hunters and fishermen are intrigued by the complex rather than the simple, they have concentrated on articles with a high appeal potential for this group.

PARIS, Feb. 23--Activity in the metallurgical industries in the Paris area gradually came to a halt today as more and more workers walked out to support their demands for a 3,000-franc (about $8.20) cost-of-living bonus. It was estimated tonight that close to 100,000 men were on strike.

Although sales and operating revenues of the Continental Can Company, Inc., last year were 5 per cent above those of 1948, consolidated net income declined to $12,108,132 from $14,811,562, the preliminary annual statement revealed Yesterday.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 23--A broadcast sponsored by Burma's armed forces and published in full in all Rangoon newspapers this morning noted an "American intrusion in the British sphere" in Southeast Asia since events in China and Indo-China have turned the spotlight this way.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--The White House said today that President Truman would establish an emergency board to recommend terms for averting a strike of railroad trainmen and conductors.

ALBANY, Feb. 23--Governor Dewey issued an executive order tonight outlining the policy of his administration with respect to the collective bargaining rights of state employes and setting up a procedure for the resolving of grievances.

George Balanchine revived his "Prodigal Son" for the New York City Ballet, Company at the City Center last night, Jerome Robbins had the title role, and on both counts it was an occasion of first importance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 15, the Federal Receive Board reported today:

Standard Oil Company (Kentucky) which markets petroleum and allied products in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky and Mississippi, had slightly lower sales last year than in 1948 but profits increased to the largest in the company's sixty-four-year history, the annual report of W. G. Violette, president, revealed yesterday.
A distinguished collection of custom tailored coats and suits by Knize was joined by custom hand-knit fashions by Aileen Rice in a showing yesterday at Knize, 24 East Fifty-sixth Street.

Since last Monday it has been the law of the land that federal police officials may search premises and seize property without a search warrant if this action is incidental to the arrest of a person for whom a warrant has been issued. Such is the result of a decision handed down by the United

Under existing circumstances, passage of a Fair Employment Practices bill by the House yesterday represents no real victory for those who sincerely desire fair employment practices legislation. The original Administration bill has been so diluted that very little is left of it but an expression of good intentions. Thus, almost exactly five

The thrilling general election in Britain is all over except the counting, but the indications early this morning pointed clearly to a Laborite victory. Some doubts remain, however, because yesterday's results were confined largely to the urban centers where the Socialists are traditionally strong.

Bert Lahr has been signed to an exclusive three-year television contract by the Columbia Broadcasting System. He will be starred in a half-hour weekly comedy program, but no starting date has been set.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)-- Four 17-year-old high school seniors, winners of the third annual Voice of Democracy contest, received President Truman's personal congratulations today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23-- Ralph I. Straus, former official of the Macy Department Store in New York, has been appointed special assistant to Roving Ambassador W. Averell Harriman in Paris, the Economic Cooperation Administration announced today.

ALBANY, Feb. 23--Senator Charles V. Scanlan, Republican, of the Bronx, proposed in a bill introduced through the rules committee today that young women caring for well babies in institutions be licensed. The bill would not apply to baby sitters employed in private homes.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23--Perhaps as much as $600,000,000 in projected FHA-insured rental housing operations may be stymied through the impending expiration of Section 608 of the National Housing Act, according to Franklin D. Richards, Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--The deadlocked coal-wage contract conferences adjourned until 2:30 P.M. tomorrow after fruitless discussion all day today.

LONDON, Feb. 23--It took Mrs. William Dean just twenty-five minutes today to go to record her vote of confidence in the Labor Government that has provided for her family and ruled Britain for the last four and a half years.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady 1 point lower to 8 points higher yesterday. Trading was fairly active.

The principle of paying for water on the basis of the amount of water used is so just that it seems needless to argue the point. That is the principle involved in the extension of metering to multiple dwellings, and we are happy to learn that the city administration has at last revived a plan to do this.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 23--Greentree Stable's Flamingo Stakes nominee, Androcles, won a $4,000 purse at Hialeah today, but he didn't boost his stock much for next week's $50,000 run.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--By a vote of 240 to 177, the House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to establish a "voluntary" fair employment practice system, rather than one of compulsion such as the Roosevelt and Truman Administrations had pressed for nearly six years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)-- A Government engineer testified today it would cost $500,000 to build a landing place for helicopters on the roof of New York's General Post Office.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23--General buying developed in all grains on the Board of Trade here today, with a heavy trade in soybeans which were up as much as 4 cents a bushel at one time, the March position leading and going to a new high here since last August. Closing trades were up 1 to 3 5/8 cents.

John Foster Dulles, who last year was Republican candidate for Senator from New York, has signed a contract with Macmillan for the publication in April of his book, "Peace or War." He discusses the peace policies that have emerged from post-war conferences and actions, the present foreign policies and the need of programs and techniques to prolong peace.

MONTREAL, Feb. 23 (Canadian Press)--Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, outlined today the World Bank's contributions to economic stability in many countries.

The Board of Education approved yesterday the Mitchell-Schupler bill that would permit the appointment of qualified "outsiders" to top supervisory positions in the public school system's Bureau of Attendance.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 23-- Henry Green Duffield, for twentynine years treasurer of Princeton University until his retirement in 1930, died here early this morning at his home. He was 90 years old.

The American Export liners' Independence and Constitution, now under construction at the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyard at Quincy, Mass., will be ready for service between New York and the Mediterranean early next year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--Harold Christoffel, former Milwaukee labor leader, was convicted late today on charges he lied under oath in telling a Congressional committee that he had never been a Communist.

Directors of the American Locomotive Company reduced the dividend on the common stock with the declaration yesterday of 25 cents a share, payable April 1. Shareholders had received 35 cents quartarly for several years.

All the finesse of detail--the draping of beautiful decolletages and the hanging of graceful skirts --that are such familiar signatures of Fira Benenson's designs were woven into her spring collection shown yesterday at Lord Taylor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23-- Captain John G. Crommelin, the Navy officer who is under orders to refrain from public statements critical of the Department of Defense, kept a speaking engagement today at noon before the San Francisco Business League.

Madison Square Garden, the house of upsets, was the site of two more reversals last night, as L.I.U. and C.C.N.Y., absorbing their heaviest setbacks of the campaign, bowed to Cincinnati and Syracuse. Each visiting quintet amassed 83-points, while Long Island was held to 65 by the Bearcats and City College to 74 by the Orange.

Lavern Roach, middleweight boxer from Plainview, Tex., died yesterday at St. Clare's Hospital. He had been knocked out in the final round of his ten-round bout with Georgie Small of Brooklyn at St. Nicholas Arena Wednesday night on his twenty-fourth birthday anniversary.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 24--The British Communists, who won two seats in Parliament in 1945 while the grand alliance with the Soviet Union still was in operation and then polled 102,780 votes in a total of 25,018,393, took a severe drubbing in yesterday's general election.

ALBANY, Feb, 23--The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that the 1945 law under which the State Liquor Authority promulgated fair trade regulations for the retail liquor industry was unconstitutional. There was no opinion in the case.

James H. Sheils, investigation commissioner, announced last night that his department would widen the scope of its inquiry into the price of bread here. He said his assistants already had questioned officials of five major baking companies and now his staff would check on the prices charged by the independent bakeries.
Mass layoffs and payless "holidays" for thousands of steel and automobile workers were reported yesterday as industrial coal piles neared exhaustion.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 24--On the basis of 42 per cent of the total vote cast in Britain's general election yesterday it looked this morning as if Labor would be returned to power with a majority of between fifty and seventy seats in the new House of Commons.

The seventy-five-family garden suite development at 3461 Wilson Avenue, corner of Boston Post Road, the Bronx, known as Wilson Post Apartments, has been sold by Wilson Post Apartments, Inc., to an investing client of the Fred

Cutting tool salesmen are notifying purchasing agents in industry that prices are to be advanced 10 per cent on April 1. Martin Fee, vice president of Avildsen Tools and Machines, Inc., New York and Chicago, cutting tool maker, yesterday confirmed reports that

Richard O'Connor of 366 West Olive Street, Long Beach, L.I., a retired inspector of the New York Police Department, died Wednesday in St. Anthony's Hospital, St. Petersburg, Fla., according to word received here yesterday. His age was 77.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday an initial appropriation of $100,000 for Mayor O'Dwyer's Committee on Management Survey, which is to study the city government in the interest of effi-- ciency and economy.

Paddy young and Tuzo Portuguez will engage in a return bout at Madison Square Garden to night. The pair met for the first time on Jan. 13 with Portuguez, a native of Costa Rica, defeating his Greenwich Village rival by a knockout in eight rounds.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 23--All advertising and selling forces "must be massed and committed to accomplish the consumption necessary to sustain the mass production to which our dynamic economy is geared," Donald Hobart, director of research for Curtis Publications, Philadelphia, said here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--Critically short of two things--money and enough deep water harbor space--the Navy finds itself unable to do anything about dispersing to less vulnerable areas the 1,972 ships of the Reserve Fleet now jammed in crowded harbors.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 23--At the shell-riddled frontier post of El Auja in Palestine, soldiers, of two countries officially at war-- Egypt and Israel--will end tomorrow a year of working together, eating and living together and going out on patrol together to keep the peace.

Mrs. Hardwick Nevin of 8 East Sixty-second Street, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Adrienne Lord, to Folke Bengt Lidbeck, son of Mrs. Robert Lidbeck of Gothenburg, Sweden, and the late Mr. Lidbeck.
A new process for obtaining pulp for papermaking from hardwood trees was announced yesterday by two professors of the New York State College of Forestry.

"Alive and Kicking" and "The Enchanted," which, by coincidence, opened within a night of each other, are quitting tomorrow night. Only forty-six performances span the engagement of the former at the Winter Garden, while the latter will have been seen forty-five times at the Lyceum.

The role of a plaintiff was reversed suddenly yesterday in the First District Municipal Court, Williamsbridge Road, the Bronx, when LeRoy C. Taylor, real estate operator who appeared as a complainant on a rent charge, was removed from that court on a charge of grand larceny.

The city and the New York City Omnibus Corporation agreed yesterday to go before the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court next week to seek a ruling on the company's right to charge an 8-cent fare on its twenty-one Manhattan bus lines without the consent of the Board of Estimate.
Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, stated flatly yesterday: "Princeton does not countenance subsidization of athletes, private or otherwise."

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 23--India invade the charge today before the United Nations Economic and Social Council that the United States had demonstrated inability or unwillingness to cope with the responsibility arising from its premier position in world economy.
CAPE MAY, N.J., Feb. 23-- William Bradford, former official of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania, died today in his home here at the age of 60.
LONDON, Friday, Feb. 24-- There was a New Year's Eve atmosphere in London last night as people gathered in large groups and small to await election results.

FORT MONROE, Va., Feb. 23 (AP)--First Lieut. Glenn Davis, one of the greatest gridiron stars in West Point history, said tonight the Army had accepted his resignation and he would join the professional Los Angeles Rams for the 1950 season.

Benefits from pensions will be great if the purchasing power of the dollar remains stable but a continued decline in such purchasing power will not only create a demand for increased pensions but could also arouse considerable political unrest among those affected.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 23 (AP) --Willy Gerber, 47, a Swiss Army mechanic who at one time had $10,000 in a New York bank, pleaded guilty today to being a wartime spy for the United States and to serving France and Britain for a longer period.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 24-- Among Labor party casualties in yesterday's election were four former women members of Parliament. Conservative women had gained two new seats and lost one, according to results available at 4 A. M.

The role of a plaintiff was reversed suddenly yesterday in the First District Municipal Court, Williamsbridge Road, the Bronx, when LeRoy C. Taylor, real estate operator who appeared as a complainant on a rent charge, was removed from that court on a charge of grand larceny.

The city and the New York City Omnibus Corporation agreed yesterday to go before the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court next week to seek a ruling on the company's right to charge an 8-cent fare on its twenty-one Manhattan bus lines without the consent of the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland, called on the United States today to repudiate any international control of atomic-hydrogen weapons that was not accompanied by disarmament in ordinary weapons.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 23-- The women's team of McGill University won the downhill race, opening event of the nineteenth annual Middlebury College Winter Carnival today, against the challenge of eight other teams at the Snow Bowl.

Britain's Labor party appeared to have won yesterday's Parliamentary elections by a majority of 50 to 70 seats on the basis of the tabulation of more than twofifths of the voting districts. Figures released early today showed Labor had won 163 seats, the Conservatives 102 and the Liberals 1, [1:8.]

ALBANY, Feb. 23--Henry Root Stern, chairman of the State Board of Social Welfare, today coupled a spirited defense of recent cuts in food grants to New York City relief recipients with an attack on political "scavengers" who seek votes from the destitute and social workers who want to make belief a "socially acceptable" way of life.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--The Truman Administration was not concerned tonight about who would win the British Election, but was hoping that one of the parties would win it with a sufficient margin to govern effectively.
ATLANTIC CITY, FEB. 23-- Officials of the leading educational organizations took the first cooperative step today to get better-prepared teachers for the nation's 30,000,000 school children.

Discord among the New Friends of Music was disclosed yesterday in a suit filed in Supreme Court by Hortense Monath, concert pianist, who is seeking to impound the organization's funds. Justice Felix C. Benvenga set 10 o'clock this morning for the hearing on a motion for a temporary injunction.

DETROIT, Feb. 23--The Henry Ford Hospital disclosed today receipt of a gift of $13,600,000 from the Ford Foundation to build and equip a seventeen-story addition to the present clinic, already regarded in medical circles as one of the most complete in the nation.

Steps to obtain audited or otherwise certified figures on the circulation of foreign newspapers, together with a breakdown of their readership, and for more accurate and complete data on radio station coverage in foreign markets were urged yesterday by representatives

The tax burden of the private motorist and general taxpayer should be lightened, while fees for the heaviest types of trucks should be increased to help solve the state's highway finance problem, a civic organization told a joint legislative committee yesterday.
BURBANK, Calif., Feb. 23-- Navy acceptance of a plane specifically designed to hunt down the formerly radar-uroof "Snorkel" submarines was announced today by Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 24-- With Labor apparently returning to Westminster with a working majority, the hope of the once great Liberal party to play a decisive role in the new Parliament appears forlorn.
Black keeps popping up as an important decorating color these days. Now it may be seen in new dinnerware patterns introduced by Macy's for its spring china and glass show, which opens next Monday.

A drastic curb on Federal "meddling" in state road construction programs was demanded yesterday at the closing session of the annual convention of the Association of Highway Officials of "the North Atlantic States at the Statler Hotel.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 23 (AP)-- Two of the nation's top industrialists joined tonight in a plea for continuance of the free enterprise system.

Long Island Rail Road trains must slow to fifteen miles an hour within 600 feet of the Rockville Centre gantlet track where thirty persons suffered mortal injuries last Friday night, according to an order issued yesterday by the Public Service Commission. Previously the maximum was thirty miles.

GENEVA, Feb. 23--The Czechoslovak delegate, Otto Benes, protested the seating of an observer from Western Germany today among the contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, but remained in the meeting when admission of the German observer was approved.

Edward T. O'Loughlin of 345 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, veteran politician and Hearst editor, who had held many city posts, died last night at the Suffern (N.Y.) Hospital, where he had been taken earlier in the day from his country place at Tompkins Cove, N.Y. His age was 72.

The New Music Quartet and Julius Baker, flutist, were the performers in Town Hall last night. They appeared in a "Debut and Encore" concert, but both were not only familiar to concert audiences but of the highest professional caliber.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 24--Two United States Mormon missionaries who had been held in prison at Olomouc since Jan. 28 were released and expelled from the country by the Czechoslovak police today.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 24--The six tanker construction program of the Olympic Oil Lines drew near its close this afternoon as the Olympic Thunder, final unit of the group, went down the ways at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Sparrows Point shipyard here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24--Butler Brothers, Chicago merchandise company, last year had a net loss of $644,330 compared with net profit of $923,027, or 43 cents a common share, in 1948, the annual report to shareholders disclosed today. Net sales decreased to $122,301,652 from $153,428,422.

By the end of 1949 the Atomic Energy Commission had shipped from Oak Ridge 8,912 lots of radioactive and 958 lots of stable isotopes. The recipients were research laboratories in most of the states of the Union and in twentyseven foreign countries.

Strikes in the coal and steel industries last year cost the Pennsylvania Railroad about $45,000,000, Walter S. Franklin, president, reveals in the road's 103d annual report, issued for publication today.

Another concert representing a variety of tendencies in contemporary American music was offered at Times Hall last night by the National Association for American Composers and Conductors.

LONDON, Feb. 26--Britain's political parties will have to make difficult and fateful decisions this week to meet the situation caused by the fact that as a result of last Thursday's election the Government now in office has the smallest Parliamentary majority for more than a hundred years.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26--Grain markets were on the upgrade on the Board of Trade last week, with March and December wheat selling at a new seasonal peak. Despite the bearish sentiment that has prevailed of late, all deliveries of wheat except March sold at a new high since mid-December, and corn went into new ground since midJanuary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) --Senator Burnet R. Maybank, Democrat, of South Carolina, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said today the question whether Federal rent controls would be extended beyond next June 30 still was wide open.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26-- The loyalty oath decreed by the Regents of the University of California appeared headed today for a court test.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 26--Marshal Tito spurned today any alliance with pre-war Yugoslav leaders in the present difficulties facing this country, and in an implied warning to the West he said these politicians would never succeed in staging a comeback regardless of whose support they might have.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)--A stand-by peacetime draft bill which would require a separate act of Congress before men could be inducted is to be introduced tomorrow by Representative Carl Vinson, chairman of the Armed Services Committee. He predicted House approval in late March or April.

Handy for reference on a favorite food is a forty-page illustrated booklet just issued by the National Live Stock and Meat Board, "Meat Recipes and Menus." Michigan State has come, seen and conquered--if the hairsbreadth triumph of the heavily favored Spartans over Seton Hall, Manhattan, Yale and Army last Saturday night merits description as a conquest--for the second and last time in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor track and field championships.

Sentiment in the furniture manufacturing industry continues optimistic as the first month of 1950 witnessed an accentuation of the industry's uptrend which began late last summer and which has gained momentum ever since, according to a report by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants, released over the week-end.

The first of the twelve seeded players in the men's singles division of the Eastern indoor tennis championships was eliminated yesterday when Herb Lewis, vicepresident of the Eastern Umpires Tennis Association, seeded eighth, was beaten by Pablo Eisenberg of Millburn, N.J., in a fourth-round test at the Kingsbridge Armory. The score was 3--6, 6--2, 6--1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)-- The American Veterans Committee called on the Government tonight to put into effect quickly those recommendations of the Commission on the Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government affecting veterans. Herbert Hoover is head of the commission.
STRATHAVEN, Scotland, Feb. 28--Sir Harry Lauder, worldfamed Scottish comedian, died tonight at his home in Lanarkshire after long months of illness. He was 79 years old.

The United Nations Security Council will return this week to the one outstanding item of business on its agenda, the case of Kashmir. Before the Council is a four-Power proposal that the Kashmir Commission be dissolved, on the ground that it can be of no further service.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 26--Guatemala offered a musical snub to the United States last night, and the official newspaper Diario de la Manana hinted today that it was a deliberate token of this country's "anti-colonial" policy.

PANAMA, Feb. 24--Dr. Eduardo Santos, former Liberal President of Colombia, has written a letter to Conservative President Mariano Ospina Perez complaining of the present state of siege under which constitutional guarantees have been suspended in Colombia for more than three months.

The new motorship Winnipeg is due at Los Angeles Wednesday from Antwerp, it was announced yesterday in San Francisco by the General Steamship Corporation, Ltd. Her arrival will mark the return of the French Line fleet to its full post-war strength in the North Pacific-Europe trade route.

Development of scientific weapons capable of destroying the world stresses the need for a world federation, Dr. Floyd R. Banks, research physicist, asserted yesterday morning at St. Mark's Methodist Church, Edgecombe Avenue and 137th Street.

Helen Airoff, violinist, gave a recital in Town Hall last night. With net gains of 10 to 55 points for last week, futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange again moved into new high ground for the season. The distant deliveries showed the greatest strength.

The successful treatment on an out-patient basis of several emotionally disturbed children diagnosed as schizophrenic has been reported by Dr. Abraham A. Fabian, psychiatric director of the Brooklyn Juvenile Guidance Center.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee that recently returned from an inspection tour of Europe urged today the setting up immediately of a commission to study how the United States can aid European countries after the Marshall Plan ends in 1952.

The talk of the town today, where fashions are concerned, is the tissue-weight fabric--paperthin taffeta, silk organdy, cotton voile, tissue gingham, sheer nylon, and faille, all ideally adapted to summer wear and weather.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 26--The ring-wise golden brindle boxer, Champion Mazelaine's Zazarac Brandy, thwarted in his efforts here a year ago, climbed to the top in the twenty-fifth anniversary show of the Kennel Club of Buffalo tonight.

With 209,599 of its total of 234,540 companies owner-operated or having fewer than twenty employes, New York City continues to maintain its supremacy as the largest center of small business in the world.

J.R. Elyachar, president of the Straight Construction Company and builder of "motels" in various cities throughout the country has purchased for investment the apartment building occupying the blockfront on the west side of Madison Avenue, from East Eightysecond to Eighty-third Streets.
STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 26-- Matthew H. Kenealy, chairman of the City Board of Finance and a leading Stamford attorney, died in St. Joseph's Hospital today. He would have been 66 in September.
Methods of trapping leopards on the loose and information on the behavior of oversized members of the cat family in zoos were being sought yesterday from experts trapped behind telephones.

The Rev. Dr. John Ellis Large of Wilmington, Del., has accepted a call to the rectorship of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, it was announced yesterday by Clarence G. Michalis, senior warden.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)--A World Monetary Fund report hinted tonight that many countries were in for further inflation.
It is to be regretted that New York City's business concerns and employe groups last year gave only $5,186,179 of the $8,000,000 set as the goal of the Greater New York Fund's 1949 campaign.

LONDON, Feb. 26--A young man whose victory over physical infirmity has earned him admiration in both Britain and the United States gained his first political victory in last weeks general election. He is Richard Wood, 30-yearold son of the Earl of Halifax, who has become the Conservative Member of Parliament for Bridlington, Yorkshire.

The New York Telephone Company, largest operating unit in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company system, reported yesterday that gross income in 1949 set a record of $441,479,740. Rising costs, however, cut net income of this billion-and-a-half-dollar communications company to $28,802,685, or $1,427,729 less than the $30,230,414 reported for 1948.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26--An uneasy truce between Communists and non-Communists marked the end today of the Progressive party's second national convention, leaving in doubt whether the meeting had accomplished Henry A. Wallace's principal aim of ridding the group of its Red label.
PARIS, Feb. 26--Further declines in stock prices were noted on the Paris Bourse last week. The price index for French metropolitan stocks on Feb. 24 stood at 981 on the basis of 100 for 1938.

Fuel economy improvements are achieving record gains in America's leading industrial plants and many large projects now being approved mark the end of a cycle of obsolescence in a wide range of power plant equipment installations in the New York area, it was learned last week.

LONDON, Feb. 26--When the markets reassemble tomorrow they will be faced with the task of attempting to assess the implications and consequences of what amounts to a virtual stalemate in the general election.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 27 (AP)-- Ali Asghar Hekmat, Iranian Minister of State, told a news conference today after his return from an inspection of Azerbaijan province, bordering on the Soviet Union, that he had turned sixty highranking officials out of office and that they would be tried on charges of corruption and cruelty.
The United States Steel Corporation, colossus of the steel industry, cut production in its giant mills near Pittsburgh almost in half yesterday to conserve coal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat-Liberal, of New York, urged this Government today to try to get the British to stop sending arms to the Arab nations pending a United Nations investigation of "the entire arms situation in the Middle East."

Things are humming at Jay Thorpe's. There is plenty that is new in the specialty shop on West Fifty-seventh Street, whose name has long stood for smart fashion. Yesterday a new fourth floor of fashions was opened, with collections by two designers.
A faster pace and heated clashes between Judge Sylvester Ryan and defense counsel marked the resumption yesterday of the CoplonGubitchev spy trial in Federal Court.
ALBANY, Feb. 27--The Assembly passed unanimously tonight a Republican bill that would repeal the blanket right given women to decline jury duty when they are called. The bill now goes to the Senate.

The second of four concerts presented by the League of Composers in cooperation with publishing firms of this city was given at Carl Fisher Hall last night, with Associated Music Publishers the cosponsor on this occasion.

Establishment of a central complaint bureau in each borough to speed up the removal of the "quarter of a millon" violations in city housing is advocated in a program for housing law enforcement announced last night by the Citizens Housing and Planning Council.

More than 350,000 civilian volunteers have swung into action to rid Malaya of its bandit infestation. For several weeks the Government has been recruiting persons from all walks of life to take over essential public services and thus release men for police duty against the bandits.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--Senate subpoenas will be issued for State Department loyalty files if the Administration refuses to hand them over.

A corpulent peddler, who declaimed at length on the constitutional rights of an unlicensed itinerant to market his wares, was put behind bars for forty days by Magistrate Charles F. Murphy in Mid-Manhattan Magistrates Court yesterday.
Combined assets of all 131 savings banks in this state at the end of last year totaled $12,327,020,529, against $11,485,738,488 at the close of 1948, an increase of $841,000,000,

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27--A good balance between "business prudence and paralyzing fear" was recommended to business today by Dr. Edwin C. Nourse, former chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
MEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 27-- James P. Henigan, noted marathon runner, died today at the Veterans' Hospital, Chesterfield, S.C., according to word received at his home here. His age was 57.

The Dodgers' spring training party rolled out of Penn Station at 1:10 yesterday afternoon under the chaperonage of Secretary Harold Parrott and the boys were hoping there was something symbolic in the fact that they were ahead of the Yankees.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, and Dr. Dirk U. Stikker, Foreign Minister of The Netherlands, got down to plain speaking tonight on the subject of European economic integration.

ALBANY, Feb. 27--Convinced that they are facing a hard fight to retain control of the state, Republican county chairmen, meeting here today, decided to get the campaign under way immediately and to strengthen their local organizations.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27--Charges that Solicitor General Philip B. Perlman of the Justice Department had violated two of the legal profession's canons of ethics were presented today to the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association, with a request for an investigation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The Senate, by a vote of 53 to 24, passed the cotton acreage bill today, with a rider which would clamp strict marketing quotas on that spectacularly surplus crop, potatoes, in 1951 "and thereafter." The rider is designed to curb surpluses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--There was a stag dinner party tonight in honor of Sean Nunan, the retiring Minister of Eire, and certain recent developments suffused the occasion with an unusual degree of the wit and sentiment that always prevail when those of Irish stock foregather.
Sixty brilliant examples of Persian manuscript books, showing the art of illumination and calligraphy as it developed through the centuries will be shown today by the New York Public Library.

The vacant plot of land at the northeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and Fifty-second Street has been purchased for investment by Milton C. Rose, attorney, acting as trustee, from Robert Benenson and others.

Miss Simone M. Smith heads the debutante committee for the annual Bal des Berceaux under the auspices of the Committee of French-American Wives, to be held on the night of March 24 in the St. Regis Roof.
The American Woolen Company will open its fall 1950 women's wear line today with prices unchanged on all worsted numbers, it was announced yesterday by Charles Silver, vice president.

The Juilliard String Quartet conclude its series of four concerts in Times Hall last night. The cycle encompassed the four quartets of Arnold Schoenberg as well as individual works by Haydn, Mozart, Schubert and Beethoven.

LONDON, Feb. 27--Prime Minister Attlee went to Buckingham Palace tonight to see the King. Presumably he went to present the Cabinet with which he will face Parliament a week from today with a lead over all parties that has now dwindled to seven.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Feb. 27 (AP)-- Villanova College cannot comply with the National Collegiate Athletic Association's sanity code in its present form, Rev. Father Francis X.N. McGuire, O.S.A., president of the school, said today.

Mrs. Ellen Knauff, wife of an American veteran, faces deportation to Germany today upon the order of former Attorney General Tom C. Clark, who had reported that secret evidence indicated she was undesirable.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 27 --In urging greatly increased appropriations for the Swedish Navy, Admiral Helge Stromback, chief of the naval staff, in a speech tonight

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 27--The Argentine Congressional committee investigating the nation's press demanded last night that the two independent dailies Nacion and Prensa prepare additional data on what they had published.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27--The Junto, a nonprofit Philadelphia school for adults, plans no changes in the "immediate foreseeable future as regards leases and relations with tenants" of some 4,000 dwellings in Long Island's new Levittown development, it was learned today.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27--Four candidates for Friday's $50,000 Flamingo Stakes were among the eight 3-year-olds in today's top race at Hialeah.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP)-- The Congress of Industrial Organizations backed an expanded social security program today that would provide "adequate" old-age pensions for all and not just for its own members.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 27--Premier Marshal Tito today congratulated Frederick C. White, director of the American Joint Distribution Committee in Yugoslavia, on the successful completion of the committee's program rehabilitating Jewish war victims and in assisting them to emigrate to Israel.
Alfred de Liagre Jr. is considering a new script called "Facade," written by Michael Linenthal, as a prospect for next season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)-- Eighteen Senators who favor more liberal rules for admitting Europe's homeless to the United States offered a substitute today for the displaced-persons legislation recommended last month by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Three large package stores were caught cutting liquor prices by their suppliers here yesterday according to the distillers involved. In each case legal action was taken immediately, according to company officials.

The accounting machines division of National Cash Register Company expects this year to exceed the 1949 sales volume of $21,000,000 by at least 10 per cent, James J. Breen, divisional metropolitan area manager, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The United Mine Workers of America pleaded not guilty today as the union went on trial charged with civil and criminal contempt in the failure of its members to obey a back-to-work court order. Union counsel contended that the miners were acting as individuals.
Judge Harold M. Kennedy in Federal Court, Brooklyn, extended yesterday for another six months the period in which the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road must file its plan of reorganization.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 27--Unless the mistaken ideas that Americans have about atomic energy are corrected, our democratic freedoms may be endangered, David
Advisory policy forms under the Disability Benefits Law were released yesterday by the New York State Insurance Department.

BERLIN, Feb. 27--The steady encroachment of the principles of dialetical materialism on the educational system constitutes the greatest worry of Evangelical congregations in the Soviet zone of Germany, Dr. Otto Dibelius, Protestant Bishop of Berlin, said today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 27--The United Nations heard evidence today accusing the Soviet Union of basing its whole economy on chained manpower, with millions of workers providing cheap, enslaved labor in construction, mining, uranium extraction and other vital activities.

Eight bishops and 1,123 other clergymen of the Protestant Episcopal Church rallied yesterday to the defense of the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, ousted rector of the Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn.

Legislation should be enacted permitting rain-making under certain specified conditions if New York or other localities attempting artificially induced precipitation experiments are to be protected from costly damage suits, according to Albert P. Blaustein, member of the New York bar.

ALBANY, Tuesday, Feb. 28-- The Assembly defeated early today a Democratic move to take up for consideration a party-program bill authorizing a state bond issue of $200,000,000 for additional state aid for school construction and rehabilitation.
Mrs. Patricia Havens-Monteagle Smart of 104 East Sixty-fifth Street, daughter of Mrs. Estelle Havens-Monteagle of Pebble Beach,
THREE years ago a very young man won for himself considerable critical admiration and a lot of notoriety with a sensational novel.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was irregular yesterday and closed 14 points lower to 15 points higher.
The District Attorney office's inquiry into the boxing death of Lavern Roach, 24-year-old Texan, was brought to a conclusion yesterday.
Out of the wreckage of one of the poorest basketball seasons in New York University history, Howard Cann's Violets salvaged the big one last night at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The United States, Great Britain and Canada will review all aspects of heir security arrangements before entering into any new agreement on the exchange of atomic weapons and atomic energy information.
Of particular note in the Oldric Royce custom collection shown yesterday at this salon at 16 East Fifty-second Street were several excellent tailleurs.

An issue of $23,000,000 of bonds of the Elizabeth River Tunnel District of Virginia will be placed on the market today by an investment banking, syndicate headed by Alex Brown Sons and B.J. Van Ingen Co.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The House tentatively approved today a bill establishing a National Science Foundation to promote basic scientific research and study in this country.

The first demonstration in the United States of the use of Jet Assisted Take-off (JATO) equipment on a commercial passenger airliner will be conducted Sunday at Love Field, Dallas, by Braniff International Airways.
Dean Millicent C. McIntosh of Barnard College yesterday agreed to submit to a student poll a proposal to raise tuition fees.

The Western Union Telegraph Company's operations last year resulted in a loss of $3,363,406, it was announced yesterday. In 1948 the loss of $4,287,193 was almost entirely offset by the sale of real estate amounting to $4,115,572.

George Gillette, brother-in-law of Joe Adonis, the underworld figure, was convicted yesterday by a Federal jury on three counts of an indictment charging him with participation in a ring that counterfeited American Express Company travelers' checks.

Gwilym A. Price, president of the $694,000,000 Westinghouse Electric Corporation, assailed yesterday the Federal tax policy with the charge that it was "throttling the incentive to invest in American industry."
The physicists do not agree as to how long it will take to make a hydrogenbomb or how much harm the bomb can do after it is made.

The House of Representatives received yesterday a bill which is designed to take the place of the Selective Service Act when that law expires a few months hence. The new bill would continue the present system of registration and classification.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 27--United States High Commissioner John J. McCloy has ordered his staff to refrain from publicly criticizing activities and policies of the West German Government without first clearing it with him, it became known today.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 27 --An eye-witness of Mrs. Abbie C. Borroto's death told the jury in the "mercy killing" trial today that the patient was still "gasping" when Dr. Hermann N. Sander injected air into her veins.

Net earnings of $54,852,364 for 1949 reported yesterday by the United Fruit Company were the second largest in its fifty-year history. Equal to $6.25 a share on 8,775,000 shares outstanding, they compare with the 1948 peak earnings of $59,740,232, or $6.81 a share.
Further brakes were applied yesterday to the stock market by the continued impasse in the coal contract negotiations.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 27--Although there has been no change in United States policy toward Yugoslavia, a series of misconceptions that has arisen in the mind of the Belgrade Government has unquestionably led to a new...

Bernard Greenhouse, who played at Town Hall last night, is a 'cellist of quiet and impressive sincerity. He does not knock you eye out with virtuosity, but leaves you with a satisfying musical experience.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27--The World of 1950 is "far from attaining freedom from fear," William McChesney Martin Jr., Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, declared today before 1,000 delegates to the Chicago World Trade Conference.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 27-- The idea of Western Europe establishing itself as a neutral zone in the struggle between the United States and the Soviet Union, as recently advanced by some French newspapers, has been rejected almost without reservation in the Benelux area of the Continent.

A treaty between the United States and Canada relating to uses of the water of the Niagara River was signed here today. Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, signed for this country, and Hume Wong, Canadian Ambassador, signed on behalf of Canada.
ON my return to the White House all was ready for the signature of the United Nations Pact. Many telegrams had passed between Washington, London, and Moscow, but now all was settled.

LONDON, Feb. 27--Whitehall officials, who are professionally neutral in politics, expressed the opinion today that the Labor Government, despite its precarious majority in Parliament, would not be seriously handicapped in the handling of Britain's foreign relations.
PARIS, Feb. 27--Strike votes were being taken or were planned today in several important sectors of French economy as labor's drive for wage increases gained momentum.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP)-- The Senate Judiciary Committee today unanimously approved a proposed $100,000 Congressional investigation of alleged national crime syndicates and their reported "influence" in big-city government.
To encourage sportsmen in selective big game hunting, the Boorle and Crockett Club conducts an annual competition and awards the club medal to those entering outstanding heads or horns.

A trial began yesterday in a Federal Court in Washington to determine whether the 370,000 soft-coal diggers of Mr. Lewis' United Mine Workers were guilty of contempt in refusing to heed a back-to-work order issued by the same court on Feb. 11. Needless...

The proposed creation of a New York City Parking Authority to acquire, construct and operate parking facilities was criticized by three speakers and approved by eight at a public hearing yesterday before the City Council's Committee on State Legislation.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 27--Four hundred longshoremen marched on City Hall here this afternoon loudly protesting the failure of City Commissioner James F. Murray,

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 27--The United States Embassy today asked the Czechoslovak Foreign Office for information about Imrich Solar, a United States citizen who was arrested in Slovakia early in December on a charge of having made derogatory state-...

MOSCOW, Feb. 26--Soviet medicine is engaged in a struggle to eliminate "the influence of antirevolutionary, anti-materialistic and idealistic positions in the pathology of Virchow, Erlich, Pasteur, Koch and others."

ALBANY, Feb. 27--As a result of differences within the Republican legislative leadership over what form state rent control should take, the Stephens Temporary Commission on Rent Controls deferred a decision on the subject at a formal meeting today to another session next Monday.

Each visit made to the outpatient department of a voluntary hospital in New York results in a loss of approximately $1.65, Msgr. John J. Curry, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The State Department declared today that it would no longed validate passports for private travel in Bulgaria.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 27 (AP) --William N. Hardy, manager of the Pennsylvania Newspaper Publishers Association for the last twenty-one years, died today after an illness of three months. His age was 60.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27-- Testimony placing Harry Bridges in meetings of the "top Communist party fraction of the CIO," and in at least two conferences at the "American Kremlin" in New York
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)-- The Washington Post says that David Demarest Lloyd has identified himself as the man referred to in a speech by Senator Joseph R...

Looking at New York yesterday from the ground up, Nicole Legendre, 17-year-old visitor from France, found it "tres jolie." But from the top of the Empire State Building, it was absolutely "grandiose."

With each successive collection the young designer, Lepole (he is but 24 years old), who creates for Nona Park and Sophie Shonnard of Bonwit Teller, improves. Ever since he first presented his fashions a few years ago his talent has been evident.

GENEVA, Feb. 27--The third round of tariff negotiations on a world basis, scheduled for the end of September, will be held in Tor quay, England, according to a decision of the sponsoring countries taken here today.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 27--A killer leopard outsmarted Oklahoma City's big game hunters for the third straight day today. The spotted male leopard that leaped to freedom from a... 20-foot-deep pit at Lincoln Park Zoo Saturday was still at large tonight, despite the efforts of men, dogs and aircraft.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 27--Nassau County officials today maintained that the county had the right to continue to assess the 4,020 rental units in Levittown that-were purchased by the Junto, a Philadelphia education corporation, for a price reported at $26,500,000.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP)--A Pan American Airways stewardess owed her life today to a quickthinking purser who grabbed her as she was being blown through the broken window of a pressurized-cabin airliner flying at 20,000 feet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The State Department sent out urgent calls today for full information on new attacks on United States ships in China waters, after getting reports that two freighters had been bombed and strafed off Communist-held Tsingtao.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Feb. 27--Vigorous opposition by a few minority shareholders developed at the special meeting of the United States Steel Corporation stockholders here today. After five hours of discussion, however, stockholders overwhelmingly approved the employe pension and insurance program recommended by the management.
A bomb designed for saving lives is among the electronic wonders to be displayed by the Navy next Monday when the Institute of Radio Engineers opens a four-day meeting in Grand Central Palace.
ASMARA, Eritrea, Feb. 27 (UP) --Moslems and Coptic Christians wearing the badge of Emperor Haile Selassie fought a pitched battle at noon today on the fringe of the Moslem native quarter.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27--March wheat sold at a new seasonal high as did July soybeans, while the near-by deliveries of soybeans went to a new top since last August before scattered liquidation developed and caused a sharp recession.

The coal crisis has given another clear demonstration of the inadequacy of existing law, "particularly in the hands of an unsympathetic administration," according to the monthly survey of the Guaranty Trust Company, to be issued today.

In a corner of an office building, three floors above Brooklyn's Willoughby Street, there is a light that never goes out and a phone that never goes unanswered. A twenty-four-hour vigil is kept there taking care of emergencies that come thick and fast.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The All American Casualty Company, Chicago, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 1,000,000 shares of $1 par-value common stock that is to be offered to the public at $2 a share.

A committee representing 50,000 small storekeepers in the city appealed to Governor Dewey and Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday to urge elimination of a so-called joker in the present state commercial rent law that subjects retailers to eviction unless they meet "extortionate" rent increases.
The supervisory personnel in the New York City public-school system have taken an appeal to Albany for pay rises that will reflect more justly the cost-ofliving increase that has occurred since 1939.

Add to the films arriving this week, "Borderline," a melodrama released by Universal-International and starring Fred MacMurray and Claire Trevor, which will open at the Criterion on Saturday. William A. Seiter directed and Milton H. Bren produced from a story and screen play by Devery Freeman.

After good bookings for spring, manufacturers of work clothing and trousers are placing substantial textile orders for fall, it was learned yesterday at the midyear convention of the international Association of Garment Manufacturers in the New Yorker Hotel.
ATHENS, Feb. 27--Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, Army chief, today issued a sharp reprimand to an unnamed political group for "exploitation of my name during the current electoral campaign."

Specific and detailed recommendations designed to reduce cargo losses and theft and pilferage along the world's waterfronts were released last week by the Cargo Loss Prevention Committee of the International Union of Marine Insurance.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 27--The first unit of the Rutgers Institute of Microbiology was dedicated here today on the campus of the university's College of Agriculture.
OSLO, Norway, Feb. 27 (AP)-- Twenty-eight persons, including President Truman and Winston Churchill, were nominated tonight for the 1950 Nobel Peace Prize. Six institutions also were nominated.

Abner Katz has purchased a parcel of lots on Broome Avenue in Atlantic Beach, L.I., from John H. Reynolds. The new owner plans to improve the property with two six-room ranch style homes to be ready for occupancy this summer.

For the first time, the United States now has a standard source of supply for more than 120 rare chemicals which were not available here from domestic manufacturing plants before the war, it was learned yesterday.

Even Congress recognizes that recipes interest women. At its request, the new bulletin issued today, "Family Fare: Food Management and Recipes," has been done by the bureau of human nutrition and home economics of the Department of Agriculture.

Having committed himself to run in a special two-mile test in the Heptagonal Games in Boston Friday night, Fred Wilt yesterday discarded the idea of seeking a mile and 1,000-yard double in the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus games at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.

Directors of Ex-Cell-O Corporation authorized yesterday the payment of a dividend of 75 cents on the common plus a stock dividend of one share for each two shares outstanding, both payable on Apri1 1.

AVON, N.J., Feb. 27--Pilot trains are being sent out ahead of each of six night passenger trains on the main line of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad as a safety measure to prevent derailments or other incidents which point to sabotage, it was learned here today.
